Today, every Ukrainian knows that freedom is something to be won and defended.â€ This article was developed in cooperation with AktuÃ¡lnÄ›.cz and Kringvarp FÃ¸roya in the Faroe Islands with the support ofJournalismfund Europe.

Title: China lauds Russia relations and calls for strengthened Asia-Pacific role
Subtitle: Beijing official said relations with Moscow are at an historic high.
Content: China has heralded historically strong relations with Russia as it called for the pair to coordinate on security, stability and development in the Asia-Pacific region. China and Russia should play a â€œbetter role as an anchor of stability in the changing circumstances of the century,â€ the foreign ministry in Beijing said in a statement issued on Wednesday following a visit to Moscow by Vice Foreign Minister Sun Weidong. Although wary of damaging ties with the West, Beijing has refused to condemn Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, and relations between the two BRICS states have remained warm amid the war. Sun said in the statement that â€œunder the strategic guidance of President Xi Jinping and President Putin â€¦ relations between the two countries are at the best period in historyâ€. Such statements will do little to quell suspicion in the West, which has viewed Moscow and Beijing with increased anxiety over the past two years as theyramp up tiesin trade and defence. Beijing hasresponded with angeras Chinese companies have been blacklisted by the United States and European Union for their role in helping Russia evade trade sanctions. Moscow has looked to Beijing as a crucial economic lifeline amid the sanctions, while China has benefitted from cheap energy imports and access to vast natural resources. At the same time, Chinaâ€™s interest in Russiaâ€™s sparsely populated, resource-rich, far-eastern region has long been viewed with some concern in Moscow, which sits 11 time zones westwards. Sun stressed Chinese hopes of deepening â€œcoordinationâ€ in the Asia-Pacific region, extolling the role of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), a Eurasian political, economic, international security and defence organisation established in 2001. â€œBoth sides should promote the SCO to better play its role as a â€˜stabilizing anchorâ€™ in the century-old changes, strengthen communication and coordination in Asia-Pacific regional affairs, and jointly safeguard regional security, stability and development,â€ he said. During his trip to the Russian capital, the Chinese official also exchanged views with Moscowâ€™s foreign minister Sergey Lavrov on the Ukraine crisis, the situation on the Korean peninsula, and other international and regional matters, the statement noted, without offering details. Separately, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry said on Wednesday that its special representative for Eurasian affairs will tour Russia, Poland, Ukraine, Germany and France in early March to promote a political settlement of the Ukraine crisis.

Title: Zelenskyy in Saudi Arabia to push for peace, POW deal with Russia
Subtitle: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has sought to position himself as a potential mediator to end war between Ukraine and Russia.
Content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has held talks in Saudi Arabia with the Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MBS) in an attempt to push for an end to the invasion of Ukraine and the return of prisoners of war from Russia. A statement on Zelenskyyâ€™s website said the two men discussed a Ukrainian plan to end the conflict, and said that the president had thanked MBS for his mediation role. â€œThe head of state [Zelenskyy] noted in particular Saudi Arabiaâ€™s strivings to help in restoring a just peace in Ukraine,â€ the statement said. â€œSaudi Arabiaâ€™s leadership can help find a just solution.â€ The state-run Saudi Press Agency said that MBS had â€œaffirmed the Kingdomâ€™s keeness and support for all international endeavours and efforts aimed at resolving the Ukrainian-Russian crisisâ€. It later reported that Zelenskyy had left Saudi Arabia. MBS has sought to position himself as apotential mediatorto end the war between Ukraine and Russia â€“ even as Riyadh remains closely aligned with Russia on energy policies through the OPEC+ group of countries. Zelenskyyâ€™s trip on Tuesday came as Kyivâ€™s forces are slowly being pushed back in eastern Ukraine. Russia has gained the initiative due to its big advantage in troop numbers and weapons supplies, military analysts say, as Kyiv waits for news of new provisions from its Western partners. The Ukrainian military said Tuesday that it has withdrawn its forces from two more villages nearAvdiivkain the eastern Donetsk region following intense overnight fighting, according to a Ukrainian army spokesman. Ukrainian troops have pulled back from Sieverne and Stepove, Dmytro Lykhovyi said on national television. The two villages had a population of some 100 people in total before the full-scale invasion, he said. Ukraine continues to â€œrely on Saudi Arabiaâ€™s ongoing active supportâ€ in pushing forward with what has been described as a â€œPeace Formulaâ€ to end the full-scale invasion, which marked itssecond anniversaryover the weekend, Zelenskyy said in a message on X. Zelenskyy has presented a 10-point peace formula that, among other things, seeks the expulsion of all Russian forces from Ukraine and accountability for war crimes â€“ at a time when the two sides are fighting from largely static positions along a roughly 1,500km (930-mile) front line. Such ideas are rejected out of hand by Moscow. â€œThe second topic is the return of POWs and deportees,â€ Zelenskyy wrote. â€œThe kingdomâ€™s leadership has already contributed to the release of our people. I am confident that this meeting will also yield results.â€ On Monday MBS also met with Russian State Duma Speaker Vyacheslav Volodin, the SPA reported, adding that they had discussed ways to boost parliamentary cooperation and â€œdevelopments of common concernâ€. In recent years, MBS â€“ the de facto leader of Saudi Arabia â€“ has reached a detente with Iran, pursued a peace deal with Yemenâ€™s Houthi rebels and also offered himself as a leader in other crises worldwide. That is after facing widespread international condemnation for Saudi Arabiaâ€™s involvement in the war in Yemen and the 2018 killing of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi, which US intelligence agencies believe was carried out on his orders â€“ a claim MBS denies. In May, Zelenskyy travelled to Saudi Arabia for a meeting of Arab leaders and also met then with MBS. Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar â€“ all neighbours on the Arabian Peninsula â€“ have been involved in prisoner exchanges since the war broke out in 2022.

Title: Germany, NATO rule out sending troops to Ukraine as Russia rebukes Macron
Subtitle: Rebuttal of Macronâ€™s remarks comes as Kremlin warns of conflict if West puts boots on ground in Ukraine.
Content: Germany, Poland and NATO have ruled out sending ground troops to Ukraine, as the Kremlin warned such a move would mark a major escalation and result in direct conflict between Russia and the Western security alliance. The statements on Tuesday came a day after French President Emmanuel Macronraised the prospectfollowing a European leadersâ€™ meeting on boosting support for Ukraine in its war against Russia. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said participants of the conference in Paris discussed the matter but had agreed â€œthat there will be no ground troops, no soldiers on Ukrainian soil who are sent there by European states or NATO statesâ€. Scholz said there was also consensus â€œthat soldiers operating in our countries also are not participating actively in the war themselvesâ€. Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk and Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala â€“ two of Kyivâ€™s strongest supporters â€“ meanwhile said they too were not considering sending troops. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg also told The Associated Press news agency that while members of the alliance had provided â€œunprecedented supportâ€ to Ukraine, â€œthere are no plans for NATO combat troops on the ground in Ukraineâ€. The idea of sending troops has been taboo, particularly as NATO seeks to avoid being dragged into a wider war with nuclear-armed Russia. Nothing prevents NATO members from joining such an undertaking individually or in groups, but the organisation would get involved only if all 31 members agreed. The Kremlin, meanwhile, warned that a direct conflict between NATO and Russia would be inevitable if the alliance sent combat troops. â€œThe very fact of discussing the possibility of sending certain contingents to Ukraine from NATO countries is a very important new element,â€ Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov told reporters,commenting on Macronâ€™s remarks. It is â€œabsolutely not in the interestsâ€ of European members of NATO, Peskov said. â€œIn that case, we would need to talk not about the probability, but about the inevitability [of direct conflict].â€ With Macron increasingly looking isolated, his government subsequently sought to clarify his comments. French Foreign Minister Stephane Sejourne said on Tuesday the president had in mind sending troops for specific tasks such as helping with mine clearance, production of weapons on site, and cyber-defence. â€œ[This] could require a [military] presence on Ukrainian territory, without crossing the threshold of fighting,â€ Sejourne told French lawmakers. â€œItâ€™s not sending troops to wage war against Russia,â€ the minister said. The conference in Paris was held just after France, Germany and the UK each signed 10-year bilateral security agreementsÂ with Ukraine as its government works to shore up Western support.

Title: Russian activist Oleg Orlov sentenced to 30 months in prison
Subtitle: Moscow court finds veteran human rights advocate who spoke out against the war in Ukraine guilty of discrediting armed forces.
Content: A Russian court has sentenced prominent human rights campaignerOleg Orlovto two-and-a-half years in prison after he was found guilty of discrediting the army. Footage posted online on Tuesday byMemorial, a now-banned Russian human rights group, showed the handcuffed 70-year-old smiling as he was put by officers in a van after the verdict by the Golovinskii district court in Moscow. Nobel Prize-winning Memorial, which has Orlov as its co-chairperson, slammed the trial as â€œa mockery of justice and an attack on the fundamental right to free expressionâ€. It said in a statement cosigned by dozens of rights groups that the campaignerâ€™s legal team would appeal the verdict and pledged to continue its work. #HandsOffOrlovOleg Orlov being taken awaypic.twitter.com/ub6FAc0tFd â€” Memorial in English (@EnMemorial)February 27, 2024  Human rights groups say the targeting of Kremlin critics has escalated since Russia launched a full-scale invasion against Ukraine in February 2022. The case against Orlov was based on an article he wrote that year in which he denounced the invasion and said Russia, under the leadership of President Vladimir Putin, had descended into â€œfascismâ€. A district court initially fined him 150,000 roubles ($1,629), but a retrial was ordered, and prosecutors sought a jail sentence of two years and 11 months. The prosecution claimed that Orlov published the article motivated by hostility â€œagainst traditional Russian spiritual, moral and patriotic valuesâ€ and hatred of the Russian military, according to independent Russian news outlet Mediazona. In his closing remarks on Monday, Orlov saidÂ he had committed no crime and regretted nothing, instead slamming the â€œtotalitarianâ€ and â€œfascistâ€ Russian state. â€œAll these are links in the same chain: The death, or rather, the massacre of Alexey [Navalny], the judicial reprisals against other critics of the regime, including me, the strangulation of freedom in the country, the entry of Russian troops into Ukraine.â€ Navalny, an opposition politician and staunch Kremlin critic,died suddenlyearlier in February in an Arctic penal colony. While the circumstances of his death remain unclear, many, including world leaders and activist groups, blame Russian authorities for his death. The Kremlin rejected the allegation as â€œunsubstantiated and groundless.â€ The UN special rapporteur on human rights in Russia, Mariana Katzarova, called Orlovâ€™s trial â€œan orchestrated attempt to silence the voices of human rights defenders in Russiaâ€. Orlov himself, in a recent interview with the AFP news agency, had said he held no illusions about the trialâ€™s outcome. Even as other campaigners fled Russia as antidefamation laws intensified and those found guilty of spreading â€œfake informationâ€ about the army could face up to 15 years in prison, Orlov remained in the country where he said he was â€œmore usefulâ€ than abroad. He told AFP his long career spent working on documenting Soviet crimes and human rights abuses in modern Russia gave him no choice but to also campaign against the invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Two years in, left and right united in opposing more US aid for Ukraine
Subtitle: With no end in sight to conflict with Russia, conservatives and progressives say â€˜noâ€™ to more military aid for Ukraine.
Content: Two years after Russia invaded Ukraine, Americansâ€™ support for the war is waning, creating a surprising alliance between the political left and right. Forty-one percentof Americans told Gallup pollsters three months ago that the United States is spending too much to support Ukraine on the battlefield. That compares with 24 percent of Americans who felt similarly in August 2022, six months after the start of the war. Perhaps most surprising, though, is that the shift is most pronounced among Republicans, the political party that has historically been known for its hawkishness. In March 2022, 9 percent of Republicans believed the US was supplying Ukraine with too much military aid; by December last year,48 percentof Republicans said their government was spending too much on Ukraine, according to Pew Research Centre surveys. The percentage of Democrats who view the Biden administrationâ€™s spending on Ukraine as excessive is only 16 percent, according to the same December poll. To be sure, partisan politics shapes the rift in Washington with Republicans in the House of Representatives refusing to pass legislation that includes $60bn in military aid for Ukraine. Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson has said the bill passed by the Democratic-controlled Senate doesnâ€™t do enough to protect the southern border from immigration, a stance that bolsters Donald Trumpâ€™s presidential campaign against incumbent Joe Biden. And Representative Marjorie Taylor Green leads a group of staunch conservatives in Congress who haveconsistently opposedUS funding for Ukraine. Still, a number of liberals, such as the writer Glen Greenwald and the podcaster Jimmy Dore, have joined conservatives, such as media presenter Tucker Carlson, in questioning the federal governmentâ€™s priorities in spending billions on a distant war while the US has so many pressing needs, including immigration, affordable housing, healthcare and student debt relief. â€œThe motivations for the far left and the far right are very different, but what unites them is where they arrive on Ukraine and also this anti-establishment populist strain,â€ said Dominik Stecula, assistant professor of political science at Colorado State University While some in the Republican Party â€” like presidential candidate Nikki Haley and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell â€” have a traditional national security focus reminiscent of the Cold War, the faction of the party that identifies with former President Trumpâ€™s political movement â€“ MAGA, short for his campaign slogan Make America Great Again â€“ is increasingly rejecting Ukraine spending. Isolationism has been a feature of Trumpâ€™s political message since 2016, explained Rachel Blum, an assistant professor in the University of Oklahomaâ€™s Department of Political Science. â€œThat is a really core thread of the MAGA movement.â€ The white working-class voters who make up the bulk of Trumpâ€™s supporters are animated by the sense that they are being left behind in a shape-shifting economy and money that would be better spent on their families is going to people of colour, the LGBTQ community and big business, including defence contractors. These sentiments often converge with racist, homophobic and transphobic beliefs. Blum told Al Jazeera that Trumpâ€™s isolationism is of a particular type that does not necessarily transfer to other conflicts. â€œTrump is much warmer toward Israel than he is toward Ukraine,â€ she explained. â€œSo I think a lot of it has to do with Trumpâ€™s very personal animosity toward Ukraine and [Ukrainian President Volodymyr] Zelenskyy and his past problems there and his affinity for [Russian President Vladimir] Putin.â€ As the MAGA movement has strengthened its hold on the Republican Party, she said, â€œitâ€™s not surprising that those sentiments are starting to spill over.â€ Republicans are divided between those who remember Cold War policy and view Putin, a former Soviet intelligence officer, as a threat and those who are inclined to blindly follow Trump, she said. In a Venn diagram, those two groups do not overlap. â€œItâ€™s hard for me to think of an example of a Republican who is pro-Ukraine aid and super supportive of Trump,â€ Blum said. As the November election draws closer, Blum said Trumpâ€™s position as the presumptive nominee gives Republicans an incentive to oppose aid to Ukraine to win favour with Trump if he returns to the White House. A number of factors played pivotal roles in the Republicansâ€™Â  shift against Ukrainian aid, said David Hopkins, associate professor of political science at Boston College. A generational divide is part of the story. Older conservatives remember the Cold War alliance between the US and Western Europe against the Soviet Union while younger conservatives donâ€™t have memories of the tensions between the West and the Soviet bloc, he said. Generally, Americansâ€™ foreign policy worldview is likely to be influenced by authority figures they trust, including politicians and media personalities, he said. And conservatives are reflexively sceptical of policies favoured by Democrats, such as Bidenâ€™s support for Ukraine.    Moreover, Trump supportersâ€™ sense of American exceptionalism extends to unfavourable views on Europe â€“ which is seen as not wholly sharing the same values as the US â€“ and, consequently, NATO. â€œThey are open, just on the merits, to the argument that the US should be looking for ways to remove itself from involvement with European politics and alliances with international allies and organisations like NATO and the UN,â€ Hopkins said. Trump supporters are also open to viewing Putin as a traditionalist with similar values to theirs. â€œUnder Putin, Russia has advertised itself internationally as a bulwark of traditional Christianity,â€ Hopkins said. â€œI think there are elements of the populist right in the United States that respond very positively to that message and indeed see figures like Putin as ideological allies in the culture war and international politics.â€ In aJuly 2022 piece for Foreign Policy, Stecula and co-author Jan Dutkiewicz argued that while the majority of Americans supported aid to Ukraine, many on the far right and far left argued the US should not intervene â€” an observation they explained with the â€œhorseshoe theoryâ€. The theory comes from French philosopher Jean-Pierre Faye, who believed extreme political positions aligned like a horseshoe magnet, which widens in the middle before nearly converging at its prongs, Stecula explained. On the far right, there is a warmth toward authoritarianism, he said. â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s a feature of conservatism, but itâ€™s a feature of the Republican Party right now under Trump.â€ He agreed with Hopkins that the populist right is warming to Putinâ€™s agenda, including his anti-LGBTQ policies. â€œHeâ€™s very well-versed in American culture wars. He talks about cancel culture. He talks about woke-ism all the time,â€ Stecula said. Meanwhile on the political left, the argument is that the Democrats have become gradually more hawkish since the Vietnam War in an effort to thwart Republican efforts, especially by former President Ronald Reagan, to portray the party as soft, and naive about the threats posed by communism. It is not uncommon, for instance, to hear progressives on popular podcasts express their view that the Democrats have, in fact, become even more hawkish than the Republicans as a means of rewarding their Wall Street donors with windfall profits that accrue from investments in arms suppliers such as Lockheed Martin, Raytheon and General Dynamics. Leftist writers and pundits contend that former President Barack Obama was the most interventionist, hawkish president in US history, launching air strikes or combat operations in at least seven countries â€“ Libya, Afghanistan, Iraq, Yemen, Syria, Somalia and Pakistan â€“ and dramatically expanding the Pentagonâ€™s military footprints in Africa. And while Trump enthusiastically embraced the wars he inherited from Obama, even progressives acknowledge that he did not start any new wars, and he reduced the Pentagonâ€™s military presence in Africa. In a 2023 interview with then-Fox News host Carlson, the progressive Greenwaldsaid:â€œIâ€™ve been asking since February, in what conceivable way will the lives of American citizens be materially improved? How will you or your familyâ€™s lives be protected or fostered by sending tens of billions of dollars, now in excess of $100bn, for the war in Ukraine?â€    Another popular progressive, the YouTuber Dore, said at an antiwar rally last year: â€œWe could have spent that money saving lives with universal healthcare, but instead, we spend that money taking lives overseas, which is our specialty.â€ And Robert F Kennedy Jr, who is popular with both the left and the right in the US, announced his 2024 presidential campaign by contrasting the â€œ$113bn committed to the Ukraineâ€ with the â€œ57 percent of Americans [who] canâ€™t put their hand on $1,000 if they have an emergencyâ€ and the â€œone-quarter of Americans [who] go to bed hungryâ€. Stecula attributed the convergence of the left and right on the issue of Ukraine to a populist streak that has long been present in US politics. â€œTheyâ€™re people on the fringes who reject the establishment, who are more anti-elite. And itâ€™s a weird situation where people who are seemingly very different from each other can arrive at similar conclusions about what the US should be doing in regards to the conflict in Ukraine.â€

Title: Franceâ€™s Macron does not rule out Europeans sending troops to Ukraine
Subtitle: French president opens door to European nations sending troops to Ukraine, although he cautioned that there was no consensus at this stage.
Content: French President Emmanuel Macron has said that sending Western ground troops to Ukraine could not be â€œruled outâ€ as European allies announced new measures to deliver munitions and boost Kyiv in its fight against Russia. The comments on Monday came after some 20 European leaders gathered in Paris to send Russian President Vladimir Putin a message of European resolve on Ukraine and counter the Kremlinâ€™s narrative that Moscow was bound to win a war now in its third year. â€œWe are convinced that the defeat of Russia is indispensable to security and stability in Europe,â€ Macron told reporters after the meeting. â€œThereâ€™s no consensus today to send in an official, endorsed manner troops on the ground. But in terms of dynamics, nothing can be ruled out,â€ he said. â€œWe will do everything that we must so that Russia does not win.â€ Macron declined to provide details about which nations were considering sending troops, saying he prefers to maintain some â€œstrategic ambiguityâ€. A White House official told the Reuters news agency that the United States had no plans to send troops to fight in Ukraine and that there were also no plans to send NATO troops to fight in Ukraine. We are talking about our support for Ukraine and our collective security. A collective leap is necessary from all of us.pic.twitter.com/NViI9ntaVY â€” Emmanuel Macron (@EmmanuelMacron)February 26, 2024  The conference in Paris signalled Macronâ€™s eagerness to present himself as a European champion of Ukraineâ€™s cause, amid growing fears that US support could wane in the coming years.Â German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and Polandâ€™s President Andrzej Duda were among the European heads of state and government present at the conference, while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy joined virtually. Duda said the most heated discussion was about whether to send troops to Ukraine and â€œthere was no agreement on the matterâ€. â€œOpinions differ here, but there are no such decisions,â€ he said. Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico, who has opposed military aid to Ukraine, meanwhile said several NATO and European Union members were considering sending soldiers to Ukraine on a bilateral basis. â€œI can confirm there are countries that are prepared to send their own troops to Ukraine, there are countries that say never, among which Slovakia belongs, and there are countries that say this proposal needs to be considered,â€ he said before boarding his plane home. The conference was called as Ukraine suffered setbacks on eastern battlefields, with its generals complaining of shortages of arms and soldiers.Â It saw progress on a Czech-led initiative to buy hundreds of thousands of ammunition rounds from third countries, something that France has been cautious about as it wants to prioritise developing Europeâ€™s own industry. Ammunition supplies have become a critical issue for Kyiv. The EU, though, is falling short of its target of sending Ukraine a million rounds of artillery shells by March. Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala said about 15 countries had agreed to sign up to his initiative.Â â€œWe are talking about hundreds of thousands of pieces of ammunition we should and could get in relatively short time,â€ Fiala told reporters. Defence ministers had been mandated to come up with a plan within the next 10 days, Portugalâ€™s Prime Minister Antonio Costa said. Rutte said the Netherlands would contribute 100 million euros ($108.5m) for the purchase of munitions overseas. He said the countries that would provide the munitions had asked not to be identified. â€œI think there was a great sense of urgency, particularly for the short term on ammunition and on air defence,â€ Rutte said. â€œI hope other countries will follow.â€ Macron also announced a new coalition would be set up to supply Ukraine with â€œmissiles and bombs of medium and long range to carry out deep strikesâ€. There was a â€œbroad consensus to do more and quickerâ€, he added, saying there was also a consensus to ramp up joint production of armaments with Ukraine and boost its own military industry. The Paris conference comes after France, Germany and the UK recently signed 10-year bilateral agreementsÂ with Ukraine to send a strong signal of long-term backing as Kyiv works to shore up Western support.

Title: Hungary ratifies Swedenâ€™s NATO bid, clearing final obstacle to membership
Subtitle: Vote by Hungarian parliament ends more than 18 months of delays.
Content: Hungaryâ€™s parliament has voted to ratify Swedenâ€™s bid to join NATO, bringing an end to more than 18 months of delays that have frustrated the alliance as it seeks to expand in response to Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine. Mondayâ€™s vote, which passed with 188 members for and six against, was a culmination of months of wrangling by Hungaryâ€™s allies to persuade its nationalist government to lift its block on Swedenâ€™s membership. The government of Prime Minister Viktor Orban submitted the protocols for approving Swedenâ€™s entry into NATO in July 2022, but the matter had stalled in parliament over opposition by governing party lawmakers. Unanimous support among all NATO members is required to admit new countries, and Hungary is the last of the allianceâ€™s 31 members to give its backing since Turkey ratified the request last month.  Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson called it â€œa historic dayâ€. â€œWe stand ready to shoulder our share of the responsibility for NATOâ€™s security,â€ Kristersson wrote on X. NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said the military alliance would soon be â€œstrongerâ€. â€œNow that all Allies have approved, Sweden will become the 32nd #NATO Ally,â€ the secretary-general wrote on X. â€œSwedenâ€™s membership will make us all stronger and safer.â€ Orban, a right-wing populist who has forged close ties with Russia, has said criticism of Hungaryâ€™s democracy by Swedish politicians had soured relations between the two countries and led to reluctance among lawmakers in his Fidesz party. But the vote on Monday removed the final membership hurdle for Sweden which, along with neighbouring Finland,first applied to join the alliance in May 2022, just a few months after the start of Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Finland experienced fewer roadblocks in its membership application and joined NATO in April last year.    Addressing lawmakers before the vote on Sweden, Orban said: â€œSweden and Hungaryâ€™s military cooperation and Swedenâ€™s NATO accession strengthen Hungaryâ€™s security.â€ Orban criticised Hungaryâ€™s European Union and NATO allies for placing increased pressure on his government in recent months to move forward on bringing Sweden into the alliance. â€œSeveral people tried to intervene from the outside in the settling of our disputes [with Sweden], but this did not help but rather hampered the issue,â€ Orban said. â€œHungary is a sovereign country. It does not tolerate being dictated by others, whether it be the content of its decisions or their timing.â€ This month, a bipartisan group of United States senators visited Hungary and announced it would submit a joint resolution to the US Congress condemning Hungaryâ€™s alleged democratic backsliding and urging Orbanâ€™s government to immediately lift its block on Swedenâ€™s transatlantic integration. On Friday, Kristersson met with Orban in Budapest, where they appeared to achieve a reconciliation after months of diplomatic tensions. After their meeting, the leaders announced the conclusion of a defence industry agreement that will include Hungaryâ€™s purchase of four Swedish-made JAS 39 Gripen jets and the extension of a service contract for its existing Gripen fleet. Orban said the additional fighter jets â€œwill significantly increase our military capabilities and further strengthen our role abroadâ€ and will improve Hungaryâ€™s ability to participate in joint NATO operations. â€œTo be a member of NATO together with another country means we are ready to die for each other,â€ Orban said. â€œA deal on defence and military capacities helps to reconstruct the trust between the two countries.â€ A presidential signature is needed to formally endorse the approval of Swedenâ€™s NATO bid, which is expected within the next few days. Sweden will then be invited to accede to the Washington Treaty and officially become NATOâ€™s 32nd member.

Title: Denmarkâ€™s Nord Stream probe finds sabotage, not enough grounds for case
Subtitle: Police find deliberate sabotage responsible for 2022 blasts at Nord Stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines but not sufficient grounds to pursue criminal case.
Content: Denmark says it has closed its investigation into mysterious blasts that in 2022 damaged two pipelines built to carry Russian gas to Europe, with authorities concluding they were an act of sabotage but there were not enough grounds for a criminal case. The explosions at the multibillion-dollar Nord Stream 1 and 2 pipelines contributed to tensions that followed Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine two years ago. Russia and Ukraineâ€™s Western allies swiftly traded blame over the incident under the Baltic Sea, which also caused environmentally damaging releases of vast amounts of methane into the air. Danish police said in a statement on Monday that their investigation â€“ one of three into the explosions â€“ had found â€œthere was deliberate sabotageâ€ of the pipelines, but â€œthe assessment is that there are not sufficient grounds to pursue a criminal caseâ€. In response to the announcement, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said the decision was â€œclose to absurdityâ€ and accused Denmark of closing the case to cover up for its allies. â€œOn the one hand, they recognise that a deliberate sabotage took place, but on the other hand they are not moving forward,â€ Peskov told journalists, adding thatÂ Denmark had refused requests to provide information about its investigation. Denmarkâ€™s announcement came after Sweden also said earlier this monthit was closing its probe, noting that the case did not fall under its jurisdiction. Swedish officials also said they handed over to Germany â€œmaterial that can be used as evidence in the German investigationâ€. The German federal prosecutorâ€™s office said on Monday that its investigation continues and that it would not provide more information.  The undersea explosions shortly after midnight on September 26, 2022 ruptured the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, which was Russiaâ€™s main natural gas supply route to Germany until Russia cut off supplies at the end of the previous month. They also damaged the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, which never entered service because Germany suspended its certification process shortly before the invasion of Ukraine. The explosions took place about 80 metres (260 feet) underwater on the ocean floor in the Baltic Sea. Seismic measurements indicated that they occurred shortly before the discovery of unexplained leaks. Months after the detonations, there is no accepted explanation. As investigations continue, a series of unconfirmed reports have variously accused Russia, the United States and Ukraine of sabotage. The pipelines were long a target of criticism by the United States and some of its allies, who warned that they posed a risk to Europeâ€™s energy security by increasing dependence on Russian gas. Russia has accused the US of staging the explosions, which they have described as a terror attack. The US has denied involvement. In March 2023, German mediareportedthat a pro-Ukraine group was involved in the explosions using a vessel and setting off from the German port of Rostock. Ukraine rejected suggestions it might have ordered the attack and German officials voiced caution over the accusation. Swedish prosecutors earlier hinted that the identity of the perpetrator was likely to remain unclear. Beyond their geopolitical impact, the Nord Stream pipeline leaks were a huge environmental disaster with local wildlife affected and huge volumes of methane discharged into the Baltic Sea in what observers believe could be the single largest release of methane due to human activity.

Title: Zelenskyy says 31,000 Ukrainian soldiers killed in war with Russia
Subtitle: Ukrainian presidentâ€™s comments are the first time that Kyiv has confirmed the number of its losses since the Russian invasion began.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said that 31,000 Ukrainian soldiers have been killed in action in the two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion. Speaking at the â€œUkraine. Year 2024â€ forum in Kyiv, Zelenskyy said that â€œeach of these losses is a great sacrificeâ€ for Ukraine. He added that â€œtens of thousands of civiliansâ€ had been killed in occupied areas of Ukraine, but said that no exact figures would be available until the war was over. Itâ€™s the first time that Kyiv has confirmed the number of its losses since the start of Russiaâ€™s full-scale war against Ukraine on February 24, 2022. Russia has also provided few official casualty figures. Independent Russian news outlet Mediazona said on Saturday that about 75,000 Russian men died in 2022 and 2023 fighting in the war. A United States intelligence report declassified in mid-December 2023 estimated that 315,000 Russian troops had been killed or wounded in Ukraine. If accurate, the figure would represent 87 percent of the roughly 360,000 troops Russia had before the war, according to the report. It has been two years since RussiainvadedUkraine and commemorations to mark the second anniversary brought expressions of continued support, new bilateral security agreements and new aid commitments from Ukraineâ€™s Western allies. But Ukraineâ€™s Defence Minister Rustem Umerov highlighted that they still needed to deliver on their commitments if Kyiv is to have any chance of holding out against Moscow and stressed that delays in arms shipments will cost lives. â€œWe look to the enemy: Their economy is almost $2 trillion, they use up to 15 percent official and nonofficial budget [funds] for the war, which constitutes over $100bn annually. So basically whenever a commitment doesnâ€™t come on time, we lose people, we lose territory,â€ he said, speaking at the Kyiv forum. Europe has admitted it will fall far short of a plan to deliver more than one million artillery shells to Ukraine by March, instead hoping to complete the shipments by the end of the year. Umerov highlighted that such delays put Ukraine at a further disadvantage â€œin the mathematics of warâ€ against Russia, which the West has said is increasingly building a war economy. Kyiv has also been weakened by the blocking of a vital $60bn US aid package amid political wrangling in the US Congress. US President Joe Bidensaidthe hold-ups directly contributed to Ukraine being forced to withdraw from Avdiivka. On Sunday, Ukraineâ€™s Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal said he was â€œdeeply convinced that the US will not abandon Ukraine in terms of financial, military and armed supportâ€. In recent weeks, fighting has intensified on parts of the front line. On Sunday, Russian shelling and rocket strikes continued to pummel Ukraineâ€™s south and east, as local Ukrainian officials reported that at least two civilians were killed and eight others were wounded in the Zaporizhia and Kherson provinces. Moscow and Kyiv also continued to trade nightly drone attacks, with Ukraineâ€™s air defences shooting down 16 of 18 Iranian-made Shahed drones launched overnight by Moscow and a Russian drone on Sunday morning striking an unspecified facility in Ukraineâ€™s western Khmelnytskyi region, the regional military administration reported without giving details. Russian troops also appeared to be pressing on west ofAvdiivka, the strategic city whose capture this month handed Moscow a significant victory. Zelenskyy told a news conference on Sunday that Ukraine has a clear plan for a new counteroffensive against Russian forces. Kyivâ€™s troops conducted a counteroffensive last year, but were unable to break through prepared defensive lines in the Russian-occupied south and east. â€œThere is a plan [for a counteroffensive], the plan is clear, I canâ€™t tell you the details,â€ Zelenskyy said. He said that a major shake-up that saw the head of Ukraineâ€™s military replaced earlier this month was connected to the new plan of action on the battlefield. â€œThis plan is related to the change of management; there are corresponding changes. Several plans will be prepared due to a leak of information,â€ Zelenskyy said, without elaborating. Earlier he said that Kyivâ€™s plans to conduct a counteroffensive last year had been leaked and ended up â€œon a desk in the Kremlinâ€ before the operation had even begun. Meanwhile at the forum in Kyiv, besides highlighting issues in military deliveries, Umerov insisted that Ukrainian forces were doing â€œeverything thatâ€™s possible, and also whatâ€™s impossible, to secure a breakthroughâ€ this year. The defence minister said that a â€œstrongâ€ military strategy is already in place for the coming months, but did not disclose details.

Title: Should Russia pay Ukraine to rebuild â€“ or even to defeat its own invasion?
Subtitle: The EU finds itself in uncharted legal territory as it ponders using Russiaâ€™s frozen assets against it.
Content: Within days of invading Ukraine in February 2022, Russia lost control of the assets its central bank held in foreign currencies abroad. Some $300bn was frozen in the European Union, United States, United Kingdom, Canada and Japan â€“ about half the bankâ€™s holdings â€“ as Ukraineâ€™s allies sought to hobble Russiaâ€™s ability to wage war. Legally, the money belongs to Russia, but the EU, which holds the largest chunk â€“ about $207bn â€“ is struggling to find a legal way to use Russiaâ€™s money to rebuild Ukraineâ€™s shattered infrastructure. Some experts believe Russiaâ€™s money could even be used to generate immediate benefits for Ukraineâ€™s war effort â€“ especially since $60bn of US military aid remains stalled in Congress. On January 29, EU leaders told European financial institutions to keep separate accounts for Russian-immobilised money, along with any profits made from investing it, pending a decision on what to do. â€œThis decision paves the way for the council to decide on a possible establishment of a financial contribution to the EU budget raised on these net profits to support Ukraine and its recovery and reconstruction at a later stage,â€ said the European Council. The G7 supported its decision. â€œSo far, the EU has been putting out into the public domain the idea of taxing this money,â€ Anton Moiseienko, an international law expert at Australian National University, told Al Jazeera.    Tax on the profits made from investing the money is said to amount to about $2.5bn. â€œWhat weâ€™re seeing today is the beginning of a more ambitious approach â€¦ separating the profits suggests that the entire [proceeds] might be sent to Ukraine,â€ Moiseienko said. The proceeds could amount to between $15bn and $17bn over four years. The legal reasoning is that Russia will, at some point, be called upon to pay compensation for invading Ukraine. â€œWhat we have here is a recognised debt. Russia owes reparations to Ukraine,â€ said Moiseienko. â€œAt some point, it does become rather perverse that we all know Russia owes the debt and weâ€™re going to pay Ukraine to rebuild but weâ€™re not going to touch the Russian money.â€ Some law experts go further. â€œI would invest it in the defence industry,â€ Maria Gavouneli, an international law professor at Athens University and director of the Hellenic Foundation for European and Foreign Policy, a think tank, told Al Jazeera. â€œWe wouldnâ€™t be buying bullets to send Ukraine, weâ€™d be making bullets to send Ukraine. Under such a formula, you could use the entire principal [of $207bn] as well as the proceeds,â€ Gavouneli said. EU Internal Market Commissioner Thierry Breton last month floated the idea of a 100-billion-euro ($108bn) European Defence Investment Programme (EDIP), to revive Europeâ€™s dormant defence industries, without specifying where the money would come from. Investing Russiaâ€™s money would enable the EU to plough vast resources into raising the production of artillery rounds and air defence missiles which Ukraine sorely needs. It would, perhaps, be the first time in history that an aggressorâ€™s assets would be used to help the defenderâ€™s war effort, Gavouneli said. But, she said, it would not amount to a confiscation of Russian assets, which would be illegal. â€œWhen the war is over there has to be an accounting. It has to be clear that Russiaâ€™s property can be returned to Russia. If it is going to be kept against reparations [to rebuild Ukraine], that will be decided at that time,â€ she said. Ukrainian experts go further, still. Russian money could be leveraged and used as collateral for loans worth several times its nominal value, Tymofiy Mylovanov, president of the Kyiv School of Economics, told Al Jazeera. â€œYou can get much more than the proceeds if you need to,â€ Mylovanov said. â€œIt also serves to bring a sense of fairness.â€ As attractive as all this sounds, there are also serious risks involved, bogging the discussion down in a legal and political morass of dissent and fear of consequences. The EU was meant to propose a legal formula to make use of Russiaâ€™s assets last December, but nothing of this emerged publicly. Another discussion was to be held earlier this month â€“ but, again, there was no decision. One fear is the risk of retaliation by Russia which, on December 29, said it had a list of European, US and other assets it could seize. Russian state news agency RIA put their value at $288bn last month. RIA did not provide details, and it was not clear if this sum included assets Western companies have already written down or divested themselves of. For example, British Petroleum pulled out of a stake in Russian state oil company Rosneft, valued at $14bn, days after the war began. Shell withdrew from Russian gas projects valued at $3bn. The greater fear, however, is the reputational impact on the US dollar and the Euro, currently the worldâ€™s two most dependable reserve currencies, attracting vast investments from governments, central banks, corporations and individuals around the world. â€œIt will undermine the confidence of other countries in the United States as well as in the EU as economic guarantors. Therefore, such actions are fraught with very, very serious consequences,â€ Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told journalists in December. The European Central Bank agrees. â€œThe euro is the second most important currency in the world, and we have to consider its long-term reputation,â€ said ECB Vice President Luis de Guindos late last year. â€œWeaponising a currency inevitably reduces its attractiveness and encourages the emergence of alternatives,â€ Bank of Italy governor Fabio Panetta said last month. Despite all this, EU leaders have tried to hammer out a new legal theory that protects the reputation of the euro and deals a measure of justice for Ukraine. Although states are obliged to respect the assets of other states, international law provides an exception known as countermeasures, Dapo Akande, professor of public international law at Oxford University, told Al Jazeera. â€œCountermeasures just means that you are taking action which is ordinarily unlawful, but is justified as a response to a prior unlawful action by the other state,â€ said Akande. In this case, Russiaâ€™s unlawful act was to wage a war of aggression, against the statutes of the United Nations Charter and its recognition of Ukraineâ€™s borders in 1991. Countermeasures carry an important condition, says Akande, â€œthat the object of it is to induce compliance by the other state with its obligations, which means countermeasures have to be temporary and reversible and inducing complianceâ€. In other words, if Russia withdrew from Ukraine, its money should be returnable, so any investments made with it should be reversible. The pricklier question is who can enforce countermeasures. â€œCan the states that are not the direct victims of the violation, ie states that are not Ukraine, seize assets?â€ asked Akande. â€œThereâ€™s been a growing number of lawyers whoâ€™ve come out and said yes, that would be perfectly lawful,â€ said Moiseienko. Still, by acting on Ukraineâ€™s behalf, the EU would be breaking new legal ground that Russia might challenge in European courts. The impetus may ultimately be provided by unprecedented political circumstances. The longer US funding for Ukraine remains blocked by allies of presidential hopeful Donald Trump in Congress, and the more Russia challenges European sovereignty by pushing deeper into Ukraine, the less tenable it may become politically to hold in awe the untouchability of Russian assets.

Title: Bitter but resilient: Ukraine fights on, two years into Russiaâ€™s war
Subtitle: Short of ammunition though not determination, Ukraine faces an uncertain future. What is clear is that it wonâ€™t buckle to Russia.
Content: Kharkiv, Ukraine â€“Andriyâ€™s undermanned squad can only shoot 10 shells a day at encroaching Russian troops because of a dire shortage of ammunition. The 45-year-old suffers from stomach pains, deteriorating eyesight and other consequences of multiple contusions that landed him in hospital several times. Two years ago, Andriy defended Kyiv in the full-scale warâ€™s first weeks until Russian troops withdrew after heavy losses, and fought in the eastern town of Bakhmut that fell to the Wagner private army last May. The timing and duration of tours to â€œzeroâ€ positions, or the front lines of the eastern Donbas region, are unpredictable, and his commanding officers deliberately report less â€œzeroâ€ time for him to decrease his pay, he said. But when it comes to Andriyâ€™s determination to stand his ground, he has no doubts or qualms. â€œThis is my land, understand? I grew up here. I eat bread grown on this land. Thatâ€™s what keeps me going,â€ he told Al Jazeera while on a break in the eastern city of Kharkiv. He withheld his last name and his unitâ€™s location in accordance with wartime regulations. Theabsolute majorityof Ukrainians â€“ 85 percent â€“ are confident of victory in the war that began two years ago today, according to a survey by the Rating Group, a Kyiv-based pollster, released on Monday. Most of the remaining 15 percent hail from eastern or southern regions next to the front lines and occupied areas that witness the worst consequences of the war firsthand, it said. â€œIâ€™d agree for peace if they want to keep the occupied lands,â€ Konstantin, a resident of Kharkiv, Ukraineâ€™s second-largest city that sits near the Russian border, told Al Jazeera. Last spring, the shockwave from an explosion right next to his apartment building shattered his windows and blew open his solid metal front door. He stayed on, but almost daily bombardments and the failure of last yearâ€™s counteroffensive have worn him out. â€œI donâ€™t want to grow old hearing the incoming [shelling] every day and night, because one day itâ€™ll hit my home,â€ he said. Western aid is crucial to Ukraineâ€™s victory, say 79 percent of Ukrainians, according to the Rating Groupâ€™s poll. But the aid is dwindling, while Western governments tacitly urge Kyiv to sign a truce with Moscow by recognising the loss of occupied areas that amount to one-fifth of Ukraineâ€™s territory. Yet, the public mantra of President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and every Ukrainian politician is: Moscow has to withdraw from all occupied areas before peace talks can begin. â€œThe political acknowledgment of the occupation is impossible, no politician will go for it, and the public wonâ€™t accept it, â€ Kyiv-based analyst Alexey Kushch told Al Jazeera. â€œThere are unofficial talks about freezing the conflict according to the Korean scenario,â€ he said, referring to the Korean Armistice of 1953, under which North and South Korea agreed to an end to fighting without formally ending the war. But until the war is over, Ukraine will â€œofficially announce maximal goalsâ€ to mobilise the public and Western allies, Kushch said. The war has cost Ukraine 30 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) and 3.5 million jobs, Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal said on Wednesday. But the biggest loss is to its people. At least 6.5 million people have fled abroad, and the population in Kyiv-controlled areas is below 30 million, analysts say â€“ a far cry from the 52 million at the dawn of Ukraineâ€™s independence in 1991. Many refugees have nothing to go back to. Last June, Halyna, a 28-year-old woman from the southern city ofMariupol, where tens of thousands of civilians died during a months-long siege, told Al Jazeera about the horrors her two young children went through during Russian air raids and shelling. â€œWhen things got real tense, they just convulsed with hysteria in those basements. And they asked questions: â€˜Does it hurt to die?â€™ she said. After moving to the Czech Republic, her children are safe â€“ but still scarred. â€œOnly recently, my son stopped being frightened by the sound of planes. The daughter sometimes weeps at night, wants to go back to her past life, to her pillow with [the images of] cats,â€ she said. â€œThereâ€™s a new life looming for us, but itâ€™s not in Ukraine, unfortunately,â€ she said. Last week, Russia scored a rare victory after Ukrainian forces pulled out of the town of Avdiivka in the Donbas region held by Russian-backed separatists since 2014. But the Kremlin-funded propaganda blew it out of proportion. â€œThe Kyiv regime and its protectors have missed a blow they will possibly not recover from,â€ publicist Kirill Strelnikovwroteon Tuesday. The news coincided with the death of jailed opposition leader Alexey Navalny, and Russian President Vladimir Putin gloated. â€œThe objectives our ill-wishers had in terms of limiting, isolating Russia, obviously fell apart,â€he saidon Wednesday. While independent observers reject Putinâ€™s assessment, they admit that Russiaâ€™s economy has shown unexpected resilience to Western sanctions designed to crush it. On Friday, the US imposed its latest round of sanctions against Russia, in response to Navalnyâ€™s death in an Arctic prison. â€œThe sanctions didnâ€™t affect Russiaâ€™s economy the way they had been expected to, Russiaâ€™s isolation didnâ€™t become total,â€ Temur Umarov of the Carnegie Russia Eurasia Center, a think tank in Berlin, told Al Jazeera. With all walks of life around them militarised, many Ukrainians tilted to the political right largely accepting fiercely anti-Russian slogans spawned by fringe nationalist groups, said Kyiv-based human rights advocate Vyacheslav Likhachev. These groups stood for banning all things Russian, including the language, the literature and the Orthodox Church that reported toMoscow Patriarch Kirill. These days, millions of Russian-speaking Ukrainians voluntarily switch to Ukrainian in daily life, while Zelenskyyâ€™s government is pondering a ban on the Russia-affiliated church. â€œRadical ideas that used to be marginal are now shared by a sizable part of the public and are to some extent implemented by the government,â€ Likhachev told Al Jazeera. What the war made clear is the sense of identity, unity and true political independence. â€œThe war showed us that a sovereign state canâ€™t exist simply by default. ThatÂ sovereignty demands constant work on self-determination, self-understanding, self-respect,â€ Svetlana Chunikhina, vice president of the Association of Political Psychologists, a group in Kyiv, told Al Jazeera. Ukrainians â€œacquired the sense of volumetric political optics that lets them see themselves as full-fledged participants of the historical process within the [European] continent and the world,â€ she said. And they didnâ€™t forget about their trademarksense of humourthat helped them survive the warâ€™s first months. After Poland objected to the import of Ukrainian grain citing concerns from its farmers, Ukrainians retorted: â€œWonder whether Polish farmers can stop Russian tanks?â€

Title: Western leaders visit Ukraine to show solidarity as war enters third year
Subtitle: Visit comes as Kyiv is on the defensive amid flagging Western aid and Russian territorial gains.
Content: Western leaders including the European Commissionâ€™s Ursula von der Leyen and Canadaâ€™s Justin Trudeau have visited Kyiv to show solidarity with Ukraine as it enters the third year of its war with Russia. Von der Leyen, Trudeau, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, and Belgium Prime Minister Alexander De Croo arrived in the country on Saturday on an overnight train from neighbouring Poland as Ukraine marks the second anniversary of Moscowâ€™s invasion on the defensive amid flagging Western aid and Russian territorial gains. â€œWe have been fighting for this for 730 days of our lives. We will win on the best day of our lives,â€ Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said at an anniversary event at Kyivâ€™s Gostomel Airport, which was targeted by Russia in the first days of its invasion. Oleksandr Syrskii, the chief of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, said:Â â€œI am convinced that unity is our victory. And it will definitely happen. Because light always conquers darkness.â€ Leaders of the Group of Seven (G7) major democracies, chaired this year by Italy, also held a videoconference with Zelenskyy later on Saturday, vowing to continue supporting Ukraine. â€œAs Ukraine enters the third year of this relentless war, its government and its people can count on the G7â€™s support for as long as it takes,â€ the group said in a statement. It added that it would look for ways to make Moscow pay for the damage inflicted by its invasion: â€œWe will continue to raise the cost of Russiaâ€™s war, degrade Russiaâ€™s sources of revenue and impede its efforts to build its war machine.â€ In a post on the social media platform X, von der Leyen said: â€œMore than ever, we stand firmly by Ukraine. Financially, economically, militarily, morally. Until the country is finally freeâ€. At the Wall of Remembrance, I pay my respects to the Ukrainians who made the ultimate sacrifice fighting for our values. Freedom, democracy, the rule of law. They are in our hearts and minds. Their legacy lives on. And it will shine through the day Ukraine wins this war.pic.twitter.com/2SeulZsNPe â€” Ursula von der Leyen (@vonderleyen)February 24, 2024  Trudeau said that Ukrainians were fighting for â€œour collective futureâ€. â€œThey are fighting to remind the world that democracy is both important enough to die for and strong enough to win,â€ he said in a statement before arriving in Kyiv. â€œAs the war continues, that is what is at stake. And that is why Canada has stood with Ukraine since day one.â€ NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg expressed confidence that Ukraine will join the transatlantic military alliance. â€œIt is not a question of if, but of when. As we prepare you for that day, NATO will continue to stand with Ukraine,â€ he said. On Saturday in Kyiv, Zelenskyy also signed security agreements with Canadaâ€™s Trudeau and Italyâ€™s Meloni intended to shore up Ukraineâ€™s security until it can reach its aim of becoming a NATO member. Trudeauâ€™s office said Canada would provide more than 3 billion Canadian dollars ($2.22bn) in financial and defence aid to Ukraine in 2024, while Meloni gave no financial details about the Italian accord. Earlier, the United Kingdom announced a new $311m defence package to help boost the production of â€œurgently needed artillery ammunitionâ€ for Ukraine. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak promised: â€œWe will stand with Ukraine today and tomorrow, prepared to do whatever it takes, for as long as it takes, until they prevail.â€    Kyivâ€™s fortunes have suffered in recent weeks amid shortages of military supplies, with Russia this month capturing the eastern town ofAvdiivkain its biggest victory on the battlefield in months. United States President Joe Biden has blamed Republicans in Congress for holding up a $61bn package of military funding, casting the support as crucial to Kyivâ€™s efforts to repel Moscow. Biden on Friday announced Washingtonâ€™s largest package ofsanctions against Russia, pledging to keep up pressure on Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s â€œwar machineâ€. On Friday,Ukraineâ€™s Foreign Minister Dmytro Kulebadelivered a rebuke to sceptics who doubt Kyivâ€™s ability to defeat Moscow, insisting that â€œUkraine will win the warâ€ and victory would come â€œsooner rather than laterâ€ with international support. Zelenskyy earlier this week told diplomats in an emotional address that he remained â€œconvinced that victory awaits usâ€. While neither Ukraine nor Russia has provided official estimates of the number of military casualties in the war, both sides claim to have inflicted heavy losses. The New York Times in August cited US officials who estimated that about 70,000 Ukrainian troops had been killed and a further 100,000-120,000 wounded. In December, leaked US intelligence suggested that about 315,000 Russian troops had been killed or injured. In its latest report, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine said this week that it been able to corroborate the conflict-related deaths of 10,582 civilians since February 2022. It had verified that 19,875 civilians had been wounded. â€œThe actual numbers are likely significantly higher,â€ it said.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 731
Subtitle: These are the main developments on the second anniversary of Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.
Content: Here is the situation on Saturday, February 24, 2024.

Title: Two years after Putin ordered a war on Ukraine, whatâ€™s changed in Russia?
Subtitle: While fears simmer on the border near Ukraine, life goes on as usual in most of Russia as Putin prepares for a predictable election.
Content: On December 30,a volley of rocket firehit the Russian city of Belgorod near the Ukrainian border. â€œI live in the very centre of the city, and three or four things fell just outside my home. I donâ€™t know whether it was a shell or shrapnel or what,â€ said 21-year-old Yuliya, a journalist from Belgorod who requested Al Jazeera use only her first name. â€œThe buildings nearby were seriously damaged. My own building was fine, but it was very frightening, very loud. In that moment, you can only think, â€˜This is the end.â€™â€™â€ Belgorodâ€™s been bombarded severaltimessince the start of Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, but Decemberâ€™s barrage was the deadliest. At least 25 civilians, among them five children, were killed in the attack blamed on Ukraineâ€™s armed forces. For the residents of the Russian border city, the war had come home. â€œThe atmosphere in the city shifted dramatically since December 30 because people in Belgorod finally felt what war is, that itâ€™s nearby and that itâ€™s not so safe in the city as it seemed,â€ Yuliya said. â€œLife has greatly changed.â€ She said children now know what itâ€™s like to be shelled, recognise the sound of air raid sirens and know how to tie a tourniquet. â€œNow the council doesnâ€™t discuss how many tulips to plant for the summer festivals but how to paint the insides of bomb shelters. I think life in Belgorod will never be the same.â€ In the weeks after the invasion on February 24, 2022, the picture looked bleak for Russia as the rouble crashed and foreign investors fled. But the economy has withstood sanctions. â€œThe Russian economy went through multiple stress tests,â€ economist Artem Kochnev said. â€œThe first one was in 2014 when the first round of sanctions was introduced and Russia took some lessons from that specifically by building a national financial infrastructure and tightening the grip over the financial sector. The second was the COVID crisis and how they tried to manage logistics in very rapidly changing circumstances. So they had some experience they could draw upon.â€ Kochnev added that the gradual implementation of sanctions gave Russia time to readjust its oil exports. The European Union halted its imports from Russia, so Russia turned to China and India instead, using a â€œshadow fleetâ€ of barges registered with shell companies in third countries such as Cameroon. Russia also had vast cash reserves from its petroleum sales, which were originally set aside to offset the shock from any drop in oil prices. â€œNow this money has been used for completely another purpose â€“ financing the war,â€ Kochnev said. â€œThatâ€™s a fiscal stimulus which is actually larger than what government has put into the economy during the COVID crisis.â€ Major global brands, such as McDonalds and Starbucks, have left Russia, forced to sell off their assets far below market value to buyers approved by a government committee before being rebranded. For example, Starbucks has become Stars Coffee. A few firms have effectively been nationalised. According to Kochnev, the assets went mainly to powerful and well-connected individuals, which may have created some friction between elites. Despite adramatic mutinyby Wagner mercenaries last year, Putinâ€™s position appears to be stable. He is expected to win a fifth six-year presidential term in the upcomingMarch election. Assuming he lasts until the end of his term, heâ€™d be the longest-serving Russian leader since the tsars, overtaking even Josef Stalin. Two candidates running on an anti-war platform, Yekaterina Duntsova and Boris Nadezhdin, were disqualified by the Central Election Commission despite neither being considered a serious contender against Putin. The war has certainly left an impact on society: After a decade of decline, problematic drinking has reportedly become more common, which some health experts have attributed to geopolitical confrontations. But on the whole, life goes on. There are still music concerts and exhibitions, and customers can still buy foreign goods, such as Coca-Cola, which have been rerouted through third countries such as Uzbekistan. Some Russians are even upbeat. â€œIâ€™ve heard a lot about propaganda in the West. It makes people idiots,â€ 51-year-old Alec from St Petersburg said. â€œBut absolutely everything is still here. You think people donâ€™t want to make money? Nothing has changed except the psychopathic liberals have left. Whether we like it or not, Russia has started itâ€™s great game, and itâ€™s very interesting to see. You have to be here to understand it.â€ On the front lines in Ukraine, nearly 45,000 Russians have been killed in action since February 2022, the independent outlet MediaZona has reported. That is three times the Red Armyâ€™s losses during its decade-long occupation of Afghanistan. Even so, Russia has greater resources in terms of manpower than Ukraine. Since Ukraineâ€™s failed counteroffensive in the summer, Russian forces have slowly inched forward, capturing the town ofAvdiivkathis month after a fierce, months-long battle. â€œRussiaâ€™s hidden mobilisation has continued,â€ said Oleg Ignatov, senior Russia analyst for the International Crisis Group think tank. â€œRegions are given the number of contract soldiers they have to call up. As a result, regional officials persuade whoever they can to sign up. These include debtors, people with financial and lifestyle problems, single men, ex-criminals and so on as well as [state employees]. The military, in turn, persuades conscripts to sign a contract. Also, more foreigners are coming to the front. But apparently, such methods work. The Russian army manages to replenish its ranks faster than the Ukrainian army.â€ Russiaâ€™s defence industry appears to still be functioning at full capacity, pumping out shells to be fired on Ukrainian positions. â€œRussian military production has grown significantly, including by restoring production at old Soviet factories,â€ Ignatov added. â€œRussia has been able to outpace Western ammunition supplies and maintain its advantage in equipment and long-range weapons. Sanctions, of course, increase the price of production and create logistical problems but do not hinder the production of shells and hardly prevent Russia from modernising old Soviet equipment and sending it to the front. Russiaâ€™s industrial capability to produce weapons is very large but not enough to create a decisive advantage, so Russia buys ammunition from North Korea.â€ Besides the shelling of Belgorod, there have been several cross-border raids by the Russian Volunteer Corps, a militia of Russian citizens with far-right nationalist views fighting for Ukraine, engaging in brief skirmishes with Russian forces and border guards before falling back. Their strategic impact on the war has been limited but has undermined Russiaâ€™s sense of security. Meanwhile, drones have targeted Russiaâ€™s oil infrastructure, spectacularly blowing up a fuel export terminal near St Petersburg in January. â€œUkraine has conducted a series of successful attacks on Russian infrastructure and apparently managed to destroy several units of valuable and expensive equipment, but in general, these attacks do not change the overall picture, which is still in Russiaâ€™s favour,â€ Ignatov said. This will bring little comfort to Yuliya, whose heart still races whenever she steps outside. â€œSome of my friends whoâ€™ve left Russia and see the shelling of our city say, â€˜Well, what did you expect? People are dying in Ukraine as well, and rockets are flying from Belgorod to Kharkiv,â€™â€ she said. â€œBut I live here, and no matter what I do, I canâ€™t stop these rockets. No one in our city can. So I donâ€™t know how you can say that we had it coming. Itâ€™s very upsetting.â€

Title: US sanctions 500 Russia-linked targets ahead of Ukraine war anniversary
Subtitle: US reiterates support for Ukraine with largest package of economic restrictions as Republicans block military aid.
Content: The United States has issued sanctions on more than 500 Russian-linked targets in response to Moscowâ€™sinvasion of Ukrainetwo years ago and the death in prison of opposition leader Alexey Navalny. Washington has also imposed new export restrictions on nearly 100 entities for providing support to Russia and take action to further reduce Russiaâ€™s energy revenues, US President Joe Biden said on Friday. The entities and sectors targeted include Russiaâ€™s Mir payment system, Russian financial institutions and its military industrial base, sanctions evasion, and future energy production, and will also include officials believed to be involved in the death of Navalny, the Treasury and State departments said. The measures represent the largest single tranche of penalties since Russia invaded Ukraine onFebruary 24, 2022, and come on the back of a series of new arrests and indictments that the US Department of Justice announced on Thursday, targeting Russian businessmen, including the head of state-owned VTB Bank, Russiaâ€™s second-largest bank. â€œThey will ensure Putin pays an even steeper price for his aggression abroad and repression at home,â€ Biden said of the sanctions. The new economic restrictions come after the White House said this week that it was preparingâ€œmajorâ€ penaltiesafter the death ofNavalny, Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s most prominent critic, in an Arctic penal colony. Biden said on Thursday, after meeting Navalnyâ€™s widow Yulia and daughter Dasha in California, that â€œweâ€™re going to be announcing sanctions against Putin, who is responsible for his death, tomorrowâ€. Today, I met with Yulia and Dasha Navalnaya â€“ Aleksey Navalny's loved ones â€“ to express my condolences for their devastating loss. Aleksey's legacy of courage will live on in Yulia and Dasha, and the countless people across Russia fighting for democracy and human rights.pic.twitter.com/aiCcgTrws3 â€” President Biden (@POTUS)February 22, 2024  The Kremlin hasdeniedPutin was behind Navalnyâ€™s death and slammed the West for making assumptions before there was proof to back up its allegations. Deputy US Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo told the Reuters news agency on Thursday that the sanctions will also be taken in partnership with other countries who are looking to keep up the pressure on Russia over its war on Ukraine. â€œTomorrow weâ€™ll release hundreds of sanctions just here in the United States, but itâ€™s important to step back and remember that its not just America taking these actions,â€ Adeyemo said. Washington has been coordinating with its European allies in its efforts to cut Russia off from the global economy. The European Union on Friday announcedÂ its13th package of sanctionsagainst Russia, banning nearly 200 additional entities and individuals accused of involvement in the two-year conflict. â€œToday, we are further tightening the restrictive measures against Russiaâ€™s military and defence sector,â€ said EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell. â€œWe remain united in our determination to dent Russiaâ€™s war machine and help Ukraine win its legitimate fight for self-defence.â€ Commitment met: two years after the start of the full-scale Russian aggression against#Ukraine, the 13th package of sanctions is adopted. These measures are taking a heavy toll on Russiaâ€™s economy.https://t.co/65gyOcE67t â€” Josep Borrell Fontelles (@JosepBorrellF)February 23, 2024  The United Kingdom hasimposed sanctionson six officials overseeing the penal colony where Navalny died. â€œSanctions and export controls are geared towards slowing Russia down, making it harder for them to fight their war of choice in Ukraine,â€ Adeyemo said. The Biden administration has exhausted money previously approved for Ukraine, and a request for additional funds for military aid to Ukraine is stuck in the Republican-controlled House of Representatives. â€œBut ultimately, in order to speed Ukraine up, to give them the ability to defend themselves, Congress needs to act to give Ukraine the resources that they need and the weapons they need,â€ Adeyemo added.    The US and its allies have additionally capped the price at which Russian crude oil can be sold on global markets, frozen billions of dollars of its central bankâ€™s assets and imposed trade restrictions in an attempt to block technology and equipment used by Moscow to supply its military. However, they have not dented Russiaâ€™sability to wage war. On Friday, Putin claimed that 95 percent of Russiaâ€™s strategic nuclear forces had been modernised and that the Air Force had just taken delivery of four new supersonic nuclear-capable bombers. In a recorded speech to mark Russiaâ€™s annual Defender of the Fatherland Day, which celebrates the armed forces, he also praised soldiers fighting in Ukraine as heroes battling for â€œtruth and justiceâ€.

Title: More than 14 million people fled homes in Ukraine since Russia invasion: UN
Subtitle: As second anniversary of conflict nears, millions remain displaced at home and abroad, with â€˜no end in sightâ€™ to war.
Content: The United Nations has said that more than 14 million Ukrainians were forced to flee their homes at some point in the two years since Russiaâ€™s invasion, as UN rights chief Volker Turk spoke of the â€œhorrific human costâ€ of the conflict. AsRussiaâ€™s war in Ukrainegrinds into its third year, the UNâ€™s International Organization for Migration (IOM) said on Thursday that nearly 6.5 million people are now living outside the country as refugees. It said an estimated 3.7 million people are still displaced within Ukraine. Reflecting on thetoll of the war, which started when Russia invaded its neighbour on February 24, 2022, IOM director general Amy Pope said: â€œThe destruction is widespread, loss of life and suffering continues.â€ While a total of more than 14 million people â€“ nearly one-third of Ukraineâ€™s population â€“ fled their homes at some point during the war, the agency said that more than 4.5 million people returned home to date, from either abroad or displacement within the country. The war has been devastating for the people of#Ukraine, but IOM staff have been tirelessly working to address urgent needs, build resilience, and enable recovery. Read more ğŸ‘‰https://t.co/ePsafhCKUGpic.twitter.com/MesDKBgPi0 â€” IOM - UN Migration News (@UNMigrationNews)February 22, 2024  Volker Turk, the UN high commissioner for human rights, warned on Thursday that there was â€œno end in sightâ€ to the war, which had inflicted â€œimmense suffering on millions of civiliansâ€. â€œ[It] continues to cause serious and widespread human rights violations, destroying lives and livelihoods,â€ he said in a statement, as he renewed his call for Russia to end the conflict. â€œThe long-term impact of this war in Ukraine will be felt for generations,â€ he said. In its latest report, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine said it been able to corroborate the conflict-related deaths of 10,582 civilians since February 2022. It had verified that 19,875 civilians had been wounded. â€œThe actual numbers are likely significantly higher,â€ it said. Russiaâ€™s full-scale armed attack on#Ukraineenters its 3rd year with no end in sight, causing widespread human rights violations, & destroying lives & livelihoods.@volker_turkcalls to immediately cease the attack & for all human rights violations to be investigated. â€” UN Human Rights (@UNHumanRights)February 22, 2024  The IOM reported it had supported 6.5 million people in Ukraine and across 11 countries in Eastern Europe that were hosting refugees. But, it pointed out, needs were continuing to grow, outpacing resources. Some 14.6 million people remain in need of some form of humanitarian assistance in 2024, IOM said. For those who return home, the challenges are immense. Federico Soda, director of the IOMâ€™s humanitarian response and recovery department, said returnees faced â€œinsecurity, loss of livelihoods, damaged housing and infrastructure, and strained servicesâ€. Since the start of the war, the agency has received $957m in donations. Overall, the UN says it needs $4.2bn this year to provide humanitarian aid in Ukraine and to refugees who have fled.

Title: â€˜Era of peace in Europe overâ€™ says Ukraine, as Avdiivka falls to Russians
Subtitle: Russian forces capture their first city in more than nine months, partly a result of failing weapons deliveries from allies.
Content: Russiaachievedits first major territorial success in more than nine months in the Ukraine war, capturing the eastern city of Avdiivka last week. The once-bustling community of 30,000 civilians was gone and it was doubtful whether the local employer, Europeâ€™s biggest coking plant, could be returned to operability soon. But the capture offered Russian President Vladimir Putin bragging rights ahead of theelectionhe faces in March. Russian forces began to press Ukrainian defenders in earnest last October, after Ukraineâ€™s three-month-long summer counteroffensive had ended, promising to deal Ukraine a winter blow. They formed a pincer to the north and south of the city, and during the four months of most intense fighting Ukraineâ€™s Tavria forces commander, Oleksandr Tarnavskyi, estimated they had sustained 47,000 casualties, and lost 364 tanks, 248 artillery systems, 748 armoured fighting vehicles and five aircraft. The news fell like a bombshell on the continuing Munich Security Conference, where Ukraineâ€™s Western allies convened to survey a gloomy outlook for 2024. â€œThe era of peace in Europe is over,â€ Dmytro Kuleba, Ukrainian foreign minister, told those present. â€œAnd every time Ukrainian soldiers withdraw from a Ukrainian town because of the lack of ammunition, think of it not only in terms of democracy and defending the world-based order, but also in terms of Russian soldiers getting a few kilometres closer to your towns.â€ Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy also seized upon the moment to press allies for more weapons supplies. â€œUnfortunately, keeping Ukraine in artificial deficits of weapons, particularly in deficits of artillery and long-range capabilities, allows Putin to adapt to the current intensity of the war. This self-weakening of democracy over time undermines our joint results,â€ Zelenskyy told the conference. Many Ukrainians squarely blame the United States for the emboldening of Russia, as a $60.6bn military assistance measure for Ukraine remains stalled in Congress. Unfortunately, keeping Ukraine in artificial deficits of weapons, particularly in deficits of artillery and long-range capabilities, allows Putin to adapt to the current intensity of the war.
