Title: Russia destroys drone near Moscow in latest attack on Russian capital
Subtitle: Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says air defence systems destroyed a drone in the Istra district west of Moscow.
Content: Russian air defence has repelleda new drone attack on Moscow, the cityâ€™s mayor said, the latest of several attempts to attack the Russian capital with unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) this week. Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin said early on Saturday that a drone was destroyed by air defence systems over the Istra district west of Moscow. Emergency services were at the scene and there have been no initial reports of damage or casualties, Sobyanin said on the Telegram messaging app. The early morning drone raid on Saturday forced authorities to temporarily shut down all three main airports serving the capital. Russiaâ€™s military has reported that Ukrainian drones and a missile attack have repeatedly targeted Russian territory over the course of the past week, and three Moscow airports â€“ Sheremetyevo, Domodedovo and Vnukovo â€“ have been forced to suspend flights temporarily as a result. Flights were also disrupted at the Moscow airports on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, according to reports. Ukraine did not immediately comment on the latest drone raid and almost never publicly claims responsibility for attacks inside Russia or on Russian-controlled territory in Ukraine. Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence reported on Friday that its forces had shot down nine Ukrainian drones and suppressed 33 others with â€œelectronic warfareâ€ in the largest drone attack so far by Kyiv on the Russian-annexed Crimean peninsula since Moscowâ€™s invasion of Ukraine began last year.

Title: â€˜Absolute lieâ€™: Russia denies role in Yevgeny Prigozhin plane crash
Subtitle: Allegations that Moscow was behind aircraft explosion presumed to have killed Wagner Group boss are untrue, Kremlin spokesman says.
Content: Western suggestions that the Wagner Group mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin was killed on the Russian governmentâ€™s orders are an â€œabsolute lieâ€, the Kremlin says. It declined on Friday to definitively confirm Prigozhinâ€™s death in a plane crash, citing the need to wait for test results. Russian investigators have recovered 10 bodies and flight recorders from the scene of Wednesdayâ€™s crash northwest of Moscow, and investigations are under way. Prigozhin, who conducted a brief but shocking mutiny in Russia two months ago, hired fighters who arefeared in Africa and Syria and played a crucial role in the war in Ukraine. Some unidentified officials from the West quoted in the media have suggestedthe plane explosionappears to be vengeance for the Wagner mutiny in June, which posed the biggest challenge to President Vladimir Putinâ€™s 23-year rule. But Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov flatly rejected the allegations. â€œRight now, of course, there are lots of speculation around this plane crash and the tragic deaths of the passengers of the plane, including Yevgeny Prigozhin,â€ Peskov told reporters in a conference call. â€œOf course in the West, those speculations are put out under a certain angle, and all of it is a complete lie.â€ Prigozhin waslisted among those on boardthe plane. When asked whether the Kremlin has received an official confirmation of Prigozhinâ€™s death, Peskov referencedPutinâ€™s remarksfrom a day earlier. â€œHe said that right now all the necessary forensic analyses, including genetic testing, will be carried out. Once some kind of official conclusions are ready to be released, they will be released.â€    Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, a close ally of Putin who mediated the deal that ended the mutiny, said he â€œcanâ€™t imagineâ€ the Russian leader ordered Prigozhinâ€™s assassination. â€œI know Putin. He is calculating, very calm, even slow,â€ Lukashenko was quoted as saying by state media. â€œI cannot imagine that Putin did it, that Putin is to blame. Itâ€™s too rough and unprofessional work.â€ Britainâ€™s Ministry of Defence said the presumed death of Prigozhin could destabilise his Wagner Group of private military contractors. His â€œexceptional audacityâ€ and â€œextreme brutalityâ€ permeated the organisation â€œand are unlikely to be matched by any successorâ€, it said in a statement. The private jet crashed soon after taking off from Moscow for St Petersburg, carrying Prigozhin, six other Wagner members and a crew of three, according to the Federal Air Transport Agency. US President Joe Biden, speaking to reporters on Wednesday, said he believed Putin was likely behind the crash.Â â€œI donâ€™t know for a fact what happened, but Iâ€™m not surprised. Thereâ€™s not much that happens in Russia that Putinâ€™s not behind.â€ Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergey Ryabkov took offence at that remark. â€œIt is not for the US president, in my opinion, to talk about certain tragic events of this nature,â€ he said on Friday.    The passenger manifest also included Prigozhinâ€™s second-in-command as well as Wagnerâ€™s logistics chief and at least one possible bodyguard. It was not clear why several high-ranking members of Wagner, who were normally exceedingly careful about their security, would have been on the same flight. The purpose of their trip to St Petersburg was unknown. In his first public comments on the crash, Putin said the passengers had â€œmade a significant contributionâ€ to the fighting in Ukraine. â€œWe remember this. We know, and we will not forget,â€ he said in a televised interview with the Russian-installed leader of Ukraineâ€™s partially occupied Donetsk region, Denis Pushilin. Putin said he had known Prigozhin since the early 1990s and described him as â€œa man of difficult fateâ€ who had â€œmade serious mistakes in lifeâ€. â€œAnd he achieved the results he needed â€“ both for himself and, when I asked him about it, for the common cause as in these last months. He was a talented man, a talented businessman,â€ Putin said. Prigozhin was outspoken and critical of how Russian generals were waging the war in Ukraine, where his mercenaries were some of the fiercest fighters. For a long time, Putin appeared content to allow such infighting, but Prigozhinâ€™s brief revolt raised the ante. Numerous opponents and critics of Putin have been killed or fallen gravely ill in apparent assassination attempts, and US and other Western officials long expected the Russian leader to go after Prigozhin despite promising to drop charges in a deal that ended the June mutiny. Ekaterina Kotrikadze, a news director and anchor at Russiaâ€™s independent Rain TV, said she believes Putin made the statement about the Wagner boss to show stability to the public but also to send a message. â€œThe whole operation in killing Yevgeny Prigozhin is such an open statement that Putin decided to kill a problem to him. Putin could not pardon him. It was a traitorous action. Thatâ€™s why he showed to everyone, â€˜You should not be against me,â€™â€ Kotrikadze told Al Jazeera. Lukashenko, meanwhile, said Wagner fighters would remain based in Belarus. â€œWagner lived, Wagner is living and Wagner will live in Belarus,â€ Lukashenko said. â€œThe core remains here. As long as we need this unit, they will live and work with us.â€

Title: Putin will not attend G20 summit in India next month
Subtitle: The Russian president faces arrest if he travels abroad on a warrant accusing him of war crimes in Ukraine, issued by the International Criminal Court.
Content: Russian President Vladimir Putin will not attend the G20 summit in India next month, the Kremlin has announced. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said on Friday that travel is currently not on Putinâ€™s agenda because he is concentrating on the special military operation, which is what the Kremlin calls Russiaâ€™s war against Ukraine. But another issue is keeping him at home. The International Criminal Court has issued an arrest warrant for Putin accusing him of war crimes in Ukraine, something the Kremlin strongly denies. This means he risks arrest when travelling abroad.Â Peskov did not mention the warrant in his comments. Putin did not fly to Indonesia for the summit of the groupâ€™s summit last year. He also skipped attending theBRICS summitin South Africa this week and instead took part via video link.    At the summit of the worldâ€™s 20 largest economies, â€‹â€‹to take place on September 9 and 10, India hopes to persuade members to find amicable solutions to geopolitical issues, its G20 summit negotiator Amitabh Kant said on Friday, responding to a query on the Russia-Ukraine war. Kant said the G20 wants growth but war has created â€œa huge implication in terms of economicsâ€ by bringing challenges regarding food, fuel and fertiliser. â€œThe war is not our creation,â€ Kant said. â€œOur challenge is to put developmental issues right in the forefront.â€

Title: Dutch brewer Heineken completes its withdrawal from Russia, takes $325m hit
Subtitle: The worldâ€™s second largest brewer sold its business in Russia for just 1 euro ($1.08), months after announcing its exit.
Content: Dutch brewer Heineken has completed its withdrawal from Russia, 18 months after Moscow launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, selling its business in Russia for just 1 euro ($1.08). Heineken said on Friday it would incur a total loss of 300 million euros ($325m) for the sale to Russian manufacturing giant, the Arnest Group. Heineken had faced criticism for the slow pace of its exit in the wake of the outbreak of war, but insisted it was seeking to look after its local employees in Russia. In March last year, Heineken had said it was quitting Russia as its business there was â€œno longer sustainable nor viable in the current environmentâ€, but added that it wanted to ensure an â€œorderly transferâ€ to a new owner. â€œWhile it took much longer than we had hoped, this transaction secures the livelihoods of our employees and allows us to exit the country in a responsible manner,â€ Heineken CEO Dolf van den Brink said in a statement.    The sale covers all of Heinekenâ€™s assets in Russia, including seven breweries. The company said that Arnest has guaranteed the employment of Heinekenâ€™s 1,800 local staff for three years. Heineken brand beer was removed from the Russian market last year. One of its other key brands, Amstel, will be phased out within six months, the company said. Last month, Heineken lowered its global earnings outlook for the full year after price hikes to counter soaring costs battered beer sales, pushing down profits in the first half. The worldâ€™s second largest brewer had warned that price increases were needed to offset high commodity and energy costs, due in large part to Russiaâ€™s war against Ukraine. The result was an 8.6 percent slump in net profit to 1.16 billion euros ($1.28bn), as beer volumes fell 5.6 percent from the same period last year. For the full year, it now expects a â€œstable to a mid single-digitâ€ operating profit growth on a like for like basis, after an 8.8 percent drop in the first half to 1.9 billion euros ($2.09bn). Previously, management had forecast â€œmid to high single-digitâ€ growth.

Title: Russia says destroyed 42 Ukraine-launched drones over Crimea
Subtitle: Kyiv has promised to retake the peninsula, which was annexed by Moscow in 2014.
Content: Russiaâ€™s defence ministry has said its air defence forces destroyed a large-scale Ukrainian-launched drone attack on the Crimean Peninsula, which Moscow annexed from Ukraine in 2014. Crimea has been targeted by Kyiv since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, but has come under more intense, increased attacks in recent weeks. The Russian Ministry of Defence said early on Friday its forces shot down nine drones, while 33 others â€œwere suppressed by electronic warfare and crashed without reaching the targetâ€. It did not elaborate on whether there had been any damage or casualties. It added that it had also shot down a Ukraine-launched missile over the Kaluga region, which borders the Moscow region. Mikhail Razvozhayev, the Moscow-installed governor of the Crimean port city of Sevastopol, said on the Telegram messaging app that several drones were destroyed over the Khersones promontory. The cape is located on the outskirts of Sevastopol, which is home to Russiaâ€™s Black Sea fleet. It was not clear whether those drones were among the 42 reported by the defence ministry. â€œAll forces and services are in a state of combat readiness,â€ Razvozhayev said. Kyiv has repeatedly said it plans to take back Crimea, and the drone assault comes two days after President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told a Kyiv conference on Crimea that the peninsula would be â€œde-occupied like all other parts of Ukraine that are unfortunately still under the occupierâ€. On Thursday, Ukraine said its forces had landed on the peninsula and raised the countryâ€™s flag during a â€œspecial operationâ€ to mark its second wartime Independence Day. The special forces troops landed on Crimeaâ€™s western shore near the towns of Olenivka and Mayak, where they had â€œengaged in combatâ€, Ukraineâ€™s GUR intelligence agency said. Moscow has also accused Ukraine of attacking the Russian-built bridge that connects the peninsula to Russia and is a key supply route for the Russian military. The bridge, the only crossing over the Kerch Strait, has been closed due to multiple incidents, including anexplosion in July. Russia has shown no sign of abandoning Crimea, which it has been using as a platform to launch missiles on Ukrainian targets. Moscow took control of Crimeaafter a referendum held after Russian forces seized the peninsula nine years ago that it claimed showed the people of Crimea, who mainly speak Russian, wanted to be part of Russia. Ukraine has dismissed the referendum as a sham, and theinternational communitydoes not recognise Moscowâ€™s jurisdiction.

Title: US will train Ukrainian pilots to fly F-16s from next month
Subtitle: Fighters will boost Ukrainian air defences as soldiers face tough battles against Russians on eastern front lines.
Content: The United States has said it will start training Ukrainian pilots on F-16 fighters from next month, joining other allies working to strengthen Ukraineâ€™s air defences some 18 months since Russiaâ€™s invasion. The pilots will be brought to the US in September where they will first learn English before starting their training on how to fly the advanced fighter. Speaking in Washington, DC, on Thursday, Pentagon spokesman Pat Ryder said the training in Texas and Arizona would involve â€œseveralâ€ pilots and â€œdozensâ€ of personnel to maintain the aircraft. US President Joe Biden and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelenskyy discussed the training programme in a call on Thursday, the White House said. â€œPresident Biden reiterated the US commitment to support Ukraineâ€™s defence against Russian aggression for as long as it takes, and to hold Russia accountable for its actions,â€ it said in a statement. The US announcement expands plans by European allies Denmark and the Netherlands todonate F-16 fightersto Ukraine and train its pilots. Norway has also said it will provide the planes to Ukraine with Greece joining the countries offering training. Speaking in an interview with Jordanâ€™s Al-Mamlaka public service TV news channel, meanwhile, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley said Ukraine was likely to receive the planes â€œin the not-too-distant futureâ€, saying they would strengthen Ukraineâ€™s air defences andbolster its counteroffensiveagainst Russian forces in the countryâ€™s east. Milley noted Ukrainian troops were faced with Russian reinforcements that had many months to prepare minefields, tank ditches and dragonâ€™s teeth tank obstacles â€œin a very complex set of defensive preparations that the Ukrainians are fighting through â€¦ â€œThe Ukrainians have a significant amount of combat power remaining; this is not over yet,â€ he said. â€œClearly itâ€™s had partial success to date,â€ Milley added in the interview in Amman, adding that the speed was slower than the planners had thought. Ukrainian forces were being trained intensively in various parts of Europe on â€œcommand and control of offensive formations and combined arms manoeuvre and to break complex obstacles that will bolster its capabilities,â€ the four-star US Army general said. â€œAgain, itâ€™s bloody, itâ€™s long and itâ€™s slow. And we had predicted that several months ago,â€ he said. It is likely to be some months before Ukraine will be able to feel the benefit of the new fighter jets. Ryder said training on the F-16s was likely to last between five and eight months, depending on the pilotsâ€™ existing skills. Language training at the beginning was crucial, â€œgiven the complexities and the specialised English thatâ€™s required to fly these aircraft,â€ he said.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 548
Subtitle: As the war enters its 548th day, these are the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation on Friday August 25, 2023.

Title: What did President Putin say about the Russia plane crash
Subtitle: Here is a translation of Putinâ€™s comments after he broke his silence over the crash.
Content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has broken his silence about the plane crash that took place outside Moscow on Wednesday, almost 24 hours after the incident. He sent his condolences to the families of those who died in the crash without confirming by name if Wagner group leader Yevgeny Prigozhin, who was listed as a passenger on the plane, had died. Here is a translation by Reuters news agency of what Putin said: â€œAs for the aviation tragedy, first of all I want to express my most sincere condolences to the families of all the victims. â€œIt is always a tragedy. Indeed, if employees of the Wagner company were there, and the preliminary data indicate they were, I would like to note that these people made a significant contribution to our common cause of combating the neo-Nazi regime in Ukraine, we remember this, we know it and we shall not forget. â€œI had known Prigozhin for a very long time, since the start of the â€™90s. He was a man with a difficult fate, and he made serious mistakes in life. And he strove for the results he needed for himself, and when I asked him about it, for the common cause, as in these last months. He was a talented person, a talented businessman, he worked not only in our country, and worked with results, but also abroad, in Africa, in particular. He was involved there with oil, gas, precious metals and stones. â€œAs far as I know, he just returned yesterday from Africa. He met some officials here. But what is quite definite â€“ the head of the Investigative Committee reported to me this morning â€“ is they have already begun a preliminary investigation into this event. And it will be carried out in full, and taken right to the end. There are no doubts about this. â€œLetâ€™s see what the investigators say in the near future. And now, expert examinations, technical examinations and genetic ones are being carried out. This takes some time.â€

Title: Ukraine says troops landed on Crimea in â€˜special operationâ€™
Subtitle: Ukraine has repeatedly said it aims to take back Crimea, which has been under Russian control since 2014.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s navy and military intelligence carried out a â€œspecial operationâ€ overnight with units landing in Crimea, officials have said. A short and brief video posted on Thursday, along with a statement by the Defence Ministry intelligence service (HUR), showed a small motorboat moving through the water at night near a coastline. The alleged landing came at a poignant moment, with Ukraine celebrating its independence from the Soviet Union on Thursday, August 24. The intelligence service said the landing point was on the western tip of the Crimean Peninsula. â€œSpecial units on watercraft landed on the shore in the area of the Olenivka and Mayak settlements,â€ HUR said. It added that â€œall goalsâ€ had been achieved and that casualties had been inflicted, but did not specify the aims of the operation. â€œThe enemy suffered losses among personnel, [and] enemy equipment was destroyed,â€ HUR said, noting that the â€œstate flag flew again in the Ukrainian Crimeaâ€. If confirmed, the operation would mark a rare demonstration that Ukrainian forces can stage acts on the ground in Crimea, which Russia annexed in 2014. The reports come a day after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy vowed to end Russiaâ€™s occupation of Crimea. During a speech at an international conference on Crimea in Kyiv, Zelenskyy said Crimea will be â€œde-occupied like all other parts of Ukraine that are unfortunately still under the occupierâ€. Last month, Moscow accused Ukraine of attacking the Russian-built Crimean bridge, which has been closed due to multiple incidents, including an explosion in July 2023. Zelenskyy said that once Crimea was back under Ukrainian control, it would be part of Ukraineâ€™s economy and, therefore, the global economy. â€œToday we are taking the first such economic step. We are signing the first document with companies that are ready to enter Crimea following Ukraine,â€ he said. On Wednesday, Ukraineâ€™s military also reported deliberately luring a Russian military pilot to land his Mi-8 helicopter at a Ukrainian airfield. Ukraine has launched multiple attacks on the Russian-annexed peninsula since the start of Moscowâ€™s invasion in February 2022, and refers to the area as â€œtemporarily occupiedâ€. But Russia has shown no sign of abandoning Crimea, which it has used as a platform to launch missile strikes on Ukrainian targets. Moscow says a referendum held after Russian forces seized the peninsula showed Crimeans want to be part of Russia, a claim vehemently denied by Ukraine and much of the international community.

Title: Moscow court extends pre-trial detention of WSJ reporter Evan Gershkovich
Subtitle: Wall Street Journal newspaper condemns three-month extension, renews call for US journalistâ€™s immediate release.
Content: A court in Moscow has extended the pre-trial detention of Wall Street Journal reporterEvan Gershkovich, Russian news agencies reported, drawing condemnation from the US newspaper and renewed calls for Gershkovichâ€™s release. The court in Russiaâ€™s capital on Thursday extended the 31-year-old American journalistâ€™s detention to November 30 from August 30, the TASS state news agency said. Gershkovich, who was arrested in March on espionage charges that he has denied, was present at the hearing. He arrived in a white prison van and was led out in handcuffs, wearing jeans, sneakers and a shirt. â€œWe are deeply disappointed he continues to be arbitrarily and wrongfully detained for doing his job as a journalist,â€ the Wall Street Journal said in a statement after the courtâ€™s decision. â€œThe baseless accusations against him are categorically false, and we continue to push for his immediate release. Journalism is not a crime.â€    Russian authorities arrested Gershkovich in late March in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg, accusing him of trying to obtain classified information about a Russian arms factory. His detention has unfolded amid heightened tensions between the United States and Russia over the Russian war in Ukraine and advocates have said his arrest is part of Moscowâ€™s broader crackdown on media outlets as it pushes forward with the invasion of its neighbour. But the Russian authorities said Gershkovich was â€œcaught red-handed and violated the laws of the Russian Federationâ€. The countryâ€™s Federal Security Service said the US reporter, â€œacting on the instructions of the American side, collected information constituting a state secret about the activities of one of the enterprises of the Russian military-industrial complexâ€. Gershkovichâ€™s legal team andhis supportershave dismissed the charges as baseless. In April, the US Department of State formally designated Gershkovich as â€œwrongfully detainedâ€ and called on Russia to release him immediately. But on June 22, a Russian judge rejected an application for Gershkovich to be released from prison while awaiting trial.Â After that decision, the US ambassador to Russia, Lynne Tracy, accused Moscow of conducting â€œhostage diplomacyâ€. Tracy has metGershkovich three timessince his detention began.Â Following her last visit earlier this month, the ambassador said he appeared to be â€œin good healthâ€. â€œOnce again, the United States calls on the Russian Federation to immediately release Evan Gershkovich,â€ Tracy said through a spokesperson at that time. She also called for the release of formerUS Marine Paul Whelan, who is also detained in Russia on espionage charges that he has also denied. In Gershkovichâ€™s case,Â Russia has said that any prisoner exchange could only be considered after a court verdict, and via a special channel handled by the security services. The country has agreed to high-profile swaps in the past, most recently in December 2022 whenit traded Brittney Griner, a US basketball star convicted of a drug offence in Russia, for Russian arms trafficker Viktor Bout.

Title: Crashed Russian Embraer jet had good safety record: Company
Subtitle: The private jet crashed into a village on Wednesday, reportedly holding the Wagner Group founder, Yevgeny Prigozhin.
Content: The Embraer executive jet model that crashed in Russia, possibly with Wagner mercenary chief Yevgeny Prigozhin on board, has recorded only one accident in more than 20 years of service, and that was not related to mechanical failure. Russian authorities said Prigozhin was listed as a passenger on a private jet that crashed on Wednesday evening, killing all those on board. Russiaâ€™s TASS news agency said the plane was a Brazilian Embraer jet. Embraer said it was aware of a plane crash in Russia involving a Legacy 600 aircraft, but it did not have further information about the case and had not been providing support services for the jet since 2019. â€œEmbraer has complied with international sanctions imposed on Russia,â€ the company said. Sanctions block Western plane makers from providing parts or support for planes operated in Russia. Flightradar24 online tracker showed that the aircraft (number RA-02795) dropped off the radar at 6:11 pm local time (15:11 GMT). An unverified video on social media showed a plane resembling a private jet falling out of the sky towards the Earth. The aircraft, manufactured in 2007, fell under US Treasury sanctions in 2019 when it was listed under a prior registration, M-SAAN, according to a US government press release. It said, by October 2018, Prigozhinâ€™s employees had arranged for the purchase of the private jet M-SAAN, which was registered under the owner Autolex Transport, a company cited in the release for materially assisting Prigozhin. The United States Treasury Departmentâ€™s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) took action against Prigozhin for attempting to influence the 2018 US elections, the September 30, 2019 release said. The identification codes of the aircraft, mentioned in OFACâ€™s Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons (SDN) List, match those of the crashed plane with the tail number RA-02795, as listed in the Russian aircraft registry.    The same plane was spotted flying to Belarus from Russia after the failed mutiny in late June, presumably carrying Prigozhin to Minsk. The Legacy 600 entered service in 2002, according to International Aviation HQ, with almost 300 produced until production ceased in 2020. There is only one recorded accident involving a Legacy 600, according to International Aviation HQ, which occurred in 2006 when it crashed midair into a Gol Boeing 737-800 on its way from the Embraer factory in Brazil to the US. The Boeing commercial airliner was downed and all 154 passengers died. The pilot of the Embraer plane landed without any deaths or injuries on that aircraft. Two years later, a Brazilian air force report blamed two US pilots, traffic controllers and faulty communications for the midair collision. At the time, a lawyer for the pilots said individual air traffic controllers and flaws in Brazilâ€™s air traffic control system caused the accident.

Title: Will Russiaâ€™s Putin benefit from Prigozhinâ€™s presumed plane crash death?
Subtitle: The Wagner Group leader was listed as a passenger of a plane that crashed on Wednesday, but his death remains unconfirmed by the Kremlin.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraineâ€“ Yevgeny Prigozhin, the foul-mouthed chief of the Wagner private army who masterminded an aborted mutiny against the Kremlin, has not been officially pronounced dead. Russian authorities have yet to confirm via a DNA test that the 62-year-oldâ€™s body was among the charred and mangled remnants of 10 people found in the debris of the private jet that crashed 350km (217 miles) northwest of Moscow late on Wednesday. Prigozhin was, however, listed as one of the planeâ€™s passengers â€“ along with the companyâ€™s founder and neo-Nazi sympathiser Dmitry Utkin nicknamed Wagner.  Few doubt Prigozhinâ€™s presumed death, that took place exactly two months after the June 23 â€œjustice marchâ€, as he called it, of thousands of Wagnerâ€™s best fighters towards Moscow. The rebellion sowed panic in the Kremlin and reportedly forced Russian President Vladimir Putin to flee Moscow. The uprising was triggered by a months-old conflict with Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence that delayed or sabotaged ammunition supplies to Wagner on the front lines of southeastern Ukraine. The march stopped only 200km (124 miles) south of Moscow after Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko promised Prigozhin and all of Wagner a safe haven in his forested ex-Soviet nation bordering Ukraine. A top expert on Wagner is all but certain that Prigozhin is dead. â€œIâ€™ve heard from a source in Wagner close to him that itâ€™s likely true,â€ John Lechner, an investigative reporter in the United States who is writing a book about Prigozhin summarising years of research, told Al Jazeera shortly after Russian media reported the plane crash. Al Jazeera was unable to independently verify the claim. But those who doubt the demise cite Prigozhinâ€™s penchant for disguises â€“ and his chance to escape to the Central African Republic, Mali or other African nations where Wagner provides â€œsecurity servicesâ€ to local strongmen in exchange for a stake in mining and trading local natural resources. Russian police discovered a stash of fake passports with Prigozhinâ€™s mugshots and names of other people a day after the failed coup, and framed photos of him wearing wigs, glasses and beards were found in his St Petersburg mansion and immediately ridiculed in online memes. â€œItâ€™s nice and easy to fake oneâ€™s own death,â€ Ukrainian defence expert Maria Kucherenko, who authored a detailed report on Wagner, wrote on Facebook late Thursday. But there are no chances of really faking Prigozhinâ€™s death in Russia, given the scrutiny of officials and forensics experts investigating the crash, said another analyst. â€œThere could have been rumours [of fake death] had he done it in Africa, but not in Russia, where a DNA test will be quickly performed,â€ Nikolay Mitrokhin of Germanyâ€™s University of Bremen told Al Jazeera.  The DNA tests will be scrupulously monitored by the Kremlin given that it is the main benefactor of Prigozhinâ€™s death, Mitrokhin said. â€œJudging by the sources, the plane was shot down. Thatâ€™s what easy to believe. It is very beneficial for Russian authorities who can always shift the blame to an [air defence] lieutenant or major who made the mistake,â€ he said. According to a cellphone video purportedly showing Prigozhinâ€™sLegacy Embraer jetmidair, it was falling, not gliding down, and apparently had only one engine running. A plume of smoke that did not resemble exhaust was seen behind the plane, and its tail and one of the wings fell far apart from the fuselage, which may indicate that the crash was caused by an explosion, according to the photos and videos from the crash site. In another amateur video showing the falling plane, witnessessay they had heardâ€œtwo explosionsâ€. Air defence forces routinely shoot at a plane twice to ensure it is hit. A source in Russiaâ€™s main aviation oversight body told the Tsargrad television channel that the plane was â€œblown upâ€. However, Flightradar 24, a Swedish aircraft tracker, said that the Brazilian-made jet went up to 8,500 metres (28,000 feet). Very few air defence weapons can hit a plane that high â€“ and the Kremlin allegedly used two S-300 missiles, the VChK-OGPU Telegram channel with links to Russian law enforcement agencies claimed. Putin, a former KGB colonel who headed the FSB, the main KGB successor, in the late 1990s, is notoriously vindictive. Kremlin critics cite the case of Alexander Litvinenko, an FSB expert on organised crime who accused Putin of profiting from drug trafficking and money laundering. Litvinenko defected to the United Kingdom and died an agonising death in 2006 after drinking tea laced with radioactive polonium-210, an extremely rare and expensive poison. Putin called Litvinenko a â€œtraitorâ€, and London said the Russian president â€œprobablyâ€ sanctioned the assassination. â€œTraitorsâ€ was the epithet Putin used in his televised address on the day of Prigozhinâ€™s mutiny. And even though the riot was called off and Wagner marched back to Russia-occupied areas in southeastern Ukraine, Putinâ€™s reputation suffered greatly. High treason charges against Wagner chief and officers who shot down several Russian aircraft during their march were dropped a day later. Unlike other Putin allies who prefer to keep a low profile, Prigozhin was a motormouth. For months before the mutiny, he lambasted Russiaâ€™s top brass. And after it, thousands of key Wagner fighters relocated to hastily built camps in Belarusian forests. Some were spotted near the Suwalki Gap near the Polish-Lithuanian border that separates Belarus from Kaliningrad, Russiaâ€™s Baltic exclave. Prigozhin visited Russia several times and even met with Putin, while Wagnerâ€™s recruitment centres continued to operate. So, Putin may have followed the example of cinematic mafia boss Michael Corleone by serving his revenge cold, a Russian opposition activist said. â€œPrigozhin was relocated from the country. Within two months, they redistributed his assets, checked all contact chains, and replaced everything in the system that needed replacement. And now just got rid of [Prigozhin and his top lieutenants],â€ Sergey Bizyukin told Al Jazeera. â€œI donâ€™t know whether [Prigozhin] had a chance to sit it all out in Belarus, but that was his only teeny-weeny chanceâ€ to survive, Bizyukin said. But since Wagner proved to be so effective, it may continue to exist and operate in Ukraine and elsewhere â€“ even if itâ€™s not just â€œbled dry, but decapitatedâ€, according to independent military analyst David Gendelman. The plane crash reportedly wiped out Wagnerâ€™s top brass. One of the killed passengers was Valery Chkalov, a key Prigozhin ally in charge of Wagnerâ€™s logistics in Ukraine, Syria and Africa. Others were key lieutenants Yevgeny Makaryan and Sergey Propustin. But the companyâ€™s resources, including battle-tested fighters and smoothly functioning operations in Africa, are too valuable for the Kremlin to let Wagner disband, Gendelman said. â€œSo, they will most likely keep operating under new control affiliated somehow with Russiaâ€™s leadership. And, perhaps, such control has already been organised as part of preparation to behead the organisation,â€ he told Al Jazeera. But Wagnerâ€™s â€“ and Moscowâ€™s â€“ clout in Africa may eclipse because of the rising influence of China and other core members of the now-expanding BRICS bloc. â€œRussiaâ€™s sway in Africa will weaken irrespective of personalities at the helmâ€ of Wagner, Kyiv-based analyst Aleksey Kushch told Al Jazeera.

Title: Russian villagers report explosion before â€˜Prigozhinâ€™ plane crash
Subtitle: The Wagner boss was listed as a passenger on the private jet, but the Kremlin has not confirmed his death.
Content: The residents of a nearby village where a plane crashed and killed all on board, possibly including theWagner mercenary chief, say they heard a bang before seeing the jet fall to the ground. On Wednesday, a private jet crashed near the village of Kuzhenkino in Russiaâ€™s Tver region on its way from Moscow to St Petersburg, killing all 10 passengers on board, including three crew members.  Kuzhenkino resident Vitaly Stepenok, 72, told the Reuters news agency: â€œI hear an explosion or a bang. Usually, if an explosion happens on the ground then you get an echo, but it was just a bang and I looked up and saw white smoke.â€ â€œOne wing flew off in one direction and the fuselage went like that,â€ he said, gesturing with his arms to show how the plane headed down towards the ground. â€œAnd then it glided down on one wing. It didnâ€™t nose-dive, it was gliding.â€ Another villager named Anatoly said, â€œIn terms of what might have happened, Iâ€™ll just say this: it wasnâ€™t thunder, it was a metallic bang â€“ letâ€™s put it that way. Iâ€™ve heard things like that before.â€    The plane crash came two months after the mercenary groupâ€™saborted mutinyagainst the Russian military top generals, in which he publicly accused them of incompetence in the war in Ukraine. According to a passenger list, the people on board were members of the group, including founder Yevgeny Prigozhin and his second-in-command, Dmitry Utkin. While there has been no official comment from the Kremlin about the crash and the possible death of the mercenary leader, a Telegram channel linked to the Wagner Group pronounced Prigozhin dead. Forensic investigators erected a tent and lighting gear at the wreckage site as part of the planeâ€™s blue and white tail and other fragments lay on the ground. Reporting from the crash scene, Al Jazeeraâ€™s Amine Derghami said: â€œWe can confirm that two vehicles arrived at the crash site to transport the dead. Parts of the plane were found 2km away â€¦ but the search has been difficult.â€ â€œThe Russian authorities have confirmed Prigozhin was on board the flight. The Russian aviation federation released the passenger list earlier, seven Wagner members with three aircrew. â€œUntil now, the investigation team has not confirmed that Prigozhinâ€™s body has been found or that he was killed in the crash.â€ Russian investigators said they had opened a criminal investigation into the plane crash. But some unnamed sources, cited by Reuters, told Russian media they believed one or more surface-to-air missiles had shot the plane down. Al Jazeera was unable to independently verify those claims.

Title: Ukrainians express fear and hope as Russiaâ€™s war rages on Independence Day
Subtitle: Ukraine declared independence from the Soviet Union on August 24, 1991.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraine â€“Thirty-two years have passed since Ukraine gained independence from the Soviet Union. With the country now at war with Russia, Al Jazeera spoke to several Ukrainians about what the anniversary on Thursday means to them: Yevhen Averkin, 35, a serviceman since 2014: I was very small on the first Independence Day. I was three. The Independence Day I remember the most is in 2009. I took part in a parade on the Independence Day during my military service. Whatâ€™s utterly important is that our next generation grows up in peace without knowing what war is, so that they have real freedom of speech, so that our nation flourishes without corruption, without oligarchs. And we need to work on our victory. The most bitter thing for me is losing my brothers in arms. Since 2014, when the war began, I fought in the Donbas region. Then we were stationed in Henichesk [in the Kherson region near Russian-annexed Crimea]. Since last year, we were advancing in Kherson, liberated it. Then we fought in [the eastern towns of ] Bakhmut, Soledar, Kurdiumivka, Bakhmut again, Vasuikivka, and now we are in the Zaporizhia direction, moving towards [the Russian-occupied town of] Tokmak. The day before yesterday, we liberated [the village] of Rabotino. No one knows for real when weâ€™ll have won. Soldiers donâ€™t win wars. Politicians do. Only they know when they meet and agree and we will finally see peace. But thereâ€™s one thing I can say â€“ we will stand until the end to liberate Ukraine within its 1991 borders. Larysa Averkina, 29, Averkinâ€™s wife: The most bitter thing is when my child is growing up without a father, when he watches the news and says, â€œMy dad is a hero. My father defends Ukraine.â€ Independence is when a person is free, when one has their values, can convey their words, express themselves without fear. When things are peaceful. When you are not afraid to go out without being afraid of whatâ€™s awaiting you outdoors, whether there is shelling today or not, whether you are alive today or not. We want to live the way we did before the war â€“ in freedom, in peace.â€ Svetlana Chunikhina, vice president of the Association of Political Psychologists: I remember the [failed August 18-21, 1991, Communist] putsch in Moscow very well â€“ to be more precise, the depressing impression it made on my parents. In my youth, I perceived politics in Ukraine as â€œmoonlightâ€, as a reflection of what was happening [in Moscow], in the former metropolis. But as I began to deal with the psychology of politics professionally, the real picture of what happened on August 24, 1991, began to gradually open up to me. Ukraineâ€™s independence was not written in the scenarios of the global historical process at the time. Its value was notÂ  100 percent obvious either for Ukrainians or for its neighbours. No one and nothing guaranteed the independence. It was a desperate jump over the abyss to the freedom we dreamed about. I share the view of [American historian] Timothy Snyder. He speaks of Ukrainian statehood as history being made right now, live, at the cost of our lives. And now the situation is such that Ukraineâ€™s freedom is a prologue to the freedom of the [European] continent and the world as a whole from the new dark ages of tyranny. Antonina, 80, lived in Russia until 1994: When [the 1991 Communist putsch] failed, everyone sighed with relief because all of that was incomprehensible and frightening. Then survival began. At the time, [politicians] were saying, â€œWeâ€™ll be on our own. We will live well.â€ I didnâ€™t believe in it at the time. In 2014 [after the pro-Western Maidan revolution], I felt I was Ukrainian. Before that, I had been feeling like a Russian living in Ukraine â€“ that itâ€™s my country, that I hurt for it, that itâ€™s mine, that I have to stand for it. On the first day of the war [on February 24, 2002], I sent a text [to my nieces in Russia], so that they learned about it from me, not from television, not from the [official] lies. I told them, â€œItâ€™s such a pity that you donâ€™t come out to rally in protest,â€ and one of them said, â€œUnfortunately, we canâ€™t. Itâ€™s forbidden.â€ And the second niece whoâ€™s a bit older said she didnâ€™t get any messages [about the war]. These days, they donâ€™t believe me. Svetlana Ivanova, 65: Ukraineâ€™s independence was the dream we always had â€“ to be independent, to be strong, not to rely on anyone, to do the best you can for yourselves, for others. I donâ€™t remember the very first day of independence, but I remember the feeling of that time. A child is born, and everything about it is in the future. It may grow into a strong, beautiful person, and everything depends on us, on how we raise this child. [I remember] the feeling of future happiness. I was on the Maidan [Kyivâ€™s Independence Square during the anti-Russian revolt of 2013-2014]. I was building barricades, and when [pro-Russian President Viktor Yanukovychâ€™s troops] used water cannons against us, [other protesters] asked me, â€œLady, step aside please.â€ I cooked for them, and during the shooting on February 19, [2014, which killed 25 people,] I rushed to help the wounded. I am not a doctor, but I helped. In those days, I saw how old ladies would bring something. Everyone brought anything they could. I was proud of being Ukrainian and that this is my motherland, my nation. [When the war began,] I had no fear â€“ when [my neighbours] were looking for spies, when somebody called the police saying, â€œThereâ€™s someone suspicious sitting outside.â€ I live on Lesya Ukraininka Boulevard [in downtown Kyiv]. There was commotion around us, but there was no fear. I had a feeling that weâ€™re succeeding, that weâ€™re moving forward. But now, I have a feeling that weâ€™re losing ground. We need the support of other nations, but at the time when we have to focus everything on the victory, there are these delays. I feel that people donâ€™t understand that our destinies are being determined â€“ that, I beg your pardon, our behinds are on fire, that nothing has been set in stone and that our boys get killed [on the front lines] to protect us. When the war began, we pitched in. We lived like a big commune. And now, thereâ€™s a feeling that everything is over, that they won the war. Thereâ€™s no victory yet. The most difficult part is ahead of us. Weâ€™re at a crossroads. Thereâ€™s no return to the past. Nadia Gordiyuk, a community activist from the town ofNew Yorkin the Donetsk region who was a volunteer at the 1991 referendum on Ukraineâ€™s independence: I am 60 years old. I must be a typical product of Homo Sovieticus because I lived my entire life in the Donetsk region at the very centre of the Donbas, which was Russified at the time. I went to a Russian-language school in the town of New York. In 1951, Soviet authorities prudently and secretly removed the name, replacing it with the neutral and faceless Novgorodskoye. And from the schoolâ€™s windows one could see the buildings of [the town of] Horlivka, which is now occupied by Russians. But the outlook formed by my secondary school changed dramatically when IÂ  entered the Sloviansk Pedagogical Institute in 1980 in the very town ofÂ  Sloviansk, from where the Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine began [in April 2014 when Russian â€œvolunteersâ€ seized it]. Even then, during [Soviet leader Leonid] Brezhnevâ€™s â€œprosperous timesâ€, there where teachers of Ukrainian language and literature and even Communist history who taught their students to look at Ukrainian history not in accordance with the Communist Party textbooks and half-whispered the real history of Ukraine to us. That is why on January 21, 1990, when I was in Kyiv for professional training, I heard about the â€œLive Chainâ€ rally organized by the [pro-independence] Peopleâ€™s Movement of Ukraine. I didnâ€™t hesitate to join the rally, which became one of the most important steps towards the restoration of Ukraineâ€™s statehood. [Hundreds of thousands of] people joined hands to demonstrate the unity of Ukraine on the way to independence. Thatâ€™s why back in my New York, I actively participated in the organisation of the December 1, 1991, survey and referendum when many compatriots supported the Declaration of Independence with their signatures. We collected signatures independently, without asking for the consent and help of local authorities. It wasnâ€™t politicians who decided to declare Ukraineâ€™s independence. It was the people [who voted] at the all-Ukrainian referendum. There was only one question on that piece of paper: â€œDo you confirm the act of proclamation of the independence of Ukraine?â€ More than 90 percent of Ukrainians from various regions responded positively. Iâ€™m proud that my compatriots [from New York] were among them. For my family, Ukraineâ€™s Independence Day is full of personal symbolism. It was on this day in 2005 when my father, who hoped for the revival and prosperity of Ukraine his entire life, passed away. For many days, he was between heaven and earth, but he passed away on this particular day. He waited [to die] on his favourite holiday, the one heâ€™d been anticipating his entire life. For me, itâ€™s a symbol that despite all the hardship and trouble, Ukraine would live to see its victory and prosperity.

Title: Wagnerâ€™s boss Yevgeny Prigozhin on crashed plane: What to know
Subtitle: Russian mercenary chief Prigozhin was listed as a passenger on a private jet that crashed on Wednesday evening north of Moscow with no survivors.
Content: Russian authorities have confirmed that Yevgeny Prigozhin, head of the Wagner Group that led a mutiny against Russiaâ€™s army in June, was on board a plane that crashed outside Moscow. Russiaâ€™s emergency situations ministry said all 10 people on board were killed. Here is what we know so far: According to authorities, 10 people have died after a private jet crashed north of Moscow, Around 17:00 GMT, the ministry announced that a â€œprivate Embraer Legacy 600 aircraft traveling from Moscow to Saint Petersburg crashedâ€. It said that 10 people were on board, including three crew members. According to authorities, eight bodies have been found. Russiaâ€™s Federal Agency for Air Transport also said it launched a â€œspecially created commissionâ€ to investigate the crash. A Telegram channel believed to be linked to Prigozhin also said that the Wagner leader was dead. The FlightRadar24 online tracker showed that the Embraer Legacy (plane number RA-02795) had dropped off the radar at 6:11pm (15:11 GMT). Soon after the plane dropped out of the sky, a second private jet linked to Prigozhin, which also appeared to be heading to St Petersburg, turned back to Moscow and later landed, flight tracking data showed. Russiaâ€™s emergency situations ministry said that the plane crashed near the village of Kuzhenkino in the Tver region.  Prigozhin, 62, soared in prominence after Russiaâ€™s February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, where his fighters â€“ including thousands of convicts he recruited from prison â€“ led the Russian assault on the city of Bakhmut in the longest and bloodiest battle of the war. Prigozhin used social media to trumpet Wagnerâ€™s successes and wage a feud with Russiaâ€™s military establishment, accusing it of incompetence and even treason. In June,Prigozhin led a mutinyin which Wagner fighters took control of the southern city of Rostov-on-Don and shot down a number of military helicopters, killing their pilots, as they advanced towards Moscow. President Vladimir Putin called it an act of treason that would meet with a harsh response. The revolt was defused in a deal whereby the Kremlin said that in order to avert bloodshed, Prigozhin and some of his fighters would leave for Belarus and a criminal case against him for armed mutiny would be dropped. Confusion has surrounded the implementation of the deal and the future of Prigozhin. Born in St Petersburg on June 1, 1961, Prigozhin spent nine years in Soviet prisons for crimes including robbery and fraud. Released in 1990 amid the Soviet Unionâ€™s death throes, he launched a career as a caterer and restaurateur in his hometown. He is believed to have met Putin, then a top aide to St Petersburgâ€™s mayor, at this time. Read more about him here.    Russian civil aviation authority said that Dmitry Utkin, Prigozhinâ€™s right-hand man, was also on board and that Prigozhin and his associates had attended a meeting with officials from the Russian defence ministry. Mykhailo Podolyak, Ukrainian presidential adviser, on social media platform X reacted to the incident by saying â€œit was worth waiting for the fog of war to disappearâ€. â€œâ€¦It is obvious that Putin does not forgive anyone for his own bestial terror â€¦ The demonstrative elimination of Prigozhin and the Wagner command two months after the coup attempt is a signal from Putin to Russiaâ€™s elites ahead of the 2024 elections. â€˜Beware! Disloyalty equals deathâ€™,â€ he added. About Prigozhin: It is worth waiting for the fog of war to disappearâ€¦ Meanwhile, it is obvious that Putin does not forgive anyone for his own bestial terror. Exactly the one that nullified him in June 2023. And he was waiting for the moment. It is also obvious that Prigozhinâ€¦ â€” ĞœĞ¸Ñ…Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾ ĞŸĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»ÑĞº (@Podolyak_M)August 23, 2023  US President Joe Bidensaid he was â€œnot surprisedâ€ by reports. â€œI donâ€™t know for fact what happened, but I am not surprised,â€@POTUStells reporters when asked about the plane crash as he departed an exercise class in Lake Tahoe, where he is vacationing with his familyhttps://t.co/mAqkq3rlR7 â€” Jordan Fabian (@Jordanfabian)August 23, 2023  Kaja Kallas,prime minister of Estonia, said to CNN that if true, this was a strong message to detractors. â€œIf true, it shows Putin will eliminate opponents, and that scares anyone who is thinking of expressing [an] opinion different than his.â€ British lawmaker Alicia Kearns, chair of the UK Parliamentâ€™s Foreign Affairs Committee, said Putin was sending a loud message. â€œThe speed at which the Russian Govt has confirmed Yevgeny Prigozhin was on a plane that crashed on a flight from Moscow to St Petersburg should tell us everything we need to know. Reports Russian Air Defence shot down the plane suggests Putin is sending a very loud message.â€ Polish Foreign Minister Zbigniew Raucommented on this on the state news channel TVP Info: â€œâ€¦ We would have great trouble naming anyone who would intuitively think this was a coincidence. It so happens that political opponents whom Vladimir Putin considers a threat to his power do not die naturally.â€

Title: Global reaction to possible death of Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin
Subtitle: Russiaâ€™s ministry for emergency situations announces crash of a private plane travelling between Moscow and St Petersburg, saying Wagner chief Prigozhin was on the passenger list.
Content: Russian mercenary chiefYevgeny Prigozhinwas listed as a passenger on a private jet that crashed north of Moscow, killing all 10 passengers, the Russian authorities said. It remains to be confirmed if the Wagner chief had actually boarded the flight. Since the rebellion byWagner forcesin June, Prigozhin has been seen as the biggest challenge to Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s authority since he came to power. Here is how the world reacted to the crash and the reported death of Prigozhin: President Joe Biden says he was â€œnot surprisedâ€ at news that Prigozhin may have died in a plane crash in Russia. â€œI donâ€™t know for a fact what happened, but Iâ€™m not surprised,â€ Biden said, adding: â€œThereâ€™s not much that happens in Russia that Putinâ€™s not behind. But I donâ€™t know enough to know the answer.â€ In a statement, US National Security Council spokesperson Adrienne Watson also said that â€œif confirmed, no one should be surprisedâ€, by the apparent death. â€œThe disastrous war in Ukraine led to a private army marching on Moscow, and now â€” it would seem â€” to this.â€ Paris said that there were â€œreasonable doubtsâ€ about the cause of the plane crash that presumably killed Prigozhin. â€œWe donâ€™t yet know the circumstances of this crash. We can have some reasonable doubts,â€ government spokesperson Olivier Veran told France 2 television. Asked about US President Joe Bidenâ€™s comments, Veran agreed that â€œas a general rule, thatâ€™s a truth that can be establishedâ€. Prigozhin was â€œthe man who did Putinâ€™s dirty work. What he has done is inseparable from the policies of Putin, who gave him responsibility to carry out abuses as the head of Wagnerâ€, he said. â€œPrigozhin leaves behind him mass graves. He leaves behind him messes across a large part of the globe, Iâ€™m thinking of Africa, Ukraine and Russia itself.â€ Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told journalists with Interfax-Ukraine news agency that Ukraine was not behind the crash. â€œWe had nothing to do with it. Everybody realises who has something to do with itâ€. Presidential aide Mykhaylo Podolyak wrote on social media that the crash of the plane was a signal from the Kremlin to anyone who showed disloyalty but that it was â€œworth waiting for the fog of war to disappearâ€ before making concrete conclusions. â€œThe demonstrative elimination of Prigozhin and the Wagner command two months after the coup attempt is a signal from Putin to Russiaâ€™s elites ahead of the 2024 elections. â€˜Beware! Disloyalty equals death'â€, Podolyak wrote. About Prigozhin: It is worth waiting for the fog of war to disappearâ€¦ Meanwhile, it is obvious that Putin does not forgive anyone for his own bestial terror. Exactly the one that nullified him in June 2023. And he was waiting for the moment. It is also obvious that Prigozhinâ€¦ â€” ĞœĞ¸Ñ…Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾ ĞŸĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»ÑĞº (@Podolyak_M)August 23, 2023  Estonia Prime Minister Kaja Kallas, in an interview with CNN, said Putin will â€œeliminate opponents and that scares anyone who is thinking of expressing opinion different than hisâ€. Polish Foreign Minister Zbigniew Rau told state news channel TVP Info, â€œWe would have great trouble naming anyone who would intuitively think this was a coincidence. It so happens that political opponents whom Vladimir Putin considers a threat to his power do not die naturally.â€ Schools Minister Nick Gibb says the government must â€œavoid jumping to conclusionsâ€ over the plane crash in Russia that reportedly killed Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin. He said the government is monitoring the situation closely and working with its allies. â€œI canâ€™t go any further at the moment,â€ he added. â€œBut of course, the government will have more to say once our assessment of it has happened, and conversations with allies reach clear conclusions.â€ BBC Security Correspondent Frank Gardner, posted on the social media platform X that UK defence sources had told the British state broadcaster that the Russian federal security service most likely brought the plane down. UK defence sources tell BBC: Prigozhinâ€™s plane most likely brought down by Russiaâ€™s FSB domestic intel agency. Likely to strengthen position of Prigozhinâ€™s enemies: Shoigu and Gerasimov.#Prigozhin â€” Frank Gardner (@FrankRGardner)August 24, 2023  German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock initially warned against speculation over the crash of the plane, which authorities said was carrying Prigozhin. â€œNo quick conclusions can be drawn,â€ she told Deutschlandfunk radio on Thursday. However, she later said the presumed death of Prigozhin follows a pattern of â€œunclarifiedâ€ fatalities in Russia, adding that it was no coincidence that the focus has turned to the Kremlin for answers. â€œIt is no accident that the world immediately looks at the Kremlin when a disgraced former confidant of Putin suddenly, literally falls from the sky two months after he attempted a mutiny,â€Â  Baerbock said, referring to the Russian president. â€œWe know this pattern in Putinâ€™s Russia: deaths, dubious suicides, falls from windows, all which remain unclarified â€“ that underlines a dictatorial power system that is built on violence,â€ she said at a news conference with the Kyrgyz foreign minister. Swedenâ€™s Foreign Minister Tobias Billstrom stated that it remained â€œunclearâ€ what the crash meant for Russia and the war in Ukraine. He added that Sweden and its international partners were following the incident closely. Lithuaniaâ€™s president said the presumed death of Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin does not improve regional security. â€œWe really shouldnâ€™t think that Prigozhinâ€™s death makes us feel calmer or that it somehow improves the security situation,â€ Gitanas Nauseda said. He added that even if confirmed it â€œmakes little differenceâ€ to regional security.

Title: Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin â€˜on boardâ€™ jet that crashed in Russia
Subtitle: Russiaâ€™s civil aviation authority publishes names of seven passengers, including Prigozhin and Wagner group commander Dmitry Utkin, who were on board.
Content: Russian mercenary group chief Yevgeny Prigozhin was aboard the plane thatcrashed north of Moscow, killing everyone on board, according to Russiaâ€™s civil aviation agency. Russiaâ€™s federal air transport agency Rosaviatsia published the names of seven passengers â€” including Prigozhin and Wagner group commander Dmitry Utkin â€” and three crew members it said died in Wednesdayâ€™s crash. â€œThere were 10 people on board, including three crew members. According to preliminary information, all those on board died,â€ Russiaâ€™s Ministry for Emergency Situations said shortly before. At about 17:00 GMT, the ministry announced that a â€œprivate Embraer Legacy aircraft travelling from Moscow to Saint Petersburg crashed near the village of Kuzhenkino in the Tver Regionâ€, some 300 kilometres (185 miles) north of the capital. Officials have since said the ministry conducted search operations and recovered the remains of those aboard. Video has also emerged, allegedly showing the Embraer jet plummeting from the sky. Authorities are investigating what could have caused the crash, with theories ranging from technical problems to explosions onboard the jet. In the more than 20 years that the jet model has been in service, the news outlet Reuters said that only one previous crash has been recorded, attributed to mistakes by crew members.  Daniel Hawkins, a journalist in Moscow, told Al Jazeera that â€œreports in the Russian media, unconfirmed so far, are saying this aircraft could have been taken down by air defence systemsâ€. â€œPrigozhin was among those on board or was at least listed as among those people on board. â€œSome journalists report theyâ€™re in touch with his press secretary who is refusing to confirm that. A second jet was also in the air thatâ€™s turned around and gone back to St Petersburg.â€    The crash came two months to the day after Prigozhin led a short-lived armed rebellion against Russiaâ€™s military leadership on June 23. The incident was seen as theÂ gravest challenge ever to President Vladimir Putinâ€™s two-decade grip on power. The rebellion sparked after Prigozhin claimed the Russian military had launched missiles against Wagner mercenary fighters deployed on Russiaâ€™s behalf in Ukraine. Calling the Russian military leadership corrupt and incompetent, Prigozhin proceeded to lead his fighters across the border into Russia, where they occupied the city of Rostov-on-Don. He then sent military columns marching towards Moscow, in an apparent attempt to remove Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu from power. PrigozhinÂ had complained for months of inadequate munitions and supplies for his fighters serving on the front lines of Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine.  At the time, Putin described the revolt as â€œtreasonâ€. But shortly before his troops reached Moscow, Prigozhin ordered a retreat after negotiations with the Kremlin, in which Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko acted as mediator. As part of the deal reached to escape prosecution, Prigozhin and his Wagner fighters were offered sanctuary in Belarus. Rumours have swirled about possible retribution against Prigozhin since the rebellion, and on Wednesday,Â United States President Joe Biden expressed little shock upon hearing about his apparent demise. â€œIâ€™m not surprised,â€ Biden told reporters. He clarified, however, that he did not know exactly what was behind the crash. â€œThere is not much that happens in Russia that Putin is not behind, but I donâ€™t know enough to know the answer.â€ US National Security Council spokeswoman Adrienne Watson echoed those sentiments in a statement. â€œIf confirmed, no one should be surprised,â€ she said. â€œThe disastrous war in Ukraine led to a private army marching on Moscow, and now â€” it would seem â€” to this.â€    Experts are still being cautious about whether Prigozhin was on the plane that crashed. But some have said that regardless of the outcome, Prigozhin has been a marked man. â€œWe donâ€™t know all the details yet, but if it turns out that it is what it seems to be, itâ€™s absolutely no coincidence,â€ said Colin Clarke of the Soufan Group, speaking to Al Jazeera from the United States city of Pittsburgh. â€œEver since the mutiny in late June, in which he embarrassed [Russian President] Putin, heâ€™s been a marked man. Many were surprised it [his killing] didnâ€™t happen instantly, but this is something that everybody thought was inevitable.â€

Title: Russiaâ€™s General Surovikin dismissed as head of aerospace forces: Reports
Subtitle: Surovikin, former commander of Russian forces in Ukraine, has not been seen in public since the mutiny by Wagner mercenaries in June.
Content: RussianGeneral Sergei Surovikin, who at one time was commander of Moscowâ€™s war effort in Ukraine, has been dismissed as head of the countryâ€™s aerospace forces, a prominent journalist in Russia and media outlets have reported. Alexei Venediktov, the well-connected former editor-in-chief of the now-defunct Ekho Moskvy (Echo of Moscow) radio station, said on his Telegram channel on Tuesday that Surovikin had been removed, citing an official decree. Surovikin will remain in the defence ministry after his deposition, Venediktov said. The decree has not yet been made public but several nationalist Russian military blogs also reported on Surovikinâ€™s replacement. Surovikin wascommander-in-chief of Russian unitsin Ukraine from October 2022 to January 2023. He was the commander who ordered the withdrawal of Russian troops from the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson in November 2022.    There was no official confirmation of Venediktovâ€™s report, though the Russian-language RBC media outlet later on Tuesday also reported that Surovikin has been dismissed, citing its own sources. â€œArmy General Sergei Surovikin has been relieved of his post in connection with the transition to another job and is at the disposal of (the Ministry of Defence),â€ RBC said. One of the paperâ€™s sources said Surovikin â€œis currently on short-term leaveâ€. Russian state news agency RIA Novosti reported on Wednesday that Surovikin was replaced by a Russian Air Force commander. â€œEx-chief of the Russian Air and Space Forces Sergei Surovikin has now been relieved of his post, while Colonel-General Viktor Afzalov, head of the Main Staff of the Air Force, is temporarily acting as commander-in-chief of the Air Force,â€ RIA Novosti reported, citing an unnamed source. Surovikin has not been seen in publicsince the short-lived mutiny in June by the Wagner mercenary group and its leader, Yevgeny Prigozhin, against Russiaâ€™s defence establishment.    Surovikin was consideredone of Prigozhinâ€™s most important alliesin the regular Russian army and in the Wagner chiefâ€™s power struggle with Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of General Staff Valery Gerasimov. During the mutiny, Surovikin appeared in a video urging Prigozhin to stand down. However, following the Wagner incident, Russian and foreign news reports said that Surovikin was being investigated for possible complicity in the revolt. The Washington, DC-based think tank The Institute for the Study of War (ISW) said on Tuesday that Russian military bloggers claimed the latest news on Surovikinâ€™s fate was neither new, nor a surprise. â€œSurovikinâ€™s alleged dismissal is not new and does not change anything because Russian authorities removed Surovikin from power immediately after Prigozhinâ€™s June 24 rebellion,â€ the bloggers said, according to ISW. Surovikin earned the nickname â€œGeneral Armageddonâ€ during Russiaâ€™s military intervention in Syriaâ€™s civil war. In October, he was placed in charge of Russian military operations in Ukraine but, in January, that role washanded to Gerasimovand Surovikin was made his deputy.

Title: Russia downs 3 combat drones in latest attempted raid on Moscow
Subtitle: Air traffic at Moscowâ€™s Vnukovo, Sheremetyevo and Domodedovo airports halted for a second day in row due to drone attacks.
Content: Russian air defences shot down two unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) and electronically disabled another over central Moscow, thelatest raid on Russiaâ€™s capitalcity by combat drones that authorities have accused Ukraine of launching. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said one drone was jammed electronically and crashed into a building in downtown Moscow early on Wednesday morning, and two more were shot down by air defence systems outside the capital. Moscowâ€™s Mayor Sergei Sobyanin said on the Telegram messaging app that one downed drone had hit a building that was under construction in central Moscow, and another was shot down in a district to the west of the city. â€œTonight, air defence shot down a drone in Mozhaisky district of Moscow region. The second UAV hit a building under construction in the City,â€ Sobyanin said on Telegram. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said that the third drone was shot down in the Khimki district of Moscow. Russian state news agency TASS reported that air traffic at Moscowâ€™s Vnukovo, Sheremetyevo and Domodedovo airports was halted, the second day in a row that operations were disrupted at the airports due to a drone attack on the capital. Operations at the airports resumed later on Wednesday morning, Russiaâ€™s state aviation authority said.    The TASS state news agency quoted emergency services as saying that a building under construction in Moscowâ€™s business district sustained â€œminor damageâ€. Emergency services were inspecting the area in the business district, Sobyanin said on Telegram. â€œSeveral windows were smashed in two adjacent five-storey buildings,â€ he added. Sobyanin and the defence ministry said there were no reports of casualties. Video footages shared on Russian-language social media on Wednesday, which purported to capture the moment the drone crashed into an office block, showed a bright flash followed by a large explosion and smoke. On Tuesday morning, two drones were shot down over the Moscow region town of Krasnogorsk and the settlement of Chastsy. Two other drones were also repelled over the Bryansk region near the Ukrainian border, Moscowâ€™s defence ministry said on Telegram. Windows were broken over several floors of a multi-story residential building in Krasnogorsk and vehicles were damaged on the ground due to debris falling from the destroyed drones, according to authorities. Drone raids on Moscow havebecome regular occurrencesin recent weeks, a development that follows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s warning in late July that the war Moscow had launched in Ukraine was coming to Russia.    A spokesman for the US State Department said on Wednesday that the United States â€“ Kyivâ€™s largest military supporter â€“ does not encourage or enable attacks by Ukrainian forces on Russian territory. Ukraine decides how it chooses to defend itself against Russiaâ€™s invasion, a State Department spokesperson said, according to the Reuters news agency.
