The rebellion saw Wagner forces sweep into the southern city of Rostov-on-Don and capture military headquarters there before marching towards the Russian capital in what Prigozhin described as a â€œmarch of justiceâ€ to oust Defence Minister Sergey Shoigu and chief of the general staff Valery Gerasimov. Prigozhin said his fighters had come within 200km (124 miles) of Moscow when he ordered them to stop the advance under the deal brokered by Lukashenko. The abortive rebellion represented the biggest threat to Putin in his more than two decades in power and exposed weakness in the Kremlin. Lukashenkoâ€™s statement on Thursday followed Russian media reports that said Prigozhin was spotted in St Petersburg, Russiaâ€™s second largest city. Those reports cast his presence as part of agreements that allowed the billionaire to finalise his affairs there. Lukashenko said the issue of relocating Wagner forces had not yet been resolved, the TASS news agency reported. The Belarusian president also hit out at the West over the Ukraine war and said it was likely that Kyiv would try to demonstrate its power against Russia before a key NATO summit in Lithuania next week, TASS reported. He was quoted as saying nuclear weapons would only be used in Ukraine in the case of possible NATO â€œaggressionâ€.

Title: Russian frigates arrive in China in sign of â€˜close cooperationâ€™
Subtitle: The Cold War-era Gromkiy and Sovershenniy will take part in joint drills with the Chinese navy during a week in Shanghai.
Content: Two Russian navy ships have arrived in Shanghai in the first port visit by the Pacific Fleet to China in three years, in a further demonstration of the two countriesâ€™ close ties 16 months after Moscow began its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The Cold War-era frigates Gromkiy and Sovershenniy sailed into Chinaâ€™s largest city on Wednesday and were greeted by Chinese sailors dressed in white parade uniforms holding placards welcoming their arrival, according to Russiaâ€™s state-run TASS news agency. The ships, whose base isVladivostok, will remain in China until July 11 and are expected to take part in joint drills with the Chinese navy focusing on ship-to-ship communications, manoeuvring in formation and maritime search and rescue, Chinese state media said. â€œTheir arrival is symbolic and very important,â€ Dmitry Lukyantsev, a representative of the Shanghai Committee for Foreign Affairs and Russiaâ€™s consul general in Shanghai, told TASS. â€œThis is the first call by Pacific Fleet ships after the three-year pandemic period and this vividly shows that our states maintain exclusively close cooperation absolutely in all the directions, including the military and political sphere.â€ The same vessels passed through watersnear the self-ruled island of Taiwanat the end of June. This month they sailed past Japanâ€™s Okinawa Islands, where the United States has a major military base. China and Russiaâ€™s military cooperation underlines the strength of the two governmentâ€™s informal alliance, which has endured despite the Ukraine war. Despite having had close ties with Ukraine, China has not explicitly condemned Moscowâ€™s invasion, insisting that it is neutral in the conflict. It has also tried to mediate a peaceful solution to the crisis. The naval visit follows a meeting in Beijing this week between Chinaâ€™s Minister of National Defence Li Shangfu and the head of Russiaâ€™s navy, Admiral Nikolai Yevmenov, the first formal military talks between the two countries since a short-lived mutiny by the Russian mercenary group Wagner on June 24. China has reassured Russia of its continued support since the uprising, and Li told Yevmenov that China hoped for increased exchanges, joint exercises and other forms of cooperation to help defence ties â€œreach a new levelâ€, according to Chinaâ€™s defence ministry. â€œThe Chinese and Russian navies have close exchanges and frequent interactions,â€ the ministry quoted Li as saying. â€œIt is hoped that the two sides will strengthen communication at all levels, regularly organise joint training, joint patrols and joint war games.â€ China has the worldâ€™s largest navy by number of hulls and isvastly superiorto Russiaâ€™s not only in terms of size but also in technical prowess.

Title: Russia TV blasts Wagner boss Prigozhin, says mutiny probe ongoing
Subtitle: Russiaâ€™s state Russia-1 TV channel broadcast a programme in which Wagner boss branded â€˜a traitorâ€™ and says criminal investigation is continuing over mutiny.
Content: Russian state TV has launcheda fierce attack on Yevgeny Prigozhin, the exiled boss of the Wagner mercenary force, saying that an investigation into the private armyâ€™s short-lived mutiny against the Moscow military leadership was still under way. In a programme called 60 Minutes broadcast on Wednesday on Russiaâ€™s state Russia-1 TV channel,the Wagner boss was branded a â€œtraitorâ€and viewers were told that the criminal case against Prigozhin was in full swing. Prigozhinâ€™s Wagner force crossed from Ukraine into Russiaon June 24 and took control of the southern city of Rostov-on-Don as a unit of his fighters sped towards Moscow in an attemptto remove key Russian military officials. Butthe Wagner convoy stopped within 200km (124 miles) of Moscow, and to the surprise of many, Prigozhin said he had called off his operation after agreeing to lead his forces into Belarus after a deal was struck with the countryâ€™s leader Alexander Lukashenko, and in order to not spill Russian blood. Under the deal, all criminal charges against Prigozhin and the Wagner fighters who participated in the mutiny were to be dropped.    The host of the 60 Minutes programme, Russian lawmaker Yevgeny Popov, said Prigozhin was â€œa traitorâ€ and video footage shot during police raids of Prigozhinâ€™s office and residence in Saint Petersburg was shownas proof of the Wagner chiefâ€™s criminality. The footage showed boxes full of high-denomination roubles in Prigozhinâ€™s office and bundles of dollars in his luxurious residence, along with what was called his personal helicopter, an arms cache, a collection of wigs, a fully equipped medical treatment room, and a collection of souvenir sledge hammers, the tool Wagner fighters allegedly used to bludgeon traitors to death in videos that have surfaced online. The footage was presented by a specially invited guest â€“ journalist Eduard Petrov. â€œNobody planned to close this case. The investigation is ongoing,â€ Petrov told the viewers. He also said that Russian investigators had concluded that a video used by Prigozhin as a pretext to start his mutiny against Russian military chiefs â€“ which claimed to show a Russian missile attack on a Wagner camp â€“ was a fake.    Cash worth 600 million roubles ($6.58m) had been found in Prigozhinâ€™s properties, he added. The programme also showed what it said were multiple passports Prigozhin had used and which carried different names. â€œA normal person canâ€™t have so many passports,â€ Petrov said. â€œWhy did this person have such strange powers like the serious leader of some kind of criminal group?â€ he asked. â€œWe need to get to the bottom of who was on whose side [in the mutiny]. We need to punish and prosecute them,â€ he added. â€œI consider that the creation of Yevgeny Prigozhinâ€™s image as a peopleâ€™s hero was all done by media fed by Yevgeny Prigozhin,â€ Petrov also said, referring to media outlets financed by Prigozhin. â€œAfter it [the mutiny] failed, they quickly closed and fled,â€ he said.    Washington, DC-based think tank, the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) said on Wednesday that the general director of Russiaâ€™s TASS news agency had been replaced in what Ukrainian officials said may indicate the Kremlinâ€™s unhappiness with how the Wagner mutiny was reported. The Kremlin also continues to be concerned with security in the Russian capital following the Wagner mutiny as police in Moscow are now reportedly receiving training in the use of battlefield weapons, such as grenade throwing and light machine gun shooting, as well as â€œurban combat tacticsâ€. â€œSuch training indicates that the Kremlin is attempting to improve the ability of security forces in Moscow to defend the regime against potential future threatsâ€ in the aftermath of the Wagner rebellion, the ISW said.

Title: At least 4 killed in Russian missile attack on Lviv city, Ukraine
Subtitle: Lviv Mayor Andriy Sadovyi says Russian missile hit a residential apartment building in the city.
Content: At least four people have been killed and more than 30 injured in a Russian missile attack on a residential apartment block in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, one of the largest attacks on the cityâ€™s civilian infrastructure since the start of Russiaâ€™s invasion last year, officials said. Ukraineâ€™s Interior Minister Ihor Klymenko reported on Thursday that at least four people were killed in the attack which destroyed the third and fourth floors of an apartment building. Rescuers were working to reach those still trapped under rubble, he said. Ukraineâ€™s Interior Ministry later updated the number of injured to 32, including one child. The emergency services said they had managed to rescue seven people from the destroyed building and evacuated 64 others. â€œThis is the biggest attack on Lvivâ€™s civilian infrastructure since the beginningâ€ of Russiaâ€™s invasion, Lvivâ€™s Mayor Andriy Sadovyi said on his Telegram channel, adding that rescuers were working to â€œclear debris and pull out all the deadâ€ from the building. Russia attacked Lviv with 10 Kalibr missiles launched from the Black Sea, Ukraineâ€™s air force said, adding that seven of the 10 missiles were shot down. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy took to social media early on Thursday to condemn the attack, and to offer his condolences to the relatives of those killed in Lviv as well as promise a â€œstrongâ€ response â€œto the enemyâ€. Zelenskyyâ€™s post on Twitter featured a video which showed the extent of damage to a building in Lviv. Lviv. Consequences of the night attack by Russian terrorists. Unfortunately, there are wounded and dead. My condolences to the relatives! There will definitely be a response to the enemy. A strong one.pic.twitter.com/9yl1MT6Eu4 â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)July 6, 2023  Lvivâ€™s regional Governor Maksym Kozytskyi also posted a 13-second video clip showing a wide, curving, four-storey apartment building with parts of the upper floors missing or in rubble. Kozytskyi said earlier that a critical infrastructure facility had been damaged, without providing further details. The reports ofdamage and civilian deaths in Lvivfollowed air raid alerts across Ukraine in the early hours of Thursday morning and reports of cruise missiles entering Ukrainian airspace. Sadovyi, the cityâ€™s mayor, had reported a series of explosions in his city. â€œFriends, we will not talk about the consequences of shelling now,â€ he said on his Telegram channel earlier. â€œAll the city services are doing their work,â€ he said.    Russia has launched waves of drone and missile attacks across Ukraine since its invasion in February 2022, though the Lviv region â€“ which is located hundreds of kilometres from the front lines â€“ had been largely peaceful. In late June,Lviv was hit in an extensive Russian drone assaultthat had hit Kyiv and other cities. Ukraine has recently bolstered its air defence systems with Western-supplied weapons and the number of Russian missiles and drones breaking through has diminished. But the spokesperson for Ukraineâ€™s air forces, Yuriy Ignat, recently said that newly supplied air defence systems were still insufficient to cover the entire country.

Title: UN wants more access to Ukraine nuclear plant amid sabotage warnings
Subtitle: International Atomic Energy Agency seeks access to rooftop of Zaporizhzhia reactors to check for presence of explosives.
Content: The United Nationsâ€™s nuclear watchdog, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), has called for increased access to the Russian-controlled Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in southern Ukraine asMoscow and Kyiv accused each other of planning acts of sabotageat what is Europeâ€™s largest nuclear power facility. The IAEA said on Wednesday that it was seekingadditional access to the Zaporizhzhia plantto â€œconfirm the absence of mines or explosives at the siteâ€. â€œWith military tension and activities increasing in the region where this major nuclear power plant is located, our experts must be able to verify the facts on the ground,â€ IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi said in a statement on Wednesday. Recent inspections at the siteby IAEA staff had not found â€œany visible indications of mines or explosivesâ€, but additional access â€œwould help clarify the current situation at the siteâ€ at a time when â€œunconfirmed allegations and counter allegationsâ€ were circulating, Grossi said. â€œIn particular, access to the rooftops of reactor units 3 and 4 is essential, as well as access to parts of the turbine halls and some parts of the cooling system at the plant,â€ the IAEA chief said in the statement. IAEA experts at ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦'s#Zaporizhzhyanuclear power plant have inspected parts of the facility â€“ including sections of the perimeter of the large cooling pond â€“ so far without observing any visible signs of mines or explosives, but additional access is neededhttps://t.co/UlWeMsaFdUpic.twitter.com/Fpq124tDap â€” IAEA â€“ International Atomic Energy Agency âš›ï¸ (@iaeaorg)July 5, 2023  Ukraine and Russia accused each other Wednesday ofplanning to attack the Zaporizhzhia plant, though neither side provided evidence to support their claims of an imminent threat to the facility, which has been under Russian control since the beginning of March 2022, shortly after Moscowâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. Citing intelligence reports, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy alleged on Tuesday night that Russian forces had placed â€œobjects resembling explosivesâ€ on top of several of the plantâ€™s power units to â€œsimulateâ€ an attack from the outside. â€œTheir detonation should not damage power units but may create a picture of shelling from Ukraine,â€ according to a statement from the general staff of Ukraineâ€™s armed forces.    On Wednesday evening,Zelenskyy once again accused Russia of planning to stage an incidentat the nuclear plant similar to the destruction last month of the Nova Kakhovka dam in Ukraineâ€™s southern Kherson region. â€œNow they have also mined this nuclear power plant. And this is a fact,â€ Zelenskyy said in a video address to university students and staff in Argentina. â€œWhy? Moscow is considering various scenarios, including those similar to the man-made disaster at the Kakhovka hydroelectric power plant â€¦ [that is], for cynical military purposes. But we should not even think about which scenario is the most likely. We should only think about how to prevent any disastrous scenario,â€ he said.    In Russia,authorities claimed Kyiv was also plotting an act of â€œsabotageâ€ at Zaporizhzhia. â€œThe situation is quite tense because the threat of sabotage from the Kyiv regime is really high â€“ sabotage that could have catastrophic consequences,â€ Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters on Wednesday. â€œThe Kyiv regime has repeatedly demonstrated its readiness not to rule anything out,â€ he said. Peskov said Russia was pursuing â€œall measuresâ€ to counter the alleged Ukrainian threat. Renat Karchaa, an adviser to Russiaâ€™s state nuclear company Rosenergoatom, which controls the Zaporizhzhia plant, said there was â€œno basisâ€ for Zelenskyyâ€™s claims of a plot by Moscow to simulate an explosion at the facility. â€œWhy would we need explosives there? This is nonsenseâ€ aimed at â€œmaintaining tensionâ€, Karchaa said on Wednesday, according to the Interfax news agency. Karchaa had alleged in televised remarks on Tuesday that Ukraineâ€™s military was planning to strike the plant overnight with ammunition laced with nuclear waste, but no such attack occurred.    Regular power outages resulting from shelling around the Zaporizhzhia plant made it impossible to operate the site safely, and its six reactors have been shut down since September to minimise the threat of a disaster. Over the last year, the IAEA has repeatedly expressed alarm over the possibility of a radiation catastrophe like the one at Chornobyl after a reactor exploded in 1986. Ukraine has claimed in recent weeks that Moscow might try to cause a deliberate leak at the nuclear plant to derail Kyivâ€™s ongoing counteroffensive in the surrounding Zaporizhia region. Al Jazeeraâ€™s Rob McBride, reporting from Kyiv, said that Ukraine has warned that Russia may be planning â€œa so-called false flagâ€ operation by setting off explosives on the roof of the Zaporizhzhia plant to make it appear as though Ukrainian forces had attacked the site. The Kremlin, on the other hand, has accused Kyiv of planning to strike the nuclear facility with long-range precision weapons. And both sides have compared the situation at Zaporizhzhia with the destruction last month of the Nova Kakhovka dam, for which each blames the other.    â€œMoscow says the destruction of the dam shows what Kyiv is capable of,â€ McBride said. â€œUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says the failure of the international community to punish Russia for destroying the dam has emboldened it now to attack the nuclear plant,â€ he said. Amid the heightened tensions at Zaporizhzhia, people living in the vicinity of the plant have beenwarned by Ukraineâ€™s health ministry to be ready to evacuatein case of a major radiation leak, McBride added. Last week, Ukrainian emergency workers held a drill to prepare for a potential release of radiation from the plant. In case of a nuclear disaster at the plant, approximately 300,000 people would be evacuated from the areas closest to the facility, according to the countryâ€™s emergency services. Ukrainian officials have said the shut-down reactors are protected by thick concrete containment domes, and experts have said that the plantâ€™s design allows it to withstand barrages. Ukraineâ€™s health ministry on Tuesday released guidelines in the event of an emergency and urged residents to pack emergency bags, containing supplies like face masks and food, wrapped in plastic. â€œIf authorities have officially announced a radiation emergency, stay indoors or get out as soon as possible,â€ the ministry said in a statement. â€œStay tuned for further announcements and follow the instructions.â€

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 498
Subtitle: As the war enters its 498th day, these are the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation on Thursday, July 6, 2023.

Title: Biden â€˜anxiously looking forwardâ€™ to Sweden joining NATO
Subtitle: US president reiterates support for Swedenâ€™s NATO application as he meets the countryâ€™s prime minister at White House.
Content: Washington, DC â€“United States President Joe Biden has said he is â€œanxiously looking forwardâ€ to Swedenjoining NATOas he hosted the northern European countryâ€™s Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson. The White House also renewed calls for Turkey to approve Swedenâ€™s bid to join the alliance on Wednesday in advance of a NATO summit in Lithuania next week. â€œI want to reiterate: The United States fully, fully, fully supports Swedenâ€™s membership in NATO. The bottom line is simple â€“ Sweden is going to make our alliance stronger,â€ Biden told reporters before the meeting. White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre also urged Swedenâ€™s admission into NATO â€œas soon as possibleâ€. â€œSweden is a strong, capable defence partner that shares NATOâ€™s values and will strengthen the alliance and contribute to European security,â€ Jean-Pierre said on Wednesday as the two leaders held talks in Washington, DC. Sweden and neighbouring Finland started seekingNATO membershiplast year after Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The US-led alliance has acollective defencepact, meaning an attack on one member is considered an attack on all.    On Wednesday, Kristersson thanked Biden for his â€œstrong supportâ€ for Swedenâ€™s NATO bid. â€œWe do seek common protection, but we also do think that we have things to contribute with to be a security provider for the whole of NATO,â€ he said. NATO members need to unanimously agree to allow new countries into the bloc. Finlandofficially joinedthe alliance in April, but Swedenâ€™s application is still pending. Hungary and Turkey have not ratified Swedenâ€™s accession, but Ankara is seen as the main hurdle. Turkey has accused Sweden of providing a safe haven to members of the Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party (PKK), which it considers a â€œterroristâ€ group. In June of last year, Turkey, Sweden and Finland signed a so-called trilateral memorandum to address Ankaraâ€™s grievances about banned armed groups. Turkey, however, has said that Sweden has not fulfilled all of its commitments in the agreement. Further complicating the issue are the twoQuran-burning protestsby far-right activists during demonstrations in Sweden this year that have angered Turkey. The Swedish government has condemned the desecration of Islamâ€™s holy book but allowed the demonstrations to proceed â€“ with the countryâ€™s courts allowing them as free speech. Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan criticised a Quran-burning protestlast month. â€œTurning a blind eye to such atrocious acts is to be complicit,â€ he said on Twitter. Earlier this week, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan also signalled that Ankara is sticking to its position against Stockholm. â€œWe have made it clear that the determined fight against terrorist organisations and Islamophobia are our red line,â€ he said.    For its part, Washington has rejected the burning of the Quran while calling on Turkey to approve Swedenâ€™s NATO bid. â€œThe burning of religious texts is disrespectful and hurtful, and what might be legal is certainly not necessarily appropriate,â€ US Department of State spokesperson Vedant Patel said in June. Meanwhile, US officials have been calling on Turkey to lift its opposition to Swedenâ€™s NATO bid. Kristerssonâ€™s visit to the White House as come weeks after he met Secretary of StateAntony Blinkenin Sweden. At that time, Blinken said he hoped Swedenâ€™s NATO accession would be finalised before the Lithuania summit, which is set to start on July 11.

Title: â€˜Steady, deliberateâ€™: Ukrainian advance meets Russian resistance
Subtitle: Ukraine says its counterattack has been successful so far given its lack of air power and limited resources.
Content: Just over a month into its counteroffensive, Ukraine continues to make incremental advances and claims to be eroding the ability of invading Russian forces to fight back. Ukrainian forces recaptured 28.4 square kilometres (11 square miles) of territory in the previous week, bringing the counteroffensiveâ€™s total gains to 158sq km (61sq miles), said Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar. The Ukrainian army was â€œadvancing steadily, deliberately working its way through very difficult minefields â€¦ 500 metres a day, 1,000 metres a day, 2,000 metres a day, that kind of thing,â€ Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley told the National Press Club in Washington on June 30. He estimated the counteroffensive could take as many as 10 weeks. Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu said his forces destroyed 2,500 pieces of Ukrainian equipment since the counteroffensive began on June 4. â€œOverall, neither of the enemyâ€™s goals in either direction has been met,â€ said Shoigu during a speech at the defence ministry. â€œThis confirms the prowess of Russian warriors and the obviously inflated hopes for the acclaimed Western armaments.â€ Al Jazeera could not verify either Russian or Ukrainian figures, but Ukrainian officials insisted that territorial gains were not the priority at this stage. Ukraineâ€™s Secretary of the National Security and Defence Council Oleksiy Danilov described â€œthe number one taskâ€ of the armed forces as â€œthe maximum destruction of manpower, equipment, fuel depots, armoured vehicles, command posts, artillery, and air defence forces of the Russian armyâ€. These are softening operations in advance of a major attack, say military experts, and they reflect the tactics Ukraine employed ahead of major advances in September last year. Ukrainian commander of the armed forces Valery Zaluzhny told the Washington Post he was â€œpissed offâ€ by those who complained about the slow pace of the counteroffensive. â€œThis is not a show,â€ Zaluzhny said. â€œItâ€™s not a show the whole world is watching and betting on or anything. Every day, every metre is given by blood.â€ The counteroffensive would be both faster and more effective if it had been accompanied by mastery of the air, he said, referring to Western alliesâ€™ reluctance to provide F-16 planes in a timely manner. He also said his forces were outgunned â€“ sometimes 10 to 1 â€“ because of ammunition shortages. Throughout the 71st week of the war, the main action was concentrated in specific battles. On the eastern front, Russia and Ukraine fought in the areas of Lyman, Bakhmut, Avdiivka and Marinka, all in the Donetsk region. On the southern front, Ukraine claimed to be making progress in at least two areas â€“ south of Orikhiv, in western Zaporizhzhia and on the Zaporizhzhia-Donetsk administrative border.  Bakhmut remained of special importance to both sides. Russia occupied most of the town in early June after fighting for it for a year. Ukraine has since been engaged in an attempt to retake the city by flanking it to the north and south. On June 28, Ukraineâ€™s general staff said its forces seized â€œa strategic initiative and are leading a broad offensive actionâ€ forcing Russians out of captured positions. Maliar reported advances of 1,200 metres towards Klishchiivka and 1,500 metres towards Kurdyumivka, both south of Bakhmut. She said Ukrainian troops still controlled the southwestern outskirts of Bakhmut, but the heaviest fighting was now around the city. â€œThe offensive is proceeding in several directions and our troops are advancing everywhere,â€ she said during a telethon. Russia responded by moving elite troops to Bakhmut. Ukraineâ€™s eastern forces spokesman Colonel Serhiy Cherevatyi said a Russian airborne forces regiment had been transferred to Bakhmut from Lyman. Ukraineâ€™s general staff said it was still â€œkicking outâ€ Russian forces from their positions around Bakhmut on July 3. â€œThe opponent is doing crazy resistance and suffers huge losses. Some tough fighting going on here,â€ it said. Cherevatyi said of the 180,000 Russian troops on the eastern front, the best 50,000 were defending Bakhmut armed with more than 300 tanks, 330 artillery pieces, and 140 multiple-launch rocket systems. â€œFor them, the city is not only of military importance, but also of information and propaganda,â€ he said. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said it repelled all Ukrainian attacks on the eastern front near Bakhmut and Lyman. â€œRussian sources are increasingly claiming that Ukrainian forces are currently conducting assaults in southern Ukraine with smaller infantry groups and fewer armoured vehicles than during earlier counteroffensive operations,â€ wrote the Washington-based Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a think-tank. One source cited described Ukrainian tactics: â€œNow the enemy is acting in relays, using small assault groups in waves. As soon as one unit runs out of steam, a new unit takes its place.â€ ISW said the reporting suggests Ukrainian forces are not currently attempting large-scale operations that would result in rapid territorial advances. â€œUkrainian officials have routinely indicated that Ukrainian forces have yet to commit a substantial portion of their forces to counteroffensive operations, and have yet to launch the main phase of the counteroffensive,â€ it said. Ukraine started its counteroffensive with mechanised units, but appeared to have returned to guerrilla tactics it employed early in the war after sustaining highly publicised losses of tanks and armoured fighting vehicles in June. Russian drones were able to ferret out armoured columns and guide artillery strikes against them. However, those guerrilla tactics were not always successful. Russian occupation governor of Kherson Vladimir Saldo said a few dozen Ukrainian troops had been cleared from the eastern side of the Antonivsky Bridge in a special forces operation. He said there were no further Ukraine troops the left bank of the Dnipro river. â€œThe destruction of the [Ukrainian] units that landed â€¦ in the Antonovsky bridge area has been completed,â€ said the Russian defence ministry on July 3. Ukraine indirectly confirmed increased Russian activity on the Dnipro. Russian forces were stepping up artillery attacks and air strikes against the right bank of the Dnipro from the Kinburn Spit, said Natalia Humeniuk, spokesperson for Ukraineâ€™s southern forces. The aim was to distract Ukraineâ€™s forces from efforts to cross the river to the left bank. Humeniuk said Russian forces returned to positions they retreated from after the Nova Kakhovka Dam breach flooded them, and were launching reconnaissance patrols across the river to spy on Ukrainian activities. In just one day, she said, Ukrainian forces had sunk two boats with 66 Russian troops in the Mykolaiv area.  Ukraine has warned for weeks that Russia is preparing to create a nuclear contamination incident at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, where it maintains about 5,000 troops. â€œAccording to operational information, outside objects resembling explosive devices were placed on the outer roofs of the third and fourth power units of the [power plant],â€ the general staff said. The goal of this sabotage was not necessarily to damage the reactors, but to make it look as if Ukraine had shelled the plant, it said. â€œIt is important that all Ukrainians are morally prepared for the detonation of the [facility], as well as trained in how to act in any situation. We simply have no other way out,â€ said Maliar. Russia, meanwhile, accused Ukraine of planning to attack the nuclear plant. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov raised the specter of a potentially â€œcatastrophicâ€ provocation by the Ukrainian army at the facility, which is Europeâ€™s largest. â€œThe situation is quite tense. There is a great threat of sabotage by the Kyiv regime, which can be catastrophic in its consequences,â€ Peskov said.

Title: Russian reporter returns to Moscow after Chechnya attack
Subtitle: Russian journalist and her lawyer were severely beaten and threatened with weapons in Chechnya.
Content: An award-winning Russian investigative journalist was flown back to Moscow after being attacked in Chechnya and hospitalised with injuries. Media advocates and rights groups voiced concern afterYelena Milashinasaid she was beaten and held at gunpoint with her lawyer during a work trip to the Chechen capital Grozny in southern Russia. â€œMilashina is in Moscow in hospital. Her condition is, frankly, difficult. She was really severely beaten, beaten with a stick,â€ said Dmitry Muratov, editor of her paper, Novaya Gazeta. Alexey Venediktov, former editor-in-chief of the disbanded Ekho Moskvy radio station, posted photos on Telegram showing Milashina and her lawyer, Alexander Nemov, in a small plane together flying back to Moscow. Muratov said Milashinaâ€™s fingers had been broken after the attackers demanded access to her phone. The journalist also had her head shaved and green dye poured on her. It remains unclear who the assailants were. Milashina, 45, has won widespread acclaim for her investigative reporting, which included exposing the alleged torture and killings of gay people in Chechnya and other abuses by feared Chechen paramilitary forces. In a video interview, the journalist said 10 to 15 attackers beat her with plastic pipes. Milashina said authorities routinely used such pipes to strike detainees in Chechnya, and she had written about the practice before. She described how the assailants stopped the pair while driving.Â â€œThey threw the driver out of the car, got in, bent our heads down, tied my hands, forced me down to my knees and put a gun to my head,â€ Milashina said. In a different interview with the Russian rights group Team Against Torture, she said the attack was linked to her work with Nemov, adding the assailants told the lawyer: â€œYou are defending too many people here. There is no need to defend anyone here.â€ On Wednesday, Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s spokesman said it would take time for a full investigation into the attack to be conducted. â€œLetâ€™s just wait. The reactions have all been voiced and now all actions are being taken,â€ Dmitry Peskov told reporters. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov said those responsible for Tuesdayâ€™s violence should be identified. For years, Milashina has exposed human rights violations in Chechnya and has faced threats, intimidation, and attacks. In 2020, a dozen people beat her and another lawyer in a hotel lobby. Since 2000, Novaya Gazeta has seen six of its journalists and contributors killed, including investigative reporterAnna Politkovskayawho was shot dead in Moscow.

Title: Ukraine says â€˜particularly fruitfulâ€™ few days in counteroffensive
Subtitle: Officials acknowledge stiff resistance from Russian forces as they make incremental advances in east and south.
Content: A Ukrainian counteroffensive against Russian forces has been â€œparticularly fruitfulâ€ in recent days, according to a senior security official. The comments by Oleksiy Danilov, who heads Ukraineâ€™s National Security and Defense Council, were Kyivâ€™s latest positive assessment of the month-old counterattack, although Moscow has not acknowledged advances by Ukraine. Ukraineâ€™s Deputy Defence MinisterHanna Maliaralso reported gains around the ruined eastern city of Bakhmut amid fierce Russian resistance. Russian forces captured the city in May after 10 months of fighting. â€œAt this stage of active hostilities, Ukraineâ€™s Defense Forces are fulfilling the number one task â€“ the maximum destruction of manpower, equipment, fuel depots, military vehicles, command posts, artillery and air defense forces of the Russian army,â€ Danilov wrote on Twitter. â€œThe last few days have been particularly fruitful,â€ he said, without providing any details from the battlefield. The Ukrainians are in the early stages of their campaign to take back land occupied by the Russians since they launched theirfull-scale invasion in February 2022, and are up against minefields, anti-tank ditches and other obstacles, as well as layered defensive lines reportedly up to 20 kilometres (12 miles) deep in some places. In its latest assessment, the Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a Washington, DC-based think tank, said Danilovâ€™s comments appeared to underline an â€œongoing campaign to attrit Russian manpower and assets over attempting to conduct massive sweeping mechanized maneuvers to regain large swaths of territory rapidlyâ€. Earlier, Maliar said on July 3 Ukraine had liberated about 37.4sq km (14.4sq miles) of territory in eastern and southern Ukraine over the previous week. â€œThe current pace of Ukrainian operations is not indicative of a stalemate or evidence that Ukraine cannot retake large areas,â€ ISW said. Gains were reported in the south where Valeriy Shershen, spokesperson for the Tavria, or southern military command, said Ukrainian troops had advanced by up to 2km (1.2 miles) in the Berdyansk direction against fierce Russian resistance.    In the areas outside Bakhmut, Maliar said, troops had pushed forward in the south but there was no progress in the cityâ€™s north where fighting was intense. â€œâ€¦ Our forces are encountering serious resistance,â€ she told national television. â€œThe enemy is pouring in all its forces to stop in the south and in the east.â€ Russian forces, she said, were also making advances further north, near Lyman and in Svatove, where Russian troops have recently been particularly active. In Makiivka, a town in the Russian-controlled part of the eastern Donetsk region, Ukraineâ€™s military had destroyed a formation of Russian forces. Russia-installed officials said one civilian died and 36 others were injured in the attack. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry spokesperson Lieutenant General Igor Konashenkov, meanwhile, said Russian troops repelled 10 Ukrainian attacks in the direction of Donetsk in the previous 24 hours, according to state news agency TASS. He said dozens of Ukrainian soldiers were injured or killed and key equipment including HIMARS systems destroyed. Russia also claimed to have repelled attacks near Lyman and disrupted Ukrainian operations in the Zaporizhia region, where Ukraine says its forces have captured a cluster of villages. Each side has said the other is suffering heavy losses, and it is not possible to verify the front-line accounts.

Title: At least 43 hurt after Russian attack on small Ukrainian town
Subtitle: Twelve children, including two babies, among the injured as residents of Pervomaiskyi in northeast express shock at events.
Content: Ukrainian officials said at least 43 people, including 12 children, were injured after a Russian attack on the small town of Pervomaiskyi in the northeastern Kharkiv region. Television footage showed black smoke billowing from a block of tall flats with cars in flames nearby, while Andriy Yermak, the head of Kyivâ€™s presidential office, shared images from the town of burned and destroyed cars. Regional governor Oleh Syniehubov said the attack happened at about 1.35pm Kyiv time (10:35 GMT) on Tuesday. Pervomaiskyi is home to about 28,000 people and is relatively far from the front lines. â€œI only remember that when the explosion sounded, we were thrown up into the air,â€ a local, who gave her name only as Alla, said on the street as she hugged her granddaughter. â€œThen we continued walking, we saw blown out windows everywhere, I saw cars on fire. I just canâ€™t get a grip of myself, my legs are still shaking.â€ Syniehubov said the youngest of the injured was a three-month-old baby. The childâ€™s condition was not immediately clear. Another baby was also hurt. Both were among dozens taken to hospital. Some said the attack was linked to a military funeral that was taking place in the town. Major Maksym Zhorin, a former commander of a fighting unit known as theAzov battalionthat is now part of the Ukrainian army, said about 100 people had gathered for the funeral of Oleh Fadeenko, a soldier with the call-sign Baby who he said had been killed in fighting near Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine. â€œThey targeted the site where the ceremony was taking place,â€ Zhorin said on the Telegram messaging app. Russia did not immediately comment on the attack. Moscow has denied deliberately targeting civilians but its missile and drone attacks have repeatedly struck cities across Ukraine since it began its full-scale invasion in February last year. Last month, a Russian missile hit a crowded pizza restaurant in the eastern city of Kramatorsk, killing 12 people.Victoria Amalina, a prominent writer and war crimes researcher who was badly injured in the attack, died from her injuries on July 1.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 497
Subtitle: As the war enters its 497th day, these are the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation on Wednesday, July 5, 2023.

Title: NATO extends Stoltenbergâ€™s mandate in move welcomed by Ukraine
Subtitle: The NATO chief has been leading the worldâ€™s largest military alliance since 2014.
Content: NATO has decided to extend Secretar-General Jens Stoltenbergâ€™s contract by another year, seeking to stick with an experienced leader to lead the military alliance, amid Russiaâ€™s raging war in Ukraine. The NATO chief, a former prime minister of Norway, has led the alliance since 2014. His current term in office was due to expire on October 1. He has already had his tenure extended three previous times. The news of his latest extension comes a week before the allianceâ€™s annual summit, which is due to take place in Vilnius, Lithuania, this year. Stoltenberg welcomed the NATO membersâ€™ decision in a tweet, writing, â€œThe transatlantic bond between Europe & North America has ensured our freedom & security for nearly 75 years, and in a more dangerous world, our Alliance is more important than ever.â€ Honoured by#NATOAllies' decision to extend my term as Secretary General until 1 October 2024. The transatlantic bond between Europe & North America has ensured our freedom & security for nearly 75 years, and in a more dangerous world, our Alliance is more important than ever. â€” Jens Stoltenberg (@jensstoltenberg)July 4, 2023  The 64-year-old is viewed by his supporters as a reliable figure who has played a key role in building consensus across the alliance. US President Joe Biden said in a statement that Stoltenbergâ€™s â€œsteady leadership, experience and judgementâ€ has helped the alliance wade through some of the most â€œsignificant challenges in European security since World War IIâ€. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hailed the news, saying â€œNATO has evolved to meet new threats, continued to protect our people and has been steadfast in support of Ukraine.â€ Under@jensstoltenbergâ€™s leadership, NATO has evolved to meet new threats, continued to protect our people and has been steadfast in support of Ukraine. Looking forward to continuing that work together, Jens.https://t.co/xXrdpH9HFc â€” Rishi Sunak (@RishiSunak)July 4, 2023  Meanwhile, Ukraine, which hopes to join the alliance, said the Norwegianâ€™s support has been important. â€œExcellent news â€¦ Tough times demand strong leadership. Jens Stoltenberg has demonstrated just that. I look forward to furthering our cooperation,â€ Ukraineâ€™s Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba said on Twitter. Excellent news on the extension of@JensStoltenberg's mandate as NATO Secretary General. Tough times demand strong leadership. Jens Stoltenberg has demonstrated just that. I look forward to furthering our cooperation. â€” Dmytro Kuleba (@DmytroKuleba)July 4, 2023   Stoltenberg will continue his tenure until October 1 next year. His next tasks include overseeing the transformation of NATO forces to refocus on defending against any possible Russian attack, and concentrating on missions beyond its borders, such as in Afghanistan, the Balkans and the South China Sea.

Title: Putin reassures Asian nations of stability after Wagner mutiny
Subtitle: During a Shanghai Cooperation Organisation meeting, the president casts Russian society as united after the rebellion.
Content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has assured leaders in Asia that his country is stable and united despite a brief mutiny instigated by the Wagner Group, which sent shock waves across the world. â€œThe Russian people are consolidated as never before,â€ Putin told a virtual meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) on Tuesday. The Eurasian group includes China and India and focuses on international security, defence, and economic and political policy. â€œRussian political circles and the whole of society clearly demonstrated their unity and elevated sense of responsibility for the fate of the fatherland when they responded as a united front against an attempted armed mutiny,â€ Putin added. Putin thanked members of the SCO, who he said had backed his efforts â€œto protect the constitutional order, the lives and security of citizensâ€. He told them that Russia would stand up against Western pressure, sanctions and â€œprovocationsâ€ imposed over what Moscow calls its â€œspecial military operationâ€ in Ukraine. The president added that he seeks to boost economic ties with members of the SCO. Russia views countries such as China, India and Iran â€“ the newest member of the SCO â€“ as key partners in confronting the United States and resisting what it portrays as Washingtonâ€™s attempts to dictate the world order. Last month,Wagner Group boss Yevgeny Prigozhin seizedthe city of Rostov-on-Don and marched towards Moscow, demanding the removal of Russian Defence Minister Sergey Shoigu. Prigozhinâ€™s uprising ended hours after it began within 200km (124 miles) of Moscow. He struck a deal with the Kremlin to end the operation with a pact brokered by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko. Prigozhin, now in exile in Belarus, later released an audio statement saying the march was not meant to overthrow the government. The future of Wagnerâ€™s assets and subsidiaries remains uncertain, but some of the groupâ€™s businesses have shut down. After the short-lived mutiny, Western leaders said the revolt had displayed vulnerabilities in Russiaâ€™s security and defence policies. Iran and Chinadownplayedthe unexpected mutiny and called it an â€œinternal affairâ€.

Title: Health fears for jailed, emaciated ex-Georgia leader Saakashvili
Subtitle: Supporters and family fear that former Georgian president Mikheil Saakashvili has been poisoned in prison after losing about 60kgs in weight.
Content: Georgiaâ€™s imprisoned former presidentMikheil Saakashviliappeared frail and severely emaciated via video link at a court hearing considering an abuse-of-power case against him. Saakashvili and his supporters claim he has been poisoned while imprisoned and that henow weighs about 60kg(132 lbs), half of what he weighed when he was arrested in October 2021. From a private clinic where he was being held, he told the court on Monday that despite his poor health, he was â€œspiritually fit and determined to serve the countryâ€, according to local news site Agenda. Saakashvili, 55, lifted his shirt to show his ribs protruding from his chest, a hollow abdomen and skin clinging tightly to his bones. â€œA totally innocent man is being kept in custody,â€ he said in coverage carried live on several independent TV channels. â€œI did not commit any crime,â€ he said. The former president is being held at a civilian hospital, where he was transferred last year after staging a 50-day hunger strike to protest his detention. â€œPutting me in jail will not break me. I am going to be actively involved in Georgian politics,â€ he said.    Saakashvili, who served as Georgiaâ€™s president from 2004-13 and led the so-called Rose Revolution protests that drove the previous president out of office, left for Ukraine after the end of his second term. He holds Ukrainian citizenship and was the governor of the Odesa region in 2015-16. After leaving Georgia, Saakashvili was convicted in absentia for abuse of power and sentenced to six years in prison. He wasarrested in October 2021after returning to Georgia to try to bolster opposition forces before nationwide municipal elections. The former president is now on trial on charges of â€œabuse of officeâ€ connected to the violent dispersal of an opposition rally in 2007. Doctors have said Saakashvili risks dying from conditions he developed while in custody, though Georgian authorities say he is being given adequate medical care. His brother, David Saakashvili, said the ex-president was continuing to lose weight, was at risk of dying and might have been poisoned. The family says he is not receiving proper medical treatment.    The European Union and United States have urged Georgia to ensure Saakashvili is provided medical treatment and that his rights are protected. Amnesty International has branded his treatment as â€œapparent political revengeâ€. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Monday called forGeorgia to send Saakashvili to Ukrainefor medical treatment and said the Georgian ambassador would be called to the foreign ministry and encouraged to return to Georgia within two days for consultations with his government. In his daily video message on Monday evening, Zelenskyy accused Moscow of being behind the ex-leader poor treatment in prison andÂ  called on the international community not to ignore Saakashvili but to â€œsave this manâ€. â€œUkraine has repeatedly called on the Georgian authorities to stop this demonstrative execution. Both we and our partners have offered various options to save Mykhailo,â€ he said. Right now, Russia is killing Ukrainian citizen Mykhailo Saakashvili at the hands of the Georgian authorities. We have repeatedly called on the official Tbilisi to stop this abuse and agree on Saakashvili's return to Ukraine. Our partners, in coordination with Ukraine, have alsoâ€¦pic.twitter.com/Gzvl4zJPR1 â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)July 3, 2023  â€œNo government in Europe has the right to execute people â€“ life is a basic European value,â€ he added. Zelenskyy has repeatedly claimed that Saakashvili is being slowly killed in Georgian custody, describing it as a de facto public execution. Georgia, which had received significant US support under Saakashvili, lost a brief war against Russia in 2008, including control of its breakaway territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. To Zelenskyyâ€™s annoyance, Georgia does not support theWestâ€™s sanctions against Moscowover its invasion of Ukraine.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 496
Subtitle: As the war enters its 496th day, these are the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation on Tuesday, July 4, 2023

Title: US ambassador to Russia visits jailed WSJ reporter Gershkovich
Subtitle: Evan Gershkovich is in â€˜good health and remains strongâ€™, US State Department says, reiterating call for his release.
Content: The United States ambassador to Russia has visited jailed Wall Street Journal journalist Evan Gershkovich, the US State Department confirmed, in only the second such meeting sinceGershkovich was detainedin March on espionage charges. Ambassador Lynne Tracy met with Gershkovich at Lefortovo Prison in the Russian capital, Moscow, a State Department spokesperson said on Monday. Tracylast visitedthe detained journalist on April 17. â€œAmbassador Tracy reports that Mr Gershkovich is in good health and remains strong, despite his circumstances,â€ the spokesperson said. â€œWe expect Russian authorities to provide continued consular access.â€ Russia arrested Gershkovich in late March in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg, accusing him of trying to obtain classified information about a Russian arms factory.Gershkovichâ€™s legal team andhis supportershave dismissed the charges as baseless.    â€œEvan is a member of the free press who right up until he was arrested was engaged in newsgathering,â€ The Wall Street Journal previously said. â€œAny suggestions otherwise are false.â€ In April, the US State Department formally designated Gershkovich as â€œwrongfully detainedâ€ and called on Russia to release him immediately. But on June 22, aRussian judge rejectedan application for Gershkovich, 31, to be released from prison while awaiting trial. After that decision, Tracy â€“ the US ambassador â€“ accused Moscow of conducting â€œhostage diplomacyâ€. US officials have been calling on Russia to grant consular access to Gershkovich since his arrest, accusing the Russian authorities of violating international law by not allowing American diplomats to contact him. â€œThis week marks 100 days that press freedom supporters & colleagues have pushed for the release of [Wall Street Journal] reporter Evan Gershkovich, unjustly imprisoned in Russia,â€ the Committee to Protect Journalists advocacy group tweeted on Monday. â€œLetâ€™s stand together on this chilling milestone and demand Evanâ€™s immediate release.â€ ğŸš¨This week marks 100 days that press freedom supporters & colleagues have pushed for the release of@WSJreporter Evan Gershkovich, unjustly imprisoned in Russia. Let's stand together on this chilling milestone and demand Evan's immediate release.#IStandWithEvan#FreeThePresspic.twitter.com/Lv9fqKtdUP â€” Committee to Protect Journalists (@pressfreedom)July 3, 2023  Gershkovichâ€™s detention is unfolding as tensions between Washington and Moscow continue to mount amidRussiaâ€™s war in Ukraine. Advocates say the journalistâ€™s arrest is part of Russiaâ€™s broader crackdown on media outlets as it pushes forward with the invasion of its neighbour. But Russian authorities say Gershkovich was â€œcaught red-handed and violated the laws of the Russian Federationâ€. They have not presented evidence to back up their allegations. On Monday, the US State Department again called for theÂ immediate release of Gershkovich andPaul Whelan, a former US Marine serving a 16-year sentence in a Russian penal colony on espionage charges. The department also described Whelan, who wasdetained in Moscowin 2018, as â€œwrongfully detainedâ€.

Title: Russia claims to have foiled an assassination attempt in Crimea
Subtitle: Moscow says Ukraine ordered the alleged attack on Sergey Aksyonov, the Russian-installed head of the annexed peninsula.
Content: Russia has claimed to have thwarted a Ukrainian assassination attempt on Sergey Aksyonov, the Russian-installed head of Crimea. The Federal Security Service (FSB) said in a statement on Monday that it had arrested a Russian national recruited as an assassin by Ukraineâ€™s SBU intelligence agency, alleging the suspect had undergone explosives, reconnaissance and sabotage training in Ukraine. There was no immediate comment from Ukraine on the Russian allegation. It came amid Russian media reports that security has been stepped up in Crimea, the Black Sea peninsula which Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014, and that additional security checks are being made on people wanting to cross a bridge from Russiaâ€™s southern Krasnodar region into Crimea. The FSB statement added that the plan had been to blow up Aksyonovâ€™s car, but the agent was detained as he tried to retrieve an explosive device from a hiding place. The agency did not name the man it detained, but said he was in his mid-30s and had entered Crimea in June. He was being investigated on suspicion of â€œattempting to commit a terrorist actâ€ and â€œillegally possessing explosivesâ€. Aksyonov thanked the FSB for stopping what he called an attempt on the lives of the â€œRepublic of Crimeaâ€™s leadershipâ€ and said he was sure the individuals who ordered the foiled attack would be found and punished. Ukraine has pledged to retake full control of Crimea and areas in the east and south of the country that Russia claims to have annexed since launching its invasion in February 2022. Kyiv has repeatedly said it will not negotiate any peace agreement until every Russian soldier has been removed from Ukrainian territory.    On Monday, Ukraine said its forces had reclaimed 37.4 square kilometres (14.4 square miles) of territory along the eastern and southern fronts in its counteroffensive against Russian troops. Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar said forces were advancing in the Bakhmut direction, adding that Russian troops were attacking in the Lyman, Avdiivka and Mariinka directions in the Donetsk region. â€œHeavy fighting is going on there now,â€ Maliar said on Telegram. Maliar added that â€œas a result of improving the operational [tactical] position and aligning the front lineâ€, 9sq km (3.5sq miles) over the past week along the eastern front were reclaimed. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy also said Ukraineâ€™s military was progressing despitedifficulties. â€œLast week was difficult on the front line. But we are making progress,â€ he wrote on Telegram. â€œWe are moving forward, step by step! I thank everyone who is defending Ukraine, everyone who is leading this war to Ukraineâ€™s victory!â€

Title: Victoria Amelina, Ukrainian novelist, killed in Russian attack
Subtitle: A war crimes researcher and novelist, the 37-year-old died from wounds sustained in Tuesdayâ€™s missile attack in Kramatorsk.
Content: A Ukrainian war crimes researcher and novelist has died from injuries sustained in last Tuesdayâ€™s missile attack in the city of Kramatorsk, located in the Donetsk region of Ukraine. Victoria Amelina, 37, had been dining at the popular Ria Pizza restaurant with a delegation of Colombian writers and journalists when it was struck by a Russian missile that killed 12 people, including four children, and wounding dozens. She was rushed to Mechnikov Hospital in the Ukrainian city of Dnipro, located in the centre of the country, but succumbed to her injuries on Saturday, making her the13th fatality in the attack. Amelina is also the latest cultural figure killed in the full-fledged war launched on Ukraine launched by Russia in February 2022. PEN, a nonprofit organisation that aims to defend and celebrate free expression through literature, announced her death via a statement on Facebook. â€œIt is with great pain that we inform you that the heart of the writer Victoria Amelina stopped beating on 1 July,â€ the statement read. â€œIn the last days of Victoriaâ€™s life, her family and friends were by her side.â€ Writer Victoria Amelina was injured in Russian attack on Kramatorsk this week. Her poem reflects how everyone here feels. AlertAn air raid alert goes off across my landIt's as if they're here again to execute usBut shoot just oneIt's usually someone randomToday it isn'tâ€¦pic.twitter.com/44bTXnTG1W â€” Maria Avdeeva (@maria_avdv)July 2, 2023  Born in the western city of Lviv, Amelina began her career in IT before becoming a full-time writer and poet in 2015. She would quickly become one of the countryâ€™s most celebrated young writers. Her second novel Domâ€™s Dream Kingdom, or Dim dlya Doma, published in 2017, was shortlisted for several national and international awards, including the European Union Prize for Literature. Her first non-fiction book in English, War and Justice Diary: Looking at Women Looking at War, is due to be published. When Russia launched the full-scale invasion of Ukraine last year, Amelina began documenting war crimes. She also worked with children near the front line. Her work had brought her all over eastern, southern and northern parts of Ukraine during the war, in particular in the village of Kapytolivka near Izyum in the northeast of the country. Last year she unearthed the diary of Volodymyr Vakulenko, an editor, journalist and translator who had authored 13 books and who was abducted and killed by Russian troops in the city of Izyum soon after the invasion. Vakulenko and Amelina are not the only cultural figures to have died since the start of Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion. In the Kyiv suburb, Bucha, Oleksandr Kysliuk, a well-known translator from ancient Greek and Latin, was reportedly shot dead in his house during Russiaâ€™s attempt to take over the capital. In Kherson, located in southern Ukraine, Yuri Kerpatenko, the chief director of the Mykola Kulish Kherson Musical and Drama Theatre, was executed whilst the city was under occupation after he refused to take part in a concert. Former ballet dancer and dance teacher Oleksandr Shapoval was killed by heavy shelling during a battle in September 2022 near Maiorske in the Donetsk region. Pasha Lee, an actor and TV presenter, was killed in the Kyiv suburb of Irpin when the area came under heavy artillery bombardment.

Title: Arms dealer swapped for Griner to contest Russian local election
Subtitle: Viktor Bout will campaign for a seat in the Ulyanovsk regionâ€™s legislative assembly with the ultra-nationalist Liberal Democratic Party of Russia (LDPR).
Content: A Russian arms dealer freed in a prisoner swap for United States basketball starBrittney Grinerhas been chosen as the candidate of a far-right party for a seat in a Russian regional legislature, according to state news agency RIA. Viktor Bout, once dubbed â€œThe merchant of deathâ€, served 10 years of a 25-year sentence in US prisons on arms dealing charges until his release last December under theexchange with Griner, an Olympic gold medallist. RIA cited an official in the ultra-nationalist Liberal Democratic Party of Russiaâ€™s (LDPR) local organisation as saying that Bout had been nominated as a candidate for the legislative assembly of the Ulyanovsk region in central Russia. Bout was arrested by US agents during a sting in Thailand in 2008. The US Department of Justice described him as one of the worldâ€™s most prolific arms dealers, charges Bout has always denied. Griner was sentenced in 2022 in Russia to nine years in a penal colony for possessing vape cartridges containing cannabis oil â€“ which is banned in Russia â€“ after a judicial process Washington labelled as a sham. Griner has since resumed her sports career. Bout publicly joined the LDPR following his return to Russia. Despite its name, the LDPR holds far-right, ultra-nationalist views and strongly supports President Vladimir Putinâ€™sinvasion of Ukraine. The LDPR has previously provided a home to Andrei Lugovoi, who iswanted in the United Kingdomfor the 2006 murder of ex-KGB officer and Putin critic Alexander Litvinenko. Lugovoi has served as an LDPR member of Russiaâ€™s national parliament since 2007. Litvinenko died after drinking tea poisoned with polonium-210, a radioactive isotope.

Title: â€˜Everywhere, things are hotâ€™: Ukraine battles Russian onslaught
Subtitle: Mixed picture for Kyivâ€™s forces as Russia fights to hold onto Ukrainian territory captured in its 16-months-old invasion.
Content: Kyivâ€™s forces are fighting a fierce onslaught by Russian troops in parts of northeastern Ukraine, even as they make advances in the area around Bakhmut and in the south, Ukraineâ€™s deputy defence minister has said, describing the situation as â€œcomplicatedâ€. Hanna Maliar said that Russian troops were advancing near Avdiivka, Marinka, Lyman and Svatove. â€œFierce fighting is going on everywhere,â€ Maliar wrote on social media on Sunday, adding: â€œThe situation is quite complicatedâ€. Russian accounts of the front-line fighting reported success in containing Ukrainian troops in the northeast and said its forces had pushed back Ukrainian attacks near villages ringing Bakhmut and in areas further south, particularly the strategic hilltop town of Vuhlear. Ukraineâ€™s military has been engaged in a counteroffensive to recapture areas of the east and south seized by Russia since it began itsfull-scale invasion in February 2022. Initial Ukrainian advances have focused ontaking back clusters of villagesin the south, but have so far failed to produce a major breakthrough. Maliar said Ukrainian troops were advancing with â€œpartial successâ€ on the southern flank of Bakhmut in the east and near Berdyansk and Melitopol in the south. In the south, she said Ukrainian forces faced â€œintense enemy resistance, remote mining, deploying of reservesâ€ and were only advancing â€œgraduallyâ€. â€œEverywhere, things are hot,â€ she said. General Oleksander Tarnavskiy, responsible for the southern front, said Ukrainian forces were â€œsystematically destroying the enemyâ€ and reported the deaths of several hundred Russian forces over the last 24 hours. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraineâ€™s commander-in-chief, General Valery Zaluzhniy, have reported steady, if slow, advances in the campaign. The president has acknowledged the relatively limited progress but said the fight is â€œnot a Hollywood movieâ€ with instant success. Ukraine has also had to endure persistent Russian air attacks on cities, although the Kremlin denies attacking civilian targets. On Sunday, Ukrainian writer Victoria Amelina died from injuries sustained when aRussian missile hit a busy pizza restaurantin the eastern city of Kramatorsk last week. The attack killed 12 people, some of them children, and injured dozens. Amelinaâ€™s death raises the death toll to 13. â€œWith our greatest pain, we inform you that Ukrainian writer Victoria Amelina passed away on July 1st in Mechnikov Hospital in Dnipro,â€ PEN Ukraine said in a statement on its Facebook page. The 37-year-old, who was also a war crimes investigator, had been in the city with a delegation of Colombian journalists and writers, PEN said. Her novel â€œDomâ€™s Dream Kingdomâ€ was published in 2017 and shortlisted for the UNESCO City of Literature Prize and the European Union Prize for Literature, according to PEN. Her poems, prose and essays have been translated into English, German, Polish and other languages. Since 2022, she had been working to document Russian war crimes since the invasion and advocate for accountability, PEN said.
