Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 494
Subtitle: As the war enters its 494th day, these are the main developments.
Content: This is the situation as it stands onÂ Sunday, July 2.

Title: Russia attacks Ukraineâ€™s Kyiv as fierce battles rage in Donetsk
Subtitle: Russia launches first overnight drone attack on Kyiv in 12 days as Ukrainian officials report more civilian casualties in the front-line Donetsk region.
Content: Russia has launched an overnight drone attack on Kyiv after a 12-day break, according to a senior Ukrainian official, with air defence systems preliminarily destroying all targets on their approach. â€œAnother enemy attack on Kyiv,â€ Serhiy Popko, a colonel general who heads Kyivâ€™s military administration, said in a post on the Telegram channel early on Sunday. â€œAt this moment, there is no information about possible casualties or damage,â€ he said. The Reuters news agency reported blasts resembling the sound of air defence systems hitting targets in Kyiv. The Ukrainian capital and a number of central and eastern Ukrainian regions were under air raid alerts for about an hour after 2am local time (23:00 GMT). There was no immediate information about the scale of the attack. It came a day after Ukrainian officials reported more civilian casualties from Russian shelling in the countryâ€™s east and south.    In the eastern front-line Donetsk region, at least three civilians were killed and 17 wounded on Friday and overnight on Saturday, according to Governor Pavlo Kyrylenko. The Ukrainian General Staff reported that fierce clashes continued in three areas in Donetsk where it said Russia has massed troops and attempted to advance. It named the outskirts of three cities â€“ Bakhmut, Lyman and Marinka â€“ as front-line hot spots. In Ukraineâ€™s southern Kherson region, five people including a child were wounded on Friday as well as in overnight attacks, according to Governor Oleksandr Prokudin. He said that Russian forces launched 82 artillery, drone, mortar shell and rocket attacks on the province, which is cut in two by a stretch of the 1,500km (930 mile) front line and still reeling from flooding unleashed by the collapse earlier this month of a major Dnipro River dam. Meanwhile, in Ukraineâ€™s northwest, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy held a meeting of the countryâ€™s top military command and atomic energy officials at the Rivne nuclear power plant to discuss â€œthe security of our northern regions and our measures to strengthen themâ€. Zelenkyyâ€™s trip to Rivne was a rare journey for the Ukrainian leader to an area relatively far from the fighting. But it is near the border with Belarus, whereRussiaâ€™s Wagner mercenarieshave a deal to go after last weekâ€™s aborted uprising. Their leader Yevgeny Prigozhin was offered the option of resettling in Belarus, on Ukraineâ€™s northern border. Separately, earlier on Saturday, Zelenskyy warned thata â€œserious threatâ€remained at the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraineâ€™s south and said Russia was â€œtechnically readyâ€ to provoke a localised explosion at the facility. He cited Ukrainian intelligence as the source of his information. Energoatom, Ukraineâ€™s nuclear power authority, said on Friday it had conducted two days of exercises simulating the effects of an attack on the Zaporizhzhia plant. Russiaâ€™s ambassador to the United Nations, Vassily Nebenzia, issued a statement describing the Ukrainian allegations as â€œsimply preposterousâ€. The facility, located near the city of Enerhodar in southern Ukraine, has been occupied by Russia since shortly after Moscowâ€™s full-scale invasion in February 2022.

Title: Ukraine commander irked by lack of arms promised for offensive
Subtitle: Commander-in-chief of Ukraineâ€™s armed forces Valery Zaluzhny says lack of fighter jets, artillery hampering offensive.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s counteroffensive planshave been slowed by a lack of adequate firepower, from modern fighter jets to ammunition for artillery guns, the countryâ€™s military commander-in-chief Valery Zaluzhny has said. Complaining about the slow deliveries of weapons promised by the West, Zaluzhny said in an interview with the Washington Post published on Friday that Kyivâ€™s Western supporters would not themselves launch an offensive without air superiority, but Ukraine is still awaiting F-16 fighters promised by its allies. â€œI do not need 120 planes. Iâ€™m not going to threaten the whole world. A very limited number would be enough,â€ he told the newspaper, saying that it â€œpi**es me offâ€ when some in the West complain about the slow start and progress of the push against Russian forces. â€œThey are needed. Because there is no other way. Because the enemy is using a different generation of aviation,â€ he said. He also complained he has a fraction of the artillery shells that Russia is firing.    Zaluzhny said he is in constant contact with Western partners, like Pentagon Joint Chiefs Chairman General Mark Milley, who arekeenly aware of Ukraineâ€™s needs. â€œWe have an agreement: 24/7, weâ€™re in touch. So, sometimes I can call up and say, â€˜If I donâ€™t get 100,000 shells in a week, 1,000 people will die. Step into my shoes,â€™â€ he told the Washington Post. But Milley alone canâ€™t make the decision, and the delays are deadly, Zaluzhny said. â€œItâ€™s just that while that decision is being made, in the obvious situation, a lot of people die every day â€“ a lot. Just because no decision has been made yet,â€ he said. â€œThis is not a show,â€ he added. â€œItâ€™s not a show the whole world is watching and betting on or anything. Every day, every metre is given by blood,â€ he said. The Washington, DC-based think tank, the Institute for the Study of War (ISW), said on Friday that Zaluzhny responded to a question regarding military equipment losses in battles with Russian forces saying that Ukraine used its tanks and armoured cars in combat and did not save them up for â€œparadesâ€. Zaluzhnyi also stated that#Ukrainianforces are continuing to use Western-provided armored vehicles and tanks in combat instead of saving them for â€œparadesâ€ when responding to a question about military equipment losses. 2/3 â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)July 1, 2023  Speaking later Friday in Washington, Milley said the United States and allies were working hard to supply Ukraine. â€œWe are giving them as much help as humanly possible,â€ he said. Milley said the US was still in talks on providing Ukraine with F-16s and ATACMS, precision missiles that could more than double the range Ukraine forces are able to target. He acknowledged that some people had expressed impatience with the pace of the counteroffensive.    Milley told an audience at the National Press Club in Washington that Ukraineâ€™s counteroffensive was â€œadvancing steadily, deliberately working its way through very difficult minefields â€¦ 500 metres a day, 1,000 metres a day, 2,000 metres a day, that kind of thingâ€. He saidhe was unsurprised that progress was slowerthan some people and computers might have predicted. â€œWar on paper and real war are different. In real war, real people die. Real people are on those front lines and real people are in those vehicles. Real bodies are being shredded by high explosives,â€ he said. â€œWhat I had said was this is going to take six, eight, 10 weeks, itâ€™s going to be very difficult,â€ he added. â€œItâ€™s going to be very long, and itâ€™s going to be very, very bloody. And no one should have any illusions about any of that.â€ On Friday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said his forces advanced â€œin all directions of our active operationsâ€, while Hanna Maliar, the countryâ€™s deputy defence minister, said Ukraineâ€™s military assessed progress as â€œgoing according to planâ€, and that the counteroffensive should be evaluated by â€œa lot of different military tasks.â€ Zelenskyy also ordered security to be beefed up at his countryâ€™s border with Belarus, where fighters from the Russian mercenary group Wagner have been offered exile.    Zelenskyy said he had been informed on Friday of the situation in Belarusby the Ukrainian intelligence service GUR, foreign intelligence services and border guards. â€œBy the decision of the Stavka [chief of staff], Commander-in-Chief [Valery] Zaluzhny and General [Serhiy] Nayev were instructed to strengthen the northern direction in order to guarantee peace. There are appropriate deadlines,â€ the Ukraine leader said in a video posted on Telegram. Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko has offered Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin refuge in his country after his fighters called off their mutiny to remove Russiaâ€™s military leadership. Western officials now fear that Wagner forces could destabilise Central and Eastern Europe from the soon-to-be bases in Belarus. The ISW said on Friday that sources report that Wagner will operate three large field camps in Belarus, and media reports have claimed that recruitment centres for the private mercenary force are still open in Russia and accepting new recruits.

Title: Poland detains Russian ice-hockey player on suspicion of spying
Subtitle: Russia demands explanation after Polish justice minister says suspect was 14th member of spy ring to be arrested in NATO member country.
Content: Authorities in Poland have detained a Russian ice-hockey player who played for a top-tier Polish club on suspicion of spying. Zbigniew Ziobro, Polandâ€™s justice minister and chief prosecutor, said on Friday the unnamed suspect was the 14th member of a spy network to be arrested by the countryâ€™s secret service. â€œRussian spies are falling one by one!â€ Ziobro said. â€œA spy who operated under the guise of an athlete was caught.â€ Later on Friday, Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said Moscow â€œstrongly protestsâ€ the arrest of a Russian citizen in Poland and demanded an explanation.    Polandâ€™s National Prosecutorâ€™s Office said the man, who was arrested on June 11, was accused of participating in an organised crime group and of acting on behalf of foreign intelligence against the interests of Poland. Such acts are punishable by up to 10 years in prison. The suspect regularly passed on information â€œabout the results of his reconnaissance operations, for which he was regularly paidâ€, a statement released by the Office of Special Services in the Prime Ministerâ€™s Office. The statement said the group of spies was used by the Russians to conduct intelligence activities, including the monitoring of railways and the spreading of propaganda targeting NATO and Poland. â€œThe suspects also prepared acts of sabotage ordered by the Russian intelligence. The whole ring was paid for the tasks carried out,â€ it said. NATO member Poland is a major hub for Western weapons going to Ukraine in support of its fight against Russiaâ€™s invasion.

Title: HRW reports new evidence of Ukrainian use of banned landmines
Subtitle: The rights group has previously published four reports documenting the use by Russian troops.
Content: HumanÂ RightsÂ WatchÂ (HRW) said on Friday that it uncovered new evidence of the indiscriminate use by Ukrainian forces of banned anti-personnel landmines against Russian troops who invaded Ukraine in 2022. The group called on Ukraineâ€™s government to follow through with a commitment made earlier this month not to employ such weapons, investigate their suspected use and hold accountable those responsible. â€œThe Ukrainian governmentâ€™s pledge to investigate its militaryâ€™s apparent use of banned anti-personnel mines is an important recognition of its duty to protect civilians,â€ Steve Goose,Â HumanÂ RightsÂ Watchâ€™s arms director, said in a statement. HRW said it shared its findings with the Ukrainian government in a May letter to which it received no response. Ukraineâ€™s embassy in Washington did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment. Ukraine in 2005 ratified a 1997 international treaty banning such mines and mandating the destruction of stocks of the weapons. Russia did not join the treaty and its use of anti-personnel mines â€œviolates internationalÂ humanitarian law â€¦ because they are inherently indiscriminate,â€ the report said. Anti-personnel mines are detonated by a personâ€™s presence, proximity or contact and can kill and maim long after a conflict ends. Since Russiaâ€™s February 2022 invasion, HRW has published four reports documenting the use by Russian troops of 13 types of anti-personnel mines that killed and injured civilians. The new report is a follow-on to a January report that Ukrainian soldiers fired rockets that scattered thousands of PMF-1 mines in Russian-occupied areas in and around the eastern city of Izium between April and September 2022, when Kyivâ€™s forces recaptured it. The latest report said that fresh evidence of Ukrainian forcesâ€™ use of anti-personnel mines in 2022 came from photographs posted online by an individual working in eastern Ukraine that showed warhead sections of Uragan 220mm rockets. Those rockets each indiscriminately disburses 312 PFM-1S anti-personnel mines, said the report. Analysis of handwriting on one warhead determined that the first word was Ukrainian for â€œfrom,â€ while a second Latin alphabet word related to an organisation in Kyiv, which the report did not identify. The person who headed the organisation â€“ also unidentified â€“ had social media posts â€œindicating that they had donated funds to the Ukrainian military via a non-governmental organisation (NGO).â€ Photographs of Uragan warheads posted online bearing messages written in Ukrainian were linked to a different Ukraine-based group, the report said.

Title: Future of Wagner contracts up to African states: Russiaâ€™s Lavrov
Subtitle: Saturdayâ€™s attempted mutiny in Russia has led to speculation about the status of Wagner operatives in the Central African Republic and elsewhere in Africa.
Content: Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov has said the future of contracts signed between various African countries and the Wagner mercenary group was a matter for those governments who had concluded such agreements. Speaking at a news conference on Friday, Lavrov said Wagner had worked in the Central African Republic (CAR) and other countries on the basis of contracts drawn up directly with the governments concerned. He also said Russiaâ€™s defence ministry had long had â€œseveral hundredâ€ military advisers working in the CAR. Wagner mercenaries, who have been heavily involved in the Ukraine conflict, staged a brief mutiny last Saturday, taking control of the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don and marching on Moscow before a deal abruptly ended their revolt. The incident has led to speculation about the status of Wagner operatives in CAR and elsewhere in Africa as well as Moscowâ€™s level of involvement with the groupâ€™s activity on the continent. On Tuesday, Russian president Vladimir Putin said Wagner was â€œfully financedâ€ by the state, adding that around 86 billion rubles (approximately $940 million) was paid to the group between May 2022 â€“ May 2023. Mali, where military authorities seized power in coups in 2020 and 2021, is battling a years-long operation against armed groups affiliated with ISIL (ISIS) and al-Qaeda. It has said that Russian forces there are not Wagner mercenaries but trainers helping local troops with equipment bought from Russia. The mercenaries have been blamed for human rights abuses including most notably an incident in March 2022 in Moura in central Mali, where local troops and suspected Russian fighters allegedly killed hundreds of civilians. In nearby Mauritania, thousands of Malians have fled to the Mâ€™bera refugee camp since 2021, according to United Nations officials running the camp. Almost 7,000 new arrivalswere recordedbetween March â€“ April 2022 alone. In February, French President Emmanuel Macron described the deployment of Wagner troops in Africa as the â€œlife insurance of failing regimes in Africaâ€ that will only sow misery.

Title: Wagner mercenary â€˜merchâ€™ prices jump online after Russia mutiny
Subtitle: Merchandise bearing Wagnerâ€™s insignia â€“ a human skull against a black and red backdrop â€“ has shot up in price online.
Content: Online prices for merchandise bearing the insignia of Russiaâ€™s Wagner mercenary force â€“ a human skull against a black and red backdrop â€“ have shot up since the groupâ€™s short-lived armed mutiny against the Russian military, with buyers also posting five-star reviews and support for the mercenaries. Russiaâ€™s largest online retailer Wildberriesâ€™ weekly price breakdowns showed how costs have risen for Wagner paraphernalia after the private armyâ€™s boss, Yevgeny Prigozhin, sent an armed convoy of fighters on a 1,200-kilometre (750-mile)charge towards Moscow on Saturday. After occupying the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don and appearing to have a clear shot at entering Moscow, Prigozhin abruptly halted the advance of his fighters on Saturday after agreeingto lead his forces into Belarus following talks with that countryâ€™s leader Alexander Lukashenko. Wagner fighters may be out of sight in Russia, but they appear to still be on the minds of Russian online shoppers. A Wagner uniform patch depicting the skull that can be sewn onto clothes fetched 525 roubles ($6) in the period June 25-29, up sharply from 294 ($3.36) roubles during June 18-25. Prices for a black T-shirt emblazoned with a picture of a Wagner fighter holding a violin jumped this week to 1,650 roubles ($18.80) from 1,236 roubles ($14.10). â€œDue to the situation in the country, the purchase was spontaneous,â€ wrote one buyer, Tatiana.    People have also been buying other regalia, such as Wagner keyrings, on the rival Russian E-commerce site, Ozon. â€œVery beautiful and original keyring,â€ wrote one five-star reviewer. â€œIn memory of all those in Wagnerâ€™s ranks who died.â€ Wildberries and Ozon declined to comment on Thursday on the surge in Wagner merchandise prices. Elsewhere, Prigozhin face masks are now on sale in Saint Petersburg, alongside those of Putin, Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and jailed opposition politician Alexey Navalny. Writing a review of a Wagner flag on Wildberries, one buyer, Vladimir, said: â€œThe Wagner Private Military Company is the best. Good luck to you guys. The flag is excellent.â€ Wagner fighters, who have spearheaded some of Russiaâ€™s fiercest battles in Ukraine, have beenaccused of committing atrocities in conflicts around the worldin which they have become involved in recent years. United Nations experts in January called for an independent investigation intopossible war crimes and crimes against humanitycarried out in Mali by government forces and Wagner mercenaries. Russian President Vladimir Putin has described the private armyâ€™s actions as â€œtreasonâ€. Yet, when Wagnerâ€™s armoured convoy crossed from Ukraine into Russia on their so-called â€œmarch to Moscowâ€ on Saturday, they were cheered enthusiastically by residents in Rostov-on-Don â€“ the city they briefly took control of in southern Russia.

Title: EU officials concerned over Russian threat with a â€˜weaker Putinâ€™
Subtitle: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy tells EU summit that turmoil for Putin in Russia was advantageous to the West.
Content: The European Union officials have warned thatRussia has become more dangerousfollowing last weekendâ€™s short-lived mutiny by the countryâ€™s Wagner mercenary force which had exposed that President Vladimir Putin was politically weaker than previously thought. Attending an EU summit in Brussels on Thursday, senior officials reiterated that the recent chaos in Russia â€“ wherethe mercenary force came within 200km of Moscow(125 miles) on Saturday â€“ Â was an internal matter in which their governments played no role, but a weakened Putin was a concern for Europe. â€œA weaker Putin is a greater danger,â€ EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said as he arrived for the meeting on Thursday. â€œPutin has lost the monopoly of force,â€ Borrell said, adding that he expected that Putin â€œwill be in cleaning mode internally, and a more assertive modeâ€ following the threat to his power exposed by the mutiny of Wagner fighters. Borrell said EU member states intelligence services were analysing scenarios as â€œnow we have to look at Russia as a risk because of the internal instabilityâ€.    NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said that while it was â€œtoo earlyâ€ to draw conclusions regarding the effects of recent events, Wagnerâ€™s weekend mutiny revealed â€œcracks and divisionsâ€ in Russia. â€œThe mutiny we saw at the weekend demonstrates that there are cracks and divisions within the Russian system. At the same time, it is important to underline that these are internal Russian matters,â€ Stoltenberg said. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said that â€œa regime change in Russiaâ€ was not a goal. However, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who addressed Thursdayâ€™s EU summit by video link, had a blunt message for those who claimed that a weakened Putin would make him more unpredictable and dangerous. â€œWe are seeing their weakness, which we so badly need,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œThe weaker Russia is, and the more its bosses fear mutinies and uprisings, the more they will fear to irritate us. Russiaâ€™s weakness will make it safe for others, and its defeat will solve the problem of this war,â€ he said.    EU leaders agreed thatPutin had suffered a blow to his authority from the Wagner affair. Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda, one of several EU nations bordering Russia, insisted the chaos from the Wagner mutiny was all the more reason to take a robust posture towards Putin. Some say â€œthat a strong Putin is less dangerous than a weak Putin. I donâ€™t agree with that. We have to move forward and be decisive because now is a crucial moment of historyâ€, Nauseda said. â€œThis showed deep cracks in Putinâ€™s system. This mutiny of last weekend will also have aftershocks that we will see,â€ said EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.    Officials from several member states and EU institutions said the chaos and instability created by the rebellion would not only force the EU to double down on its support for Ukraine with commitments for more ammunition but also to ensure fighting and violence do not spill over into the EU bloc itself afterWagner forces were allowed to leave Russia for neighbouring Belarus. â€œThere is no room for hesitation,â€ said Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas. â€œWe must continue to increase the price of Russian aggression.â€ Many EU nations are also members of NATO, and at NATOâ€™s July 11-12 summit, they will look to offer Ukraine more security guarantees, if stopping short of full NATO membership. That approach for more support is expected to be fully endorsed by the time the two-day summit ends. As Putin has moved to reassert control since the Wagner uprising, the Kremlin has remained silent over the conspicuous absence of the deputy commander of Russiaâ€™s military operations in Ukraine and other senior Russian military figures.    Speculation about General Sergei Surovikin has been growing since he fell out of public view after the aborted weekend revolt by Wagner fighters and amid reports that he was sympathetic to the mercenary forceâ€™s objectives. While several media outlets have claimed that Surovikin has been arrested, the generalâ€™s whereabouts were a matter for the defence ministry, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told the Russian news agency Interfax on Thursday. The Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a Washington, DC-based think tank, said on Thursday that Peskovâ€™s response to questions regarding the missing general was insightful. â€œPeskov could have denied ongoing speculations about Surovikin if there were no investigation of him,â€ the ISW said. â€œPeskovâ€™s refusal suggests that Russian officials may be investigating Surovikin since Russian officials usually refuse to comment on ongoing investigations,â€ it said. The ISW also noted that Russian sources have given conflicting accounts of what may have happened to Surovikin, including that he was questioned by the security services over links to Wagner and has since been released. #KremlinSpokesperson Dmitry Peskov refused to address Army General Sergei#Surovikinâ€™s whereabouts on June 29, prompting more speculations in the Russian information space.https://t.co/N68gnBsZSthttps://t.co/USgXEoQHG8pic.twitter.com/Jp6RWBGqLO â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)June 30, 2023  â€œIt would be logical for Russian officials to question Surovikin or any other military officials with ties to Prigozhin after Wagnerâ€™s armed rebellion,â€ the think tank said. Asked whether Putin continued to trust Surovikin, Peskov said only that the president was working with Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Russiaâ€™s top general, Valery Gerasimov. Surovikin is considered an ally of Prigozhin but sided with the powers that were in Moscow during the Saturday march by Wagner forces towards Moscow. Prigozhin said his move on Moscow was to overthrow senior military leaders. He has long accused Defence Minister Shoigu and General Gerasimov of incompetence and blamed them for the multitude of battlefield failures Russian forces have suffered in Ukraine.

Title: China unlikely to be worried by â€˜weaker Putinâ€™ post Wagner revolt
Subtitle: â€˜New eraâ€™ ties are expected to continue given China and Russiaâ€™s shared concerns, with Beijing enjoying an even stronger position.
Content: Taipei, Taiwanâ€“ Ties between China and Russia will remain strong even after the failed mutiny by the Wagner Group last weekend, but analysts say Beijing is likely to become increasingly cautious about Russian leader Vladimir Putin and the future stability of his government. Beijing, like many governments, remained largely silent on Saturday as Yevgeny Prigozhinâ€™s mercenary troopsmarched towards Moscowafter seizing the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don. The following day, as the dust settled and Prigozhin agreed toexile in Belarus, China released a statement. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs called the incident â€œRussiaâ€™s internal affairâ€ and said it supported Russiaâ€™s attempts at â€œmaintaining national stability and achieving development and prosperityâ€. State media, which spent little time on Saturdayâ€™s events, also picked up on the theme of stability, noting the speedy resolution to the crisis by Putinâ€™s government. Still, despite thepublic messaging downplayingthe weekendâ€™s events, the mutiny probably did unnerve top Chinese officials, including President Xi Jinping, said Elizabeth Wishnick, a senior research scientist at Columbia Universityâ€™s Weatherhead East Asian Institute. â€œFor Xi Jinping, developments in Russia this weekend would have had to be very concerning,Â as they raised questions about regimeÂ security,Â a top concern for the Chinese leader,â€ she said.    Xi, who has developed strong ties with Putin in recent years, is in the midst of extending his rule into a personal grip over China as themost powerful leader since Mao Zedong. For a government that emphasises stability at all costs, even locking down tens of millions for COVID-19 and overturning the economy to achieve it, a situation such as that faced by Putin as the Wagner Group advanced on Moscow would have been Xiâ€™s worst nightmare. â€œI think China will become more cautious in understanding that Mr Putinâ€™s control of his country may not be as solid as people used to think. The perception that he is strong man in command of his country now has cracked,â€ said Shen Dingli, a Shanghai-based international relations scholar. â€œThat will be calculated into the decisions of all players, not only Chinaâ€¦ [but] Kazakhstan, Ukraine, Germany, the US,â€ he said. â€œEven Putin himself, he knows his image has been tarnished.â€ China and Russia have long had a complex relationship but the two sides have become closer since Xi came to power in 2013, thanks to his close friendship with Putin and their shared animosity towards the United States. Both view the US as meddling in their backyards, either through Ukraine and NATO or Taiwan and Japan, and both oppose expanded US influence in their respective regions. The two countries declared a â€œno limits partnershipâ€ shortly before Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine last year, which was conspicuously held off until the conclusion of the Beijing Winter Olympics. As the war drags on, China has helped keep Russiaâ€™s economy afloat in the face of Western sanctions despite maintaining an officially neutral position and offering tonegotiate peace talks. In March, Xi travelled to Moscow, shook hands with Putin, who had just been named in an arrest warrant by the International Criminal Court, and later agreed to a â€œnew eraâ€ of cooperation between the two countries. â€œWhile recent events are of concern to Chinaâ€™s government, because of both geographical proximity and shared challenges, they are unlikely to negatively affect Chinaâ€™s desire and commitment to working with Russia on both bilateral and global issues,â€ Andy Mok, a senior research fellow at the Center for China and Globalization in Beijing, told Al Jazeera. Yurii Poita, the head of the Asia-Pacific section at Ukraineâ€™s Center for Army, Conversion and Disarmament Studies, agrees the partnership is expected to continue in the short term. But he said Beijing might be making more contingency plans based on a revised understanding about the weaknesses in Russian security and defence. The mutiny also exposed Russian elites as unreliable partners, he noted. â€œWe saw that Russian leadership just kept silent and some of them fled from Moscow to other cities. Even the price on the international flights just skyrocketed,â€ he said. For Xi, who is known tosurround himself with loyalistsand install them in key government positions, such a scenario would have been another nightmare had it happened in China. Wen-ti Sung, a political scientist at Australian National University, said while he expected the close relationship between China and Russia to continue over the long-term, the feeling may begin to shift. Russia was very much the junior partner before the coup and the mutiny has underlined that status, he stressed. â€œXi still prefers Putin to the alternatives but Beijing now has reasons to have more reservations and become more transactional in dealings with Putin,â€ Sung said. â€œAweaker Putinwill become less useful to China. A weaker Putin will have to be more beholden to domestic constituencies, less able to project a coherent foreign policy, therefore less able to consistently advance Russiaâ€™s common cause with China.â€

Title: Russia holds General Sergei Surovikin over Wagner mutiny: Reports
Subtitle: The Moscow Times Russian-language service and a military blogger reported Surovikinâ€™s arrest over links to the Wagner mercenary force uprising.
Content: Russian authorities have reportedly detained General Sergei Surovikin, the deputy commander of Russiaâ€™s military operations in Ukraine, amid a reported purge of military officials following the short-lived rebellion by Wagner mercenary forces, according to sources cited by the Moscow Times newspaper and a Russian military blogger. Surovikin, nicknamed â€œGeneral Armageddonâ€ by the Russian media for his reputed ruthlessness, is a veteran of Russiaâ€™s wars in Chechnya and Syria who has been decorated by Russian President Vladimir Putin. Citing two sources close to Russiaâ€™s Defence Ministry, the Russian-language service of The Moscow Times reported on Wednesday that Surovikin was arrested due to what one of the unnamed sources said was choosing Wagner chief Yevgeny â€œPrigozhinâ€™s side during the uprisingâ€. A Russian military blogger, Vladimir Romanov, also reported Surovikinâ€™s arrest on Wednesday, according to the Moscow Times, while the Washington, DC-based think tank Institute for the Study of War (ISW) reported another Russian source as claiming that military â€œaffiliatesâ€ of Surovikin had been â€œaccused of complicity in the rebellionâ€. Russiaâ€™s Defence Ministry has yet to comment on the reports of Surovikinâ€™s detention, the newspaper said. The Defense Ministry has yet to comment on the alleged arrest of Surovikin, who has not been seen in public since Saturday.https://t.co/dr7xM4N33k â€” The Moscow Times (@MoscowTimes)June 28, 2023   The ISW reported on Wednesday that a prominent Russian military blogging site had claimed that a â€œlarge-scale purgeâ€ of the Russian military command was under way following the attempt by Wagner forces to enter Moscow and apprehend the countryâ€™s senior military leaders. Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence is undergoing what Rybar, a pro-Kremlin military analysis channel on Telegram, described as a â€œcrash testâ€ for loyalty amid apparent â€œindecisivenessâ€ by some in the Russian military command when it came to crushing the Wagner mutiny and their â€œsupportâ€ for the private mercenary force, the ISW reported. Rybar said the uprising by the Wagner force had â€œbecome a pretext for a massive purge in the ranks of the Russian Armed Forcesâ€. 3/ Russian authorities reportedly arrested Army General Sergei#Surovikinon June 28, possibly indicating that the#Kremlinintends to purge the MoD of figures viewed as disloyal.https://t.co/owjfEW9jU1pic.twitter.com/GMqcvNBZnF â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)June 29, 2023   â€œIf Russian authorities did arrest Surovikin then the Kremlin will likely use Surovikin and his affiliates as scapegoats to publicly explain why the Russian military and Russian internal security apparatuses responded poorly to the rebellion and to justify a potential overhaul of the Russian military leadership,â€ the ISW wrote. â€œISW cannot confirm any of these speculations about the command changes at this time, but it is evident that the armed rebellion is continuing to have substantial ramifications in the information space.â€ The Reuters news agency cited three United States officials on Wednesday as saying that Surovikin was known to be sympathetic to the Wagner rebellion but it was unclear if he actively supported it. Surovikin had been in support of Prigozhin but Western intelligence did not know with certainty if he had helped the rebellion in any way. As the uprising unfolded, he had publicly urged Wagner fighters to return to their bases on Saturday, Reuters reported. The New York Times also reported that Surovikin had advance knowledge that Prigozhin was planning a rebellion and that Russian authorities were checking if he was complicit.    The Kremlin, asked on Wednesday about the Times report, said there would be â€œa lot of speculationâ€ in the aftermath of the Wagner mutiny, which saw mercenaries reportedly come to within 200km (124 miles) of Moscow. â€œThere is now a lot of different speculation and gossip surrounding these events,â€ Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said on Wednesday, according to Russian news agencies. â€œI think thatâ€™s an example of that,â€ he said, dismissing the Times report. The Russian army and the people â€œall stood by the President (Vladimir Putin) during the uprisingâ€, Peskov added. Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko confirmed on Tuesday that the Wagner boss, Prigozhin, had arrived in the country as part of a deal he brokered and which narrowly prevented Wagner mercenaries from marching into Moscow. Wagner fighters have been offered an abandoned military site where they can â€œput their tents while thinking what to do nextâ€, Lukashenko said.    Germanyâ€™s Chancellor Olaf Scholz said on Wednesday the failed mutiny had weakened Putin but it was unclear if it would make the Kremlin any more likely to withdraw its troops from Ukraine. â€œI do believe he is weakened as this shows that the autocratic power structures have cracks in them and he is not as firmly in the saddle as he always asserts,â€ Scholz said in an hour-long interview with German broadcaster ARD. Scholz said he did not want to participate in speculation about how long Putin would likely remain in office, saying the Westâ€™s aim in supporting Ukraine was to help it defend itself, not to bring about regime change in Russia.    Asked if at any point on Saturday he had hoped the insurrection by the Wagner mercenaries was the end of Putinâ€™s rule, he said it would have made no sense as it was unclear if what would come after Putin would be better. â€œThe Wagner troops are a military unit that is acting very aggressively all over the world, and very concretely also in Russiaâ€™s war against Ukraine,â€ Scholz said.

Title: Ukraine says suspect directed Russia missile attack in Kramatorsk
Subtitle: Ukraineâ€™s President Zelenskyy says man who allegedly â€˜spottedâ€™ for Russian forces attack on restaurant to be charged with treason.
Content: Ukraine has arrested a man accused of directing the Russianmissiles that hit a restaurantin the countryâ€™s city of Kramatorsk, killing at least 12 people and wounding more than 60, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and security officials said. Two sisters, both aged 14, were among three teenagers killed in the attack on Tuesday evening that hit the Ria Pizza restaurant in the city centre, which was popular with locals, soldiers, aid workers and journalists. The other teenager killed was 17, according to Prosecutor General Andrii Kostin. Ukrainian security officials said the man it arrested, an employee of a fuel transportation company, was suspected of filming the restaurant for Russian forces and informing them about its popularity. â€œThe Security Service of Ukraine together with the police special forces detained the person who coordinated this terrorist attack,â€ Zelenskyy said in his nightly address to the nation on Wednesday. â€œEveryone who helps Russian terrorists destroy life deserves the maximum punishment. And this applies not only to some collaborators,â€ he said. â€œThe spotter is being charged with treason. The possible punishment is life imprisonment. Accomplices of a terrorist state must be treated as betrayers of humanity,â€ he added, warning that more bodies may yet be found beneath the rubble of the restaurant. First of all, regarding yesterday's ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º attack on Kramatorsk. Today, work continued all day at the site of the attack. Unfortunately, the death toll has increased. ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡º missiles claimed the lives of 11 of our people, including three children. My condolences to the families. Moreâ€¦pic.twitter.com/U1iNlfDqLd â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)June 28, 2023   Officials initially said Tuesdayâ€™s attack on the restaurant involved a Russian S-300 missile, a surface-to-air weapon that Moscowâ€™s forces have repurposed for loosely-targeted attacks on cities, but Ukraineâ€™s National Police later said Iskander short-range ballistic missiles were used. Kramatorsk is a front-line city that houses the Ukrainian Armyâ€™s regional headquarters. The death toll from the attack rose to 12 on Thursday following the discovery of another body, Ukraineâ€™s emergency services said, as rescuers continued to search through rubble for possible survivors in a city where last year, about six weeks after the start of Moscowâ€™s full-scale invasion,52 civilians were killedin a Russian missile attack on a train station. Tuesdayâ€™s missile attack also damaged 18 multi-story buildings, 65 houses, five schools, two kindergartens, a shopping centre, an administrative building and a recreational building, Ukraineâ€™s Donetsk regional Governor Pavlo Kyrylenko said. Three Colombian citizens were also injured in the attack on the restaurant, Colombiaâ€™s President Gustavo Petro said in a tweet on Wednesday, adding that Bogota would lodge a diplomatic protest with Moscow for the attack that had harmed â€œdefenceless Colombian civiliansâ€. The three injured Colombians were identified as well-known writer Hector Abad Faciolince, former Colombian peace negotiator Sergio Jaramillo and journalist Catalina Gomez. Abad and Jaramillo were reported to be on a mission to express Latin American solidarity with the people of Ukraine. Rusia ha atacado a tres civiles colombianos indefensos. It thus violates the protocols of war. The Foreign Ministry must deliver a diplomatic note of protest. We await the safe and sound return to their homes of Sergio, HÃ©ctor and Catalina.] On social media, the Colombians said they were with Ukrainian writer Victoria Amelina in the restaurant at the time of the attack and that she was in critical condition. Russia has insisted that it does not attack civilian targets, although its missiles havekilled many civiliansand destroyed civilian infrastructure â€“ such as homes and businesses â€“ across the country. The Russian Ministry of Defence said on Wednesday that its forces had hit a facility used by Ukrainian army officers in Kramatorsk but did not mention the pizza restaurant. â€œStrikes are only carried out on objects that are in one way or another linked to military infrastructure,â€ said Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov. â€œThe Russian Federation does not carry out strikes on civilian infrastructure,â€ he said.

Title: As Wagner troops marched on Moscow, Ukraine made further gains
Subtitle: Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s position weakened by the Yevgeny Prigozhinâ€™s mutiny amid Ukraine war, analysts say.
Content: Seventy weekssince he ordered his troops into neighbouring Ukraine, Russian President Vladimir Putin faced a major mutiny back home. On June 23, Wagner Group boss Yevgeny Prigozhin circulated a video purportedly showing a missile attack against his private military company that has been fighting alongside Russian soldiers. â€œAccording to eyewitnesses, the strike was delivered from the rear, that is, it was delivered by the military of the Russian Federation Ministry of Defence,â€ he wrote on Telegram. Prigozhin said his 25,000 armed men would â€œmarch for justiceâ€ to â€œstop the evil brought by the Russian military leadershipâ€. He promised that after settling scores with Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of Staff General Valery Gerasimov, his troops would then return to the front lines in Ukraine. Prigozhin has frequently criticised the Russian military leadership, claiming their incompetence has led to the deaths of tens of thousands of soldiers. He put himself in competition with Shoigu and Gerasimov by claiming credit for the capture of Severodonetsk, Lysychansk and Bakhmut in Ukraineâ€™s east, elevating Wagnerâ€™s reputation. After the occupation of Bakhmut in May, Russiaâ€™s defence ministry cycled Wagner mercenaries out and replaced them with regular marines and paratroopers. On June 10, Shoigu announced that all volunteer formations must sign military contracts with the Russian defence ministry by July 1. Prigozhin said that would not happen. â€œHe was pushed to act because the defence ministry was trying to absorb Wagner, and he knew that once they grabbed Wagner, he had nothing â€“ and God knows what would happen to him afterwards,â€ Seth Krummrich, a former US army colonel who is now the vice president at Global Guardian, a security consultancy, told Al Jazeera. Following their withdrawal from Bakhmut, Wagner forces either redeployed to Krasnodar in Russia, or remained encamped behind the front lines in Ukraineâ€™s eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk. Unengaged in the war, they were free to attack Russia itself. Well before 8am local time [05:00 GMT] on June 24, footage showed Prigozhin casually walking through the regional military headquarters of Rostov-on-Don, which his men had occupied. They were not only the headquarters for the 58th Combined Arms Army, currently engaged in Ukraine, but also the command centre for all Russian forces on Ukrainian soil. â€œThey were able to walk in there,â€ Krummrich said. â€œThat told me the Russian headquarters there was taken completely by surprise â€¦ or theyâ€™re realising whatâ€™s happening in Ukraine, theyâ€™re seeing the losses and the lies in Moscow, so there was an emotional support level,â€ he said.    By 10:30am [07:30 GMT], geolocated footage showed Wagner forces crossing the administrative border of the Voronezh region, where Russian troops surrendered to them. Wagner quickly seized the city of Voronezh with relatively little resistance. By early afternoon, Wagner forces had advanced past Lipetsk and were seemingly filmed driving on the M4 highway to Moscow with T-90 tanks and BMP-2 armoured personnel carriers. Bulldozer crews began to dig up a trench across the M4 to stop them. The Kremlin mobilised Rosgvardia (Russian National Guard), special police and special rapid response troops to barricade the capital, in what some observers said was increasingly looking like a coup attempt that could have led to civil war. By 6pm [15:00 GMT], Wagner troops were filmed in northern Lipetsk region, 330 kilometres (205 miles) from Moscow. In just a matter of hours, Wagner had covered half the distance from the Ukrainian border to Moscow. â€œSuch fast moving and impactful developments make it almost certain â€¦ that Wagner had a plan for a military uprising already well worked out, had stockpiled equipment, and had analysed the weak points in the Russian military and state that it could exploit,â€ Phillips Obrien, professor of strategy at St Andrews University, wrote in a Substack post. Even the Russian air force was unable to stop the advancing columns because they carried Pantsir and manually portable air defence systems. â€œThey had integrated air defence systems that are mobile, so they were able to protect their convoy and protect their movement. Any sort of aviation that came in they could strike it right away,â€ said Krummrich. The Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a Washington-based think tank, assessed that Wagner forces â€œmay have shot down up to three Mi-8 MTPR electronic warfare helicopters, one Mi-8 helicopter, one Ka-52 helicopter, one Mi-35 helicopter, one Mi-28 helicopter, and one An-26/Il-28 transport aircraft, resulting in the deaths of at least 13 pilots and airmen â€“ and one of the single deadliest days for the Russian air force of the war in Ukraine to dateâ€. The lack of resistance to Wagner was also remarkable. â€œRosgvardiaâ€™s founding mission is to protect internal threats to the security of the Russian government, such as an advance on Moscow, and it is notable that Rosgvardia failed to engage even as Wagner captured critical military assets in Rostov-on-Don and destroyed Russian military aircraft,â€ said the ISW. In an address to the nation, Putin on June 24 declared Prigozhin a traitor and described his mutiny as â€œa betrayal of our people â€¦ a knife in the back of our countryâ€. â€œInflated ambitions andÂ personal interests have led toÂ treason,â€ Putin said. â€œThose who staged theÂ mutiny andÂ took up arms against their comradesÂ â€“ they have betrayed Russia andÂ will be brought toÂ account.â€ Yet by the end of the day, Prigozhin announced a deal brokered by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko that gave him immunity in Belarus. He claimed his decision to accept it was driven by a desire to avoid further bloodshed and civil war.  â€œ[Prigozhin] did not see the people rising up. He has 25,000 soldiers. Thatâ€™s maybe 10,000 foot soldiers. The rest are logistics. You can maybe take one neighbourhood in Moscow with that â€¦ thereâ€™s no chance of him taking it militarily. What he needed was a spark to set off a coup where the people rose up, but the people are clearly not at that point,â€ said Krummrich. â€œI think he struck too early.â€ Independent Russian news service Verstka reported that a 24,000 square kilometres (9,266 square miles) training base for Wagner was already under construction at Asipovichy in Belarus, 200km (124 miles) from the Ukrainian border. But it was unlikely that Putin would allow Prigozhin to live, said Krummrich. â€œI think heâ€™s a dead man walking,â€ he added. â€œIf youâ€™re Putin, you have to kill him; you have to, because the next batch of oligarchs who decide to break off are going to be much more savvy, much more sophisticated, and theyâ€™re going to win.â€ In a second address to the Russian people on June 26, Putin left the door open for Wagner mercenaries to sign up with the armed forces, a sign of how greatly in need he is of trained and experienced personnel. â€œToday, you have the opportunity to continue your service to Russia by signing a contract with the defence ministry or other law enforcement or security agency, or return home,â€ Putin said. â€œThose who want to are free to go to Belarus. I will keep my promise.â€    Ukrainian officials, meanwhile, greeted the short-lived rebellion across the border withcaution and hope, as Kyivâ€™s troops continued to probe Russian defences for weaknesses and reclaim occupied territory. Ukrainian deputy defence minister Hanna Maliar said Ukraineâ€™s counteroffensive had liberated 130sq km (50.1sq miles) by June 26, a gain of 17sq km (6.6sq miles) compared with a week earlier. Ukraine had also launched new offensives north and south of Bakhmut, Maliar said, in Orikhovo-Vasylivka, Bohdanivka, Yahidne, Klishchiivka and Kurdyumivka, reinforcing a flanking action that began in mid-May. Ukrainian troops advanced 1-2km (0.6-1.2 miles) along these new axes, she said. Ukraineâ€™s southern forces continued to put pressure on Russian defences in front of the port cities of Melitopol and Berdyansk. â€œThe Russian occupation forces are putting up strong resistance, while suffering significant losses in personnel, weapons and equipment. The enemyâ€™s casualties over the past week are eight times more than ours,â€ Maliar said. It was not possible to independently verify the figures. But in an upbeat address to Ukrainians, President Volodymyr Zelenskyysaidhis countryâ€™s forces had â€œadvanced in all directionsâ€. â€œThis is a happy day. I wished the guys more days like this,â€ he said in the video message that was released in the early hours of Tuesday after visiting Ukrainian forces on the front lines. â€œIt was a busy day, a lot of emotions â€¦ I was honoured to award our warriors, to thank them personally, to shake their hands,â€ Zelenskyy added. Many observers noted that, despite the failure of Prigozhinâ€™s mutiny, the chaotic weekend events left Putin looking weak. â€œThereâ€™s still other players in the game of thrones in Moscow that are waiting and watching,â€ said Krummrich. â€œThey see the weakness. Bloodâ€™s in the water, and here come the sharks â€¦ His situation has become much more dangerous.â€ Lawrence Freedman, emeritus professor of war studies at Kingâ€™s College London, wrote that the Russian president â€œlet the Shoigu-Prigozhin argument fester without dealing with it decisivelyâ€. â€œAs the confrontation reached a critical stage, the masses were not running out onto the streets to support [Putin] â€¦ Those urging Prigozhin to back off did so in regretful tones â€¦ without going out of their way to praise Putin as a glorious and irreplaceable war leader, whose judgement bordered on the infallible and whose bravery moved all those who witnessed it,â€ he continued. â€œPutin will be aware that at this vital moment when his position was under the greatest threat, many were watching to see what happened next.â€

Title: What future awaits Russiaâ€™s Wagner army and its boss, Prigozhin?
Subtitle: Observers say Yevgeny Prigozhin is â€˜doomedâ€™ after turning on Russian President Vladimir Putin, known for vindictiveness towards turncoat allies.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraine â€“Back in 2013, the year after Vladimir Putinâ€™s return to presidency and the year before Moscow annexed Crimea, Aleksandra Garmazhapova got an undercover job. The investigative reporter briefly worked as an â€œonline operatorâ€ typing up hundreds of pro-Kremlin comments from a snow-white office outside St Petersburg, Russiaâ€™s second-largest city and Putinâ€™s hometown. The office reportedly hosted a â€œtroll farmâ€ that belonged toYevgeny Prigozhin, known at the time as â€œPutinâ€™s chefâ€ for his catering services to the Kremlin. Garmazhapovaâ€™s story was a major scoop that put the now infamous â€œtroll farmsâ€ on the map and eventually got their owner blacklisted by Washington for meddling in the US presidential election in 2016. She is confident that afterWagnerâ€™s marchon Moscow, that stopped only 200km (124 miles) south of the Russian capital, â€œPutinâ€™s chefâ€ is a doomed man. â€œHeâ€™s not going to live long,â€ said Garmazhapova, who lives in Prague and was recently accused of â€œspreading fakes about the Russian armyâ€. She now runs a group helping thousands of Russian men escape mobilisation. â€œWe remember that Vladimir Putin is a pretty vindictive character, and he wonâ€™t forget the fact that he was humiliated in front of the entire world,â€ she told Al Jazeera.  After Prigozhin agreed to march Wagner back to southwestern Russia, Putin dropped incursion charges against him and his men and allowed them to relocate toBelarus. Even if Prigozhin is pressured to leave Belarus, he still has strongholds in Syria and several sub-Saharan nations, where Wagner fought and still has lucrative security contracts and stakes in timber trade and mining. â€œAfrica awaits him, Syria awaits, thereâ€™s no one down there to replace him,â€ Marat Gabidullin, a former Wagner mercenary who fled to France and wrote about his experiences, told Al Jazeera. â€œHis projects there can be called successful.â€ Alas, on Tuesday, the Al Hadath television channel in Saudia Arabia claimed that Russian military police raided Wagner headquarters in Syria and arrested four Wagner commanders. Africa may become Prigozhinâ€™s last resort, reporter Garmazhapova said. â€œIt canâ€™t be ruled out that Prigozhin will have to spend the rest of his life in the Central African Republic or some other African nation,â€ she said. But Putin has indeed been notorious for punishment, especially to turncoat allies and colleagues. One of them was Aleksander Litvinenko, an intelligence officer who accused Putin of allegedly ordering several residential buildings blown up so that attacks could be blamed on Chechen separatists. Litvinenko, who defected to the United Kingdom, was lethally poisoned with radioactive polonium-210 in 2006 after Putin repeatedly called him a â€œtraitorâ€. Analysts have been less inclined to think about Prigozhinâ€™s imminent murder, but are puzzled about whatâ€™s going to happen to him and tens of thousands of Wagner fighters. â€œIs all of Wagner â€“ or what is left of it â€“ going to be incorporated into Russiaâ€™s armed forces? If so, what will happen to Wagner units outside of its immediate vicinity â€“ in Syria, Africa, and elsewhere?â€ Kevork Oskanian of the UKâ€™s Exeter University told Al Jazeera. â€œBeyond the appearance that Prigozhin has been well and truly expelled from the Russian elite because of his miscalculation, it is really difficult to say,â€ he said. Prigozhinâ€™s life and career have been truly protean. At 62, he has the charisma of former US President Donald Trump and the business acumen of Eric Prince, the founder of theBlackwater private army, according to John Lechner, an author based in Washington, DC, who is writing a book on Prigozhinâ€™s operations in Ukraine, Middle East and Africa. â€œHe is a mix of people such as Prince, Trump, founders of Silicon Valley companies, and, of course, this mafia type, who speaks prison slang,â€ Lechner told Al Jazeera. â€œHe knows how to build a companyâ€™s culture, knows how to make people admire him, be loyal to him.â€     Contrary to media reports, Prigozhin did not found Wagner, but joined the nascent military company around 2015 as a food supplier, Lechner said. â€œI can imagine a step from providing food to providing people, soldiers. In principle, he replaced what he provides,â€ he said. Food was what made Prigozhin famous. Putin hosted several dignitaries in Prigozhinâ€™s riverboat restaurant, and awarded him contracts to supply food to the military and public schools. The food was not as good as the delicacies served to Putin, and hundreds of servicemen and schoolchildren have reportedly been hospitalised after partaking in it. But Putin did not seem to care about the poisonings â€“ and his â€œchefâ€™sâ€ checkered past. Prigozhin spent most of the 1980s in jail after being convicted of armed robberies and recruiting minors into a criminal gang. Recruitment and knowledge of prison slang are what Prigozhin excelled at â€“ especially when touring dozens of penitentiaries last year to enlist tens of thousands of inmates. Wagner was founded by Dmitry Utkin, a former special forces officer with a penchant for Nazi ideology and the music of Adolf Hitlerâ€™s favourite composer, Richard Wagner. The group fought for pro-Russian separatists in southeastern Ukraine in 2014. One of them was Igor Strelkov, who fell out with Prigozhin after his men allegedly killed separatist leaders who disobeyed Moscow. Strelkov maintains that Prigozhinâ€™s Belarusian banishment means that his powerful allies within the Kremlin still back him. In a Tuesday Telegram post, he claimed that Prigozhin will turn into â€œanother [Mikhail] Khodorkovsky,â€ a Russian tycoon who opposed Putin and served 10 years in jail. â€œThe difference is that Khodorkovsky â€˜wanted [a coup], but didnâ€™t dare try, but the â€˜chefâ€™ â€˜tried but chickened out,â€™â€ Stelkov wrote. On Tuesday morning, Prigozhinâ€™s private jet landed near the Belarusian capital, Minsk. â€œYes, he is in Belarus. As I promised him â€“ if you choose to switch sides with us for a while, weâ€™ll help you,â€ said Belarusian President Aleksander Lukashenko, who brokered a truce between Prigozhin and Putin. But Wagnerâ€™s operations in Russia have not been terminated. Its recruitment centres in five St Petersburg sports clubs still enlist aspiring mercenaries, the Bumaga publication, an independent news website based in St Petersburg, found out. Wagner â€œhas not been liquidated or outlawed, everything keeps on working,â€ one of the managers told Bumaga.    Several publications connected to Prigozhinâ€™s media empire are blocked, and companies affiliated with him stopped working, Bumaga reported. The Wagner Center in a luxurious skyscraper in St Petersburg has also remained closed. â€œBecause of the current situation and good weather, the Center recommends its residents and staffers to spend the weekend outdoors and in good company!â€ its administration posted on Saturday. Prigozhinâ€™s presence in Belarus will be a constant threat to Putin â€“ especially if thousands of his mercenaries refuse to join the Russian army and move to the bases that Belarusian authorities are reportedly building. â€œWagner in Belarus will hang over Putin,â€ Kyiv-based analyst Aleksey Kushch told Al Jazeera. Prigozhin may even try to seize the Kremlin again â€“ via the Smolensk road Napoleon used in 1812 to invade Russia and take Moscow. â€œA march towards Smolensk and Moscow can be as fast as the one to Rostov-on-Don [where the Saturdayâ€™s rebellion began] and farther towards the capital,â€ Kushch said. Wagner will operate in Belarus with even more impunity given the weakness of Lukashenkoâ€™s police and army, he said. â€œLetâ€™s not bury Wagner quite yet. Belarusian law enforcement agencies will counter Wagner even less than the Russian guards,â€ he said.

Title: Russia to continue work in CAR, Wagner business separate: Kremlin
Subtitle: The fate of Wagner mercenaries at home and in parts of Africa is uncertain after its abortive mutiny in Russia on Saturday.
Content: Russian advisers will continue working with the forces of the Central African Republic, but the operations there of the Wagner Group are the private military contractorâ€™s own, separate business, the Kremlin says. The Kremlin statement on Wednesday concerns a country with which Russia has had close ties with in recent years. Hundreds of Russian operatives, including many from the Wagner Group, have been helping its government fight rebel uprisings against President Faustin-Archange Touadera since 2018. And Touadera is scheduled to attend the second Russia-Africa Summit in St Petersburg in July. But Wagnerâ€™s fate is uncertain after its abortive mutiny in Russia on Saturday. This week, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told state broadcaster Russia Today that Wagnerâ€™s work in CAR â€œas instructors â€¦ will continueâ€ and that the weekendâ€™s events would not impact relations between Moscow and its partners and allies. Meanwhile, Bangui has remained upbeat about the situation with minister and presidential adviser FidÃ¨le Gouandjika telling the Agence France-Presse news agency that what the country had in place was â€œa defence deal with Russia and not Wagner. â€¦ Moscow has subcontracted to Wagner, and if Russia doesnâ€™t agree, it will send us a new contingent.â€ The mercenary group has been accused of multiple human rights abuses in CAR, Burkina Faso and Mali. And no, there are questions about whether the group could still be seen as a stabilising force for tackling armed groups after its mutiny in Russia. â€œThey will be seen as too unstable and potentially a threat to the leadership in those countries,â€ Michael Mulroy, a former senior Pentagon official, told the Reuters news agency. â€œThey almost started a coup in their own [country].â€

Title: Wagner boss Prigozhin has arrived in Belarus, says Lukashenko
Subtitle: The Belarusian leader confirms that Wagner forces are in Belarus as he hails his own role in halting the recent mutiny.
Content: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko has confirmed that the head of the Wagner paramilitary group, Yevgeny Prigozhin, has arrived in the country. He said he offered the mercenary group an abandoned military site where they could â€œput their tents while thinking what to do nextâ€. Lukashenko is said to have brokered a deal which narrowly prevented Wagner mercenaries from marching on Moscow after theprivate army mutiniedagainst Russiaâ€™s military leaders. Lukashenko said there would be no Wagner recruitment points in Belarus but the nationâ€™s citizens may join the group and issued an ominous warning that those who make such a decision should realise the â€œdanger of deathâ€ for the job. Commenting on reasons that led to the mutiny, the Belarusian leader said it was an â€œinterpersonal conflictâ€ between Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Prigozhin â€œescalated into this fightâ€. â€œI know the work of Shoigu. Undeservedly he is sometimes criticised,â€ he said.    Lukashenko asked that he not be called â€œa mediatorâ€, arguing he was â€œa participantâ€ because it was a common problem for Russia and Belarus. He also said lessons have to be learned from the situation with the mutiny. â€œWe need to be more attentive to such military collectives if we have spawned them. And we need to respond to their requests in time.â€ Putinâ€™s supporters have insisted that his rule was not weakened by the revolt. Asked whether Putinâ€™s power was diminished by the sight of Wagnerâ€™s rebel mercenaries seizing a military headquarters, advancing on Moscow and shooting down military aircraft along the way, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov accused political commentators of exaggerating, adding that: â€œWe donâ€™t agree.â€ Putin himself attempted to portray the dramatic events at the weekend as a victory for the Russian army. â€œYou de facto stopped civil war,â€ Putin told troops from the defence ministry, National Guard, FSB security service and interior ministry gathered in a Kremlin courtyard to hold a minuteâ€™s silence for airmen slain by Wagner.

Title: NATO will defend members from threat of Wagner forces in Belarus
Subtitle: Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg says the military alliance will protect members from threats by either â€˜Moscow or Minskâ€™.
Content: NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has said the Western military alliance is ready to defend itself against any threat posed by the move of Russiaâ€™sWagner mercenary force to Belarusamid fears the relocation of the private army could create instability for NATOâ€™s Eastern European members. Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin was reported to have arrived in Belarus on Tuesday under a deal negotiated by Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, which narrowly prevented the mercenaries from marching on Moscow on Saturday after theprivate army mutiniedagainst Russiaâ€™s military leaders. â€œIf Wagner deploys its serial killers in Belarus, all neighbouring countries face even bigger danger of instability,â€ Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda said after a meeting in The Hague with NATOâ€™s Stoltenberg and government leaders from six other NATO allies. Polish President Andrzej Duda said he hoped the threat posed by Wagner mercenaries to NATO would be on the agenda at a summit of all 31 members in Vilnius, Lithuania, on July 11-12. â€œThis is really serious and very concerning, and we have to make very strong decisions. It requires a very, very tough answer of NATO,â€ Duda said.    NATOâ€™s Stoltenberg said it was too early to say what the Wagner presence in Belarus could mean for NATO allies, but that the military alliance would protect â€œevery ally, every inch of NATO territoryâ€ against threats from either â€œMoscow or Minskâ€. â€œWe have already increased our military presence in the eastern part of the alliance and we will make further decisions to further strengthen our collective defence with more high-readiness forces and more capabilities at the upcoming summit,â€ Stoltenberg said. Prigozhin hasnot been seen since Saturday, when he waved to well-wishers from a vehicle in the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don, which his fighters briefly occupied. On Tuesday morning, a private jet believed to belong to Prigozhin flew from Rostov to an airbase southwest of the Belarusian capital of Minsk, according to data from FlightRadar24. Amid the fallout from Prigozhinâ€™s mutiny against Moscow, Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s supporters have insisted his rule has not been weakened by the revolt and that Russian officials have been trying to put the crisis behind them, with the FSB intelligence service dropping all criminal charges against Wagner fighters. Putin has also attempted to shore up his authority by thanking regular Russian troops for what he described as averting a civil war and has portrayed events over the weekend as a sort of victory for the Russian army.    â€œYou de facto stopped civil war,â€ Putin told troops from Russiaâ€™s defence ministry, National Guard, FSB security service and interior ministry who gathered in a Kremlin courtyard on Tuesday. â€œYou proved your loyalty to the people of Russia and the military oath,â€ Putin said, before holding a minute of silence for the airmen shot down and killed by Wagner forces on Saturday. In a separate meeting with defence officials, Putin said for the first time that the Wagner Group was wholly funded by the Russian federal budget, despite operating as an independent mercenary force. He added that since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, Moscow has paid the group 86.262 billion rubles (about $1bn) in salaries. Moscow has said that preparations were under way for Wagner fighters still in Ukraine, who number about 25,000 according to Prigozhin, to hand over their heavy weapons to Russiaâ€™s military.    Talking to his military officials on Tuesday,Belarusâ€™s Lukashenkosaid he had urged Putin not to kill the rebellious mercenary boss Prigozhin. â€œI said to Putin: we could waste him, no problem. If not on the first try, then on the second. I told him: donâ€™t do this,â€ Lukashenko said, according to state media. Lukashenko also said that his military can learn much from the Wagner mercenaries. â€œThey were at the very front of the attacking troops. They will tell us whatâ€™s important now,â€ Lukashenko said, according to the Belarusian news agency Belta. Wagner fighters could report on which weapons worked well in Ukraine and how attack and defence could be conducted successfully, Lukashenko was reported to have said.    â€œThis is very valuable. We have to get this from the Wagner fighters,â€ Lukashenko said, adding that the mercenary troops were still in their bases in the Russian-occupied Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine. â€œBut if they would like â€“ and I understand that they are looking at a number of locations â€“ then we will accommodate them,â€ he said. The Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a Washington, DC-based think tank, said on Monday that Russian-language opposition media had reported that Belarus was in the process of constructing several military camps to house the Wagner fighters. The think tank added that a base, which would accommodate up to 8,000 fighters, was in the process of being constructed in the countryâ€™s Mogilev region, located approximately 200km (124 miles) east of Minsk. The ISW also said that Belarus is unlikely to be a truly safe place for Wagner fighters if Putin decides to renege on his deal to not prosecute them for mutiny. â€œBelarus will not offer Prigozhin or Wagner fighters a true haven if the Kremlin pressures Belarus,â€ the ISW said. â€œPutin may be presenting Belarus as a haven for Wagner fighters as a trap. The Kremlin will likely regard the Wagner Group personnel who follow Prigozhin to Belarus as traitors whether or not it takes immediate action against them,â€ it said. Putin is also attempting to destroy Prigozhinâ€™s reputation among his fighters and within Russian society, the ISW said on Wednesday. NEW:#Putinis trying to present#WagnerGroupfinancier Yevgeny#Prigozhinas corrupt and a liar to destroy his reputation among#Wagnerpersonnel and within Russian society. The ongoing Putin-#Lukashenko-Prigozhin powerplay is not yet over.ğŸ§µhttps://t.co/4A8bWmWlVlpic.twitter.com/NUDNdWoLNf â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)June 28, 2023   The Russian leader has â€œlikely decided that he cannot directly eliminate Prigozhin without making him a martyr at this timeâ€, the institute said. â€œThe Kremlin will likely continue to attack Prigozhinâ€™s character to break Prigozhinâ€™s popular support, discourage Wagner personnel from following him to Belarus, and destroy his financial power.â€

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 490
Subtitle: As the war enters it 490th day, these are the main developments.
Content: This is the situation as it stands on Wednesday, June 28, 2023.

Title: Russia bombs busy Ukraine restaurant
Subtitle: At least eight killed and dozens injured after Russian missile hits crowded pizza restaurant in centre of Kramatorsk.
Content: Three children were among the victims of a Russian missile attack on Kramatorsk city in eastern Ukraine that has killed at least eight people and injured dozens more, officials said. Russia fired two S-300 surface-to-air missiles at the city on Tuesday evening, authorities said, with one missile hitting the popular Ria Pizza restaurant in the city centre. A second missile struck a village on the fringes of the city, injuring five. â€œAs of 07:00 (04:00 GMT) on June 28, the bodies of eight dead people (including three children, two of them born in 2008 and 2011)â€ were removed from beneath â€œthe rubble of the destroyed cafe buildingâ€, the State Emergency Service of Ukraine said on Telegram. Ukraineâ€™s interior ministry also confirmed one of the bodies pulled from the ruins of the restaurant was a teenager, while a baby was among the 47 who were injured. The restaurant was hit just before 8pm local time (17:00 GMT) when many people were eating dinner. Emergency services rushed to the scene. Photos showed twisted metal and piles of rubble with rescuers using cranes and other equipment to get to those trapped inside and dozens of volunteers working alongside them. â€œThere were a lot of people in there â€” there are children under the rubble,â€ Yevgen, who had been dining with two friends told the AFP news agency. â€œWe were just about to leave,â€ he said, but one of his friends was now â€œunder the rubbleâ€. In tears, a witness Natalia said her half-brother Nikita, 23, was trapped inside. â€œThey canâ€™t get him out, he was coveredâ€ by debris, she said. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said in his nightly video message that the attacks showed that Russia â€œdeserved only one thing as a consequence of what it has done â€” defeat and a tribunalâ€. Kramatorsk was one home to about 150,000 people and is about 30km (18 miles) west of the front lines in Donetsk province. The city has been afrequent target of Russian attacks, including a raid on its railway station in April 2022 that killed 63 people. Russia denies that it targets civilian sites. The attack came amid the continuing fallout from the Wagner mutiny with the leader of the mercenary force, Yevgeny Prigozhin, arriving in neighbouring Belarus, according to President Alexander Lukashenko. Prigozhin, 62, said he launched the mutiny to save his armed group after being ordered to place it under the command of the defence ministry, which he has cast as ineffectual in its conduct ofthe war in Ukraine. His fighters ended their campaign on Saturday to avert bloodshed after nearly reaching Moscow in a convoy of tanks.  Lukashenko, who has ruled Belarus with an iron hand for 29 years while relying on Russian subsidies and support,portrayed the uprisingas the latest development in the clash between Prigozhin and Russian Defence Minister Sergey Shoigu. He said he had told Prigozhin he would be â€œsquashed like a bugâ€ if he tried to attack Moscow, and warned the Kremlin would never agree to his demands to remove Shoigu and his top generals. A plane linked to Prigozhin was shown on a flight tracking service taking off from the southern Russian city of Rostov early Tuesday and landing in Belarus. Lukashenko said his country would accommodate Wagner fighters who wanted to go there. â€œWe offered them one of the abandoned military bases. Please â€“ we have a fence, we have everything â€“ put up your tents,â€ Lukashenko was quoted by the state-run news agency BELTA.  Russian authorities said on Tuesday they closed a criminal investigation into the aborted armed rebellion led by Prigozhin and would press no charges against him or his troops. The Federal Security Service, or FSB, said its investigation found those involved in the mutiny, which lasted less than 24 hours, â€œceased activities directed at committing the crime,â€ so the case would not be pursued. It was the latest twist in a series of stunning events that have broughtthe gravest threat so farto President Vladimir Putinâ€™s grip on power following Moscowâ€™s full scale invasion of Ukraine 16 months ago. In a military ceremony,Â Putin told about 2,500 Russian security personnel the people and the armed forces stood together in opposition to the rebel mercenaries.Â â€œYou have saved our motherland from upheaval. In fact, you have stopped a civil war,â€ he said. Putin was joined by Shoigu whose dismissal had been one of the mutineersâ€™ main demands. He also praised Wagner troopsâ€™actions in Ukraineand credited those who â€œdidnâ€™t engage in fratricidal bloodshed and stopped on the brinkâ€. That was â€œlikely in an effort to retain themâ€ in the fight in Ukraine because Moscow needs â€œtrained and effective manpowerâ€ as it faces a Ukrainian counteroffensive, according to a Washington-based think tank. The Institute for the Study of War also noted the break between Putin and Prigozhin was probably beyond repair, and providing the Wagner chief and his loyalists with Belarus as an apparent safe haven could be a trap.

Title: UN documents summary execution of 77 Ukrainian civilians
Subtitle: A United Nations monitoring mission in Ukraine finds both Russia and Ukraine guilty of breaching international law.
Content: A United Nations mission in Ukraine has expressed grave concern over the summary execution of more than 70 Ukrainian civilians by Russian forces while also documenting other breaches of international law by both warring sides. The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) on Tuesday released its findings gathered between the start ofRussiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of its neighbouring countryin February last year to May of this year. â€œOHCHR is gravely concerned by the summary execution of 77 civilians â€“ 72 men and 5 women â€“ while they were arbitrarily detained by the Russian Federation, and the further death of one detainee (a man) as a result of torture, inhumane detention conditions and/or denial of necessary medical care,â€ read the report, referring to the UNâ€™s Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights. The UN agency also documented 864 cases of arbitrary detention by Russian troops, many of which also amounted to enforced disappearances. It also reported the detention of 260 civilians â€œbased on their perceived political views or other legitimate exercise of freedom of expressionâ€. The true number of cases might vary considering that Russia did not provide OHCHR with any access to conflict-related detainees, despite repeated requests, the UN agency said. More than 90 percent of the reported cases described being subjected to torture and ill-treatment, including sexual violence. â€œSuch treatment appeared to be carried out to force the victims to confess to provision of assistance to Ukrainian armed forces, to compel them to cooperate with the occupying authorities, or to intimidate those considered to hold pro-Ukrainian views,â€ said the report.    Ukrainian security forces have also been found guilty of unlawfully detaining at least 75 individuals â€“ mostly suspected of conflict-related criminal offences. They also held 65 civilians incommunicado to extract confessions. â€œFifty-seven percent of interviewed detainees described being subjected to torture and ill-treatment by Ukraine, predominantly in unofficial places of detention and, to a lesser extent, in pre-trial detention facilities,â€ it said. OHCHR also raised concern over the â€œvagueness and overly broadâ€ wording of a law introduced in Ukraine in March last year that established criminal liability for collaborationists. Under this law, the office of Ukraineâ€™s prosecutor general opened more than 5,400 criminal proceedings leading to 500 guilty verdicts. â€œThe vagueness and overly broad terminology in the legal provisions raise concerns with respect to the principle of legality and have led to arbitrary detention in a number of cases,â€ the UN agency said. So far, Ukraine has convicted 23 Russians, OHCHR said, adding that it was not aware of any criminal proceeding launched against Ukrainians involved in arbitrary detention or enforced disappearance.

Title: â€˜Donâ€™t see why notâ€™: China envoy on backing Ukraineâ€™s â€™91 borders
Subtitle: Chinaâ€™s EU envoy, Fu Cong, says Beijing respects the territorial integrity of all countries and stands for peace.
Content: Brussels, Belgium â€“Chinaâ€™s envoy to the European Union has suggested that Beijing could back Ukraineâ€™s aims of reclaiming its 1991 territorial integrity, which includes Crimea â€“ the peninsula annexed by Russia in 2014. In a recent interview with Al Jazeera and two other media outlets, when Fu Cong was asked about supporting Kyivâ€™s goals, which includes reclaiming other Ukrainian regions now occupied by Russia, the senior Chinese diplomat said: â€œI donâ€™t see why not. â€œWe respect the territorial integrity of all countries. So when China established relations with the former Soviet Union, thatâ€™s what we agreed.
