Title: Timeline: How Wagner Groupâ€™s revolt against Russia unfolded
Subtitle: Feud with Wagner Group owner Yevgeny Prigozhin is seen as the biggest threat Russian President Vladimir Putin has faced to his 22-year rule.
Content: Mutinous Russian mercenary fighters from theWagner Groupwere making their way to the capital before their leader Yevgeny Prigozhin ordered their to return to base to avoid bloodshed. This latest incident with Prigozhin in a months-long feud with Russiaâ€™s defence ministry over the fight in Ukraine was the biggest threat President Vladimir Putin has faced in his 22-year rule. The group rose to prominence after taking an increasinglyvisible role in the war in Ukraine, including hoisting the Russian flag in the city of Bakhmut after a months-long battle. Here is a timeline of how the events unfolded since Friday:

Title: Wagner mutiny reflects fault lines in Russia: Analysts
Subtitle: Ukraine war has produced â€˜entitlement-carrying actorsâ€™ who have now clashed, moving the military action inside Russia, observers say.
Content: There was a meme, â€œBombing Voronezhâ€, poking fun at how Russiaâ€™s government responds to sanctions in ways that hurt itself. Today, the meme has become a reality as, afterseizing the city of Rostov, mutinous Wagner mercenaries advance on the actual city of Voronezh, halfway to Moscow. â€œI saw clouds of smoke from where the oil depot blew up, not far from my house,â€ 25-year-old Olesya from Voronezh told Al Jazeera. â€œPeriodically, [people] post videos of how in different parts of the city either a shell is falling, or theyâ€™re shooting, or they blow up a car. There are lots of soldiers on the streets. My family and I do not leave the house, but just in case weâ€™ve packed our things.â€ Olesya told Al Jazeera she has not heard of any casualties yet. Early on Saturday, Wagner troops took control of Rostov, one of Russiaâ€™s largest cities, meeting minimal resistance from local security forces and occupying the regional military headquarters. A video soon emerged ofWagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhinmeeting with senior Russian defence officials in Rostov. The oligarch and former Kremlin ally hasclaimedhis actions are not an attempted coup but a â€œmarch of justiceâ€ against the military high command that has â€œdestroyed many tens of thousands of Russian soldiersâ€™ livesâ€. Marat Gabidullin, a former Wagner fighter who was deployed in Syria, told Al Jazeera he believed Prigozhin â€œoverestimated his genius, as it happened to him beforeâ€, and does not think the mutiny will succeed. But from a military point of view, Gabidullin added, Wagner is in the right place. â€œHeâ€™s in a strong position for negotiations: he managed to capture the headquarters of the [Southern Military District] group, located within the boundaries of a large city,â€ he explained. â€œThe headquarters are his hostages. To smoke him out of there, you need to attract large forces. His mercenaries have learned to fight in the city; starting an operation against them means deploying a lot of military personnel.â€    But Wagnerâ€™s revolt has implications aboutPresident Vladimir Putinâ€˜s grip on power, the Russian war effort, and the state of affairs at home. â€œAmong the few remaining sources of authority for the Putin regime was his longstanding claim that he restored â€˜law and orderâ€™ after the â€˜chaoticâ€™ 1990s,â€ Kevork Oskanian, lecturer in comparative politics at the University of Exeter, told Al Jazeera. â€œThis perception will now lie in tatters and leave him much more vulnerable over the longer term, even if he eventually prevails.â€ Historically, much of Putinâ€™s popularity rested on restoring stability in Russiansâ€™ lives: During the post-Soviet collapse of the 1990s, Russia was plagued with turf wars between organised crime syndicates, pyramid schemes robbed citizens of money, an attempted coup left more than one hundred corpses on the streets of Moscow, while a real war raged with Chechen separatists to the south. He did this by incorporating a wide set of business, political, religious and even criminal interests into what has been termed his â€œpower verticalâ€. Up until now, he has been able to balance the competing interests of the Russian elite with a great level of success. But as the war in Ukraine has dragged on with no clear path to victory in sight, that hasempoweredplayers such as Prigozhin, as well as Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov â€“ who commands his own private militia known as â€œthe kadyrovtsyâ€ â€“ at the expense of the official armed forces. â€œThe current unravelling of the seeming Russian political stability reflects the internal pressures and the fault lines of a country that waged an unjust and disastrous war with its neighbour,â€ Gulnaz Sharafutdinova, professor of Russian politics at Kingâ€™s College London, told Al Jazeera. â€œThe war produced the inter-elite pressures, blame-shifting games and the entitlement-carrying actors who have now openly clashed, thereby moving the military action inside Russia.â€

Title: Wagner revolt in Russia dims outlook for its operations in Africa
Subtitle: Mali and CAR sought closer ties with Russia and military support to fight armed groups in both countries.
Content: A revolt by theWagnerforce in Russia poses a diplomatic quandary for Mali and Central African Republic (CAR), where forces from the mercenary group have played anincreasingly central rolein long-running internal conflicts. As the Wagner fighters barrelled towards Moscow on Saturday after seizing a southern city overnight, spokespeople for the governments of Mali and CAR declined to comment on the turmoil and how it might affect their security strategies against armed groups. Both countries havesought closer tieswith Russia and military support to battle the armed fighters, saying in the past that their military cooperation agreements are with Russia rather than with Wagner. â€œ[Wagnerâ€™s] presence in Mali is sponsored by the Kremlin and if Wagner is at odds with the Kremlin â€¦ naturally Mali will suffer the consequences on the security front,â€ said Malian political analyst Bassirou Doumbia. Mali, where military authorities seized power in coups in 2020 and 2021, is battling a years-long operation against armed groups affiliated with ISIL (ISIS) and al-Qaeda. It has said Russian forces there are not Wagner mercenaries but trainers helping local troops with equipment bought from Russia. But the alliance has soured relations with the United Nations and alienated Western powers, who have said the fighters are Wagner forces and have alleged that they have committedpossible war crimesalongside Malian soldiers. The governments in Mali and Russia have denied the allegations. Wagnerâ€™s continued presence in Mali amid the continuing insurrection in Russia could prove problematic for Bamakoâ€™s relations with Moscow, which last year committed to send Mali shipments of fuel, fertiliser and food worth about $100m. â€œ[The] exact consequences for Mali really depend on factors largely unknown such as the organisational autonomy of Wagner and their chain of command, and, of course, whether things escalate or not between [Russian President Vladimir] Putin and Wagner,â€ said Yvan Guichaoua, senior lecturer at the Brussels School of International Studies. He said there were no reports of unexpected troop movements in Mali as of Saturday morning. The power struggle in Russia could also have significant ramifications for CAR, wherehundreds of Russian operatives, including many from Wagner, have been helping the government fight several rebel insurgencies since 2018. Both CAR and Mali have been drawn increasingly into Russiaâ€™s orbit in recent years as the Kremlin sought greater influence inFrancophone Africato the dismay of former colonial power France, which has faced anti-French protests in the region and worsening relations with several West African governments. In February, French President Emmanuel Macron described the deployment of Wagner troops in Africa as the â€œlife insurance of failing regimes in Africaâ€ that will only sow misery. A suspension of Wagner operations in Africa could impact the groupâ€™s finances. The United States last October accused the mercenaries of exploiting natural resources in CAR, Mali and elsewhere to fund fighting in Ukraine â€“ a charge Russia rejected at the time. Wagner began operating in Africa and the Middle East when it was founded in 2014 and was thought to have about 5,000 fighters, but has grown significantly since then. The paramilitary group made a name for itself internationally through its involvement in Russiaâ€™s annexation of Ukraineâ€™sCrimean Peninsula in 2014, a move widely viewed as illegal by the international community. The group has also been involved in the continuing Russia-Ukraine war that began in February 2022 after Wagner forces were deployed in Ukraine on March 28, 2022. The group has 50,000 active fighters in Ukraine, according to British intelligence. According to the US National Security Council, while about 80 percent of its troops in Ukraine were withdrawn from prisons, it was stated that Wagner was effective in Russiaâ€™s alleged capture ofBakhmutin eastern Ukraineâ€™s Donetsk region. Wagner has also sent fighters outside Ukraine to various conflicts in the Middle East and Africa, including the war inSyria. The group has cemented strong ties with several African governments over the past decade with operations in at least eight African nations, according to leaked US documents.

Title: Wagner boss calls off march on Moscow, agrees to exile in Belarus
Subtitle: Backdown by Yevgeny Prigozhin came after Belarusâ€™s leader negotiated with him to end the mutiny.
Content: Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin ordered his mercenaries to halt their march on Moscow to avoid â€œshedding Russian bloodâ€ and agreed to live in exile in Belarus â€“ ending one of the biggest challenges to President Vladimir Putinâ€™s decades-long rule. Prigozhin said while his men were just 200km (120 miles) from the Russian capital, he decided on Saturday to turn them back to prevent killings. â€œThey wanted to disband the Wagner military company. We embarked on a march of justice on June 23. Now, the moment has come when blood could be spilled,â€ said Prigozhin in an audio message. â€œUnderstanding responsibility [for the chance] that Russian blood will be spilled on one side, we are turning our columns around and going back to field camps as planned.â€  Moscow braced for the arrival of the private army led by the rebellious mercenary commander by erecting checkpoints with armoured vehicles and troops on its southern edge. Red Square was shut down and the mayor urged motorists to stay off some roads. Wagnerâ€™s lightning insurrection appeared to develop with little pushback from Russiaâ€™s regular armed forces, raising questions aboutPutinâ€™s grip on powerin the nuclear-armed nation even after the abrupt halt to Wagnerâ€™s advance.    Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko negotiated with the mercenary boss to stop Wagnerâ€™s troop movement after discussing the issue with Putin. Prigozhin accepted Lukashenkoâ€™s offer to halt the Wagner groupâ€™s advance and further steps to de-escalate the tensions, Lukashenkoâ€™s office said, adding the proposed settlement contains security guarantees for Wagner troops. Prigozhin did not say whether the Kremlin responded to his demand toremove Defence Minister Sergey Shoigu. The Wagner chief will move to neighbouring Belarus as part of the deal and the criminal case against him will be closed, the Kremlin said on Saturday. Prigozhinâ€™s troops who joined him in the uprising will not face prosecution and those who did not will be offered contracts by the defence ministry, spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. Lukashenko offered to mediate, with Putinâ€™s agreement, because he had known Prigozhin personally for about 20 years, Peskov said.Â â€œAvoiding bloodshed, internal confrontation, and clashes with unpredictable results was the highest goal.â€ Putin faced the biggest threat to his 22-year rule yet with rebel mercenaries advancing towards the Russian capital after seizing a key southern military base. Wagner began pulling back fighters and equipment from the Russian city of Rostov-on-Don late on Saturday. Pavel Felgenhauer, a Russian defence analyst, said it remained to be seen how the incident plays out. â€œWhatâ€™s really going to happen, weâ€™ll have to see tomorrow. And who actually did give which concessions to whom,â€ he told Al Jazeera. â€œCeasefires donâ€™t hold that easily. Before you see the small print, itâ€™s not the time to say that itâ€™s over. It can easily unravel in an hour or two, or tomorrow.â€ Anna Matveeva, from the Russia Institute at Kingâ€™s College London, said the events marked a significant change for Russiaâ€™s political landscape. â€œItâ€™s the first chapter in Russiaâ€™s political transition. Thatâ€™s the opening bid. We will see more developments to come,â€ she told Al Jazeera. If he accedes to Prigozhinâ€™s demand to remove Shoigu, Prigozhin would emerge from the crisis as a clear winner in a major blow to Putinâ€™s authority. If Prigozhin agreed not to press the demand, Putin could award him with more lucrative government contracts like those on which he has built his fortune in the past. However, it would be awkward and politically damaging for Putin to backtrack after branding Prigozhin a backstabbing traitor. Some observers speculated that Prigozhin could make concessions such as putting the Wagner Group under federal authority, or he could shift the forceâ€™sactivities back to Africa, where his mercenaries have been active in recent years. In a televised speech to the nation, Putin called the rebellion a â€œbetrayalâ€ and â€œtreasonâ€. â€œAll those who prepared the rebellion will suffer inevitable punishment,â€ Putin said. â€œThe armed forces and other government agencies have received the necessary orders.â€ Authorities declared a â€œcounterterrorist regimeâ€ in the capital and its surrounding region, enhancing security and restricting some movement.Â On the southern outskirts, troops erected checkpoints, arranged sandbags and set up machine guns. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said on Saturday the revolt by Wagner troops exposed complete chaos in the country. â€œToday, the world can see that the masters of Russia control nothing. And that means nothing. Simply complete chaos. An absence of any predictability,â€ Zelenskyy said in his nightly video address. Addressing Putin while switching from Ukrainian to Russian language, Zelenskyy said, â€œThe longer your troops remain on Ukrainian land, the greater the devastation they will bring to Russia.â€

Title: Ukraine responds to Wagner mutiny in Russia with caution, hope
Subtitle: While the leadership in Kyiv is weighing how best to seize the moment, average Ukrainians are far less optimistic.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraineâ€” Ukraineâ€™s top military expert has said that Kyiv has to make a â€œstrategic, principal decisionâ€ on how to benefit from theunfolding turmoil in Russia. One such move could be an order to invade western Russia to bypass massive defence installations on the 1,000-kilometre-long (620-mile-long) front line in eastern and southern Ukraine, according to Lieutenant General Ihor Romanenko. â€œThose who make unorthodox decisions and implement them will succeed,â€ the former deputy chief of Ukraineâ€™s general staff of armed forces told Al Jazeera, adding that it was time to strike Russian forces in the back. Such a plan looked like a â€œfairy taleâ€ just a day ago, but the panic and disarray in Russia as troops of theWagnerprivate military contractor march on Moscow may provide Kyiv with a perfect opportunity to deliver the least expected blow, he said. Ukraineâ€™s Western backers will, however, inevitably step in to dissuade Kyiv from such decisions to avoid Moscowâ€™s use of nuclear weapons, Romanenko added. â€œOf course, our allies will meddle, will try to influence it somehow, in the â€˜letâ€™s-not-let-something-bad-happenâ€™ way, to avoid escalation, the use of the weapons of mass destruction,â€ he said. The path to western Russia has already been paved. TheRussian Volunteer Corps(RVC), a group of fugitive Russian ultra-nationalists fighting for Ukraine, has conductedthree incursionsinto western Russian regions. They were backed by former Russian war prisoners who fight for Ukraine, as well as by volunteers from neighbouring Poland and Belarus. On June 1, they crossed into the western Russian region ofBelgorodto attack Shebekino, a city of 40,000, and seize the village ofNovaya Tavolzhanka. Tens of thousands of civilians fled Belgorod, and Novaya Tavolzhanka became Russiaâ€™s first area beyond Moscowâ€™s control. On Saturday, RVC head urged its supporters to â€œget readyâ€. The groupâ€™s head, Denis Nikitin, wrote on RVCâ€™s Telegram channel thatWagner chief YevgenyÂ Prigozhinemerged from the â€œprocesses of rot and decayâ€ in Russia. â€œAnd what we have is an ambitious patriot, popular among people and servicemen, who has his own private army; the population demoralised by the prolonged bloody war and an incoherent government. Letâ€™s get ready!â€ Nikitin wrote. While the top brass in Kyiv distanced themselves from the RVCâ€™s incursions,Â Prigozhinâ€™s rebellion caught them by surprise. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said, â€œRussiaâ€™s weakness is obviousâ€ and that the longer Moscow keeps its troops and mercenaries in Ukraine, the more chaos it would invite back home. â€œAnd the longer Russia keeps its troops and mercenaries on our land, the more chaos, pain and problems it will have for itself later,â€ Zelenskyy wrote. Everyone who chooses the path of evil destroys himself. Who sends columns of troops to destroy the lives of another country and cannot stop them from fleeing and betraying when life resists. Who terrorizes with missiles, and when they are shot down, humiliates himself to receiveâ€¦ â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)June 24, 2023  Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to Zelenskyy, tweeted, â€œThe next 48 hours will define the new status of Russia. Either a full-fledged Civil War, or a negotiated Transit of Power, or a temporary respite before the next phase of the downfall of the Putin regime.â€ â€œAll potential players are now choosing which side they are on. A deafening â€˜eliteâ€™ silence is in Russia so far,â€ he wrote. The next 48 hours will define the new status of#Russia. Either a full-fledged Civil War, or a negotiated Transit of Power, or a temporary respite before the next phase of the downfall of the#Putinregime. All potential players are now choosing which side they are on. Aâ€¦ â€” ĞœĞ¸Ñ…Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾ ĞŸĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»ÑĞº (@Podolyak_M)June 24, 2023  Meanwhile, Ukraineâ€™s foreign minister said the international community should â€œabandon false neutralityâ€ on Russia and provide Kyiv with all the weapons it needs to push Moscowâ€™s forces out of Ukrainian territory. â€œThose who said Russia was too strong to lose: look now,â€ Dmytro Kuleba tweeted. â€œTime to abandon false neutrality and fear of escalation; give Ukraine all the needed weapons; forget about friendship or business with Russia.â€ â€œTime to put an end to the evil everyone despised but was too afraid to tear down.â€ Those who said Russia was too strong to lose: look now. Time to abandon false neutrality and fear of escalation; give Ukraine all the needed weapons; forget about friendship or business with Russia. Time to put an end to the evil everyone despised but was too afraid to tear down. â€” Dmytro Kuleba (@DmytroKuleba)June 24, 2023  Russia has already experienced a war that turned into a quagmire and showed how disorganised, demoralised and badly supplied the army was. Squads of servicemen rioted and marched home, triggering popular unrest and the governmentâ€™s fall, a bloody civil war and the emergence of a totalitarian dictatorship. This is not a prediction of what may or may not happen in Russia next, but it is what took place more than a century ago, when dispirited tsarist troops left the World War I front lines to flock back to Russia. Tsar Nicholas II abdicated in 1917 after the Bolshevik Revolution, which paved the way for the Communist takeover. Russian President Vladimir Putin recalled the fear of â€œanother 1917â€ in hisnational addresson Saturday. His Ukrainian counterpart also referred to the fateful year. Putin â€œagain and again scares [Russians] with another 1917, but he canâ€™t lead it to anything else,â€ Zelenskyy tweeted. â€œUkraine is able to protect Europe from the spread of Russian evil and chaos. We keep our strength, unity and strength. All our commanders, all our soldiers know what to do,â€ Zelenskyy wrote. Average Ukrainians were far less optimistic about Russiaâ€™s possible disintegration as it may trigger the exodus of millions of refugees and the use of nuclear weapons. â€œThis is happening again, and Ukraine will suffer greatly,â€ Andriy Lokshin, who serves in the â€œterritorial defenceâ€ volunteer militia in Kyiv, told Al Jazeera. â€œWe donâ€™t need another Wedding in Malinovka,â€ he said, referring to the 1967 musical describing life in a Ukrainian village during the 1918-20 civil war in the former Russian empire. Other Ukrainians responded with schadenfreude and said that Putinâ€™s plans of a blitzkrieg in Ukraine backfired. â€œThey wanted to take Kyiv in three days, but got Rostov-on-Don in one,â€ Halyna Kerzhenets, who sells souvenirs in central Kyiv, told Al Jazeera, referring to the southwestern Russian city Prigozhin seized early on Saturday. Predictably, memes and jokes about the mutiny have been going viral. One of them ridiculed the Russian Ministry of Defenceâ€™s exaggerations while reporting Ukraineâ€™s battlefield losses. â€œ250,000 Wagner fighters were killed, 25,000 tanks destroyed, and three Prigozhins taken prisoner,â€ it read. Yet, observers saw the unfolding developments as a replay of the â€œTimes of Troubleâ€ that followed the death of Russian Tsar Ivan the Terrible more than four centuries ago. â€œAlmost a reincarnation of the algorithm of Ivan the Terribleâ€™s era, but in the mode of condensed historic time,â€ Kyiv-based analyst Aleksey Kushch told Al Jazeera. The notoriously cruel tsar was succeeded by his mentally challenged, childless son and two noblemen, as Russian nobles consolidated power and Poland tried to install its own candidates, including two â€œfalseâ€ sons of Ivan the Terrible. â€œAccording to the genreâ€™s laws, there must be an emergence of the oligarchic â€˜seven noblemenâ€™ and false-Putins, for the real Putin has enough doubles,â€ Kushch said.

Title: Turmoil in Russia: What foreign governments are saying
Subtitle: Countries are keeping a close eye on the situation in Russia as Wagner rebellion escalates instability in region.
Content: Governments around the world are closely watching the events rapidly unfolding in Russia, where arevolt by the Wagner mercenary grouphas posed the most serious challenge to President Vladimir Putinâ€™s long rule. Wagner headYevgeny Prigozhinon Saturday saidÂ his fighters had crossed from Ukraine into the Russian border city of Rostov-on-Don, taking control of military facilities in the city, including the airfield. During an emergency televised address in Moscow, Putinpromised to crushwhat he called an â€œarmed mutinyâ€ and an act of treason. Here is what governments and political institutions are saying about the extraordinary situation taking place in nuclear-armed Russia: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the Wagner mutiny showed Russia was weak. â€œRussiaâ€™s weakness is obvious. Full-scale weakness. And the longer Russia keeps its troops and mercenaries on our land, the more chaos, pain, and problems it will have for itself later,â€ he said in a statement on social media. â€œAnyone who chooses the path of evil destroys themselves,â€ Zelenskyy also wrote on Twitter. â€œFor a long time, Russia used propaganda to mask its weakness and the stupidity of its government. And now there is so much chaos that no lie can hide it.â€ Everyone who chooses the path of evil destroys himself. Who sends columns of troops to destroy the lives of another country and cannot stop them from fleeing and betraying when life resists. US President Joe Biden was briefed on the situation in Russia and Washington and â€œwill be consulting with allies and partners on these developmentsâ€, National Security Council spokesman Adam Hodge said. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the US â€œwill stay in close coordination with Allies and partners as the situation continues to developâ€. Spoke today with G7 Foreign Ministers and the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security PolicyÂ to discuss the ongoing situation in Russia. The United States will stay in close coordination with Allies and partners as the situation continues to develop. â€” Secretary Antony Blinken (@SecBlinken)June 24, 2023  British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak urged â€œall parties to be responsible and to protect civiliansâ€. â€œWeâ€™re in touch with our allies as the situation evolves. Iâ€™ll be speaking to some of them later today and the most important thing is for all parties to behave responsibly,â€ he told the BBC. The countryâ€™s defence ministry said that â€œover the coming hours, the loyalty of Russiaâ€™s security forces, and especially the Russian National Guard, will be key to how this crisis plays out.â€ â€œThis represents the most significant challenge to the Russian state in recent times,â€ it said. It added that Wagner troops had â€œalmost certainlyâ€ occupied key security sites in Rostov-on-Don and that â€œfurther Wagner units were moving north through Voronezh Oblast, almost certainly aiming to get to Moscowâ€. â€œWith very limited evidence of fighting between Wagner and Russian security forces, some have likely remained passive, acquiescing to Wagner,â€ it said. European Council chief Charles Michel tweeted the bloc was â€œclosely monitoring the situation in Russia as it unfolds. In touch with European leaders and @G7 partners. â€œThis is clearly an internal Russian issue,â€ he tweeted, adding â€œour support for Ukraineâ€ is â€œunwaveringâ€. Closely monitoring the situation in Russia as it unfolds. In touch with European leaders and@G7partners. This is clearly an internal Russian issue. Our support for Ukraine and@ZelenskyyUais unwavering. â€” Charles Michel (@CharlesMichel)June 24, 2023  President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Turkey is ready to help seek a â€œpeaceful resolutionâ€ to the armed rebellion in Russia in a phone call with his Russian counterpart. Erdogan â€œunderlined the importance of acting with common senseâ€, the presidency said in a statement. â€œPresident Erdogan said that we, as Turkey, are ready to do our part for the peaceful resolution of events in Russia as soon as possible.â€ â€œEstonia is closely following the development of the situation in Russia and exchanging information with allies. I can assure that there is no direct threat to our country. Border security has been strengthened. I also urge our people not to travel to any part of Russia,â€ said Prime Minister Kaja Kallas. We are not distracted. We see clearly in the chaos. The goal, as ever, is victory and justice for Ukraine. The time is now.â€ â€œLatvia is closely following the developing situation in Russia and exchanging information with allies. Border security has been strengthened, visa or border entry from Russians leaving Russia due to current events wonâ€™t be considered. No direct threat to Latvia at this time,â€ said Latvian Foreign Minister Edgars Rinkevics. President Andrzej Duda said: â€œIn connection with the situation in Russia, this morning we held consultations with the prime minister and the ministry of defence, as well as with allies. â€œThe course of events beyond our eastern border is monitored on an ongoing basis.â€ German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock has spoken to her counterparts within the Group of Seven industrialised nations, the foreign ministry in Berlin said, adding the German governmentâ€™s crisis team was also meeting. â€œGerman nationals in Russia should definitely take advantage of our adapted travel advice,â€ Baerbock said earlier, after the ministry told travellers to avoid Moscow city centre. German Defence Minister Boris Pistorius said it is too early to guess the possible consequences of the armed uprising and what it may mean forthe Kremlinâ€™s war on Ukraine. â€œThat is difficult to assess, especially since we do not know how unstable Russia will become and who will ultimately have the upper hand and who will join forces with whom,â€ he said. French President Emmanuel Macron â€œis following the situation very closely,â€ the Elysee said. â€œWe remain focused on supporting Ukraine.â€ Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni said the events taking place in Russia showed â€œhow the aggression against Ukraine is causing instability also within Russiaâ€, her office said in a statement. Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said for the moment there was no concern for Italians living in Russia, but said they were â€œadvised to be cautiousâ€. â€œWith regard to the ongoing military invasion of Ukraine and the possible threat of erosion of the security situation in the country, especially for citizens of EU and NATO countries, our strong warning against travel to the Russian Federation is still in place,â€ news agency CTK quoted Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky as saying. Kazakh President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev spoke to Putin by phone, Tokayevâ€™s office said, and described the events in Russia as its internal affair while saying rule of law was necessary to maintain order. Putin briefed Tokayev on the situation, the Kazakh presidentâ€™s office said, and thanked him for the understanding Kazakhstan has expressed. Russian state news agency TASS said Putin had also spoken to the leaders of Belarus and Uzbekistan. The countryâ€™s Security Council said in a statement that Minsk remained an ally of Russia and that internal disputes were â€œa gift to the collective Westâ€. Qatar expressed its concern over the situation in Russia and called for â€œmaximum restraintâ€ from all parties. â€œThe foreign ministry warns that escalation in Russia and Ukraine will have negative consequences for international peace and security and will impact food and energy supplies,â€ it said in a statement. The ministry called for restraint, reason and â€œsparing civilians the repercussions of confrontationâ€. â€œThe escalation in Russia and Ukraine will have negative repercussions on international peace and security, and on food and energy supplies, which are already affected by the Russian-Ukrainian crisis,â€ the ministry said. Iran supports the rule of law in the Russian Federation and considers the latest developments there an internal Russian matter, Iranian state media quoted foreign ministry spokesperson Nasser Kanaani as saying. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Canadaâ€™s incident response group will meet to discuss the latest developments in Russia. â€œWeâ€™re in contact with our allies and will continue to monitor the situation closely,â€ Trudeau wrote on Twitter.

Title: â€˜Spitting on soldiersâ€™ gravesâ€™: Russians react to Wagner mutiny
Subtitle: Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin has angered Putin supporters as he stages mutiny against military command.
Content: The Russian-Ukrainian war took an unexpected turn on Saturday after the head of the Wagner Group, which has played a prominent role in the Kremlinâ€™s war in Ukraine, called for a rebellion against Russiaâ€™s top military brass. The mercenary outfit Wagner, which carried out much of the grunt work in the battle of Bakhmut, mutinied against high command and seized the city of Rostov in southwestern Russia, largely unopposed by local security forces. The mutiny is the fruition of a long-running feud between Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin and Russian military chiefs. Prigozhin claims to have shot down three Russian helicopters, and that the armed forces have fired rockets on Wagnerâ€™s positions. Al Jazeera could not independently verify his claims. â€œAny internal turmoil is a mortal threat to our statehood and to us as a nation,â€ Russian President Vladimir Putin said in a televised speech on Saturday. â€œThis is a blow to Russia, to our people. And our actions to defend the fatherland against such a threat will be tough. All those who deliberately stepped onto the path of treachery, who prepared an armed insurrection, who followed the path of blackmail and terrorist methods, will suffer an inevitable punishment, will have to answer before the law and before our people.â€ Although no one is certain what will happen next, all voices agree on one thing: this rebellion undermines Moscowâ€™s war effort in Ukraine. â€œWe should help even the devil if heâ€™s against this regime!â€ exiled tycoon and Putin opponent Mikhail Khodorkovsky wrote on Instagram. â€œWe should help because there is no worse crime than unleashing an aggressive war. If one criminal is ready to interfere with another â€“ nowâ€™s not the time to make sour faces â€“ we need to help, and then, if necessary, we will fight this one [Prigozhin], too. And yes, this is just the beginning.â€ Supporters of the Russian government decried the mutiny and urged for unity. â€œItâ€™s a tough time, I didnâ€™t think Iâ€™d live to see this,â€ said pro-Kremlin pundit and talk show host Vladimir Solovyov in a video address to his million-plus Telegram followers. â€œ[Wagnerâ€™s] 25,000 men would be very useful at the front for the march on Lviv, Kyiv and if necessary, even further. But when you look at whatâ€™s going on, you ask yourself, how did this happen?â€ â€œThe enemy is there, in Ukraine. We need to be fighting with Ukro-fascism. Stop, before itâ€™s too late. Thereâ€™s nothing scarier than civil war.â€ Russiaâ€™s former space chief Dmitry Rogozin said:Â â€œIn war, you need to shove your political ambitions up your ass and support the front with all your might.â€ â€œAny attempt to weaken it is nothing but aiding the enemy.â€ Pro-Kremlin journalist Armen Gasparyan, who is wanted in Ukraine for â€œpublically calling for the genocide of Ukrainian peopleâ€, called Prigozhinâ€™s actions a betrayal and a â€œstab in the back of the armyâ€. â€œSpitting on the graves of soldiers and officers who gave their lives to the Motherland,â€ he wrote on Telegram. â€œBut we have a president and there is a consolidation in our society for the sake of a holy goal. We will win! Stop, do not go against the Motherland!â€ Igor â€œStrelkovâ€ Girkin, the former Russian military intelligence operative who led the initial uprising in Ukraineâ€™s Donbas back in 2014, analysed the situation at length for his 845,000 Telegram followers. He called Prigozhinâ€™s claim of a missile attack on Wagnerâ€™s positions â€œa complete lieâ€. â€œTo eliminate Wagner, itâ€™s completely unnecessary to inflict blows on any camp,â€ he assessed. â€œItâ€™s enough to whack Prigozhin himself. Well, maybe someone else from his inner circle along with him. And thatâ€™s all. And to hit ordinary soldiers and commanders is utter stupidity â€“ even [generals Sergei] Shoigu and [Valery] Gerasimov have enough brains to understand this.â€ Girkin said he doubted that Prigozhin will be able to hold out for long, lacking the resources, support from the military and even control over Wagner itself, with much of his manpower still in Ukraine, to successfully march on Moscow. â€œIf after five-six hours Wagner does not achieve significant success and military units do not openly go over to its side, the rebellion will drag on, and with each passing day its final success will be more and more improbable,â€ he wrote. â€œWell, if the Kremlin doesnâ€™t screw up out of habit, of course, and start urgently searching for compromises.â€ Still, the fact of such a mutiny taking place is a sign of the tenuous grip President Putin has on power, according to Russian economist and University of Chicago professor Konstantin Sonin. â€œThe fact that Wagner was able to easily capture the million-strong Rostov-on-Don, the 10th largest city in Russia, in which the headquarters of the Southern Military District is located, shows that Prigozhinâ€™s plan has serious support among the regular army. Wagner was allowed into Rostov without resistance,â€ Sonin wrote on Facebook. â€œOne way or another, this brings the end of both Putin (not in two years, as I wrote in the spring, but faster), and the war. Even if nothing changes at all, Prigozhin is captured or killed, and key Wagnerites are imprisoned, what has already happened is the collapse of the state on an epic scale, a historic episode.â€

Title: â€˜Internal betrayalâ€™ in Russia: Transcript of Putinâ€™s address
Subtitle: The Russian president says his country is fighting for its future, as he accuses Wagner chief Prighozin of fomenting armed civil conflict.
Content: Speaking during an emergency televised address in Moscow on Saturday, President Vladimir Putin has promised that he would not allow Russia to slip into civil war, after Yevgeny Prighozin, the leader of the Wagner mercenary force,seizeda key military headquarters overseeing the offensive in Ukraine. Below is the full transcript of Putinâ€™s address: â€œI appeal to the citizens of Russia, to the personnel of the armed forces, law enforcement and security services, fighters and commanders currently fighting on their positions, repelling the enemy attacks, doing it heroically. I spoke to the commanders in all directions last night. I appeal also to those who were deceptively pulled into the criminal adventure, pushed towards a serious crime of an armed mutiny. Today Russia is fighting fiercely for its future, repelling the aggression of neo-Nazis and their handlers. Directed against us is the whole military, economical and information machines of the West. We fight for the lives and security of our people; for our sovereignty and independence; for the right to remain Russia, a state with a thousand-year history. This battle, where the fate of our people is being decided, requires all our forces to be united; unity, consolidation and responsibility. Everything that weakens us must be put to the side, any differences that may be used or are used by our enemies to disrupt us from within. Thus, the actions splitting our unity are a betrayal of our people, of our brothers in combat who fight now at the front line. Itâ€™s a stab in the back of our country and our people. It was such a blow that was dealt to Russia in 1917 when the country was fighting in World War I, but its victory was stolen. Intrigues, bickering and politicking behind the back of the army and the people turned out to be the greatest catastrophe, the destruction of the army and the state, loss of huge territories, resulting in a tragedy and a civil war. Russians were killing Russians, brothers killing brothers. The beneficiaries of that were various political chevaliers of fortune and foreign powers who divided the country, and tore it into parts. We will not let this happen again. We will protect our people and state from any threats, including internal betrayal. What weâ€™re facing is exactly a betrayal. Big ambitions and personal interests led to treason. Betrayal of oneâ€™s own country and people and of the cause that fighters of Wagner were dying for alongside our soldiers. Heroes who liberated Soledar and Artemovsk, towns and cities of the Donbas, who fought and gave their lives to Novorossiya and for the unity of the Russian world. Their name and glory have been betrayed by those who are trying to organise the mutiny, pushing the country into anarchy and fratricide, to a defeat, in the end, and capitulation. I repeat: any internal mutiny is a deadly threat to our state, to us as a nation. Itâ€™s a blow against Russia, against our people. And our actions to defend the fatherland from such a threat will be brutal. Anyone who consciously went on the path of betrayal, who prepared the armed mutiny, went on the path of blackmail and terrorist actions, will be punished inevitably. They will answer before the law and our people. The armed forces and other departments have received the necessary orders. Additional anti-terrorist security measures are now being implemented in Moscow, Moscow region, and a number of other regions. Decisive actions will be taken to stabilise the situation in Rostov-on-Don, which still remains difficult. The operation of civilian and military control departments is practically blocked. As a president of Russia and the commander-in-chief, as a citizen of Russia, I will do everything to defend the country, protect the Constitution, lives and safety, liberty of the citizens. Those who organised and prepared the military mutiny, who turned weapons against their comrades-in-arms, have betrayed Russia, and will be held accountable for that. And those who are being pulled into the crime, Iâ€™m calling on you to not make this crucial, tragic, unrepeatable mistake. Make the only right choice â€“ stop participating in criminal actions. I believe that we will defend and preserve whatâ€™s sacred for us. And together with the motherland, we will overcome all challenges, and become even stronger.â€

Title: Who is Yevgeny Prigozhin, Wagner boss on passenger list of crashed plane?
Subtitle: Once known as â€˜Putinâ€™s chefâ€™, Yevgeny Prigozhin rose to prominence after mercenaries from his Wagner Group played a role in the Ukraine war.
Content: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the RussianWagner Groupmercenary force, was listed as a passenger on a private jet which crashed north of Moscow on Wednesday, Russiaâ€™s state-owned TASS news agency has reported, citing Rosaviatsia, Russiaâ€™s aviation authority. Prigozhin rose to prominence after taking an increasinglyvisible role in the war in Ukraine, where his mercenaries were fighting on behalf of Moscow after regular troops suffered heavy attrition and lost territory in humiliating setbacks. Wagner troopsraised a Russian flagin the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut in April after a long and bloody battle, bagging a badly needed victory in the 15-month conflict. Prigozhin turned that moment of triumph into an opportunity just days later to accuse Russiaâ€™s military top brass of being responsible for the failures in Ukraine,Â something only a select few can do publicly without drawing retribution from the Kremlin. The running feud with the defence ministryreached new heightsin June when the Wagner leader claimed his fighters had crossed from Ukraine into the Russian border city of Rostov-on-Don â€“ and that they would fight anyone who tried to stop them. The Wagner chief has alsoquestionedthe official Kremlin version of why Russia invaded Ukraine. â€œThe defence ministry is trying to deceive society and the president and tell us a story about how there was crazy aggression from Ukraine and that they were planning to attack us with the whole of NATO,â€ Prigozhin said in a video clip released on Telegram by his press service at the time. In an emergency televised address, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the â€œarmed mutinyâ€ by Wagner amounted to treason and that anyone who had taken up arms against the Russian military would be punished. The revolt was defused in a deal whereby the Kremlin said that in order to avert bloodshed, Prigozhin and some of his fighters would leave for Belarus and a criminal case against him for armed mutiny would be dropped. Confusion has surrounded the implementation of the deal and the future of Prigozhin. The Kremlin said he attended a meeting with Putin five days after the mutiny. On July 5, state television said an investigation against him was still being pursued, and broadcast footage showing cash, passports, weapons and other items it said were seized on a raid on one of his properties. But in late July, Prigozhin was photographed in St Petersburg while a Russia-Africa summit was taking place in the city. This week he appeared in a video which he suggested was shot in Africa, where Wagner has operations in several countries.  Prigozhin, 62, was convicted of robbery and assault in 1981 and sentenced to 12 years in prison. Following his release, he opened a restaurant business in Saint Petersburg in the 1990s. It was in this capacity that he got to know Putin, then the cityâ€™s deputy mayor. He used that connection to develop a catering business and won lucrative Russian government contracts that earned him the nickname, â€œPutinâ€™s chefâ€. He later expanded into other areas, including media and an infamous internet â€œtroll factoryâ€ that led to his indictment in the US for meddling in the 2016 presidential election. In January, Prigozhin acknowledged founding, leading and financing the shadowy Wagner company. He said he had 50,000 men at his disposal â€œin the best times,â€ with about 35,000 on the front lines at all times. He did not say whether these numbers included convicts, but he is known to have toured Russian prisons to recruit fighters, promising pardons if they survived a half-year tour of front-line duty with Wagner. Prigozhinâ€™s scarred face, tightly shaven head and uneven tobacco-stained teeth have become widely recognised, as is his vocabulary filled with expletives. Polls suggest he has become thefifth most recognisable figure after Putin, Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin, Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu. He staked out a political niche among conservative Russians who revere Soviet leader Joseph Stalin and want to win the war in Ukraine, no matter what. â€œComrade Stalin was absolutely right,â€ Prigozhin said in May, touting the death penalty for servicemen and officials who â€œfailâ€ to support the faltering war effort. Such a law would be similar to Stalinâ€™s WWII policies. Prigozhin also said that after losing tens of thousands of mercenaries in eastern Ukraine, his Wagner Group will have to recruit more people and â€œtransform into an army with an ideologyâ€. To some outside observers, Prigozhinâ€™s transformation may be part of the Kremlinâ€™s power transfer plan in case of a collapse similar to the â€œTimes of Troublesâ€ between the death of Tsar Ivan the Terrible and the ascension of the Romanov dynasty four centuries ago. Prigozhinâ€™s company was called Wagner after the nickname of its first commander, Dmitry Utkin, a retired lieutenant colonel of the Russian militaryâ€™s special forces. It soon established a reputation for brutality and ruthlessness. Wagner was first seen in action in eastern Ukraine soon after a separatist conflict erupted there in April 2014, in the weeks following Russiaâ€™s annexation of Ukraineâ€™s Crimean peninsula.    While backing the separatist uprising in the Donbas, Ukraineâ€™s eastern industrial heartland, Russia denied sending its own weapons and troops there, despite ample evidence to the contrary. Engaging private contractors in the fighting allowed Moscow to maintain a degree of deniability. Wagner personnel also deployed to Syria, where Russia supported President Bashar al-Assadâ€™s government in a war. In Libya, they fought alongside the forces of renegade commander Khalifa Haftar. The group is also believed to operate in the Central African Republic and Mali. Prigozhin has reportedly used Wagnerâ€™s deployment to Syria and African countries to secure lucrative mining contracts. US Under Secretary of State Victoria Nuland said in January the company was using its access to gold and other resources in Africa to fund operations in Ukraine. Some Russian media alleged that Wagner was involved in the 2018 killings of three Russian journalists in the Central African Republic who were investigating the groupâ€™s activities. The slayings remain unsolved. Western countries and United Nations experts have accused Wagner mercenaries of human rights abuses throughout Africa, including in the Central African Republic, Libya and Mali. In 2021, the European Union accused the group of â€œserious human rights abuses, including torture and extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions and killings,â€ and of carrying out â€œdestabilising activitiesâ€ in the Central African Republic, Libya, Syria and Ukraine. Several videos have surfaced purporting to show some of the activities that have contributed to Wagnerâ€™s fearsome reputation. A 2017 online video showed a group of armed people, reportedly Wagner contractors, torturing a Syrian and beating him to death with a sledgehammer before mutilating and burning his body. Russian authorities ignored requests by the media and rights activists to investigate. In 2022, another video showed a former Wagner contractor beaten to death with a sledgehammer after he allegedly fled to the Ukrainian side and was repatriated. Despite public outrage and demands for an investigation, the Kremlin turned a blind eye.

Title: Why Wagner mercenary force has moved against Russiaâ€™s military
Subtitle: Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin claims his fighters are not involved in a military coup but â€˜a march of justiceâ€™.
Content: The head of Russiaâ€™s Wagner mercenary forceYevgeny Prigozhin claimed his forces have entered Russiato remove the countryâ€™s top military leadership. The Wagner chief on Saturday claimed his forces were in control of military sites in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don. The military headquarters in the city oversees the fighting in Ukraine. Other videos posted on social media showed military vehicles, including tanks, on the streets outside. Russian President Vladimir Putin condemned the rebellion, saying it was â€œa stab in the back of our country and our peopleâ€. â€œAll those who prepared the rebellion will suffer inevitable punishment. The armed forces and other government agencies have received the necessary orders,â€ Putin said in a televised address to the nation on Saturday. Earlier, Russiaâ€™s security services said they had opened a criminal investigation into Prigozhin for launching what they describe as a mutiny. The Wagner chief also questioned the official Kremlin version of why Russia invaded Ukraine. For months, Prigozhin has beenaccusingDefence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Russiaâ€™s top general, Valery Gerasimov, of incompetence, but this was the first time he rejected Russiaâ€™s core justifications for invading Ukraine. â€œThe defence ministry is trying to deceive society and the president and tell us a story about how there was crazy aggression from Ukraine and that they were planning to attack us with the whole of NATO,â€ Prigozhin said in a video clip released on Telegram by his press service on Friday. â€œThe special operation was started for different reasons,â€ he said. â€œThe war was needed â€¦ so that Shoigu could become a marshal, â€¦ so that he could get a second â€˜Heroâ€™ [of Russia] medal. The war wasnâ€™t needed to demilitarise or denazify Ukraine.â€ Hereâ€™s what we know of Prigozhinâ€™s stated aims:

Title: Wagner chief rejects Putinâ€™s accusations of treason
Subtitle: Yevgeny Prigozhin says Putin is â€˜deeply mistakenâ€™ and that Wagner fighters are not traitors but â€˜patriots.â€™
Content: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Russian military contractorWagner Group, has rejected accusations of â€œtreasonâ€ by President Vladimir Putin after his troops crossed crossed from Ukraine into the Russian border city of Rostov-on-Don, vowing to fight anyone who tried to stop them. On Saturday, Prigozhin posted an audio message on the social media app Telegram, claiming his forces had taken control of military facilities in the city, including the airfield. Videos and pictures posted online, including by Russiaâ€™s TASS news agency, showed armed men surrounding administrative buildings in Rostov and tanks deployed in the city centre. â€œAll of us are ready to die. All 25,000, and then another 25,000,â€ he said, after earlier accusing the Russian top brass of having launched an attack onÂ their camps in Ukraine, where the mercenaries are fighting on behalf of Moscow. â€œWe are dying for the Russian people.â€ In an emergency televised address on Saturday, Putin said that the â€œarmed mutinyâ€ by Wagner amounted to â€œtreasonâ€ and that anyone who had taken up arms against the Russian military would be punished. He added that he would do everything to protect Russia, and that â€œdecisive actionâ€ would be taken to stabilise the situation in Rostov. The Federal Security Service (FSB) said Prigozhinâ€™s actions were â€œa call to start an armed civil conflict on the territory of the Russian Federationâ€ and â€œa stab in the back to Russian servicemen fighting pro-fascist Ukrainian forcesâ€. In response, Russian authorities said security had been tightened in several regions and the mayor of Moscow announced that â€œanti-terroristâ€ measures were being taken in the capital. â€œWith the aim of preventing possible terrorist acts on the territory of the city of Moscow and the Moscow region, an anti-terror operation regime has been introduced,â€ the countryâ€™s national anti-terrorist committee was quoted by Russian agencies as saying. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry addressed Wagnerâ€™s mercenary fighters in a statement, saying that they had been â€œdeceived and dragged into a criminal adventureâ€. It urged them to contact its representatives and those of law enforcement services, and promised to guarantee their security. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the armed insurrection was evidence of Russiaâ€™s inherent political instability. â€œRussiaâ€™s weakness is obvious,â€ he said. â€œAnd the longer Russia keeps its troops and mercenaries on our land, the more chaos, pain, and problems it will have for itself later.â€ The events in Rostov were the latest provocation from Prigozhin since Russian authorities announced they would launch a criminal case against the mercenary chief, over threats he allegedly made to remove the countryâ€™s Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu. On Friday,Prigozhin accusedShoigu of ordering a rocket attack on Wagnerâ€™s field camps in Ukraine and railed against the toll it has taken on Wagner forces. â€œHuge numbers of our fighters, of our combat comrades, have been killed,â€ he said. â€œThe evil that the military leadership of the country bears must be stopped. They neglect the lives of soldiers. They forget the word justice.â€ Prigozhin estimated that 2,000 of his fighters had been killed in the blasts, though he failed to provide evidence for that death toll. His message included a call to action that the Russian government has since interpreted as an appeal to mutiny. â€œThere are 25,000 of us, and weâ€™re going to figure out why this chaos is happening in the country,â€ Prigozhin said, indicating that he had more forces in reserve and support from military members. â€œEveryone is welcome to join. We must end this disgrace.â€ He also posted a video in which he dismissed Moscowâ€™s claims that Kyiv was planning to launch an offensive on the Russian-controlled territories in eastern Ukraine in February 2022, a claim that had served as a rationale for launching a full-fledged invasion. He accused the defence ministry of â€œtrying to deceive the public and the presidentâ€ and â€œspin the story that there was insane levels of aggression from the Ukrainian side and that they were going to attack us together with the whole NATO blocâ€. Prigozhinâ€™s words marked a significant escalation in his long-running standoff with the Russian militaryâ€™s top brass. In response, the ministry issued a statement saying Prigozhinâ€™s accusations were â€œnot true and are an informational provocationâ€. Prigozhinsaid his actions did not amount to a military coup but were rather, â€œa march of justiceâ€.    Russiaâ€™s FSB security service opened a criminal case against him for calling for an armed mutiny, the TASS news agency said on Friday, citing the National Antiterrorism Committee. The security service also called on Wagner fighters to â€œtake measures to detainâ€ their leader. The deputy commander of Russiaâ€™s campaign in Ukraine, General Sergei Surovikin, appealed to the forces to submit to Moscowâ€™s command. â€œI urge you to stop,â€ Surovikin said in a Telegram video, where he appeared in military fatigues, his hand perched on a rifle. â€œYou must do this before it is too late. Obey the will and command of the elected president of the Russian Federation. Stop the convoys. Return to bases and places where youâ€™re stationed.â€ The Kremlin has also said Putin was being â€œconstantlyâ€ informed of the unfolding events and that â€œnecessary measures are being takenâ€. Yulia Shapovalova, reporting for Al Jazeera from Moscow, said Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence released a statement in which it said Ukraine was taking advantage of the Wagner chiefâ€™s â€œprovocationâ€ and that Kyivâ€™s forces had launched an offensive in the direction of Bakhmut city. â€œAlso, at the moment, armoured military personnel vehicles can be seen in the streets of Moscow. But generally, people report that the capital looks pretty calm right now. Thatâ€™s probably because security measures have been stepped up in the capital and all the most important facilities have been taken under protection,â€ Shapovalova said. Several high-ranking Russian generals also released video messages addressing Prigozhin, saying that it was a time for unity in Russia as the countryâ€™s enemies in Ukraine and the West were â€œrejoicing right nowâ€. The generals described the Wagner chiefâ€™s comments as a â€œstab in the back of the country and the presidentâ€, and the FSB has also appealed to Wagner fighters to detain their boss, Shapovalova added. The United States said it was monitoring the situation, with National Security Council spokesperson Adam Hodge telling reporters that US allies were also being consulted. The standoff, many of the details of which remained unclear, appears to be the biggest domestic crisis Putin has faced since he sent thousands of troops into Ukraine in February of last year in what he called â€œa special military operationâ€. â€œOver the past few months, Wagner Group played a vital role in the Russian attack on Bakhmut, on Soledar, and this conflict with the Ministry of Defence has been brewing for a lot of time,â€ Al Jazeera correspondent Ali Hashem reported from Donetsk. â€œWhatâ€™s happening right now is just the top of the iceberg.â€ Prigozhin, whose frequent tirades on social media belie his limited role in the war as head of the Wagner private militia, has for months been openly accusing Shoigu and Russiaâ€™s top general, Valery Gerasimov, of rank incompetence and of denying his forces ammunition and support. â€œItâ€™s really quite extraordinary. Prigozhin has been critical of the way in which the Ministry of Defence and the official Russian military have been prosecuting this war, really from the very beginning, calling them unprofessional, accusing them of leading unnecessary deaths of Russian soldiers,â€ Sam Greene, the director for democratic resilience at the Center for European Policy Analysis, told Al Jazeera. â€œBut he has certainly taken that quite a few steps further.â€ Greene described the Russian war in Ukraine as a â€œmoney-making endeavourâ€ for defence services â€” and the way he sees it, Prigozhin and Shoigu are jostling for resources and control. But Greene added that it is unclear what Prigozhinâ€™s strategy is at present. â€œI will be honest: It is very difficult for me to understand the calculation that Prigozhin is making here,â€ Greene said. â€œThis really is such a significant challenge that he either has to win it outright, or itâ€™s hard to see how heâ€™s going to survive in this system â€” or in fact, to survive at all.â€

Title: â€˜Fakeâ€™ video of Ukrainians criticising Titan crew debunked
Subtitle: A fake video attributed to Al Jazeera claimed Ukrainians were upset with the Titan submersible crew for â€˜wasting moneyâ€™.
Content: Al Jazeera has debunked a fake video that has been circulating on social media. The video, falsely bearing the Qatar-based media networkâ€™s logo, reported that Ukrainians were criticising theTitan submersibleâ€™s crewfor wasting money that could have been donated to support Ukraine. An Al Jazeera spokesperson told the Reuters news agency that the content of the video clip was â€œfabricatedâ€. â€œThe video circulating on social media, claiming to be from Al Jazeera and featuring content that depicts Ukrainian people condemning the passengers of the Titan submarine for lavishly spending money on their expedition is not authentic,â€ the spokesperson said in an email on Friday. â€œWe want to clarify that the video does not originate from Al Jazeera, and we assert that the content has been fabricated by a third party.â€    Captions in the 94-second clip said Ukrainians were upset with the crew of the Titan submersible for â€œwasting moneyâ€, and that the funds should have gone to them amid Russiaâ€™s invasion of their country. â€œUkraine needs help while these people spend fortunes on silly entertainment,â€ said an unidentified social media user, according to a caption in the video. The clip was widely shared on Twitter, Facebook and TikTok, garnering tens of thousands of views. The Reuters Fact Check team concluded that the video was â€œfalseâ€. â€œThe video is an example of imposter content. It was not published by Al Jazeera.â€ The Titan submersiblehad been missingfor days in the Atlantic Ocean with five men on board. On Thursday, the United States Coast Guard said the submersible suffered a â€œcatastrophic lossâ€ that was consistent with the implosion of the vessel. Each person paid a sum of $250,000 for a chance to see the legendary Titanic wreckage some 13,000 feet (3,962 metres) below the ocean surface. Among those on board the vessel â€“ owned by the company OceanGate â€“ were UK billionaire Hamish Harding, Pakistani-British businessman Shahzada Dawood and his 19-year-old son Suleman. This is not the first time a video misidentified as Al Jazeeraâ€™s has circulated on social media. In November,a fake videoattributed to Al Jazeera alleged that drunk Ukrainian football fans vandalised World Cup-related posters with Nazi symbols in the capital city Doha. According to the fake video, three Ukrainians were detained after they painted a â€œHitler moustacheâ€ on the 2022 World Cupâ€™s mascot Laâ€™eeb, and further vandalised the poster with a Nazi salute.

Title: Zelenskyy urges world to heed Ukraineâ€™s â€˜terrorâ€™ attack warning
Subtitle: President slams â€˜countries pretending to be neutralâ€™ after warning Russia could be planning an attack at Europeâ€™s largest nuclear plant.
Content: Ukraine wants other countries to heed its warning that Russia may be planning to attack anoccupied nuclear power plantto cause a radiation disaster, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said. On Thursday, he said Ukraineâ€™s intelligence agencies had received information that Russia was considering what they cast as a â€œterrorâ€ attack involving a release of radiation. â€œUnfortunately, I had to be reminded more than once that radiation knows no national borders, and who it hits is determined only by the direction of the wind,â€ he said. Members of his government briefed have international representatives on the possible threat to the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, which has been controlled by Russia since March 2022, and is run by Ukrainian technicians. In his nightly address, Zelenskyy said he expected other nations to â€œgive appropriate signals and exert pressureâ€ on Moscow. â€œOur principle is simple: The world must know what the occupier is preparing. Everyone who knows must act,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œThe world has enough power to prevent any radiation incidents, let alone a radiation catastrophe.â€ The potential for a life-threatening release of radiation has been a concern since Russian troops invaded Ukraine last year and seized the plant, which is Europeâ€™s largest nuclear power station.    The head of the UNâ€™s atomic energy agency spent months unsuccessfully trying to negotiate for a safety perimeter to protect the facility as nearby areas came under repeated shelling. The Ukrainian leaderâ€™s nighttime remarks Thursday carried a tone of frustration with â€œcountries that are pretending to be neutral even nowâ€ in the war. He accused â€œanyone who turns a blind eye to Russiaâ€™s occupation of such a facilityâ€ of enabling Moscow to commit an act of evil and terror. â€œObviously, radiation does not ask who is neutral and can reach anyone in the world. Accordingly, anyone in the world can help now, and it is quite clear what to do,â€ Zelenskyy said. Russia has denied the accusations. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov dismissed the claim as â€œanother lieâ€. On Friday, Russia claimed it was the target of â€œan information and propaganda campaign to discredit the country in the international arenaâ€. Russiaâ€™s Federal Security Service, the FSB, said five people were arrested for trying to smuggle a kilogram of the radioactive isotope Cesium-137 out of the country under the direction of a Ukrainian citizen. The FSB said the material was to be used for â€œorganising staged scenes of the use of weapons of mass destruction.â€ Cesium-137 is often mentioned as of potential use in making a â€œdirty bombâ€ that could contaminate a wide area. The International Atomic Energy Agency noted Thursday that â€œthe military situation has become increasingly tenseâ€ while a Ukrainian counteroffensive that got under way this month unfolds in Zaporizhia province, where the namesake plant is located, and in an adjacent part of Donetsk province. On Friday, IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi met with the director of Russian state nuclear corporation Rosatom to discuss the conditions at the plant. Rosatom director Alexey Likachev and other officials at the meeting in the Kaliningrad exclave â€œemphasised that they now expect specific stepsâ€ from the UN agency to prevent Ukrainian attacks on the plant and its adjacent territory, said a statement from the Russian corporation, whose divisions build and operate nuclear power plants. The governor of Zaporizhia, Yuriy Malashko, reported on Friday that Russian shelling in the southern province killed two people in the past day. An attack that hit a transportation company in Kherson, the capital of Kherson province, killed two others on Friday, governor Oleksandr Prokudin said.

Title: Western countries commit billions to rebuild war-ravaged Ukraine
Subtitle: Homes, hospitals and key infrastructure lie in ruins nearly 16 months since Russia began its full scale invasion of Ukraine.
Content: Foreign donors have pledged 60 billion euros ($66bn) for Ukraine over a multi-year period to help the country rebuild following Russiaâ€™s February 2022 invasion. The commitments were made at the two-day Ukraine Recovery Conference in London and were mostly comprised of a 50 billion euro ($55bn) commitment from the European Union announced on Tuesday and new pledges from the United Kingdom and the United States. â€œWe had not envisaged this to be a pledging conference. Nevertheless, today at this conference, we can announce a combined 60 billion euros in support to Ukraine,â€ said British Foreign Minister James Cleverly. Nearly 16 months since Russia began itsfull-scale invasion, homes,hospitalsand critical infrastructure lie in ruins and Kyiv faces years, possibly decades, of rebuilding. The World Bank has estimated the cost of reconstruction at more than $400bn, a figure rising daily alongside the human toll of the war. Stressing the vast scale of the task, diplomats and political leaders at the London conference urged private-sector companies to invest as well. Nearly 500 companies from 42 countries have pledged to play their part, Cleverly said. Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal, who was at the conference, thanked the delegates for their financial backing adding that Ukraine would not wait for the end of the war to start rebuilding. Ukraineâ€™s initial focus will be its energy sector, which has come under sustained attack in successive Russian raids, leaving families in the dark and unable to heat their homes during thebitterly cold winter months. A US promise of more than $1.3bn in new aid, included more than $500m to restore and improve the countryâ€™s energy grid. The conference also touched on issues such asUkraineâ€™s future membership of the European Union, with officials stressing the need for the country to make additional progress toÂ meet conditions such as reducing corruption and reforming the judiciary. Such reforms would send â€œa powerful messageâ€ to investors that they will get the â€œtransparency, fairness and the functioning institutions they need to invest in Ukraineâ€, said European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken also highlighted the importance of anti-corruption efforts by Ukraine, a country long plagued by graft. He said some of the money pledged by the US would also go towards upgrading ports and border infrastructure and digitising customs procedures to make it harder to break the rules. â€œThe goal is to rebuild a Ukraine that is fit for [the] EU,â€ said German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock. Germany will host the next Ukraine recovery conference in 2024.

Title: Russia on UN â€˜list of shameâ€™ for killing children, Israel absent
Subtitle: UN chief Antonio Guterres criticised by right workers for â€˜disserviceâ€™ to Palestinian children by leaving Israeli forces off list.
Content: The United Nations has placed Russiaâ€™s military and allied armed groups on its â€œlist of shameâ€ over thekilling and maiming of hundreds of children in its war against Ukraine, butIsraeli forces have been left off the listdespite killing more than 40 Palestinian children last year, according to reports. Human rights organisations had made repeated requests thatIsrael be added to the UN blacklistover the killing and maiming of Palestinian children in the occupied West Bank. Palestinian Ambassador to the UN Riyad Mansour on Thursday called UN Secretary General Antonio Guterresâ€™s decision to leave Israel off the shame list a â€œbig mistakeâ€. In the UNâ€™s annual reporton the treatment of children in conflict zones, which was distributed to members of the UN Security Council on Thursday, Guterres said that he was â€œappalled by the high number of grave violations against children in Ukraineâ€ in 2022. According to news organisations that had seen a copy of the report, 477 children were listed as killed in Ukraine last year, including 136 deaths directly attributed to Russian forces and affiliated groups.    Ukrainian armed forces were responsible for killing 80 children, according to the report. Of the remaining child victims, neither of the two warring sides could be blamed with certainty. The children were mostly killed by air attacks, the UN report said. The UN also verified thatRussian forces and affiliated groupsmaimed 518 children in Ukraine and carried out 480 attacks on schools and hospitals. Russian armed forces also used 91 children as human shields, according to the report. Ukrainian armed forces maimed 175 children and carried out 212 attacks on schools and hospitals. Ukraineâ€™s forces were not placed on the list. The UN chief said in the report that he was â€œdeeply concernedâ€ by the number of Palestinian children killed by Israeli forces in 2022. According to the report,42 Palestinian children were killedand 933 injured in 2022 by Israeli forces. In 2021, Israeli forces killed 78 Palestinian children. Israel has never been on the UN list of countries shamed for killing children.    Guterres said that he noted a â€œmeaningful decrease in the number of children killed by Israeli forces, including by air strikesâ€ last year compared with the previous report. Human Rights Watch welcomed the UNâ€™s decision to name Russian forces but criticised the UN chiefâ€™s decision to leave Israel off the shame list, saying that he â€œhad failed Palestinian children againâ€. â€œBy adding Russiaâ€™s forces to his list of shame, the Secretary General is holding them to account for horrific violations against children,â€ said Jo Becker, the groupâ€™s advocacy director for childrenâ€™s rights. â€œHis [Guterresâ€™s] unwillingness, year after year, to hold Israeli forces accountable for their grave violations against children has backfired, only emboldening Israeli forces to use unlawful lethal force against Palestinian children,â€ Becker said. â€œFrom 2015-2020, the UN attributed over 6,700 child casualties to Israeli forces. He has just verified 975 more in 2022. Yet he still omits Israel from his â€˜list of shameâ€™,â€ Becker wrote in a tweet. UN Secretary-General@antonioguterreshas failed Palestinian children again. From 2015-2020, the UN attributed over 6,700 child casualties to Israeli forces. He has just verified 975 more in 2022. Yet he still omits Israel from his "list of shame."https://t.co/lCMSmkR9cgpic.twitter.com/3d48AOlsvj â€” Jo Becker (@jobeckerhrw)June 22, 2023  Mansour, the Palestinian UN ambassador, said leaving Israel off the UN list was â€œvery disappointing to the Palestinian people and to the Palestinian childrenâ€. â€œThe Secretary General made a big mistake in not listing this current Israeli government. This is the most extreme government, loaded with fascist elements. If you do not list this government now, when will you list the Israeli government?â€ Mansour said. â€œItâ€™s very unfortunate that he selected not to list them.â€ The UN report has long been controversial, with diplomats saying Saudi Arabia and Israel have exerted pressure in recent years in a bid to stay off the list of shame. A Saudi-led military coalition was removed from the list in 2020 several years after it was first named for killing and injuring children in Yemen. Al Jazeeraâ€™s diplomatic editor James Bays said that Russiaâ€™s inclusion marks the first time that â€œa permanent member of the Security Council has been on that black listâ€. â€œAgain the report is controversial. Part of that is because of Israel, which the report said killed 42 children in 2022. Now the Secretary General says thatâ€™s a meaningful decline and heâ€™s not putting them on the blacklist,â€ Bays said, but noting also that Israelâ€™s war in Gaza in 2021 was 11 days long and the war in August 2022 lasted just three days. â€œThe reality is #Israel is still killing many children,â€ Bays wrote in a tweet. BUT this is only because#Gazawar in May 2021 was 11 days long, and in August 2022 lasted three days. The reality is#Israelis still killing many children. â€” JAMES BAYS (@baysontheroad)June 22, 2023  The UN report also condemned violence against children in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Somalia, Syria, Haiti and other countries.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 485
Subtitle: As the war enters it 485th day, these are the main developments.
Content: This is the situation as it stands on Friday, June 23, 2023.

Title: Ukraine missiles damage bridge to Crimea: Russian officials
Subtitle: The Chonhar road bridge connecting Kherson to Crimea is damaged but there are no casualties, Russian-appointed officials say.
Content: Ukrainian missiles have struck the Chonhar road bridge connecting Crimea with Russian-held parts of the southern Kherson region, according to Russian-appointed officials. The so-called â€œgate to Crimeaâ€, known to Russians by a different spelling as the Chongar bridge, is one of a handful of links between Crimea â€“ which Moscow annexed from Ukraine in 2014 â€“ and mainlandUkraine. It is on a route used by the Russian military to move between Crimea and other parts of Ukraine under its control.  Russian investigators said four missiles had been fired by Ukrainian forces at the bridge, the RIA news agency reported. It quoted a spokesman for military investigators as saying that markings found on the remains of one of the missiles suggested it had been made in France. Al Jazeeraâ€™s Ali Hashem, reporting from Mariupol, said one of the three bridges in the area was damaged. â€œSome analysts say that the attack came due to fear that the Russians are mobilising from that region for the army to resupply towards Kherson,â€ he said. â€œâ€¦ Now we are still waiting to hear more from the Russian side about how this will be dealt with.â€ Vladimir Saldo, the Russian-appointed governor of Kherson, parts of which Russian forces have captured during what Moscow calls its â€œspecial military operationâ€, said the road bridge had been damaged but that there were no casualties. One picture Saldo posted on Telegram showed a large hole in the bridgeâ€™s surface with water visible beneath it and debris scattered nearby. Saldo suggested Ukraine may have used British-supplied Storm Shadow cruise missiles for the attack. â€œThe Kyiv terrorists want to intimidate Kherson residents and sow panic among the population, but they will not succeed. We know how to repair bridges quickly: vehicle passage will be restored in the very near future,â€ he said. â€œWe have an answer to every move by the enemy. A link between the Kherson region and Crimea continues to operate â€“ a reserve route has been temporarily organised for vehicular traffic.â€ Sergei Aksyonov, Crimeaâ€™s Russian-appointed governor, told people to stay calm and said specialists were examining the site to determine when traffic over the bridge could resume. Kyiv says it wants to retake Crimea and drive all Russian forces from its territory. Yuriy Sobolevsky, a Ukrainian official on the governing body for the Kherson region, said the attack was â€œa blow to the military logistics of the occupiersâ€. â€œThe psychological impact on the occupiers and the occupying power is even more important. There is no place on the territory of Kherson region where they can feel safe,â€ he said on the Telegram messaging application.

Title: Ukraine offensive against Russia not â€˜Hollywood movieâ€™: Zelenskyy
Subtitle: Ukraineâ€™s President Zelenskyy said vast minefields laid by Russian forces have slowed his countryâ€™s counteroffensive.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s counteroffensive against Russian forceshas been â€œslower than desiredâ€, but Ukrainian forces will not be pressured into speeding up, the countryâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said, while Russian President Vladimir Putin said Moscow had observed a â€œlullâ€ in Kyivâ€™s campaign. Ukrainian forces are being slowed in their advanceby vast minefields laid by Russian forces, Zelenskyy told to the United Kingdomâ€™s BBC in an interview on Wednesday. With some 200,000 square kilometres (more than 77,000 square miles) of Ukrainian frontier territory littered with Russian land mines, the Ukrainian leader said that â€œat stake is peopleâ€™s livesâ€. â€œSome people believe this is a Hollywood movie and expect results now. Itâ€™s not,â€ Zelenskyy told the BBC. â€œWhatever some might want, including attempts to pressure us, with all due respect, we will advance on the battlefield the way we deem best,â€ he said. Confirming that Ukrainian forces had retaken eight villages in the south and east of the country, Zelenskyy also said that Ukraine would never negotiate while Russian forces remain on Ukraineâ€™s territory and that the conflict would not be allowed to stagnate. â€œNo matter how far we advance in our counteroffensive, we will not agree to a frozen conflictâ€ which would be â€œa prospectless development for Ukraineâ€, he said.
