Title: Pro-Ukraine fighters attack southern Russia; offer to trade POWs
Subtitle: Pro-Kyiv Russian Volunteer Corps and the Legion for Freedom of Russia called on Belgorod governor to meet and retrieve captive Russian soldiers.
Content: Fighting is ongoing in southern Russia after armed groups launched more cross-border attacks from Ukraine with Moscow saying it targeted the â€œterroristsâ€ with artillery fire. The governor of the besieged Belgorod region, Vyacheslav Gladkov, said on Sunday that clashes again erupted on his side of the border, and acknowledged for the first time that pro-Ukrainian forces had taken Russian prisoners of war during incursions. He said he was ready for talks to retrieve â€œour guysâ€ and told the armed groups he would meet them for the exchange. â€œA sabotage group came in. There is combat in [the] Novaya Tavolzhanka [border village],â€ Gladkov said. â€œI hope they will all be destroyed.â€ The pro-KyivRussian Volunteer Corpsand theFreedom of Russia Legioncalled on the Belgorod governor to meet and retrieve captive soldiers. â€œThe only thing stopping me from negotiating with them is our guys that are in their hands, maybe they are already dead,â€ said Gladkov. Ukraine has intensively shelled Russian settlements on the border recently, forcing thousands to flee to the regional hub of Belgorod. Russiaâ€™s military later claimed it repelled a â€œsabotage group of Ukrainian terroristsâ€ seeking to cross the frontier near the settlement. â€œThe enemy was hit by artillery. The enemy scattered and retreated,â€ it said in a statement. Gladkov earlier asked residents of the Shebekino border district to leave their homes because of the shelling.    Fighting around Novaya Tavolzhanka follows last monthâ€™s dramatic armed incursion from Ukraine that forced Russiaâ€™s military to use artillery and air strikes on home soil. The border breach was claimed byanti-Kremlin nationalists. Earlier, the armed groups published a video addressing the governor. It claimed to show â€œprisonersâ€ their captors called â€œsimple soldiers sent by your leadership to this warâ€. The one minute and 26 second clip showed what appeared to be about a dozen Russian soldiers being held captive, with two lying on hospital beds.Â  A man identifying himself as the commander of the Russian Volunteer Corps said he would hand over the soldiers in exchange for a meeting with Governor Gladkov. He described the captives as â€œordinary soldiers whom you and your political leadership sent to the slaughterâ€, said a statement posted with the video. Hours later, Gladkov appeared in a video message in which he agreed to meet the group if the soldiers were still alive. â€œMost likely they killed them, as hard as it is for me to say. But if they are alive, from 5-6pm â€“ Shebekino checkpoint. I guarantee safety,â€ Gladkov said.  The fighter in the video said Gladkov did not turn up at the designated meeting place.Â â€œWe have already decided the fate of these guys. They will be transferred to the Ukrainian side for the exchange procedure,â€ he said. Ukraine officials have predicted the rise of what they call forces opposed toRussian President Vladimir Putin. â€œThese Russian men took up arms against their will. Soon they will understand the whole vileness and injustice of the war unleashed by Putin,â€ another Corps member, who did not identify himself, said in the video. Ukraine has consistently denied responsibility for attacks on Russian soil, but presidential adviser Mykhailo Podolyak said on Sunday the situation in the border areas â€œshould be viewed as the future of Russiaâ€. Gladkov said on Sunday that Ukrainian forces continued to shell his region overnight after two people were killed the previous evening and hundreds of children were evacuated away from the border. The attacks on the Belgorod region come as Kyiv says it ispreparing a major counteroffensiveagainst Russian forces. In a video published on Sunday, the Ukrainian army appeared to call on soldiers to stay silent about the plans and said there will be no announcement on the start of the long-awaited counterattack.

Title: Russian attack wounds 20, including children in Ukraineâ€™s Dnipro
Subtitle: Regional governor says three of the five children wounded in Saturdayâ€™s attack were in â€˜serious conditionâ€™.
Content: A Russian air raid on the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro has wounded 20 people, including five children, according to officials. Serhiy Lysak, the regional governor of Dnipropetrovsk, said on Saturday that three of the children were in â€œserious conditionâ€ following the attack on a residential district. A total of 17 people were being treated in hospital, he added on Telegram. Media reports said emergency teams had pulled four people from under rubble in the area known as Pidhorodnenska. Lysak said another child was likely still trapped. Reports on social media said a Russian missile caused the explosion and that an emergency services building was also hit. There was no confirmation of a missile strike from Ukrainian military officials. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, also writing on Telegram, said the explosion occurred between two residential buildings. â€œUnfortunately, there are people under the rubble,â€ Zelenskyy wrote. â€œOnce again, Russia proves it is a terrorist state.â€ Moscow denies its military forces target civilians. Pictures posted on social media showed rescue teams working at a shattered, smouldering building amid piles of twisted building materials. Russian air raids over Ukraine haveratcheted upin recent weeks as haveincursions in the oppositedirection. Russian officials said on Saturday that Ukrainian shelling killed two people in Belgorod, a border region that has been hit by repeated attacks this week. The latest deaths bring the overall toll in Belgorod border villages to seven this week. Kyiv has for months said it is preparing for amajor counteroffensiveagainst Moscowâ€™s occupation forces as it looks to reclaim territory lost since Russia invaded in February 2022.

Title: Wagner boss says Russian forces laid mines to harm his fighters
Subtitle: Mercenary force boss Yevgeny Prigozhin says Russian defence officials planted explosives on route of Wagner fighters withdrawal from Bakhmut city.
Content: The boss ofRussiaâ€™s Wagner mercenary force, Yevgeny Prigozhin, has continued his months-long war of words with the leadership of the Russian armed forces by accusing pro-Moscow forces of planting explosives to harm his fighters as they retreated from Bakhmut. Prigozhin made his claims on Friday as Wagner mercenaries had largely pulled back from the easternUkrainian town of Bakhmutafter months of bloody fighting and a huge death toll.Wagner positions in the destroyed townwere given over to the Russian army, he said. Writing on Telegram, Prigozhin said his men had discovered a dozen locations in rear areas where Russian defence ministry officials had planted various explosive devices, including hundreds of anti-tank mines. When asked why the mines had been laid and the explosives set, the defence ministry officials indicated it was an order from their superiors, Prigozhin said. â€œIt was not necessary to plant these charges in order to deter the enemy, as it (the area in question) is in the rear area,â€ he said. â€œTherefore, we can assume that these charges were intended to meet the advancing units of Wagner,â€ Prigozhin said. None of the charges went off and no one was hurt, he added â€œWe assume this was an attempt at a public flogging.â€    Russiaâ€™s defence ministry was not immediately available for comment. Prigozhin complained for months that his men were not given enough ammunition by Russiaâ€™s top brass for the assault on Bakhmut and claimed that his fighters were being discriminated against. The Wagner bossâ€™s often expletive-laden criticism of the Russian military leadership was criticised by another pro-Moscow commander who has fought in Ukraine â€“ potentially signally growing fissures among the Kremlinâ€™s allied forces in the war. Addressing Prigozhin in a video message on Thursday, and using the diminutive of â€œZhenyaâ€ and the familiar Russian form of you (â€œtyâ€), Adam Delimkhanov,a close ally of Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov,cast the Wagner boss as a blogger who shouts all the time. â€œYou have become a blogger who screams and shouts off to the whole world about all the problems,â€ Delimkhanov said. â€œStop shouting, yelling and screaming,â€ he said. â€œIf you donâ€™t understand, then you can contact us and tell us the place and the time, I, we will, explain to you what you donâ€™t understand,â€ Delimkhanov said in the message to Prigozhin.    The message then drew a swift rebuke from one of Wagnerâ€™s most senior fighters, Dmitry Utkin, a former special forces officer who served in Russian military intelligence. â€œWhere did such familiarity come from: who gave you the right to use the address â€˜tyâ€™ and â€˜Zhenyaâ€™?â€ Utkin said in a message which Prigozhin reposted on Telegram. â€œCertain citizens should be put against a wall for the SHAME that we have,â€ Utkin said. â€œWe are always ready to talk man to man,â€ he said. Chechen leader Kadyrov had last year supported some of Prigozhinâ€™s criticism of Russiaâ€™s top brass but their relations have distanced in recent months. Kadyrov is also a close ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin and has recently refrained from echoing criticism of the defence ministry.

Title: â€˜Stop sending weapons, hold talksâ€™ to end Russia-Ukraine war
Subtitle: Chinaâ€™s envoy Li Hui says in order to achieve peace, Kyivâ€™s allies must â€˜stop sending weapons to the battlefieldâ€™.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s allies should stopsending weaponsto Kyiv and move towards negotiations to bring lasting peace, Chinaâ€™s envoy for Eurasian affairs has said. Li Huiâ€™s appeal came as Washington and many European nations are ramping up supplies of missiles, tanks and other weapons to Ukrainian forces that are trying to take back territory occupied by Russia. â€œIf we really want to stop the war, save lives and achieve peace, we should stop sending weapons to the battlefield,â€ Li told reporters in Beijing on Friday. â€œThe painful lessons of how the Ukraine crisis developed to its current state merit deep reflection by all parties.â€ Li said there are currently â€œmany difficultiesâ€ in sitting down and engaging in talks to end the war. He added that those fighting the war are â€œnot without points of consensusâ€. â€œThe two sides have not fully shut the door on peace talks,â€ Li insisted.  The Chinese envoy toured European capitals last month seeking to promote Ukraine peace talks. In May, Li completed a 12-day tour of Kyiv, Warsaw, Paris, Berlin, Brussels and Moscow in what China said was a bid to find common ground for an eventual political settlement. â€œThe risk of escalation of the Russia-Ukraine war is still high,â€ Li said, adding that all sides must take concrete measures to â€œcool down the situationâ€ and ensure the safety of nuclear facilities. Chinese leader Xi Jinpingâ€™s government says it is neutral and wants to serve as a mediator but has supported Moscow politically. In February, Beijing released a proposed peace plan but Ukraineâ€™s allies insisted President Vladimir Putin must first withdraw Russian forces. Beijing has refused to criticise the invasion and used its status as one of five permanent United Nations Security Council members to deflect diplomatic attacks on Russia. The United States, which is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine, has so far provided about $37bn in military aid since the invasion last year. The majority of that has been in weapons systems, millions of munitions and ammunition rounds, and an array of trucks, sensors, radars and other equipment pulled from Pentagon stockpiles and sent quickly to Ukraine. European nations have also stepped up their military aid to Kyiv amid calls from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskky to further bolster weapons. Last month, the United Kingdompromised Ukrainefurther arms for its fight against Russia. Britain said it would supply Ukraine with hundreds of additional air defence missiles, as well as â€œlong-range attack dronesâ€. French President Emmanuel Macron pledged his country would supply dozens of light tanks, armoured vehicles and more air defence systems. Despite its initial hesitance to provide Kyiv with lethal weapons, Germany has become one of the biggest suppliers of arms to Ukraine, including Leopard 1 and 2 battle tanks, and the sophisticated IRIS-T SLM air defence system.

Title: US seeking TNT in Japan for Ukraine artillery shells: Report
Subtitle: Procurement could court controversy because export rules ban Japanese companies from selling lethal weaponry overseas.
Content: The United States is seeking to secure supplies of TNT in Japan for 155mm artillery shells, as Washington rushes weapons and ammunition to Ukraine for a planned counteroffensive against Russian forces. For pacifist Japan, any procurement could court controversy because export rules ban Japanese companies from selling lethal items overseas, such as the howitzer shells that Ukraine fires daily at Russian units occupying its southeastern regions. Nonetheless, the allies appear to have found a workaround to enable the TNT sale amid global shortages of munitions, two people familiar with the matter told the Reuters news agency. â€œThere is a way for the United States to buy explosives from Japan,â€ one of the people with knowledge of discussions on the matter in Japan told Reuters on condition of anonymity, citing the issueâ€™s sensitivity. Export restrictions for dual-use products or equipment sold commercially are less stringent than for items with a purely military purpose. Tokyo, which hosted US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin this week, has told the US government it will allow the sale of industrial TNT because the explosive is not a military-use-only product, the other source said. The US wants to add a Japanese company into a TNT supply chain to deliver explosives to US army-owned munitions plants that would pack them into 155mm shell cases, the person added. Japanâ€™s Ministry of Trade, Industry and Economy declined to say whether any Japanese company had approached it about exporting TNT. It added in an email that items not subject to military restrictions would be assessed under regular export rules that consider the buyerâ€™s intent, including whether their use would impede international security. The Japanese defence ministryâ€™s Acquisition, Technology and Logistics Agency declined to comment. The US state department did not directly address questions from Reuters about whether the US planned to buy TNT in Japan but said Washington was working with allies and partners â€œto provide Ukraine with the support it needsâ€ to defend itself. Japan, it added, â€œhas demonstrated leadership in supporting Ukraineâ€™s defenceâ€. Japan has already imposedsanctions on Russiaover its full-scale invasion of Ukraine and offered assistance in the form of non-lethal aid, such as body armour and food rations. Following Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s visit to Japan during theG7 leaders summitin Hiroshima last month, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida agreed to donate jeeps and trucks. Kishida wants to help Ukraine because his administration fears a Russian victory would embolden China to attack the self-ruled island of Taiwan and embroil his country in a regional war. Last year, he warned that Ukraine me be â€œEast Asia tomorrowâ€, and his administration announced Japanâ€™s biggest military build-up since World War II. There appears to be growing acceptance in Japan about providing military aid to Ukraine, but the degree of lethality is contentious, said Tsuneo Watanabe, a senior fellow at the Sasakawa Peace Foundation. â€œThe fact that Japan has decided to give trucks to Ukraine shows that things are changing. However, there doesnâ€™t yet appear to be any political consensus around the issue of sending lethal aid,â€ he said. Japan is one of the dozens of allies that Washington is asking to helparm Ukraineas it wrestles with stretched military supply chains. South Korea, which also uses 155mm shells, is among those the US has approached. A South Korean defence official told Reuters that Seoulâ€™s stance against providing lethal aid to Kyiv had not changed. Asked in Tokyo this week about the possibility of a shift in Japanese policy on lethal aid, Austin said at a press briefing that any change would be a matter for Japan but â€œany bit of supportâ€ for Ukraine was â€œalways welcomeâ€. The sources who spoke to Reuters declined to identify the Japanese company that would supply explosives to the US government and did not say how much TNT Washington wanted to buy. Reuters contacted 22 explosives makers listed on the Japan Explosives Industry Associationâ€™s website. The only one that said it made industrial TNT was Chugoku Kayaku, a Hiroshima-based firm that supplies Japanâ€™s military. â€œWe have not received any direct inquiry from the US government or US military,â€ the company said in an email. Asked if it was discussing any TNT sales through an intermediary, the firm, which lists an industrial TNT product on its website, said it did not disclose the identity of customers or potential buyers.

Title: Russia thwarts more Belgorod attacks, blames Ukraine
Subtitle: Defence ministry says it repelled three attacks in the border area, which has come under intensified fire since last month.
Content: Russiaâ€™s defence ministry has said it thwarted three cross-border attacks near the town of Shebekino, as it accused Ukraine of using what it said were â€œterrorist formationsâ€. Shebekino lies in the Belgorod region, which has been targeted in a number of attacks since May. â€œOverall, the attack involved up to 70 militants, five tanks, four armoured vehicles, seven pick-up trucks and a Kamaz truck,â€ the Russian defence ministry said on Thursday evening, reporting at least three attempted crossings. It said it used air force and artillery to repel the attacks and killed more than 50 Ukrainian fighters. The Russian Volunteer Corps (RVC), a far-right paramilitary group of ethnic Russians that supportsÂ Ukraine, claimed to be fighting inside Russia. â€œThe second phase promised by the RVCâ€™s commander has begun!â€ it said on Telegram, referring to a previous incursion, alongside images of fighters firing weapons. Another anti-KremlinÂ groupÂ that calls itself the Freedom of Russia Legion also announced a plan to launch a cross-border raid. The Belgorod region saw an unprecedented two-day armed incursion last week and has come under intensified fire in the past days. Ukraine denies its military is involved in theincursionsand says they are conducted by Russian volunteer fighters. Vyacheslav Gladkov, the Belgorod regionâ€™s governor, accused Ukrainian armed forces of repeatedly shelling Shebekino with Soviet-designed grad 122mm rockets, setting alight a dormitory and damaging an administrative building. Gladkov said at least 12 people had been wounded in the previous 24 hours. Residents poured into centres for displaced people in Belgorod city. â€œThere are many families with children, including infants and disabled people. We will try to provide them with as much care as possible,â€ said city mayor Valentin Demidov. Two people were wounded in the city when a drone crashed near a petrol station, he added. It was not possible to independently verify accounts from either side. The RVC and Freedom of Russia Legion claimed responsibility for last monthâ€™scross-border raidthat marked one of the most serious attacks on Russian territory since Moscow began its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

Title: US cuts data sharing with Russia under New START nuclear deal
Subtitle: US says withholding information is retaliatory measure for Moscowâ€™s suspension of New START (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty).
Content: The United States will stop providing Russia with some notifications requiredunder the New START nuclear arms control treaty, including updates on missile and launcher locations, in what Washington describes as a retaliatory â€œcountermeasureâ€ due to Moscowâ€™s â€œviolationsâ€ of the accord. The US state department said on Thursday that it had ceased providing the status and locations of its nuclear missiles and launchers but would continue to provide notification of the launch of intercontinental ballistic missiles and submarine-launched ballistic missiles. Russian inspection activities on US territory have ceased and visas issued and pending for Russian New START (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty) inspectors and their aircrews â€“ as well as diplomatic clearance for Russian inspection aircraft â€“ have been revoked, according toa state department fact sheet released on Thursday. The US will also not provide telemetric information to Russia on the launch of US intercontinental and submarine-launched ballistic missiles. Such data involves information that originates during a missileâ€™s test flights and under the treaty, both Moscow and Washington were to exchange such information annually. â€œThe United States has adopted lawful countermeasures in response to the Russian Federationâ€™s ongoing violations of the New START treaty. The Russian Federationâ€™s purported suspension of the New START treaty is legally invalid,â€ the state department said in the fact sheet released on Thursday.    â€œThe United States notified Russia of the countermeasures in advance and conveyed the United Statesâ€™ desire and readiness to reverse the countermeasures and fully implement the treaty if Russia returns to compliance,â€ it added. Russian President Vladimir Putin has not formally withdrawnfrom the New START treaty, but he announced in February that Moscow would suspend its participation in what is a key pillar of US-Russian nuclear arms control. Putin said Moscow could not accept US inspections of its nuclear sites under the agreement when Washington and its NATO allies had openly declared Moscowâ€™s defeat in Ukraine as a primary goal. In March, Moscow emphasised that it had not withdrawnfrom the START pact altogether and would continue to respect the caps on nuclear weapons the treaty sets. Russiaâ€™s foreign ministry had also said that Moscow would continue to notify the US of planned test launches of its ballistic missiles â€“ a key element of the agreement. Notices on ballistic launches are an essential element of nuclear strategic stability for decades, allowing Russia and the US to correctly interpret each otherâ€™s moves and make sure neither country mistakes a test launch for a preemptive nuclear missile attack. Moscow and Washington collectively control nearly 90 percent of the worldâ€™s nuclear warheads â€“ enough to destroy the planet several times over.    The New START limits the number of strategic nuclear warheads countries deploy. Signed in 2010 and due to expire in 2026, the New START treaty caps the number of strategic nuclear warheads that the US and Russia can deploy to no more than 1,550 strategic nuclear warheads and 700 land- and submarine-based missiles and bombers to deliver them. A US administration official, quoted by the Reuters news agency on Thursday, said Washington â€œwill continue to adhere to the [treatyâ€™s] central limits â€¦ and expect that Russia will continue to do so as wellâ€. Speaking to reporters on condition of anonymity, the official said the USâ€™ steps were reversible and that the country was looking todraw Moscow back into arms control talks. â€œWeâ€™ve taken a stepwise approach,â€ he said, explaining that the US wanted to use its responses to Russiaâ€™s suspension to â€œpresent them with an opportunity to return to the table to talk about returning to compliance under a New STARTâ€. The New START agreement envisages sweeping on-site inspections by Russia and the US to verify compliance. But inspections went dormant in 2020 because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Discussions on resuming inspections were supposed to have taken place in November 2022, but Russia abruptly called them off, citing US support for Ukraine following Moscowâ€™s invasion.

Title: Sweden will join NATO soon, Joe Biden promises
Subtitle: â€˜It will happen,â€™ US president says as he underscores transatlantic allianceâ€™s commitment to supporting Ukraine.
Content: Washington, DC â€“US President Joe Biden has said he is confident that Sweden will join NATO â€œas soon as possibleâ€, despite Turkey and Hungary continuing to block the northern European countryâ€™s accession to the alliance. Speaking at a United States Air Force Academy graduation ceremony on Thursday, Biden praised NATOâ€™s unity amid the Russianinvasion of Ukraine. â€œNATO is more energised and more united than itâ€™s been in decades. Itâ€™s now even stronger with the accession of our newest ally, Finland â€“ and soon Sweden â€“ to the alliance, as soon as possible. It will happen. I promise you,â€ the US president said. His remarks come just days after US Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged Turkey to approve Swedenâ€™s bid to become a NATO member. â€œFrom the perspective of the United States, the time is now to finalise Swedenâ€™s accession,â€Blinken told reportersin the northern Swedish city of Lulea on Tuesday. The top US diplomat also voiced hope that the process would be completed before a NATO summit in the Lithuanian capital Vilnius in July. NATO countries need to ratify new members. The US-led bloc has a collective defence pact â€“ known as Article 5 â€“ that stipulates that an attack on one NATO member-state is an attack on the entire alliance. Sweden and neighbouring Finland began seekingNATO membershiplast year after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Finlandofficially joinedthe alliance in April, but Swedenâ€™s application is still pending.    Hungary and Turkey have yet to approve Swedenâ€™s accession, but Ankara is seen as the main obstacle. Turkey has accused Sweden of providing a safe haven to members of the Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party (PKK), which it considers a â€œterroristâ€ group. Sweden says it is addressing Turkeyâ€™s concerns in accordance with atrilateral memorandumsigned by the two countries as well as Finland last year. On Thursday, as the foreign ministers of NATO member-states held talks in Norway, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu tweeted at his Swedish counterpart: â€œFulfill your commitments arising from Trilateral Memorandum & take concrete steps in the fight against terrorism. The rest will follow.â€ Biden said earlier this week that he raised the issue in a phone call with newly re-elected Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. â€œI congratulated Erdogan. He still wants to work on something on the F-16s. I told him we wanted a deal with Sweden, so letâ€™s get that done,â€Biden told reporterson Monday, referring to a push by Ankara to finalise a $20bn deal for US-madeF-16 fighter jets. Biden did not mention Turkey when he raised Swedenâ€™s NATO bid on Thursday.Â But he stressed that the alliance continues to stand together in response to the invasion of Ukraine, adding that Russian PresidentVladimir Putinthought NATO would â€œcrackâ€. The US president also renewed a commitment to backing Ukraine against the invasion. Washington has provided billions of dollars in humanitarian and military aid to Kyiv since the war started last year. â€œThe United States has rallied the world to stand strong with Ukraine and defend the values that the American people hold so dear â€“ freedom, sovereignty, democracy, simple dignity,â€ Biden said. â€œThe American peopleâ€™s support for Ukraine will not waver.â€ A crystal clear message to our Swedish Friends! Fulfill your commitments arising from Trilateral Memorandum & take concrete steps in the fight against terrorism. The rest will follow.https://t.co/PS1gpSMyA0 â€” MevlÃ¼t Ã‡avuÅŸoÄŸlu (@MevlutCavusoglu)June 1, 2023

Title: NATO divided on Ukrainian membership as Zelenskyy renews call
Subtitle: Ukrainian president appeals to dozens of European leaders as divisions among NATO members meeting in Norway become apparent.
Content: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has taken his quest for more arms and Ukrainian membership of powerful Western institutions to a sprawling summit of European leaders. But as Zelenskyy renewed his demands for NATO and EU membership at the European Political Community meeting in Moldova, held on Thursday, leaders of the military alliance gathered in Norway and were divided on Ukraineâ€™s call. Zelenskyy said all countries bordering Russia should be full members of both organisations since Moscow â€œtries to swallow only those who are outside of the common security spaceâ€. He called for more European support on the ground, which he said is saving lives and â€œliterally accelerating peaceâ€. According to Al Jazeeraâ€™s Stefanie Dekker, reporting from the summit, Zelenskyy was the first foreign leader to arrive at the venue, a move unlikely â€œby chanceâ€. The choice to hold the summit in Moldova, a former Soviet republic of approximately 2.6 million people near Ukraine, was seen as a message to the Kremlin from the EU and Moldovaâ€™s pro-Western government. Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte told the summit, â€œOur meeting today in Moldova speaks volumes. The country borders on Ukraine and here, the Russian threat is palpable.â€ German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, French President Emmanuel Macron and UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak also attended. Meanwhile in Norway,Â divisions among NATO allies about the speed of Kyivâ€™s accession became apparent, only weeks before a decisive mid-July summit in Vilnius. â€œAll allies agree that Moscow does not have a veto against NATO enlargement,â€ NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg told reporters foreign ministers gathered in Oslo, seeking to dispel any signs of discord. NATOÂ agreed in 2008 that Ukraine would eventually join the alliance but leaders have so far stopped short of taking steps, such as giving Kyiv a membership action plan, that would lay out a timetable for bringing Ukraine closer to the military pact. While Kyiv and its closest allies in Eastern Europe have called for concrete steps to bring Ukraine closer to membership, Western governments, such as the United States and Germany, have been wary of any move that might take the alliance closer to war with Russia. Lithuaniaâ€™s Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis said Kyiv had suffered two invasions while waiting for an answer fromÂ NATOÂ for 14 years. â€œIt is high time that we actually sit down and find a very concrete answer as to how Ukraine is going to move closer to NATO and when they become a member of the alliance,â€ he said, a call that was echoed by his Estonian counterpart. Other allies, such as Germany and Luxembourg, stressed the risks should NATO rush to let Kyiv join, while Hungary stated clearly Ukraineâ€™s NATO accession could not be on the agenda at the upcoming summit. â€œNATOâ€™s open door policy remains in place, but at the same time, it is clear that we cannot talk about accepting new members [who are] in the midst of a war,â€ German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock said.

Title: Chechen troops said to mobilise as Russian children flee border
Subtitle: Russiaâ€™s Belgorod regional Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov says more than 1,000 children due for evacuation from border areas.
Content: Fighters fromRussiaâ€™s Chechnya regionunder the command of leader Ramzan Kadyrov have likely been ordered to take a leading role in the fighting in Ukraine in a week when the governor of Russiaâ€™s Belgorod region announced theevacuation of childrenamid ongoing cross-border attacks from Ukraine. The Institute for the Study of War (ISW), a Washington, DC-based think tank, said in its latest report on Thursday that Russian military commanders had likely ordered the Chechens into battle following the withdrawal of Wagner Group mercenary forces from the destroyed city of Bakhmut. According to the ISW, Kadyrov claimed on Wednesday that his forces had received new orders and would be deploying to â€œactive combat activitiesâ€ to â€œliberateâ€ a series of settlements after assuming responsibility for the front line in Ukraineâ€™s southeast Donetsk region, which includes the contested city of Bakhmut. Kadyrov said that Chechen special forces were preparing for offensive operations ahead of Ukraineâ€™s expected counteroffensive to reclaim territory from Russian forces. â€œThe claimed return of Chechen forces to offensive operations would break Kadyrovites from a nearly yearlong hiatus from participating in high-intensity combat operationsâ€ in Ukraine, the ISW said. 5/ The#Kremlinmay perceive Chechen units as an untapped assault force that can restore#Russiaâ€™s ability to sustain simultaneous offensive efforts on multiple axes of advance. â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)June 1, 2023  Chechen fighters have primarily operated in areas behind the front line following their involvement in the bloody battles in Ukraineâ€™s cities of Mariupol, Severodonetsk and Lysychanak, the institute said. â€œThe Kremlin may perceive Chechen units as an untapped assault force that can restore Russiaâ€™s ability to sustain simultaneous offensive efforts on multiple axes of advance,â€ the ISW added. However, the ISW also noted that if reports of 7,000 Chechen troops in Ukraine are correct, Kadyrovâ€™s forces will not have the numbers â€œto mount multiple significant offensive operations successfullyâ€. Describing himself as a â€œfoot soldierâ€ of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Kadyrov had previously deployed his Chechen Republic forces in support of Russian military operations in Syria and Georgia. Reports of the possiblereturn of Chechen forcesto offensive operations come amid intensifying shelling of the border region of Russiaâ€™s Belgorod, where authorities have begun evacuating children from the districts of Shebekino and Graivoron.    Belgorodâ€™s regional Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said on Telegram on Wednesday that the first 300 evacuated children would be taken to Voronezh, a city about 250km (155 miles) further into Russia. Another 1,000 children will be removed to other provinces over the coming days, he said. â€œThe question of childrenâ€™s safety in the two districtsâ€¦ is very important,â€ Gladkov said. â€œAll of us, adults, are very worried.â€ A correspondent for state-run agency RIA Novosti near Voronezh said buses had arrived with about 150 people on board on Wednesday. Gladkov said the situation was growing worse in the village of Shebekino, where he reported more shelling during the day that injured four people but did not cause any deaths. The governor also urged Russian forces on Wednesday to launch attacks and capture Ukraineâ€™s Kharkiv region, including Kharkiv city, to create a buffer zone between Belgorod and Ukraine, according to the ISW.    Heavy shelling of Shebekino was reported early on Thursday morning by local news sources. On Tuesday, one person was reportedly killed and two others were wounded in a strike on a centre for displaced people in Belgorod. Several oil depots in the region have also been hit in recent weeks. The attacks on Russian soil have come as Kyiv says it is preparing for a major offensive against Moscowâ€™s forces. â€œThe situation is quite alarming,â€ Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on Wednesday about the shelling of Belgorod. â€œWe have not heard a single word of condemnation from the West so far,â€ Peskov said of the attacks which have affected Russian civilians in the region. More than a year into its Ukraine campaign, Russia has experienced intensifying attacks on its territory, with an unprecedented incursion by Russian anti-Putin fighters last week into Belgorod and adrone attack on Moscowon Tuesday.    The incursion into Russia from Ukraine by the Russian Volunteer Corps (RVC) and the allied Freedom of Russia Legion last week was the largest since the Russian full-scale invasion last year. The Kremlin also said on Wednesday that it was not considering the introduction of martial law in Russia despite the drone attacks on Moscow and the ongoing shelling of border regions. The Kremlinâ€™s Peskov said the imposition of martial law in Russia was not currently being discussed. According to media reports, Peskov was reacting to Chechen leader Kadyrovâ€™s demands for harsher attacks on Ukraine and the declaration of martial law after the drone attacks on Moscow. Peskov said such a decision was up to Moscow and not the regions. He also expressed concern about the ongoing shelling of Belgorod. â€œMeasures are being taken,â€ Peskov said.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 463
Subtitle: As the war enters its 463rd day, hereâ€™s a look at the main developments.
Content: This is the situation as it stands on Thursday, June 1, 2023.

Title: Mother, daughter among 3 killed in Russian missile attack on Kyiv
Subtitle: An 11-year-old girl, her mother, and another woman killed in latest Russian air attack on the Ukrainian capital.
Content: A mother and her 11-year-old daughter were among three people reported killed and at least 10 injured in a Russian missile attack on Ukraineâ€™s capital Kyiv, city officials say. Thursdayâ€™s attack, which began at about 3am (00:00 GMT), inflicted the largest number of casualties from a single attack by Russia on Kyiv in weeks. Ukraineâ€™s military said air defences shot down all 10 ballistic and Iskander cruise missiles launched from Russiaâ€™s Bryansk region in the 18th attack on the capital since the start of May. But falling missile debris often causes damage during such attacks and police said a medical clinic, kindergarten, residential buildings and cars were damaged. Authorities did not say how the three were killed. â€œInternational Childrenâ€™s Day. At night, RF [Russian Forces] again killed a child in Kyiv,â€ Andriy Yermak, chief of President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s office, wrote in a tweet, describing Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine as a â€œreal genocideâ€. International Children's Day. At night, RF again killed a child in Kyiv. Since 2014, the terrorist country has been committing crimes against small Ukrainians. From February 24, 2022, no one has any doubts â€“ this is a real genocide. And there will be responsibility for this. â€” Andriy Yermak (@AndriyYermak)June 1, 2023  The Kyiv military administration, in a post on the Telegram messaging app, said earlier on Thursday that two children were among the three people killed in Desnianskyi district on the capitalâ€™s eastern outskirts. The Kyiv Independent news outlet reported that multiple explosions were heard in the city in the early hours of Thursday and that the cityâ€™s Mayor Vitali Klitschko said emergency workers were responding in the cityâ€™s Dniprovskyi district â€“ nearer to the centre of the capital. Klitschko said on Telegram that a medical clinic had been hit as well as residential buildings. âš¡ï¸Explosions reported in Kyiv. Numerous explosions were heard in Kyiv early on June 1, as reported by a Kyiv Independent journalist. â€” The Kyiv Independent (@KyivIndependent)June 1, 2023  Debris from projectiles shot down by the cityâ€™s air defences had fallen in Desnianskyi, according to the cityâ€™s military administration, the news outlet reported. Pictures from the scene of one site posted on social media showed rescue teams attending to residents in buildings, with shattered building materials strewn about on the street outside. Ukrainian member of parliament Inna Sovsun deplored the deaths of children in â€œyet another missile attackâ€. â€œThe air raid alert is off now, but I cannot sleep. Holding my sonâ€™s hand, making sure he sleeps well,â€ Sovsun wrote in a tweet. Two children have been killed as the result of yet another missile attack in#Kyiv30 minutes ago. They went to bed last night, and now they are deadâ€¦The air raid alert is off now, but I cannot sleep. Holding my sonâ€™s hand, making sure he sleeps well â€” Inna Sovsun (@InnaSovsun)June 1, 2023

Title: Iraqi man reported killed fighting for Russiaâ€™s Wagner in Ukraine
Subtitle: Abbas Abuthar Witwit is reported to have died in Ukraine in April after being injured in the battle for Bakhmut.
Content: An Iraqi citizen fighting with Russiaâ€™s Wagner mercenary force was killed in Ukraine in April, Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin has said, in what is believed to be the first confirmed case of a Middle East native to have died fighting in the war. Abbas Abuthar Witwit died on April 7, a day after arriving at a Wagner hospital in the Russian-occupied eastern Ukrainian city of Luhansk, according to the Russian-language RIA FAN news site. Prigozhin confirmed to the Reuters news agency on Wednesday that he had recruited Witwit from prison in Russia, adding that he was not the first native of an Arab country to have joined his mercenary unit from jail. He said the Iraqi national had fought well and â€œdied heroicallyâ€. Much of the fighting for the destroyed Ukrainian city of Bakhmut has been undertaken by convicts recruited by Wagner from Russian prisons on the promise of a pardon if they survived six months at the front in Ukraine.    In February, the United States said the Wagner mercenary group had sufferedmore than 30,000 casualtiessince Moscowâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine last February and that 90 percent ofWagner fighterskilled in Ukraine since December 2022 were convicts. Prigozhin said last week thatapproximately 20,000of his mercenaries were killed in the months-long battle for control of Bakhmut. He also said he recruited about 50,000 prisoners tofight with Wagnerin Ukraine and that about 20 percent of them were now dead. RIA FAN news said that Witwit died after being wounded in Bakhmut. According to court papers seen by Reuters, Witwit was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison on drug charges in July 2021 by a court in the Russian city of Kazan. The documents said Witwit was a first-year student at a technical university in Russia at the time of his conviction. In a video published by RIA FAN, a man identified as Witwitâ€™s father is shown receiving awards posthumously given to his son by Wagner and saying he had supported his sonâ€™s decision to enlist as a â€œvolunteerâ€ to fight in Ukraine. â€œAbbas always pursued his freedom and wanted to be a man who defends his freedom and himself and he told me he found his freedom in Russia,â€ the man identified as the father is shown saying.

Title: Bakhmut falls silent as Russia and Ukraine trade air raids
Subtitle: Silence proves worse than the noise of battle for Russian morale, as units desert and Ukraine appears to attack Russian soil at will.
Content: After 10 months of warfare, ground assaults have largely come to a halt and the guns have mostly fallen silent in the city of Bakhmut. Russian troops pausedto rotate out the Wagner Group mercenaries who spearheaded the battle to capture the eastern Ukrainian city. Ukrainian forces paused a flanking manoeuvre that recently captured the high ground around Bakhmut â€œto perform other military tasksâ€. Only one combat clash was reported in the 66th week of the war â€“ on Saturday. â€œThere are no active battles there â€“ neither in the city, nor on the flanks,â€ Ukraineâ€™s Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar said in a Telegram post. â€œInstead, the enemy is actively shelling the outskirts of the city and the approaches to it.â€ in a video interview he posted to his Telegram channel, Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin said he had lost 20,000 mercenaries in the battle for Bakhmut alone. The Russian defence ministry has not said how many supporting troops were killed from airborne and mechanised units. â€œThe amount of killing that took place is really hard to imagine â€¦ thereâ€™s rotting bodies, Iâ€™m sure, everywhere still,â€ retired US Colonel Seth Krummrich told Al Jazeera on Tuesday. â€œThey were talking about human waves â€¦ Prigozhin was becoming really frustrated shoving all these mercenaries in, trying to take 10 metres [32.8 feet] of ground,â€ said Krummrich, who has led special forces detachments in Afghanistan and the Middle East, and currently serves as vice president for Global Guardian, a security consultant. Russia claimed victory in Bakhmut on May 21, and nine days later Ukrainian eastern forces spokesman Serhiy Cherevaty admitted the city itself was in Russian hands. â€œThe enemy fought for this district centre for 10 months, but did not manage to capture it until the end,â€ he said. He hinted at an anticipated Ukrainian counteroffensive. â€œThe Russians are well aware that, in addition to military losses, failure to hold the city can also cause them great reputational losses,â€ Cherevaty said. â€œI think the Russians are setting themselves up for an incredible failure,â€ Krummrich said. â€œWith the imminent counteroffensive, they stand to lose Bakhmut and much, much more. If theyâ€™re going to claim a Russian victory to the Russian people now, theyâ€™re going to lose big-time if they get their supply lines cut off and they end up having to abandon the city.â€ Ukraine has said it has 12 trained and equipped battalions ready to throw into the counteroffensive, and Krummrich believed weather was now the only factor holding them up. â€œThe units are trained, so I believe as soon as the ground dries, theyâ€™re going to go.â€ â€œThe Russians are sitting in Bakhmut, they understand whatâ€™s coming next, they understand theyâ€™re going to get attacked,â€ he said. On May 28, Ukraineâ€™s general staff said 80 Russian troops had deserted their positions in Lysychansk, the city in Luhansk province Russian forces seized last July. Another 30 Russian troops deserted in Bakhmut, taking military equipment with them, the staff said. Instead of continuing the attritional ground battle for Bakhmut, Russia and Ukraine turned to a largely psychological war in the air. On May 26, Ukraineâ€™s air force said it had destroyed an airborne armada of 31 drones and 17 missiles overnight, including 10 Kh-101 and Kh-155 missiles fired from Russian planes over the Caspian Sea, seven S-300 and S-400 repurposed air defence missiles fired from occupied Zaporizhia, and 31 Iranian Shahed-131 and Shahed-136 drones. The targets were â€œcritical infrastructure and infrastructure of the defence forcesâ€ in the east of the country, said the air force. Ukrainian military intelligence spokesman Andriy Yusov said the operation was chiefly of propaganda value. â€œThe enemy would like to show that their â€˜analogovnetâ€™ weapons can do something to the Ukrainian army and Western weapons. But it turns out not,â€ he said. Two days later, Ukrainian air defences shot down at least 40 drones Russia launched at the capital, Kyiv, said the cityâ€™s mayor, Vitali Klitschko. Falling debris killed a man and wounded a woman. The pre-dawn attacks came on the last Sunday of May, when the capital celebrates â€œKyiv Dayâ€, the anniversary of its official founding 1,541 years ago. And the following day, Ukraineâ€™s commander of the military, General Valery Zaluzhny, said the armed forces had destroyed all 11 Iskander-K and Iskander-M cruise missiles launched north of the border into Ukraine. But on May 30, Ukraine seemed to have responded by sending eight drones to Moscow. Russia said it had jammed or shot down all eight drones. In a post on Telegram after the attack, Alexander Khinshtein, a prominent member of Russiaâ€™s parliament from the governing United Russia bloc, said three of the eight drones had been downed over Rublyovka, a suburb west of Moscow where much of Russiaâ€™s political and business elite live. â€œThis is clearly a sign of terrorist activity,â€ Russian President Vladimir Putin said. Ukrainian Colonel Petro Chernyk commented, â€œIf drones of unknown origin break through multi-layered defences and practically fly to the capital of a country that considers itself a superpower, do their weapons have any value?â€ Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin blamed the defence ministry for a weak defence. â€œYou, the defence ministry, have done nothing to launch an offensive,â€ Prigozhin said. â€œHow dare you allow the drones to reach Moscow?â€ Ukraine denied responsibility. â€œWe have nothing directly to do with this,â€ Ukrainian presidential adviser Mykhailo Podolyak said. Russiaâ€™s ambassador to Washington blamed the US for encouraging the attack, and mocked the Biden administrationâ€™s statement that it was gathering information on the incident. â€œWhat are these attempts to hide behind the phrase they are â€˜gathering informationâ€™?â€ Anatoly Antonov said in remarks published on Telegram. â€œThis is an encouragement for Ukrainian terrorists.â€ On May 29, another attack by two drones caused an explosion in Russiaâ€™s Pskov region near the border with Belarus that left an oil pipelineâ€™s administrative building damaged, local Governor Mikhail Vedernikov said. Ukraine has sometimes initially denied responsibility for attacks it later claimed. The New York Times reported unnamed US sources as saying Ukrainian special forces or military intelligence were behind a similar drone attack on the Kremlin on May 3. On May 27, the leader of Ukraineâ€™s intelligence service confirmed Kyivâ€™s involvement in an explosion that badly damaged the Kerch Bridge, connecting Russia to Russian-occupied Crimea, seven months after it happened.  Ukraine has also denied involvement in a May 22 incursion onto Russian territory by anti-Putin Russian nationalists. The Russian commander of that raid said his group would soon return. â€œI think you will see us again on that side,â€ said Denis Kapustin at a news conference in Ukraine, describing himself as the commander of the Russian Volunteer Corps. â€œEvery operation that takes place on the territory of Russia forces the military leadership to move a large amount of forces precisely to that quadrant, therefore laying bare some parts of the front, parts of the border,â€ he said. â€œThe shaping of the battlefield is happening now for the counteroffensive,â€ Krummrich said. â€œWe see the attacks behind enemy lines, we see the attacks in Russia by those militias. We see the drone attacks in Moscow. That is all shaping what is coming next,â€ he said, adding that the complexity was aggravating Russian decision-makers, already politically divided over a war that is not going well. â€œRussia now has to defend all the way back to their capital. Theyâ€™re already spread thin. So, theyâ€™re going to have a lot of complex decisions to make about where to put their forces. If the last 15 months are any indicator, they will absolutely put their forces in the wrong place, and theyâ€™re going to lose,â€ Krummrich said. â€œWe need to prepare for an arduous war,â€ Wagner boss Prigozhin said in his interview. â€œWe are in such a condition that we could f***ing lose Russia â€“ that is the main problem â€¦ We need to impose martial law.â€ Russian former President Dmitry Medvedev also sought to prepare public opinion for a long fight. â€œThis conflict will last a very long time, most likely decades,â€ the RIA news agency cited Medvedev as saying during a visit to Vietnam. US Chairman of the Joint Chiefs Mark Milley said Ukraine could liberate all of its territories by military means, â€œbut probably not in the near futureâ€, adding that such a war would be â€œbloody and difficultâ€. â€œRussia will not win this war militarily,â€ Milley said.

Title: Russia accuses US of â€˜encouraging terroristsâ€™ after Moscow strike
Subtitle: President Putin casts the attack as a Ukrainian attempt to intimidate Moscow residents and says the capitalâ€™s air defences will be â€˜beefed upâ€™.
Content: The United States is encouraging Ukraine to launch cross-border â€œterroristâ€ attacks, a Russian official alleged, after Moscow was hit by a series of drone strikes. The White House, meanwhile, said on Tuesday it did not support attacks inside Russia, and that it is still gathering information on the incident. â€œWhat are these attempts to hide behind the phrase they are â€˜gathering informationâ€™?â€ Anatoly Antonov, Russiaâ€™s ambassador to the US, said in remarks published on the Telegram messaging channel. â€œThis is an encouragement for Ukrainian terrorists.â€ Russia has long accused what it calls the â€œcollective Westâ€ ofstaging a proxy war against Moscowby supporting Ukraine with military and financial aid. President Vladimir Putin also cast the assault, which brought the 15-month war in Ukraine to the heart of Russia, as a â€œterrorist actâ€. Ukraine, on the other hand, has accused Russia of â€œterrorismâ€ for its bombing of Ukrainian civilians, allegations Moscow denies. A Ukrainian presidential aide denied Kyiv was directly involved in the drone attack on Moscow, but said Ukraine was enjoying watching events and forecast more to come.    The drone attack on Moscow exposed glaring breaches in its air defences and underlined the capitalâ€™s vulnerability, analysts said. Mark Cancian, a senior adviser with the Center for Strategic and International Studies, noted part of the reason why drones could make it all the way to Moscow undetected was because Russian air defences are mostly focused on fending off more sophisticated weapons. â€œThey are oriented on missiles, ballistic missiles, regional missiles, aircraft, bombers, but not short-range drones, you know, which might be flying very low over the ground,â€ Cancian said. â€œThe Russian air defence was just not designed to do this.â€ The Russian military will likely move some of its air assets away from the front line to help protect Moscow, Cancian said, a move that would weaken Russian troops in the face ofa Ukrainian counteroffensive. â€œThatâ€™s good for the Ukrainians in the sense that theyâ€™re pulling these systems away from other areas where they could be used maybe from front-line units,â€ he said. The attack, which lightly damaged three apartment buildings and wounded two people, angered Russiaâ€™s hardliners who scathingly criticised the military brass for failing to protect the capital â€“ more than 500km (310 miles) from the front line in Ukraine. Putin cast the attack on Moscow as a Ukrainian attempt to intimidate its residents. He said Moscowâ€™s air defences worked as expected, but admitted protecting a huge city is a daunting task. â€œItâ€™s clear what needs to be done to beef up air defences â€“ and we will do it,â€ the Russian leader said. Military watchers said the drones used in the attack were relatively crude and cheap, but could have a range of up to 1,000km (620 miles). They predicted more could follow.  Some Kremlin watchers noted Putinâ€™s calm reaction that contrasted withangry statements from Russian hawksreflects his belief the public will not be unsettled by the attack. â€œPutin has talked repeatedly about the Russian peopleâ€™s remarkable patience and tenacity,â€ Tatiana Stanovaya of the Carnegie Endowment said in a commentary. â€œNo matter how defiant another Ukrainian attack is, Putin doesnâ€™t think that it could provoke public discontent with the government.â€ James Nixey, director of the Russia and Eurasia programme at Chatham House, said the drone strikes signalled a growing Ukrainian determination to launch attacks deep inside Russia and he predicted more will come. â€œThis is not the first and itâ€™s not the last,â€ said Nixey. â€œThe Ukrainians are in various respects flexing their muscles, seeing what theyâ€™re capable of hitting back. It is one more part of the Ukrainian play to ensure they are not just playing defence, but they can play some offence as well.â€ Despite loud calls for revenge, the Russian military cannot do much more than what it has done since starting the war in February 2022, Nixey noted. â€œThe reality is that Russia does have limits in what it can do. Itâ€™s got limits on manpower, limits on its finances, limits on its artillery munitions, missiles, drones, everything,â€ he said. â€œTheyâ€™re already expending all their efforts, all their monies, all their treasure, all their blood, if you like, on prosecuting their war in Ukraine.â€ Last week, the Russian borderregion of Belgorod was the targetof one of the most serious cross-border raids since the war began, with two pro-Ukrainian paramilitary groups claiming responsibility. The attacks also drew calls for bolstering Russiaâ€™s borders.

Title: Wagner boss blasts Russiaâ€™s elite following Moscow drone attack
Subtitle: Russian mercenary force boss Yevgeny Prigozhin issued expletive-laden statement criticising failure to protect Moscow.
Content: The head ofRussiaâ€™s Wagner mercenaryforce has again criticised the Russian military and political elite following the drone attack on Moscow that injured two people, damaged property and left some furious the Kremlin had not better protected the capital city. In an expletive-drenched statement posted on Telegram by his press service on Tuesday,Yevgeny Prigozhinâ€“ whose mercenary fighters have played a key role in the war in Ukraine â€“ blamed the drone attack on out-of-touch officials living in Moscowâ€™s affluent suburb of Rublyovka. â€œYou, the Defence Ministry, have done nothing to launch an offensive,â€ Prigozhin said. â€œHow dare you allow the drones to reach Moscow?â€ â€œAnd what do ordinary people do when drones with explosives crash into their windows?â€ Focusing his ire on powerful residents of the upmarket Rublyovka area in Moscowâ€™s western suburbs, Prigozhin spoke of the â€œscumâ€ and â€œswineâ€ who sat quietly while Moscow was attacked. In a post on Telegram after the attack on Tuesday, Alexander Khinshtein, a prominent member of Russiaâ€™s parliament from the ruling United Russia bloc, said three of the eight drones had been downed over three Rublyovka villages, one of which is located just 10 minutes drive from Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s residence at Novo-Ogaryovo. Rublyovka, a patchwork of elite gated communities in the forests west of Moscow, which once boasted some of the worldâ€™s highest real-estate prices, is home to much of Russiaâ€™s political, business and cultural elite. Former President Dmitry Medvedev and Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin have been reported to own homes in Rublyovka, alongside many of Russiaâ€™s richest business figures. A post shared by Al Jazeera English (@aljazeeraenglish) Wagner boss Prigozhin, known for his blunt and often foul language, has repeatedly cast Rublyovkaâ€™s residents as an out-of-touch elite insufficiently committed to the war in Ukraine and has blamed the top brass for Russian failures on the battlefield. Russian military blogger Igor Girkin â€“ whom a Dutch court found guilty of the murder of 298 people who were killed when flight MH17 was shot down over Russian-controlled eastern Ukraine in 2014 â€“ also criticised Rublyovka residents on Tuesday who, he said, had â€œnever thought about the countryâ€. He also chided Putin for continuing to state the war in Ukraine was a â€œspecial military operationâ€, despite drone attacks on the Russian capital, the Institute for the Study of War (ISW)wroteon Wednesday. Following the drone attacks,Ramzan Kadyrov,the strongman leader of the Russian province of Chechnya, urged the Kremlin to declare martial law nationwide and use all its resources in Ukraine â€œto sweep away that terrorist gangâ€. The ISW, a Washington, DC-based think tank, said that Kadyrov also warned European countries over supplying Ukraine with weapons, stating that â€œif they continue to supply Ukraine with weapons, they will not have the weapons needed to defend themselves when Russia â€˜knocks on their doors'â€. Some Kremlin watchers noted that Putinâ€™s calm reaction to the drone attack contrasted starkly with angry statements from Russian hawks and appears to reflect his belief that the Russian public will not be unsettled by the attack. Putin said it was clear that Moscowâ€™s air defences need to be improved against what he described as Ukrainian â€œterrorismâ€. Russiaâ€™s envoy to the United States said on Wednesday that Washington was encouraging Kyiv to carry out such attacks by not speaking out against the drone raid on Moscow. The White House said it did not support attacks inside of Russia and that it was still gathering information on the incident. â€œWhat are these attempts to hide behind the phrase that they are â€˜gathering informationâ€™?â€ Russian ambassador to Washington Anatoly Antonov said in remarks published on the Telegram messaging channel. â€œThis is an encouragement for Ukrainian terrorists,â€ he said. Though not commenting specifically on the Moscow drone attacks, the United Kingdomâ€™s Foreign Secretary James Cleverly said on Tuesday that Ukraine had the right to attack targets on Russian territory for the purpose of self-defence. â€œUkraine does have the legitimate right to defend itself,â€ Cleverly said during a press conference with his Estonian counterpart Margus Tsahkna in Estoniaâ€™s capital Tallinn.    â€œIt has the legitimate right to do so within its own borders, of course, but it does also have the right to project force beyond its borders to undermine Russiaâ€™s ability to project force into Ukraine itself,â€ he said. â€œSo legitimate military targets beyond its own border are part of Ukraineâ€™s self-defence. And we should recognise that,â€ he added. Ukrainian forces shelled a Russian town close to the border for the third time in a week on Wednesday, damaging buildings and setting vehicles on fire, the governor of the region said on Wednesday. At least one person was injured during the artillery strike on Shebekino, Belgorod Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said. A Ukrainian drone also sparked a fire at the Afipsky oil refinery in southern Russia on Wednesday, the governor of Russiaâ€™s Krasnodar region said. The fire was soon extinguished and there were no casualties, Governor Veniamin Kondratyev said on the Telegram messaging app. The Afipsky refinery is not far from the Black Sea port of Novorossiisk, near another refinery that has been attacked several times this month.

Title: NATO launches Arctic exercises, pledges protection of Finland
Subtitle: NATO aircraft and troops from Norway, the UK, US and Sweden are participating in Arctic exercises
Content: NATO countries have kicked off military exercises with a pledge to defend theirnewest member, Finland, which is hosting its first joint training in the Arctic region since becoming part of the Western alliance in April. Nearly 1,000 allied forces from Norway, the United Kingdom andÂ the United States â€“ as well as NATO applicant Sweden â€“ joined approximately 6,500 Finnish troops and some 1,000 vehicles for exercises this week, which mark Finlandâ€™s biggest modern-time land-force drill above the Arctic Circle. Overseeing NATO exercises just a two-hour drive from the Russian border at one of Europeâ€™s largest artillery training grounds in Rovajarvi, northern Finland, US Army Major-General Gregory Anderson from the 10th Mountain Division said his country stood ready to defend Finland. â€œWe are here, we are committed. The US Army is here training with our newest NATO ally to build that capability, to help defend Finland if anything happened,â€ Anderson said on Tuesday. Some 150 aircraft from 14 NATO members and partner countries are also participating in Arctic Challenge 2023 exercises, according to NATO Air Command. The objective of#ACE23is to train participating forces to conduct dissimilar aircraft combat in large composite air operations safely and effectively.The ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ 48th Fighter Wing heritage F-15E Strike Eagle is also part of the ACE23 fighting force.@HQUSAFEAFAF@NATO_AIRCOMpic.twitter.com/QmSB9LDrYJ â€” Ilmavoimat (@FinnishAirForce)May 30, 2023  Theaddition of Finlandto the NATO bloc has more than doubled the length of the border the military alliance shares with Russia amid increasing tension between Moscow and the West following Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. â€œItâ€™s of no question at all. We have prepared plans on what to do if we are to be part of the defence of Finland,â€ said Major-General Karl Engelbrektson, commander of the Swedish land forces. Sweden is Finlandâ€™s closest military partner and it was Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine that convinced Sweden and Finland last year to ditch long-held policies of military non-alignment and seek the security of NATOâ€™s collective defence commitment. Finland formally joined NATO on April 4, drawing a threat from Moscow of â€œcounter-measuresâ€. Sweden hopes to be a NATO member by the time of the allianceâ€™s summit in Vilnius, Lithuania in July.    Sweden has been what NATO describes as an â€œofficial inviteeâ€ since 2022, which allows attendance at meetings and the coordinating of activities with other NATO allies. Full membership will take place once all NATO allies haveratified Swedenâ€™s accessionapplication, the bloc has said. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg voiced guarded optimism on Tuesday that Swedenâ€™s accession by the July 11-12 NATO summit was â€œwithin reachâ€. â€œThere are no guarantees but itâ€™s absolutely possible to reach a solution and enable the decision on full membership for Sweden by then,â€ Stoltenberg told reporters in Oslo on the eve of a NATO foreign ministersâ€™ meeting to prepare for the summit. Turkeyratified Finlandâ€™s NATO membershipbut has yet to do so for Sweden. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Sweden has not yet met all of his countryâ€™s demands on securing his support for membership, particularly because of what he sees as Sweden providing safe haven to members of the Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party (PKK) and the Democratic Union Party (PYD) in Syria, both of which Ankara considers â€œterroristsâ€.    Ilmari Laukkanen, a 20-year-old Finnish conscript who operated a field gun in the exercise but in his civilian life works looking after a family farm near the Russian border, said he would be ready to fight for Finlandâ€™s new allies if needs be. â€œOf course, I would. If we are given something good then we give in return,â€ Laukkanen told the Reuters news agency.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 462
Subtitle: As the war enters its 462nd day, hereâ€™s a look at the main developments.
Content: This is the situation as it stands on Wednesday, May 31, 2023.

Title: â€˜Time is nowâ€™ for Sweden to join NATO, Blinken says
Subtitle: Top US diplomat urges Turkey to approve Sweden accession to alliance, says Washington committed to Stockholmâ€™s security.
Content: The United States has urged Turkey to approve Swedenâ€™s accession into NATO, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken saying that â€œthe time is nowâ€ for the northern European country to join the alliance. Speaking alongside Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson on Tuesday, the top US diplomat said Sweden has been qualified to join NATO â€œfrom day oneâ€ and has taken significant steps to address Turkeyâ€™s â€œlegitimateâ€ security concerns. â€œFrom the perspective of the United States, the time is now to finalise Swedenâ€™s accession,â€ Blinken told reporters in the northern Swedish city of Lulea. Sweden and neighbouring Finland started seekingNATO membershiplast year after Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The US-led alliance has a collective defence pact, meaning an attack on one member is considered an attack on all. All members of NATO have to agree to allow new countries into the bloc. Finlandofficially joinedthe alliance last month, but Swedenâ€™s application is still pending.    Hungary and Turkey have not ratified Swedenâ€™s accession, though Ankara is seen as the main hurdle. Turkey has accused Sweden of providing a safe haven to members of the Kurdistan Workersâ€™ Party (PKK), which it considers a â€œterroristâ€ group. In June of last year, Turkey, Sweden and Finland signed a so-called trilateral memorandum to address Ankaraâ€™s grievances about banned armed groups. Turkey, however, says Sweden has not fulfilled all of its commitments in the agreement. An IslamophobicQuran-burning protestin Stockholm in January â€” which the government condemned â€” further strained ties between the two countries. â€œTurkey has raised important and legitimate concerns. Sweden and Finland both addressed those concerns. And so, the time to move forward is now. Weâ€™d like to see that happen before the Vilnius summit,â€ Blinken said on Tuesday, referring to a NATO meeting in the Lithuanian capital in July. Earlier this week, US President Joe Biden said he discussed Swedenâ€™s NATO bid with his Turkish counterpart Recep Tayyip Erdogan,who won re-electionon Sunday. They also spoke about Turkeyâ€™s push to buy F-16s, a model of US fighter jet. â€œI congratulated Erdogan. He still wants to work on something on the F-16s. I told him we wanted a deal with Sweden, so letâ€™s get that done,â€Biden told reporterson Monday. On Tuesday, Blinken said the Biden administration does not see the $20bn F-16 deal and Swedenâ€™s NATO bid as connected, but he warned that some US lawmakers do. â€œSome members of Congress â€¦ are linking Swedenâ€™s accession to NATO to the moving forwardon the F-16s. Congress is a fully equal and independent branch of government,â€ he said.Â  â€œTheir voice and their vote in any such decisions, of course, is critical.â€ Congress can veto arms deals approved by the administration, though it has never successfully blocked weapon sales to foreign countries.    Regardless of Swedenâ€™s NATO status, Blinken added on Tuesday, the US will back its security. â€œWe and our allies are both committed to and well-positioned tohelp Swedenaddress its security needs, irrespective of whether accession happens tomorrow or in two weeks or in a few weeks after that,â€ he said. For his part, Kristersson, the Swedish prime minister, said his country is moving forward with fulfilling its pledges to its â€œTurkish friendsâ€ in accordance with the trilateral memorandum. â€œWe have always recognised the fact that every NATO ally has to make its own decision, and only Turkey can make Turkeyâ€™s decisions, and we fully respect that,â€ he said.

Title: Opposition sues South Africa government to force Putin arrest
Subtitle: The ICC warrant to arrest Putin has launched a debate in South Africa which now faces a diplomatic dilemma ahead of the BRICS summit.
Content: South Africaâ€™s leading opposition party said on Tuesday it had taken legal action to force the government to arrest Russian President Vladimir Putin if he were to attend a planned summit in the country. In March, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issued an arrest warrant against Putin â€“ over accusations that Russia unlawfully deported Ukrainian children â€“ who is to visit Cape Town for a Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa (BRICS) bloc meeting in August. On Tuesday, the Democratic Alliance (DA) party said it launched a court application to ensure the government detains the Russian leader and hands him over to the ICC â€œshould President Putin set foot in South Africa.â€ â€œThis pre-emptory court action aims to ensure that South Africa upholds its obligations,â€ DA shadow justice minister Glynnis Breytenbach said in a statement. An ICC member, South Africa, which has close diplomatic ties with Moscow, is now in a diplomatic dilemma. â€œWe will explore various options with regard to how the Rome Statute was domesticated in our country including the option to look at extending customary diplomatic immunity to visiting heads of state in our country,â€ justice minister Ronald Lamola said in May. Breytenbach said the DA was seeking a â€œdeclaratory orderâ€ to avoid a repeat of 2015 when Pretoria failed to arrest then-Sudanese President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who was similarly wanted by the ICC. South Africa threatened to pull out of the ICC at the time but ended proceedings to do so due to legal barriers. Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov on Tuesday declined to say whether Putin will travel to South Africa for the summit. â€œRussia will be duly represented,â€ Peskov said, adding Moscow expected its BRICS partners â€œnot be guidedâ€ by â€œillegitimate decisionsâ€ such as the ICC arrest warrant. The DAâ€™s legal action comes as the government granted diplomatic immunity to officials attending a BRICS foreign ministers meeting this week and the groupingâ€™s heads of state summit in August. Some read the move as a preparatory step to provide legal cover for Putinâ€™s visit â€” something Pretoria has denied. â€œThese immunities do not override any warrant that may have been issued by any international tribunal against any attendee of the conference,â€ South Africaâ€™s foreign affairs department said in a statement. Their issuing was â€œstandardâ€ procedure for the hosting of international conferences, it said. South Africa has refused to condemn Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, saying it wants to stay neutral and prefers dialogue to end the war. Earlier this month, President Cyril Ramaphosa said his country has been under â€œextraordinary pressureâ€ to pick sides in theÂ  conflict, following accusations it has tilted towards the Kremlin.

Title: After drone attack, fears, anger and a sense of calm in Moscow
Subtitle: Russians reel from a rare drone attack which Putin says was aimed at civilian targets.
Content: On Tuesday morning, at least eight attackdrones entered Moscowâ€™sairspace before being shot down by the cityâ€™s air defences, a few hitting residential buildings on the way down. The Russian government accused Ukraine of a â€œterrorist attackâ€, which Kyiv officials wryly denied. â€œYou know, we are being drawn into the era of artificial intelligence. Perhaps not all drones are ready to attack Ukraine and want to return to their creators and ask them questions like: â€˜Why are you sending us [to hit] the children of Ukraine? In Kyiv?â€™â€ Ukrainian presidential adviser Mykhailo Podolyak said on the YouTube breakfast show of exiled Russian journalist Alexander Plushev. President Vladimir Putin said the attack was aimed at â€œcivilian targetsâ€ with the goal of frightening Russians. But some Muscovites are unfazed, even though Tuesdayâ€™s assault came after a recent incursion intoBelgorod, a Russian region bordering Ukraine, and a drone attack aimed at theKremlin. â€œYep, those are Ukrainian UFOs buzzing around us,â€ a banker in his 30s in the Russian capital, who requested anonymity, told Al Jazeera. â€œItâ€™s still pretty calm here; thereâ€™s no fuss, but donâ€™t forget how they gracefully landed by theKremlinas well. So the â€˜great planâ€™ [for the invasion of Ukraine] turned out to be so-so â€“ I wonder how the public will react further.â€ On his Telegram feed, Moscow mayor Sergey Sobyanin said two people were injured but â€œnobody needed hospitalisationâ€. After targeted buildings were inspected, residents who had fled began returning to their homes. â€œIt sounded like a motorbike,â€ a witness said, in comments carried by the popular Russian channel Shot on the Telegram messaging app. â€œThen there were two claps, and the smell of kerosene,â€ said the woman. â€œWe live on the fourth floor and felt some heavy object hitting the building, which forced us to get up and have a look.â€ As some in the capital reeled, questions are being asked about security. â€œStinking beasts, what are you doing?â€ Yevgeny Prigozhin, the chief of Russiaâ€™s force of Wagner mercenaries, raged on his Telegram channel, blaming Russian officials, with whom he has had frequent public disagreements, for failing to stop the attack. â€œYou are the Department of Defence. You didnâ€™t do a damn thing to step up. Why the f*** are you allowing these drones to fly to Moscow? The fact that they are flying to your homes in Rublyovka [a posh neighbourhood] â€¦ to hell with it! Let your houses burn. What will ordinary people do when explosive drones crash through their windows?â€ Parliamentary deputy Maxim Ivanov described it as the most serious attack on the nationâ€™s capital since World War II. â€œThe morning attack on Moscow is the most serious since the time when the Nazi invader in 1941 trampled our land on the outskirts of the capital,â€ Ivanov wrote on Telegram, although Moscow has suffered several deadly bombings and hostage incidents since then. The bloodiest example is the 1999 apartment bombings, in which at least 300 people were killed in attacks blamed on Chechen rebels. â€œYou will either defeat the enemy as a single fist with our Motherland, or the indelible shame of cowardice, collaboration and betrayal will engulf your family,â€ said Ivanov.    Other politicians were less melodramatic. Lawmaker Alexander Khinshtein said that â€œa new reality â€¦ needs to be realised.â€ â€œUndoubtedly, the sabotage and terrorist attacks of Ukraine will only increase,â€ he wrote on Telegram, â€œand it is necessary to radically strengthen defence and security measures, especially in terms of countering drones.â€ That eight drones were shot down was â€œremarkableâ€, he said. â€œBut this should not reassure anyone. Donâ€™t underestimate the enemy!â€ The influential military analysis channel Rybar, which has more than a million subscribers on Telegram, speculated that Ukraine was behind the attack, that it was aided by the United Kingdom, and that it was an attempted attack on military installations. â€œWe do not believe the Ukrainians intentionally launch UAVs at residential buildings in Moscow. Not because Ukrainians are so innocent and cuddly, itâ€™s quite the opposite â€“ give them free rein, they will turn all of Russia into dust. But because the decision on such strikes is made not by the Ukrainians, but by the British. There are enough objects in Moscow that Ukrainian formations could aim at. Residential buildings as a target, to put it mildly, are not militarily justified,â€ it said. Andrey Medvedev, a journalist and official of the local Moscow parliament, suggested the attack was aimed at boosting morale among Ukrainians â€“ and among Kyivâ€™s Western partners. â€œThe UAV raid on Moscow was quite predictable. But it seems that this time the Armed Forces of Ukraine prepared it in a hurry â€¦ The urgency was due to the need to somehow change the information agenda in Ukraine. Does this seriously affect the course of the war? Absolutely not,â€ he said on Telegram. â€œBut yes, the enemyâ€™s PR campaign turned out quite well. True, I repeat, for internal use and for the collective CNN. There, all the Western media, lining up like a pig, go on the attack and write about chaos and panic in the Russian capital and the Moscow region. In general, it should be understood that a UAV PR attack will now, in principle, be accompanied by disinformation on social networks and online chats. [They will say] that in fact, another 10 UAVs ended up, say, in a military hospital, but the authorities are hiding it, and so on. Information hygiene is such [an important] thing.â€

Title: Ukrainians canâ€™t sleep as Russia hits Kyiv, but morale stays high
Subtitle: Wartime noise from wailing drones to exploding missiles keeps Ukrainians up, and united against Moscow.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraineâ€“ A smoking piece of a Russian cruise missile fell just metres away from Lyudmila Lopashchenko near a book market in northern Kyiv. The fragment belonged to an Iskander, one of the 11 hypersonic ballistic missiles Moscowlaunchedon the Ukrainian capital on Monday morning, in a rare daytime attack.
