Lopashchenko did not flinch, did not rush to the cool, breezy safety of a nearby subway station that has served as a bomb shelter since the Russia-Ukraine war began. â€œWe got used to it all,â€ the 57-year-old told Al Jazeera, as she waited for a bus in central Kyiv on Tuesday. â€œNo one is hiding anymore.â€ To her â€“ and many others in the city whose pre-war population stood at 3.6 million â€“ Tuesday was business as usual, even after Kyiv woke up to a fourth attack in just three days. It was the 17th barrage this month in the Ukrainian capital as Moscow keeps changing tactics by varying the direction of attacks, the timing, and the number of cruise missiles and drones. According to Ukrainian officials, some were fired from Russiaâ€™s Black Sea fleet in annexed Crimea, some from bombers and fighter jets that flow up in western Russia without entering Ukraineâ€™s airspace and send their missiles low to avoid detection. Moscow wants to â€œconfuse and mislead our air defenceâ€, air force spokesman Yurii Ihnat said in televised remarks on Sunday. The results were painful. A 33-year-old woman was killed on Tuesday morning â€“ only because she came out to the balcony of her apartment in a high-rise building to watch the attack, Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko said. Thirteen more people were wounded, and the debris from shot-down drones and missiles caused fires in several apartment buildings and private houses, officials said.  To many Kyivans, the most harrowing sound that keeps them awake and horrified at night is the wailing ofIranian-made Shahed dronesâ€“ that are mockingly dubbed â€œmopedsâ€ here. â€œIt is so scary,â€ Olena Tkachenko, a nurse who lives on the 16th floor of a tall building in the Holosiivskyi distriÑt in southwestern Kyiv, where destroyed Shaheds often fall, told Al Jazeera. â€œI am much calmer at workâ€ because her office is in central Kyiv, she said. But then the wailing is drowned out by the louder, faster bangs of Kyivâ€™s air defence systems. Their most precious part is a handful of advanced, United States-made surface-to-air Patriot missile systems. They can target planes, cruise missiles and shorter-ranger ballistic missiles such as Iskanders â€“ and their whereabouts are top secret. The White Houseagreedto supply Patriots to Ukraine in October, and Germany and the Netherlands soon followed suit by sending their slightly older systems to Ukraine. Their collective decision maddened Moscow â€“ especially after Patriots showed overwhelming success. On May 4, they managed to shoot down a Kinzhal (â€œDaggerâ€), Russiaâ€™s newest hypersonic air-launched ballistic missile. Russian President Vladimir Putin unveiled them with much pomp in 2018, calling them â€œsuper weaponsâ€ whose speed exceeds that of sound 10 times. â€œTheir power can be enormous, and their speed makes them invulnerable to todayâ€™s missile defence and air defence systems,â€ Putin said at the time. In the hands of the Ukrainian military, the Patriots proved Putin utterly wrong, defence analysts say. â€œPutin personally presented them as an invulnerable weapon that canâ€™t be shot down and hits the target 100 percent of the time,â€ Lieutenant General Ihor Romanenko, former deputy chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, told Al Jazeera. â€œBoth claims were disavowed,â€ he said. To many Ukrainians, the late-night bangs of Patriots symbolise the imminent victory over Moscow. â€œThey wanted to seize us, but they canâ€™t overpower us,â€ Pavel Vichenskiy, a businessman from the town of Bila Tserkva some 80km (50 miles) south of Kyiv, told Al Jazeera. The 38-year-old didnâ€™t always think that way. When he woke up to the sound of explosions on February 24, 2022, the warâ€™s first day, he thought Russia would seize Ukraine â€“ because of Ukraineâ€™s endemic â€œcorruptionâ€ that weakened its armed forces and defence capabilities, he said. But by late March, Moscow withdrew its badly battered troops from around Kyiv and all of northern Ukraine â€“ and he understood Ukraine would not fall. More than a year later, an observer compares todayâ€™s stoicism to the final, fifth stage of the Kubler-Ross model of overcoming grief. â€œDuring the warâ€™s first stage, there was denial. Then anger. Every shelling caused anger: â€˜How can they do it!â€™â€ Aleksey Kushch, a Kyiv-based analyst, told Al Jazeera. â€œThen came bargaining: if we donâ€™t respond, maybe they will bomb us less. Then there were depression and apathy. Now, there is acceptance. Just like the coronavirus, ageing, cold, heat â€“ an external factor one has to co-exist with,â€ he said. Tuesday brought news about Ukraineâ€™s possible response to the question Kyivâ€™s mayor asked a day earlier. â€œIf the Russians can make Kyiv a nightmare, why do the people of Moscow rest?â€ Mayor Klitschko asked rhetorically. A day later, at least eight attack drones struckresidential areas in Moscow, damaging buildings along the central Leninsky Avenue. The Kremlin sugar-coated the news. â€œWeâ€™re talking about the response of Kyivâ€™s regime to our very effective strikes on one of their decision-making centres,â€ Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. But to the founder and owner of the Wagner Group private military force, the development was catastrophic. â€œYou stinking critters, what are you doing?â€ Yevgeny Prigozhin asked on Telegram in an expletive-ridden rant addressing the Russian Defence Ministry. And Ukrainian officials habitually denied their role in the attacks â€“ and trolled the Kremlin. â€œPerhaps, not all drones are ready to attack Ukraine and want to return to their creators and, correspondingly, ask questions [such as] â€˜Why are you sending us on Ukrainian children, on Kyiv and so on?'â€ President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s aide Mykhailo Podolyak said in televised remarks.

Title: Drone attacks hit Moscow, sparking fury at the Kremlin
Subtitle: Two are injured in a rare attack on Moscow as more heavy Russian raids target Kyiv, killing at least one person.
Content: Drones struck Moscow on Tuesday but were neutralised, Russia said, in what one politician called the worst attack on the capital since World War II, while Kyiv was also hit from the air for the third time in 24 hours. Since Russia invaded its neighbour in February last year, the war has largely been fought inside Ukraine, though Moscow has reported some attacks on its territory and blamed them on Ukraine, including an alleged assassination attempt against President Vladimir Putin. Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin said two people were injured, but not seriously, while some residents in two lightly damaged apartment blocks were briefly evacuated. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said eight drones sent by Kyiv were shot down or diverted, though Baza, a Telegram channel with links to the security services, said more than 25 were involved. Residents in southwestern Moscow said they heard loud bangs followed by the smell of petrol at about 5am to 6am local time [02:00 to 03:00 GMT]. Some filmed a drone being shot down and a plume of smoke rising over the Moscow skyline. Politician Maxim Ivanov termed it the most serious assault on Moscow since the Nazis, saying no citizen could now avoid â€œthe new realityâ€. â€œYou will either defeat the enemy as a single fist with our Motherland, or the indelible shame of cowardice, collaboration and betrayal will engulf your family,â€ he said. Two weeks ago, two drones exploded over theKremlinin an attack Russia also blamed on Kyiv and said was aimed at Putin. Ukrainian presidential aide Mykhailo Podolyak denied Kyiv was directly involved in targeting Moscow on Tuesday, though he said â€œwe are pleased to watchâ€ and forecast more to come. Russiaâ€™s defence ministry cast the assault as a â€œterrorist drone attackâ€ launched by the â€œKyiv regimeâ€. In Kyiv, Ukrainian defence forces said they shot down more than 20 Iranian-made Shahed drones on Tuesday. One person died â€“ reportedly a 30-year-old woman, and four were injured when debris from a destroyed Russian projectile hit a high-rise apartment building causing a fire, Ukrainian officials said. Two upper floors were destroyed with people possibly still under rubble. Photos from Kyiv officials showed flames engulfing the top of the building. â€œThe attack was massive, came from different directions, in several waves,â€ said Serhiy Popko, head of Kyivâ€™s military administration. Russia has attacked Kyiv 17 times in May with drones or missiles, mostly at night, in an apparent attempt to undermine Ukrainiansâ€™ will to fight after more than 15 months of war. Al Jazeeraâ€™s Natacha Butler, reporting from Kyiv, said: â€œWhere I am right now is an apartment block that was hit, the top two floors pretty much nearly destroyed. â€œAt the foot of this apartment block is a cleanup process. People are inspecting their cars that are damaged, trying to absorb what has happened. They are looking up at the top of the building, the windows are nearly blown up. A lot of [residents] are going to have to leave this building with their suitcases, their pets. Some of them are saying they donâ€™t want to leave, theyâ€™re happy they have survived. â€œThis is the worst nightmare for people here in Kyiv. These attacks have been going on night after night now. This is the third consecutive attack now. People are not sleeping. But every night, when they do go to sleep, they hear those sirens, they hear the explosions and they just donâ€™t know what will happen.â€ In Moscow, journalist Yulia Shapovalova, said there was a sense of â€œcalmâ€ in the capital despite the attacks. â€œMoscow is buzzing as usual now. People are going to work, public transport is functioning normally, it seems like nothing happened. â€œPeople on the street are very calm, but I should tell you many people in Russia sincerely believe the information they regularly hear on TV, that the conflicts between Russia and Ukraine have been inevitable and that President [Vladimir] Putin, as a great strategist, began it first on foreign soil.â€

Title: Ukraine-Russia border â€˜demilitarised zoneâ€™ floated for peace deal
Subtitle: Adviser to Ukraineâ€™s presidential office Mykhailo Podolyak said the demilitarised zone should be between 100-120km wide.
Content: A demilitarised zone between 100 and 120 kilometres wide (62 to 75 miles) should be established in Russian border territory with Ukraine as part of any post-war settlement, an adviser to Ukraineâ€™s presidential office has said. Mykhailo Podolyak, the adviser to the head of the Office of the President of Ukraine, said the demilitarised zone should cover the Russian regions of Belgorod, Bryansk, Kursk and Rostov in order to protect adjacent territories in Ukraine. â€œTo ensure real security for residents of Kharkiv, Chernihiv, Sumy, Zaporizhzhia, Luhansk, and Donetsk regions and protect them from shelling, it will be necessary to introduce a demilitarisation zone of 100-120km,â€ Podolyak wrote in a tweet on Monday. Such a zone,which cannot be used or occupied by military forces, would likely require â€œa mandatory international control contingent at the first stageâ€, Podolyak said. A demilitarised zone should be a â€œkey topicâ€ of a post-war settlement, said the presidential adviser, who has 1.2 million Twitter followers, adding that such a buffer would â€œprevent the recurrence of aggression in the futureâ€. The key topic of the post-war settlement should be the establishment of safeguards to prevent a recurrence of aggression in the future. To ensure real security for residents of Kharkiv, Chernihiv, Sumy, Zaporizhzhia, Luhansk, and Donetsk regions and protect them from shelling, itâ€¦ â€” ĞœĞ¸Ñ…Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ»Ğ¾ ĞŸĞ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»ÑĞº (@Podolyak_M)May 29, 2023  The International Committee of the Red Cross says there are detailed rules for thecreation and recognition of demilitarised zonesand the concept is not far removed from hospital zones and other areas deemed neutral during conflicts. An aide to Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy also said on Monday that Ukraine had no interest in any ceasefire that locks in Russian territorial gains. Chief diplomatic adviser Ihor Zhovkva also pushed back against international peace initiatives from China, Brazil, the Vatican and South Africa, saying that the time for mediation with Moscow had passed. â€œIn this period of open war, we donâ€™t need any mediators. Itâ€™s too late for mediation,â€ he said. â€œThere cannot be a Brazilian peace plan, a Chinese peace plan, a South African peace plan when you are talking about the war in Ukraine,â€ Zhovkva said in an interview with the Reuters news agency. Russia has said it is open to peace talks with Kyiv, which stalled a few months into the invasion. But Moscow also insists that any talks be based on â€œnew realitiesâ€, meaning recognition of the annexation of five Ukrainian provinces it fully or partly controls â€“ a condition Kyiv will not accept.    China has touted a 12-point vision for peace, which calls for a ceasefire but does not condemn the invasion or oblige Russia to withdraw from occupied territories. Beijing, which has close ties with Russiaâ€™s leadership,sent top envoy Li Hui to Kyiv and Moscowthis month to encourage peace talks. Zhovkva said the envoy was briefed in detail on the situation on the battlefield, at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, the power grid and the transfer of Ukrainian children to Russia, which Kyiv says is a Russian war crime. â€œHe listened very attentively. There was no immediate response â€¦ we will see. China is a wise country, which understands its role in international affairs,â€ Zhovkva said.    The Institute for the Study of War, a think tank based in Washington, DC, said on Monday that Chinaâ€™s foreign ministry had denied a report in the Wall Street Journal newspaper that Chinaâ€™s special representative on Eurasian affairs had urged European officials to attempt to end the war in Ukraine before it escalated or consider recognisingÂ  Russian annexed territory in Ukraine. Chinaâ€™s foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning denied the report, adding that Ukraine was now at a â€œcritical junctureâ€ and China would continue to work with all parties to resolve the crisis, the institute reported. Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Mao Ning denied a@WSJreport that#China's Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui urged European officials to end the conflict in#Ukrainebefore it escalates.https://t.co/yvUY7gYFDUhttps://t.co/jClvvEglgo â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)May 30, 2023

Title: Kyiv fends off latest Russian air attack, Zelenskyy lauds defence
Subtitle: Latest attack comes just hours after President Volodymyr Zelenskyy praises Ukraineâ€™s air defence units for saving lives.
Content: Russia has launched a wave of air attacks on Kyiv just hours after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy thanked the countryâ€™s air defence units for saving hundreds of lives byshooting down a barrage of Russian drones and missilesaimed at the capital and other locations. In the early hours of Tuesday morning, air defence systems in Kyiv were engaged in shooting down incoming targets, city officials said, as air raid sirens blared in several regions. â€œA massive attack!â€ Kyivâ€™s Mayor Vitali Klitschko said on the Telegram messaging app. â€œDo not leave shelters.â€ Klitschko said that a 27-year-old woman was taken to hospital after sustaining injuries in southwestern Holosiivskyi district. He later reported that one person had been killed in the latest Russian air attack. Kyivâ€™s military administration officials said that air defence systems were engaging and destroying the incoming projectiles and falling debris had hit several districts of the capital, including the historic Podil and Pecherskyi neighbourhoods.     Residents of a high-rise apartment building were being evacuated early on Tuesday after falling debris sparked a fire, Klitschko said. Calling it a â€œmassiveâ€ attack launched in several waves, Serhii Popko, the head of Kyivâ€™s military administration, said on the Telegram messaging app that Russia conducted the assault using Iranian-made Shahed drones and that more than 20 had been shot down. Tuesdayâ€™s attack â€“ the third in 24 hours â€“ marks Russiaâ€™s 17th aerial assaulton the capital this month, following two attacks on Monday, which included a rare daytime strike that had forced people to seek shelter underground and sent schoolchildren fleeing Kyivâ€™s streets for safety. Kyiv. Morning after sleepless night under fire. Anxiety once againâ€¦Children running and screaming for shelter to the sounds of explosions. But it should not be like this â€“ anywhere and never. Fear cannot be turned off â€“ but we do not stop, we act. Ukraine continues to fight ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦pic.twitter.com/wTKS3sv6qi â€” ĞĞ»ĞµĞ½Ğ° Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ° (@ZelenskaUA)May 29, 2023  In his nightly address on Monday, Zelenskyy said that while some of the Russian aerial attacks, which he branded â€œevilâ€, had managed to get through Ukraineâ€™s defences, most of the drones and missiles had been shot down. â€œThe world must see that terror is losing,â€ the Ukrainian leader said, calling for more help to further improve the countryâ€™s defences. â€œThere is no greater humiliation for a terrorist state than the success of our warriors,â€ he added on a day that saw 11 ballistic and cruise missiles fired by Russia at Kyiv shot down by Ukraineâ€™s air defences, according to Ukraineâ€™s commander-in-chief of armed forces, Valerii Zaluzhnyi. The Institute for the Study of War, a think tank based in Washington, DC, said overnight on Sunday and Monday, and during the daytime attack on Monday, Russia had launched 11 Iskander ballistic missiles, 38 Shahed drones, and 40 cruise missiles. The air attack campaign signals that Russia is attempting to weaken Ukraineâ€™s ability to launch an anticipated offensive to reclaim territory lost to Russia, but the â€œprioritisation of targeting Kyiv is likely further limiting the campaignâ€™s ability to meaningfully constrain potential Ukrainian counteroffensive actions,â€ the institute said. Yuriy Ihnat, a spokesperson for Ukraineâ€™s air force, suggested that US-provided Patriot anti-missile systems were behind the successful interception of incoming Iskander ballistic missiles and other weapons.    â€œI think you can guess,â€ Ihnat told Ukrainian television. â€œIf Iskander-M missiles are intercepted, you can draw conclusions about the means that specifically targeted the objectives â€“ ballistic targets.â€ Zelenskyy also singled out the Patriot system in his Monday night message, saying that with such defences, â€œterror will be defeatedâ€. The world needs to see that terror is losing. When Patriots in the hands of Ukrainians ensure one hundred percent downing of any Russian missiles, terror is losing. When the world increases pressure on Russia, including sanctions, when the terrorist's isolation grows, when itsâ€¦pic.twitter.com/KyPmzoxsPF â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)May 29, 2023

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 461
Subtitle: As the war enters its 461st day, we take a look at the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation as it stands on Tuesday, May 30, 2023.

Title: Ukraineâ€™s parliament approves sanctions against Russia ally Iran
Subtitle: Package imposes trade, financial and technology sanctions against Iran and stops Tehran from using Ukraineâ€™s airspace.
Content: The Ukrainian parliament has approved a sanctions package against Iran, a Russian ally it accuses of sending weapons to Moscow during its more than year-long invasion of Ukraine. The measures were approved on Monday, a day after Ukraine saidRussia usedIranian-made Shahed drones in the largest such attack on the capital, Kyiv, since the beginning of the invasion. â€œThe resolution synchronises Ukrainian sanctions with the actions of the entire civilised world on the path to the complete isolation of Iran,â€ the Ukrainian parliament said on its website. The new regulations include a ban on exports of â€œmilitary and dual-use goodsâ€ to Iran and the â€œsuspension of economic and financial obligations in favour of residents of Iranâ€. The package would also stop Iranian goods transiting through Ukraine and it planes through Ukraineâ€™s airspace as well as imposing trade, financial and technology sanctions against Iran and its citizens. The legislation still needs to be signed into law by President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, which is a formality because the Ukrainian leader submitted the bill himself. Zelenskyy last week appealed directly to Iranians, asking: â€œWhy do you want to be accomplices in Russian terror?â€ Tehran struck back, calling Zelenskyâ€™s comments a â€œpolitical showâ€ that had no value. â€œThis repeat of empty claims by the Ukrainian president against the Islamic Republic of Iran means going along with the anti-Iranian media war that is done with the goal of receiving more arms and financial help from Western countries,â€ foreign ministry spokesman Nasser Kanani said on Saturday. In November, the Iranian governmentconfirmedfor the first time that it had sold drones to Russia but said this was â€œmonthsâ€ before the start of the war in Ukraine in February 2022. Ukraine said on Sunday that Moscow had staged the largest drone attack to date on Ukraine overnight, using 54 Iranian-made drones. It said 52 of them were shot down.

Title: Lavrov in surprise Kenya visit after Ukraine FM trip to Africa
Subtitle: The visits come as global powers continue to tussle for influence on the continent of 1.3 billion people.
Content: Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov met Kenyan leaders on Monday on a surprise visit to Nairobi, as Moscow and Kyiv both seek to bolster support from African nations over the war in Ukraine. â€œDuring our visit, we will discuss our cooperation in the trade, investment and economic spheres, humanitarian and cultural questions, education, cooperation in the UN and many other issues,â€ Lavrov told Kenyan lawmakers, according to the Russian foreign ministry. The trip was not announced in advance. The Russian official has visited Africa several times in the past year, as global powerstussle for influenceon the continent of 1.3 billion people. Lavrovâ€™s trip to Kenya comes on the heels of a trip to the continent last week by his Ukrainian counterpart Dmytro Kuleba. Foreign Minister Kuleba visited Ethiopia, Morocco and Rwanda, but also met with current African Union (AU) Chair and Comoros President Azali Assoumani as well as AU Commission Chairman Moussa Faki Mahamat. The Ukrainian officialÂ called for certain African nations to end their neutral stances over the 15-month-old war in Ukraine and announced a push by Kyiv to intensify its ties with the continent. â€œWe speak with our African friends, trying to explain to them that neutrality is not the answer,â€ Kuleba said at a press conference on Wednesday in Addis Ababa, home of the African Union. He also announced in a statement the following day that Ukraine planned to open more embassies in Africa and stage a summit with the continentâ€™s leaders. Meanwhile, a Russia-Africa summit, the second in a series, is to be held in Saint Petersburg from July 26 to 29. Russia has ties with African countries that can be traced to the Cold War, when the Soviet Union rendered support in the form of arms and funding to liberation movements on the continent. In February, 22 of the AUâ€™s 54 member states abstained or did not vote on a United Nations General Assembly resolution that called for Russia to withdraw from Ukraine. Two of them â€“ Eritrea and Mali â€“ even voted against the resolution.

Title: US Senator Lindsey Graham on Russia wanted list after war remarks
Subtitle: Russiaâ€™s Investigative Committee says it is opening a criminal investigation into comments made by Republican senator.
Content: Russia has put United States Senator Lindsey Graham on a wanted list, according to Russian media reports citing the interior ministryâ€™s database. Ukraineâ€™s presidential office on Friday released an edited video of a meeting between Graham and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy which first showed the senator saying, â€œThe Russians are dyingâ€, and then that US support was the â€œbest money weâ€™ve ever spentâ€. After Russia criticised the comments, Ukraine released a full video of the interaction, showing that the two remarks were not linked. On Sunday, Russiaâ€™s Investigative Committee said it was opening a criminal investigation into Grahamâ€™s comments, without specifying what crime he was accused of. Russia has previously sanctioned dozens of US officials and politicians but has rarely sought the arrest of senior officeholders. Graham disputed Russiaâ€™s criticism of his support for Ukraine by saying he had praised the spirit of Ukrainians in resisting Russiaâ€™s invasion with US assistance. He struck a more defiant tone on Twitter, writing that he would wear the â€œarrest warrantâ€ as a â€œbadge of honorâ€. â€œTo know that my commitment to Ukraine has drawn the ire of [President Vladimir] Putinâ€™s regime brings me immense joy,â€ Graham posted. He also challenged Russian authorities to pursue their case at the International Criminal Court, which has previously issued anarrest warrantfor Putin. â€œCome and make your best case,â€ he quipped. â€œSee you in The Hague!â€ I will wear the arrest warrant issued by Putinâ€™s corrupt and immoral government as a Badge of Honor. ğŸ…https://t.co/0L2I5PfuoM â€” Lindsey Graham (@LindseyGrahamSC)May 29, 2023  Russian Security Council Deputy Chairman Dmitry Medvedev called the 67-year-old Republican an â€œold foolâ€. â€œThe old fool Senator Lindsey Graham said that the United States has never spent money so successfully as on the murder of Russians,â€ Medvedev said. â€œHe shouldnâ€™t have done that.â€ In an emailed statement to the Reuters news agency, Graham responded to Medvedevâ€™s comments and said, â€œAs usual, the Russian propaganda machine is hard at work.â€ He added: â€œMr. Medvedev, if you want Russians to stop dying in Ukraine, withdraw. Stop the invasion. Stop the war crimes. The truth is that you and Putin could care less about Russian soldiers.â€ During his visit to Kyiv on Friday, Graham told Zelenskyy that Ukraineâ€™s resistance reminded him of â€œour better selves in America. There was a time in America that we were this way, fighting to the last person, we were going to be free or die.â€ â€œNow you are free,â€ Zelenskyy responded, to which Graham replied: â€œAnd the Russians are dying.â€ â€œYes, but they came to our territory. We are not fighting on their territory,â€ Zelenskyy said. The US has given Ukraine military assistance valued at a total of $38bn since the war began in February 2022. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov suggested that Grahamâ€™s praise of US financial backing was linked to his comments that Russians were dying. â€œIt is difficult to imagine a greater shame for a country than having such senators,â€ Peskov said.

Title: Explosions as Russia launches 15th air assault on Kyiv in May
Subtitle: Overnight missile attack comes a day after Russia unleashed its largest ever drone assault on the Ukrainian capital.
Content: Several explosions have rocked the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, according to officials, in the 15th Russian air attack on the city this month and the second overnight attack in a row. â€œA missile shot down near Kyiv,â€ Mayor Vitali Klitschko said on the Telegram messaging channel in the early hours of Monday. â€œAir defence working!â€ He added that blasts were heard in several districts of the city, including Kyivâ€™s historic neighbourhood of Podil, where falling debris damaged the roof of a house. According to preliminary information from the mayor and the cityâ€™s military administration, there were no casualties in the overnight attacks. The attack on Monday, appearing to be a combination of missiles and drones, followsthe largest drone barrage launched on Kyivthe previous night, which killed one person and wounded several more. Officials said the cityâ€™s air defences shot down 40 drones in and around the capital in the early hours of Sunday. Most of the drones were Iranian-made Shahed loitering munitions, the Kyiv Independent news website reported. Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy thanked the countryâ€™s air defence forces for protecting the country and asked its parliament to impose sanctions against Iran for supplying Russia with weapons, including the Shahed drones. Waves of Russian attacks against Ukraine now come several times a week. The full scale of Mondayâ€™s attack is not immediately known. The Reuters news agency reported several loud blasts when the city and the rest of Ukraine were under air raid alerts in the early hours of Monday. With a long-promisedUkrainian counteroffensive loomingto recapture territory taken by Russia since it began its full-scale invasion 15 months ago, Moscow has intensified its attacks, targeting military infrastructure and supplies. While Ukraine almost never publicly claims responsibility for attacks inside Russia,a series of raidsinside the country have targeted military, energy and transport infrastructure, with Moscow blaming Kyiv for the attacks.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 460
Subtitle: As the war enters its 460th day, we take a look at the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation as it stands on Monday, May 29, 2023.

Title: Russia unleashes â€˜massiveâ€™ air raids on Ukraineâ€™s Kyiv
Subtitle: Kyivâ€™s air defences downed 40 Russian drones, with falling debris killing a 41-year-old man, officials say.
Content: Russia has unleashed two waves of air attacks on the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, killing at least one person and wounding another, according to officials. Kyivâ€™s air defence systems downed at least 40 drones moving towards the city in the early hours of Sunday, according to Mayor Vitali Klitschko, with falling debris killing a 41-year-old man and wounding a 35-year-old woman. â€œStay in shelters. The attack is massive!â€ the mayor said on Telegram. The pre-dawn attacks came on the last Sunday of May when the capital celebrates Kyiv Day, the anniversary of its official founding 1,541 years ago. The day is typically marked by street fairs, live concerts and special museum exhibitions â€“ plans which have been made for this year as well, but on a smaller scale. â€œThe history of Ukraine is a longstanding irritant for the insecure Russians,â€ Andriy Yermak, the head of President Volodymyr Zelenskyyâ€™s office, said on his Telegram channel. Several districts of Kyiv, the largest Ukrainian city with a population of nearly three million, suffered in the overnight attacks, officials said, including the historical Pecherskyi neighbourhood.    As the air raid alerts started soon after midnight, many people stood on their balconies, the Reuters news agency reported, with some screaming offensives directed at Russiaâ€™s President Vladimir Putin and â€œGlory to air defenceâ€ slogans. With aUkrainian counteroffensive looming15 months into the war, Moscow has intensified its missile and drone attacks this month after a lull of nearly two months, targeting military facilities and supplies. Waves of attacks now come several times a week. In the leafy Holosiivskyi district in the southwestern part of Kyiv, falling debris on Sunday set a three-storey warehouse on fire, destroying about 1,000 square metres (10,800 square feet) of building structures, according to the mayor. A fire broke out after falling drone debris hit a seven-storey non-residential building in the Solomyanskyi district west of the city. The district is a busy rail and air transport hub. In the Pecherskyi district, a fire broke out on the roof of a nine-storey building due to falling drone debris, Kyivâ€™s military administration officials said on Telegram. Over the past few weeks,reports of drone attacks in Russia have also multiplied, mostly in regions bordering Ukraine. On Saturday, shelling in those areas killed two people, regional authorities said. Moscow has blamed Kyiv â€“ and its Western supporters â€“ for the escalating number of attacks and sabotage operations, including on the Kremlin, but Ukraine has denied involvement.

Title: Ukraine says Russia eases attacks on Bakhmut to regroup
Subtitle: Ukrainian defence minister says Russian attacks have decreased as Moscow troops are being â€˜replaced and regroupedâ€™.
Content: Russian forces have temporarily eased their attacks on the besieged eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut to regroup and strengthen their capabilities, a senior Kyiv official has said. Separately, senior Ukrainian officials on Saturday indicated their forces were ready to launch a long-promised counteroffensive to recapture territory taken by Russia since the start of the war. Russiaâ€™s Wagner private army began handing over positions to regular troops this week after declaring full control of Bakhmut following the longest and bloodiest battle of the war. In a statement on Telegram, Ukraine Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar said Russian forces were continuing to attack but that overall offensive activity had decreased. â€œYesterday and today there have not been any active battles â€“ neither in the city nor on the flanks,â€ she wrote on Saturday, adding that Moscowâ€™s troops were instead shelling the outskirts and approaches to Bakhmut. â€œThe decrease in the enemyâ€™s offensive activity is due to the fact that troops are being replaced and regrouped,â€ Maliar said. â€œThe enemy is trying to strengthen its own capabilities.â€ Kyiv is expected to soon launch a highly anticipated counteroffensive to retake Russian-occupied territory. Oleksiy Danilov, secretary of Ukraineâ€™s National Security and Defence Council, told the BBC that the push could begin â€œtomorrow, the day after tomorrow or in a weekâ€. Presidential aide Mykhailo Podolyak, speaking to the UKâ€™s Guardian newspaper, said preliminary operations such as destroying supply lines or blowing up depots had already begun. Ukraineâ€™s top general, Valerii Zaluzhny, posted a sleekly produced video on Saturday showing Ukrainian troops swearing an oath and preparing for battle. â€œThe time has come to return what is ours,â€ he wrote. Meanwhile, Ukraineâ€™s military intelligence has claimed, without offering evidence, that Russia is plotting aâ€œlarge-scale provocationâ€ at a nuclear power plantit occupies in the southeast of the country with the aim of disrupting a looming Ukrainian counteroffensive. A statement released Friday by the intelligence directorate of Ukraineâ€™s Ministry of Defence claimed that Russian forces would attack the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, the biggest in Europe, and then report a radioactive leak in order to trigger an international probe that would pause the hostilities and give the Russian forces the respite they need to regroup ahead of the counter-offensive. In order to make that happen, Russia â€œdisrupted the rotation of personnel of the permanent monitoring missionâ€ of the UNâ€™s International Atomic Energy Agency that was scheduled for Saturday, the statement said. It did not offer evidence to back up any of the claims. There was no immediate comment from the IAEA or Russian officials on the allegations.    The White House said it is watching the situation closely and has seen no indication that radioactive material has been leaked. The claims mirrored similar statements Moscow regularly makes, alleging without evidence that Kyiv is plotting provocations involving various dangerous weapons or substances in order to then accuse Russia of war crimes. The Zaporizhzhia power plant is one of the 10 biggest nuclear plants in the world. It is located in the partially occupied Zaporizhzhia region in southeastern Ukraine. The plantâ€™s six reactors have been shut down for months, but it still needs power and qualified staff to operate crucial cooling systems and other safety features. Fighting near it repeatedly disrupted power supplies and has fueled fears of a potential catastrophe like the one at Chernobyl, in northern Ukraine, where a reactor exploded in 1986 and spewed deadly radiation, contaminating a vast area in the worldâ€™s worst nuclear disaster.

Title: Russia to US: No lectures on nuclear weapon deployments
Subtitle: Russian embassy calls US criticism of Moscowâ€™s tactical nuclear weapon deployment to Belarus hypocritical, saying â€˜before blaming others Washington could use some introspectionâ€™.
Content: Russia has dismissed criticism from US President Joe Biden over Moscowâ€™s deployment of tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus, saying Washington for decades has done the sameÂ  throughout Europe. Russia said on Thursday it was pushing ahead with the first deployment of such weapons outside its borders since the 1991 fall of the Soviet Union, and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko said the arms were already on the move. Biden said on Friday he had an â€œextremely negativeâ€ reaction to reports that Russia moved ahead with the deployment in Belarus. â€œIt is the sovereign right of Russia and Belarus to ensure their security by means we deem necessary amid a large-scale hybrid war unleashed by Washington against us,â€ Russiaâ€™s embassy in the United States said in a statement. â€œThe measures we undertake are fully consistent with our international legal obligations.â€ Tactical nuclear weapons are used for tactical gains on the battlefield and are usually smaller in yield than the strategic nuclear weapons designed to destroy American, European or Russian cities. The Russian embassy called the US criticism of Moscowâ€™s deployment hypocritical, saying â€œbefore blaming others, Washington could use some introspectionâ€. â€œThe United States has been for decades maintaining a large arsenal of its nuclear weapons in Europe. Together with its NATO allies it participates in nuclear sharing arrangements and trains for scenarios of nuclear weapons use against our country.â€ The United States has said the world faces the gravest nuclear danger since the 1962Cuban Missile Crisisbecause of remarks by President Vladimir Putin during the Ukraine conflict, but Moscow says its position has been misinterpreted. Putin, who has cast the Ukraine war as a battle for the survival of Russia against an aggressive West, has repeatedly warned that Russia, which has more nuclear weapons than any other country, will use all means to defend itself. The United States has deployed nuclear weapons in Western Europe since US President Dwight D Eisenhower authorised their deployment in the Cold War as a counter to the perceived threat from the Soviet Union. The first US nuclear weapons in Europe were deployed in Britain in 1954. Much of the detail about the current American deployment is classified, though the Federation of American Scientists says the US has 100 B61 tactical nuclear weapons deployed in Europe â€“ in Italy, Germany, Turkey, Belgium and the Netherlands.

Title: Ukraine claims Russia planning â€˜massiveâ€™ incident at nuclear site
Subtitle: Ukraineâ€™s defence intelligence directorate warns Russia will simulate an attack at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s defence ministry has warned that Russia plans to simulate a major accident at theZaporizhzhia nuclear power station, which is under the control of Russian forces, in a bid to thwart the expected counteroffensive by Ukraine to retake its territory captured by Moscow. The Zaporizhzhia plant, which lies in an area of Russian-occupied southern Ukraine, is Europeâ€™s biggest nuclear power station and the area has been repeatedly hit by shelling with both sides blaming each other for the dangerous attacks. Ahead of Ukraineâ€™s expected counteroffensive, fears have increased that a nuclear disaster could occur amid rising military activity around Zaporizhzhia. â€œRussians are preparing massive provocation and imitation of the accident at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in the nearest hours,â€ the Ukrainian defence ministryâ€™s intelligence directorate said on Friday.    â€œThey are planning to attack the territory of the ZNPP [Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant]. After that, they will announce the leakage of the radioactive substances,â€ the intelligence directorate said in a statement and later on social media channels. Reports of radioactive material leaking from the plant would cause a global incident and force an investigation by international authorities, during which all hostilities would be stopped, the directorate said. Russia would then use that pause in fighting to regroup its forces and better prepare to stop the Ukrainian counteroffensive, the intelligence service said. â€œThey obviously will blame Ukraine,â€ the directorate said, adding that the attackâ€™s aim would be to â€œprovoke the international communityâ€ into investigating the incident and forcing a pause in fighting. â€¼ï¸ Russians are preparing massive provocation and imitation of the accident at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in the nearest hours.They are planning to attack the territory of the ZNPP. After that, they will announce the leakage of the radioactive substances.pic.twitter.com/Vk6hRDD26v â€” Defence intelligence of Ukraine (@DI_Ukraine)May 26, 2023   Experts say that reports of a radiation leak at the plant would be followed by immediate evacuations, which could be extremely complex in a war zone. According to experts, for many people, the fear of being contaminated by radiation could also be more dangerous than the radiation itself. Last week, witnesses said Russian military forces were enhancing defensive positions in and around the nuclear power plant ahead of Ukraineâ€™s much-anticipated counteroffensive. In preparation for the planned radioactive incident, Russia had disrupted the scheduled rotation of inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), who are based at the plant, Ukraineâ€™s intelligence directorate said. The report of a planned incident at Zaporizhzhia was repeated in a tweet by Ukraineâ€™s representative to the United Nations in New York, Sergiy Kyslytsya, who said the events could unfold â€œin the coming hoursâ€. Moscow is preparing a large-scale provocation to create a center of radiation danger, according to@DI_UkraineIn the coming hours, the russians are preparing a large-scale provocation to simulate an accident at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.https://t.co/KuxZEGRB2i â€” Sergiy Kyslytsya ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ (@SergiyKyslytsya)May 26, 2023  The directorate statement did not provide any proof to support its claims and the Vienna-based IAEA, which frequently posts updates on the situation at the power plant, has made no mention of any disruption to its timetable. Kyiv and Moscow have repeatedly accused each other of attacking the plant. In February, Russia said Ukraine was planning to stage a nuclear incident on its territory and pin the blame on Moscow. Moscow has also repeatedly accused Kyiv of planning â€œfalse-flagâ€ operations with non-conventional weapons, using biological or radioactive materials. No such attacks have taken place so far.    The IAEAâ€™s Director General Rafael Grossi will brief the UN Security Council next week on the security situation at Zaporizhzhia and his plan for safeguards at the site. Grossi, who last visited the plant in March, has upped his efforts to reach an agreement with Ukraine and Russia to ensure the plantâ€™s protection during the fighting. In a statement last week, Grossi said: â€œIt is very simple: donâ€™t shoot at the plant and donâ€™t use the plant as a military baseâ€. â€œIt should be in the interest of everyone to agree on a set of principles to protect the plant during the conflict,â€ he added. Zaporizhzhia once supplied approximately 20 percent of Ukraineâ€™s electricity and continued to function in the early months of Russiaâ€™s invasion, despite frequent shelling, before halting power production entirely in September. None of Ukraineâ€™s six Soviet-era reactors has since generated electricity but the Zaporizhzhia facility remains connected to the Ukrainian power grid for its own needs, notably to cool the plantâ€™s nuclear reactors.

Title: Russiaâ€™s Belgorod, Ukraineâ€™s Dnipro attacked as war escalates
Subtitle: Russian officials say the border region came under attack on Friday, days after a daring incursion, as two are reported killed in Dnipro.
Content: Russiaâ€™s southern Belgorod region came under attack from Ukrainian artillery fire, mortar shells and drones on Friday, authorities said,days afterone of the most daring cross-border attacks since the war began. Hours earlier, two drones attacked a Russian city in a region next to the annexed Crimea Peninsula, officials said. The Kremlinâ€™s forces, meanwhile, attacked a medical clinic in Dnipro, in central Ukraine, killing a 69-year-old passer-by and another civilian. More than 20 others were wounded, including two children, Ukrainian officials said. Also, a Russian S-300 missile hit a dam in the Karlivka district of Ukraineâ€™s eastern Donetsk province, placing nearby settlements under threat of severeflooding. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemned the blast in Dnipro as a war crime. â€œAnother Russian missile attack, another crime against humanity,â€ he wrote on Twitter. â€œThe buildings of a psychological clinic and a veterinary clinic in the city of Dnipro were destroyed.â€ Al Jazeeraâ€™s Natacha Butler, in Kyiv, reported other missile and drone strikes across Ukraine overnight. â€œWe certainly heard at least two very loud explosions at about four in the morning,â€ she said, adding that Ukraineâ€™s armed forced claimed to have intercepted several missiles over the capital. â€œWeâ€™ve been seeing intensified strikes on Ukraine,â€ she said. â€œMany say this is because Russia is looking very closely atUkraineâ€™s anticipated counteroffensive.â€ The Belgorod town of Grayvoron, about seven kilometres (more than four miles) from the Ukrainian border, was under fire for several hours, with four houses, a store, a car, a gas pipeline and a power line damaged, Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov reported. Closer to the border, a recreation centre, a shop and an uninhabited house sustained damage in the village of Glotovo. There were no casualties, according to Gladkov. Earlier this week, the Belgorod region was the target of one of the most serious cross-border attacks from Ukraine since the war began 15 months ago. Details of that raid, which began Monday and ended Tuesday, were murky. Russia blamed the Ukrainian armed forces, but two Russian groups said they were involved, with the aim ofbringing downPresident Vladimir Putin. Officials in Russiaâ€™s southern city of Krasnodar, in the region of the same name bordering Crimea, said that two drones hit there. Witnesses told local media they heard something like the sound of a moped and then two explosions. â€œThere is damage to buildings, but essential infrastructure was not damaged. And most importantly, there were no casualties,â€ Krasnodar governor Veniamin Kondratyev wrote on Telegram. Krasnodar Mayor Yevgeny Naumov said there were no casualties. Drone attacks against Russian regions on the border with Ukraine have been a regular occurrence since the start of the war, which began in February last year, with attacks stepping up last month. Earlier this month, an oil refinery in Krasnodar was attacked by drones on two consecutive days In another apparent incident of Kyivâ€™s forces harassing Russia, Ukraineâ€™s defence ministry on Thursday published footage that appeared to show an unmanned drone boat attacking Russiaâ€™s Ivan Khurs reconnaissance ship in the Black Sea. The video did not show the drone hitting the ship. The video followed reports by Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence on Wednesday that Ukraine had launched an â€œunsuccessfulâ€ attack on the Ivan Khurs using three unmanned speedboats, with all three boats attacked and destroyed prior to reaching the ship. Moscow released footage allegedly showing the destruction of one of the un-crewed boats. After this weekâ€™s attack, the governors of Belgorod and Kursk said they favoured changing the law to allow local volunteer self-defence units to be armed when necessary. â€œWe have them [local self-defence units]. We have nearly 3,000 people in seven battalions along the border,â€ said Belgorodâ€™s Gladkov. Arming such forces could save the defence ministry from being forced to divert some of the troops it needs on the front line to respond to similar raids in future. Roman Starovoit, governor of the Kursk region which also borders Ukraine, said he favoured the idea, too. Last month, Andrei Turchak, first deputy speaker of the upper house of parliament, told President Vladimir Putin in a Kremlin meeting, â€œThe legal status of these formations is now extremely restricted, and most importantly they do not have the right to carry and use weapons. We propose that this anomaly be eliminated at the legislative level.â€ Colonel-General Andrei Kartapolov, an influential lawmaker who chairs the lower house of parliamentâ€™s defence committee, has also called for bigger structural changes to secure the border.

Title: Japan tightens Russian sanctions in line with G7
Subtitle: Japan will freeze the assets of 78 groups and 17 individuals, including army officers in Russia and ban exports to 80 Russian entities.
Content: Japan has announced additional sanctions on Russia after the Group of Seven (G7) summit the country hosted last week agreed to step up measures to punish Moscow over itsfull-scale invasion of Ukraine. In coordination with other G7 members, Japan will freeze the assets of 78 groups and 17 individuals, including army officers in Russia and ban exports to 80 Russian entities such as military-affiliated research labs, according to a foreign ministry statement released on Friday. Japan will also ban providing construction and engineering services to Russia, although the details of the measure will be announced at a later date, a trade ministry statement said. Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno, Tokyoâ€™s top government spokesperson, also condemned Russiaâ€™s move todeploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus, saying it would further intensify the situation. â€œAs the only country to have suffered atomic bombings during wartime, Japan never accepts Russiaâ€™s nuclear menace, let alone its use,â€ Matsuno told a regular press conference on Friday. The leaders of the G7, including France, Germany, the United Kingdom and the United States, underlined their resolve to support Ukraine with additional military aid andsanctions on Russiaduring their summit in Hiroshima last week. They said the restrictions would cover exports of industrial machinery, tools and technology useful to Russiaâ€™s war effort, while efforts would be made to limit Russian revenues from trade in metals and diamonds.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 457
Subtitle: As the war enters its 457th day, we take a look at the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation as it stands on Friday, May 26, 2023.    Exiled Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya said Russiaâ€™s transfer of nuclear weapons to her country represents a threat to Europe and Ukraine.

Title: US says Russia cannot win in Ukraine, Moscow sees long war ahead
Subtitle: Russiaâ€™s former President Dmitry Medvedev said the war in Ukraine is likely to last decades with bouts of fighting and truces.
Content: Russia will not achieve a military victory in Ukraine and Kyivâ€™s forces are unlikely to push back allRussian troopsfrom their territory any time soon, the United Statesâ€™s highest-ranking military official has said. â€œThis war, militarily, is not going to be won by Russia. Itâ€™s just not,â€ General Mark Milley, chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on Thursday. Russiaâ€™s original strategic objectives, including toppling the government in Kyiv, â€œare not achievable militarilyâ€, Milley told journalists after the conclusion of a virtual meeting of dozens of countries that are members of the Ukraine Defense Contact Group, which is also known as the Ramstein group. There are also hundreds of thousands of Russian soldiers in Ukraine, which would make Kyivâ€™s objective of recapturing allterritory lostto Moscowâ€™s forces unlikely â€œin the near termâ€, Milley said. â€œThat means fighting is going to continue, itâ€™s going to be bloody, itâ€™s going to be hard. And at some point, both sides will either negotiate a settlement or theyâ€™ll come to a military conclusion,â€ he said. Millyâ€™s assessment adds to a number of forecasts that the war in Ukraine appears set to drag on, with neither side positioned to win a clear-cut victory and no negotiations currently taking place.    Russiaâ€™s former President Dmitry Medvedev, a key ally of President Vladimir Putin, also said Moscowâ€™s war in Ukraine could continue for decades. According to comments published by Russiaâ€™s RIA news agency on Thursday, Medvedev described an ongoing conflict involving years of fighting with Ukraine, interspersed with multiple years of truces before fighting renewed. â€œThis conflict will last a very long time, most likely decades,â€ the RIA news agency cited Medvedev as saying during a visit to Vietnam. â€œAs long as there is such a power in place [in Kyiv], there will be, say, three years of truce, two years of conflict, and everything will be repeated,â€ said Medvedev, now the deputy chairman of Putinâ€™s powerful Security Council. Known for regularlymaking hardline commentson Ukraine and those considered Moscowâ€™s enemies, Medvedev said earlier this year that a Russian defeat could trigger a nuclear war. Tensions between Moscow and Washington continues to grow as the US spearheads the push for international support and military aid for Ukraine, including coordinating arms supplies from dozens of countries. In an apparent policy U-turn, the US last week announced it would support giving Ukraine advancedUS-made F-16 warplanes. In total, Ukraineâ€™s supporters have provided nearly $65bn in security assistance to the country, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin said at the press conference on Thursday.    On Thursday, Kyivâ€™s supporters â€œdiscussed plans for training Ukrainian pilots on fourth-generation fighter aircraft, including the F-16,â€ Austin said, speaking alongside Milley, noting that â€œplanning and executing this training will be a significant undertakingâ€. Austin said the Dutch and Danish defence ministers are working with the US on jet fighter training for Ukraine and that Norway, Belgium, Portugal and Poland have already offered to contribute to the initiative. In addition, he said the allies would set up a fund so other nations could contribute to the overall effort. Commenting on the F-16 fighters, Milley cautioned that they were not going to be â€œthe magic weaponâ€. â€œThere are no magic weaponsâ€ â€“ not the F-16s or other weapons, he said, noting that 10 F-16s could cost $2bn, including maintenance. â€œThe Russians have a thousand fourth and fifth-generation fighters, so if youâ€™re going to contest Russia in the air, youâ€™re going to need a substantial amount of fourth and fifth-generation fighters,â€ he said. F-16s have a future role as part of Ukraineâ€™s air capabilities but it is â€œgoing to take a considerable length of time to build up an air force thatâ€™s the size and scope and scale that would be necessaryâ€. Air defence systems are still the weapons that Ukraine needs most in the broader effort to control the airspace, he said. The US is poised to announce up to $300m more in military aid for Ukraine comprised mainly of ammunition, two officials told the Reuters news agency. The package is expected to contain more Guided Multiple Launch Rockets (GMLRS) for HIMARS launchers as well as other ammunition.     The Institute for the Study of War, a Washington DC-based think tank, said thatâ€œa long warâ€ is not a Russian goalbut a means of adapting to the situation in Ukraine after its plan for a swift victory failed. Russiaâ€™s ability to sustain an extended military campaign in Ukraine is not assured, while a â€œlong warâ€ would allow Russia the time and space needed to rebuild its military forces, the institute said. â€œUkrainian counteroffensives will deny the Kremlin a breather to replenish its resources, will further deplete Russiaâ€™s offensive potential, and eventually enable Ukrainian forces to expel Russia from Ukraine,â€ the ISW said. â€œThe Kremlinâ€™s â€˜long warâ€™ narrative reflects Putinâ€™s intent to rebuild Russiaâ€™s large-scale warfighting capability. But it is also an information operation aimed to peel the West away from Ukraine. This information operation builds on previous Russian efforts, such as ceasefire narratives and nuclear blackmail,â€ the ISW added.

Title: US accuses Wagner Group of supplying missiles to Sudanâ€™s RSF
Subtitle: Washington warns that the Russian mercenary group is prolonging the conflict and causing â€˜further chaosâ€™ in Sudan.
Content: Washington, DC â€“The United States has accused Russiaâ€™sWagner Groupof providing surface-to-air missiles to the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF), one side in Sudanâ€™s ongoing conflict that has displaced nearly 1.3 million people. Thursdayâ€™s allegation against the mercenary group came as the US Treasury Department also imposed sanctions on Wagnerâ€™s leader in Mali, accusing him of trying to obtain weapons for Russiaâ€™s war in Ukraine. The surface-to-air missiles in Sudan have contributed to â€œa prolonged armed conflict that only results in further chaos in the regionâ€, the Treasury said in a statement. The RSF and the Sudanese military â€” led by two rival generals â€” have been locked in a fight to control the state and its resources since mid-April, one that has killed hundreds of people. Washington, meanwhile, has helpedÂ broker several ceasefire deals since the violence broke out. On Monday, the warring sides agreed to aweeklong truce, but as with previous ceasefire agreements, residents have reported continued clashes. The US says its primary aim in Sudan is toreduce the violencebefore working towards a permanent end to the fighting and returning the country to civilian rule. Rights groups have cautioned of ahumanitarian catastropheif the conflict continues. Last month, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken voiced concern about the prospect of Wagnerâ€™s involvement in Sudan, saying the group â€œsimply brings more death and destructionâ€ with it. â€œItâ€™s very important that we not see its further engagement in Sudan. And I know a number of countries are very concerned with that prospect,â€ he said.    On Thursday, the Treasury also said Russian President Vladimir Putin has â€œresorted to relying onthe Wagner Groupto continue his war of choiceâ€ in Ukraine, which has been under a full-scale invasion since February 2022. As part of the announcement, the US imposed sanctions on Ivan Aleksandrovich Maslov, the head of Wagner in Mali, a landlocked country in western Africa. â€œThe Wagner Group may be attempting to obscure its efforts to acquire military equipment for use in Ukraine, including by working through Mali and other countries where it has a foothold,â€ the Treasury said. â€œThe United States opposes efforts by any country to assist Russia through the Wagner Group.â€ Early in 2023, the USlabelled Wagnera â€œtransnational criminal organisationâ€ and imposed sanctions on its top leaders. The State Department also accused Wagner earlier this week ofseeking to smuggleâ€œmaterial acquisitions to aid Russiaâ€™s warâ€ in Ukraine through Mali using false paperwork. â€œIn fact, there are indications that Wagner has been attempting to purchase military systems from foreign suppliers and route these weapons through Mali as a third party,â€ spokesperson Matthew Miller told reporters on Monday. â€œWe have not seen, as of yet, any indications that these acquisitions have been finalised or executed, but we are monitoring the situation closely.â€

Title: Russia signs deal to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus
Subtitle: Moscow says it will maintain control of the weapons, but Ukraine accuses Russia of taking Minsk â€˜hostageâ€™.
Content: Moscow and Minsk have signed a deal to formalisethe deploymentof Russian tactical nuclear missiles on Belarusian territory. Russia on Thursday said the step was driven by rising tensions with the West. â€œIn the context of an extremely sharp escalation of threats on the western borders of Russia and Belarus, a decision was made to take countermeasures in the military-nuclear sphere,â€ Russiaâ€™s state-owned TASS news agency quoted Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu as saying. The deployment of the missiles was first announced by President Vladimir Putin in March. Since invading Ukraine last year, Putin has said repeatedly that Russia would be ready to useÂ nuclearÂ weapons if needed to defend its â€œterritorial integrityâ€. NATO said at the time it did not see any need to adjust its own nuclear posture, although the military alliance cast Putinâ€™s nuclear rhetoric as â€œdangerous and irresponsibleâ€. But Richard Weitz, a Washington, DC-based foreign policy and defence analyst, told Al Jazeera that Russia was unlikely to benefit â€œin the purely military senseâ€.â€œRussia already has thousands of nuclear weapons, and some of them are already deployed on the ground or on aeroplanes, near where the Belarusian facilities are likely to be located. So, it adds a couple more locations to what Russia already has,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s political signalling â€¦ The Russian government at the highest levels will issue statements warning on the risk of nuclear war if NATO does give Patriots to Ukraine, give F-16s to Ukraine. â€œItâ€™s a way of just reminding the West that Russia is this great nuclear power and that the West better be careful, or we could stumble into a nuclear war. â€œ[It also] helps them strengthen ties or control over Belarus in the sense that the weapons are there. Thatâ€™s another reason why Belarusâ€™s security is tied to Russia but I think the main reason is part of this intimidation campaign.â€ Ukraine has said Russiaâ€™s ally Belarus had been â€œtaken hostageâ€ by Moscow. In March, Oleksiy Danilov, head of Ukraineâ€™s national security and defence council, called the deal â€œa step towards internal destabilisationâ€ of Belarus, and said it maximised what he termed the level of â€œnegative perception and public rejectionâ€ of Russia and Putin in Belarusian society. â€œThe Kremlin took Belarus as a nuclear hostage,â€ he wrote on Twitter. Moscow will retain control over the weapons and any decisions on their use, Shoigu said. TASS quoted him as saying that Iskander-M missiles, which can carry conventional orÂ nuclearÂ warheads, had been handed to the Belarusian armed forces, and some Su-25 aircraft had been converted for the possible use ofÂ nuclearÂ weapons. â€œBelarusian servicemen have received the necessary training in Russian training centres,â€ Shoigu was quoted as saying. He added that the agreements signed with his Belarusian counterpart covered the procedure for establishing a â€œspecial storage facility for nuclear weapons on Belarusian territoryâ€. Tactical nuclear weapons refer to lower-yield weapons designed for battlefield use, as opposed to strategic ones capable of wiping out entire cities. Russia has not disclosed how many tactical nuclear weapons it has.

Title: UN conference pledges fall short of $7bn goal for Horn of Africa
Subtitle: The $2.4bn raised is considerably less than the $7bn the UN says is needed to provide help to millions affected by drought and conflict in the region.
Content: A United Nations-backed conference raised $2.4bn on Wednesday to prevent famine in the Horn of Africa, which is reeling from its worst drought in decades as global temperatures rise. The money will provide life-saving assistance for nearly 32 million people across Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia, the world bodyâ€™s humanitarian agency OCHA said in a statement. â€œFamine has been averted, thanks in part to the tremendous efforts of local communities, humanitarian organizations and authorities, as well as the support of donors,â€ OCHA said. But the sum is considerably less than the $7bn the United Nations says is needed to provide help to people affected by drought and conflict in the region. â€œThe emergency is far from over, and additional resources are urgently required to prevent a return to the worst-case scenario,â€ OCHA added. Since late 2020, countries in the Horn of Africa â€“ Djibouti, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan and Sudan â€” have been suffering the regionâ€™s worst drought in 40 years. Five failed rainy seasons have left millions of people in need, decimated crops and killed millions of livestock. More than 23.5 million people are enduring high levels of acute food insecurity in Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia, according to OCHA. In Somalia alone, where armed groups are spearheading conflict, 3.8 million people have been displaced from their homes by conflict, drought or floods and double that number are struggling to find food, according to figures from the UN and the Norwegian Refugee Council. More than half a million children are severely malnourished, the two organisations added. Deaths from hunger are on the rise in Africa because of droughts worsened by climate change and conflict, UN officials and scientists say. The devastating drought in the Horn of Africa could not have occurred without the effects of greenhouse gas emissions, the World Weather Attribution group, an international team of climate scientists, said ina reportreleased in April. But aid organisations like the Norwegian Refugee Councilhave also saida focus on the Ukraine crisis has drastically reduced the funding available for work in the Horn of Africa. â€œThe war in Ukraine has demonstrated the immense gap between what is possible when the international community rallies behind a crisis, and the daily reality for millions of people suffering in silence within these crises on the African continent that the world has chosen to ignore,â€ the aid groupâ€™s chief Jan Egeland said last June. Earlier this week, a group of NGOs, including Islamic Relief Worldwide and Save the Children, called on donors to fully fund the humanitarian response required for â€œone of the biggest climate injustices of our timeâ€. Citing UN numbers, the organisations pointed out that despite funding mobilised aid to the region last year, an estimated 43,000 people died from the drought in Somalia alone in 2022. At the opening of the donorsâ€™ conference organised in conjunction with Italy, Qatar, the United Kingdom and the horn of Africa states, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres appealed for â€œan immediate and major injection of fundingâ€ to stop people from dying. â€œWe must act now to prevent crisis from turning into catastrophe,â€ he added, recalling that last year donor countries delivered vital help to 20 million people in the region and helped avert a famine. Guterres said people in the region, which he described as â€œthe epicentre of one of the worldâ€™s worst climate emergenciesâ€, were â€œpaying an unconscionable price for a climate crisis they did nothing to causeâ€. OCHA said the funds pledged on Wednesday would allow humanitarian agencies to sustain aid pipelines of food, water, healthcare, nutrition and protection services. Joyce Msuya, the UNâ€™s deputy emergency relief coordinator, welcomed the pledge but added: â€œWe must persist in pushing for stepped-up investments, especially to bolster the resilience of people already bearing the brunt of climate change.â€

Title: War comes home to Russia: Pro-Kyiv fighters seek Putinâ€™s downfall
Subtitle: Russia has been jolted by one of the most daring incursions, allegedly carried out by groups including Russian nationals.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraine â€“This week, a man with yellow and blue plastic bands on his helmet and camouflage uniform was filmed riding atop an armoured vehicle. The colours are unmistakably those of the Ukrainian national flag, but the man â€“ seen in the video posted on his military unitâ€™s Telegram channel on Tuesday â€“ is aRussiannational. He chose to fight for Ukraine, and brought the war home on Monday, to the western Russian region of Belgorod that hadalreadybeen shelled and attacked, apparently by Ukrainian drones, for months. The unidentified man in the video is part of theRussian Volunteer Corps, a military unit formed by fugitive far-right nationalists forced out of Russia. The group only accepts Russian nationals as members. Some of the Corpsâ€™ fighters volunteered to join Ukrainian forces in 2014, after Moscow annexed Crimea and incited separatist revolts in the southeastern Donbas region, and some joined after the latest war began in February 2022. The Corps consists of â€œdozens of fightersâ€, Fortuna, as one of the groupâ€™s founders calls himself, told a news conference in October. Two months earlier, they became part of the International Legion of Ukraine, a group of volunteers from all over the world that reports to Ukraineâ€™s defence ministry. Moscow, which is reluctant to publicly admit Russian nationals are fighting for Ukraine, blamed Kyiv for the incursion, a claim which was quickly denied. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, questioned if the attackers were ethnic Russians, said, they are â€œUkrainian fighters from Ukraine. There are many ethnic Russians living in Ukraine. But they are still Ukrainian militantsâ€. The Ukrainian defence ministry â€“ along with other officials in Kyiv â€“ initially distanced themselves from the Corps. Its first confirmed raid on Russia took place on March 2, after they entered two villages in the border region of Bryansk. The Corps then released a video of its fighters standing outside a village hospital and urging Russians â€œto riot and fightâ€. Bryansk Governor Aleksander Bogomaz said they killed a civilian and wounded a 10-year-old. Russian President Vladimir Putin cast the raid as a â€œterrorist actâ€. Mykhailo Podolyak, an aide to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, called those claims a â€œclassic deliberate provocationâ€. But Ukraineâ€™s defence ministry denied a role in organising the raid. â€œThese are the people who fight with arms against Putinâ€™s regime and supporters. Perhaps, Russians are beginning to wake up,â€ military intelligence spokesman Andriy Yusov said. On Monday, the Corps started its second, far more daring incursion in Russia. Along with The Freedom of Russia Legion â€“ also known as the Liberty of Russia Legion, a military unit which includes ex-Russian prisoners of war who have switched sides, they stormed a border checkpoint and spilled into the Grayvoron district in Belgorod. The district is surrounded by Ukrainian territory on three sides, but its administration failed to protect it with trenches, artillery and anti-tank installations. The invaders had two tanks and 10 armoured vehicles and were backed by light drones. They killed a border guard, one of the fighters told the Novaya Gazeta daily on condition of anonymity, reportedly captured one more and reached three villages, where they started building fortifications and clashed with Russian forces. The incursion highlighted the vulnerabilities of Russiaâ€™s border regions, military analysts say. â€œIt showed that Russia has no reserves in border regions and weak reserves in the operational depth, which means that the residents of all districts bordering Ukraine are in immediate danger and must be evacuated,â€ Nikolay Mitrokin of Germanyâ€™s Bremen University told Al Jazeera. The Corps claimed to have occupied a â€œpieceâ€ of Russia. â€œThe situation in a small yet our own piece of Motherland is so far alarming, and thereâ€™s a need to clean up,â€ said the caption under a video showing a Corps fighter. By Monday night, they had attacked the local headquarters of the interior ministry and the FSB, Russiaâ€™s main intelligence agency. On Tuesday, Russia claimed to have killed â€œ70 Ukrainian terroristsâ€, roughly the number of all Corps fighters. The group responded with a video showing several fighters with blurred faces and three armoured vehicles. This time, Kyiv did not deny ties to the group. Their goal is â€œto push the enemy in order to create a strip of safe land to protect Ukrainian civilian populationâ€, intelligence spokesman Andriy Yusov said on Monday. A more immediate and important goal is to force the Kremlin to deploy forces to the border regions of Belgorod, Bryansk and Kursk. The deployment will surelydecreaseRussiaâ€™s military might in Ukraine before the long-awaited counteroffensive, observers say. â€œThis is a risk for Russia to get a good screw-up on the front line,â€ Kyiv-based analyst Igar Tyshkevich told Al Jazeera. Far-right, ultranationalist and white supremacist groups mushroomed in Russia in the early 2000s, creating a decentralised movement that involved tens of thousands. Theymarchedin urban centres, killed and wounded hundreds of migrant workers from Central Asia and the Caucasus, and even hatched plans to topple Putinâ€™s government and create a neo-Nazi â€œFourth Reichâ€. Ukrainian far-right groups developed in parallel, but their ideology was different, Tyshkevich said â€“ anti-imperialistic â€œin principleâ€, less racist and xenophobic. However, in terms of organisation, the Russian influence was formative. Before 2014, the movements in both nations were â€œamorphousâ€ youth subcultures that formed a â€œsystem of connected vesselsâ€, Vyacheslav Likhachev, a Kyiv-based expert on ultranationalism, told Al Jazeera. When the Kremlin cracked down on the far right, many activists moved to Ukraine â€œto hide in the familiar linguistic and cultural environment and to keep indoctrinating and passing their experience to their Ukrainian brethrenâ€, he said. After 2014, the flight became a flood. Most of the refugees quit politics, but some kept positioning themselves as â€œthe most right Russiansâ€ who were against Putin and European liberalism, he said. The founders of the Corps were among them â€“ and they still want to topple Putin. â€œRussiaâ€™s collapse will allow us to return home,â€ Denis Kapustin, the Corps founder, told the news conference in October. â€œWe will facilitate the complete and absolute breakdown of the political order in Russia.â€ The burly 39-year-old calls himself a seasoned skinhead, football fan and organiser of mixed martial arts fights. He lived in Germany, where police described him as â€œone of the most influential activistsâ€ of the far-right movement. After returning to Russia he moved to Ukraine in 2017, where he developed ties withAzov, a regiment known for defending the southern Ukrainian city of Mariupol last spring. Some of the Azov members â€“ including fugitive Russians â€“ espoused far-right views. The US Congress banned the regiment in 2018 from using Washington-supplied military aid. The Ukrainian far-right groups and their newly-recruited Russian members were highly visible before the war. They organised rallies, assaulted Roma encampments, beat up pro-Russian politicians and LGBTQ activists, clashed with police â€“ and almost always walked awayscot-free. But since the war began, their influence waned. â€œThe [Ukrainian] society tilted to the right, but on the other hand, the extreme shifted towards the public in terms of reduced radicalism,â€ analyst Tyshkevich said.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 456
Subtitle: As the war enters its 456th day, we take a look at the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation as it stands on Thursday, May 25, 2023.

Title: Leader of anti-Putin force says expect more Russian border raids
Subtitle: Denis Kapustin, self-described commander of the Russian Volunteer Corps, said his unit will raid Russian territory again.
Content: The Russian commander of fighters thatconducted a raidon a Russian border region this week said his group would soon launch more incursions into Russian territory from Ukraine. Denis Kapustin, who described himself as the commander of the Russian Volunteer Corps (RVC), spoke to reporters on Wednesday on the Ukrainian side of the border with Russia a day after Moscow said it had repelled an attack on Russiaâ€™s Belgorod region that lasted almost 24 hours. â€œI think you will see us again on that side,â€ said Kapustin, who is known as an extreme right-wing Russian nationalist who introduced himself to reporters by his call-sign White Rex. â€œThe operation is ongoing,â€ the Moscow-born Kapustin said, flanked by some 30 fighters in camouflage. â€œEvery operation that takes place on the territory of Russia forces the military leadership to move a large amount of forces precisely to that quadrant, therefore laying bare some parts of the front, parts of the border,â€ he said. â€œOur future plans are new territories of the Russian Federation, which we will definitely enterâ€¦ You should be just a little bit patient and wait just a couple of days.â€ Two armed groups operating in Ukraine â€“ Kapustinâ€™s RVC and the allied Freedom of Russia Legion â€“ claimed responsibility for the incursion on Monday and Tuesday. Kyiv said it was not involved in the attack, indicating that it was carried out by Russian anti-Putin forces against the Russian military. Kapustin described his mission as a fight against â€œinjusticeâ€ and â€œtortureâ€ under Russian President Vladimir Putin that was aimed at spurring other Russians to act. â€œI want to prove to them [Russians] that you can fight against tyrants and that Putinâ€™s power is not boundless,â€ he said. Ukrainian authorities â€œdid encourage usâ€ but did not provide weapons or equipment or instructions for this mission, Kapustin added. Belgorod regional Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov reported that two women died and at least 12 people were wounded in the cross-border attack. Local Russian media also reported on Thursday that an estimated 500 houses were damaged in the attack, including 200 that were destroyed. Residents who had fled their homes in Belgorod have not yet returned in some areas, according to the media reports, as authorities are working to identify and make safe mines that were left on the streets and in buildings in the regionâ€™s Grayvoron district.    The Russian military said that it routed the raiders with artillery and air attacks that killed more than 70 of what it described as â€œUkrainian nationalistsâ€ on asabotage missiondesigned to deflect attention from Russiaâ€™s gains in the bombed-outcity of Bakhmut. Kapustin said the total losses on his side were two killed and 10 wounded. â€œAnd, of course, the Ukrainian military took our wounded. But anything more than this would make things difficult,â€ he said referring to Ukrainian involvement in his operations. â€œEvery decision we make â€¦ beyond the state border is our own decision. Obviously, we can ask our [Ukrainian] comrades, friends for their assistance in planning,â€ he said. Described by the United States-based Anti-Defamation League as â€œa Russian neo-Naziâ€, Kapustinâ€™s audacious cross-border raid has embarrassed the Kremlin but also raises questions about the involvement of far-right Russian nationalists in Ukraine and how this might affect Western alliesâ€™ readiness to supply Kyiv with weapons. Kapustin admitted his group was right-wing. He was also asked if he minded being labelled a Nazi. â€œI have my set of views, itâ€™s a patriotic set of views, itâ€™s a traditionalist set of views, itâ€™s a right-wing set of views.
