Some military bloggers fixated on the fact that the invading units were comprised mostly of Russians, leading some to label them â€œtraitors to Russiaâ€, according to the ISW, while Wagner mercenary force boss Yevgeny Prigozhin blamed Russiaâ€™s defence ministry for being unable to defend the countryâ€™s borders. 2/ Russian sources reported on the morning of May 22 that a detachment of the RDK & LSR consisting of several armored vehicles crossed the international border & captured Kozinka, a settlement in the Grayvoron region of#BelgorodOblast within 600m of the border with Sumy Oblast. â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)May 23, 2023  News of the cross-border attack saw the Russian information space respond â€œwith a similar degree of panic, factionalism, and incoherency as it tends to display when it experiences significant informational shocksâ€, the ISW said. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said on Monday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had been informed and that work was under way to drive out the â€œsaboteursâ€, the state-run RIA Novosti news agency reported. An effort to â€œpush them out from the Russian territory and liquidate themâ€ was under way, he said. Peskov described the action as an attempt by Ukraine todivert attention from the eastern city of Bakhmut, which Moscow claimed to have captured after months of battle butwhere Kyiv says it is still fighting. Anton Gerashchenko, an adviser to Ukraineâ€™s minister of internal affairs, posted several video clips from social media about the attacks and the groups involved in the incursion, including a video purportedly showing a Freedom of Russia Legion flag attached to balloons and reportedly flying in Moscow. Russian media report that the buildings of FSB (Federal Security Bureau) and internal affairs ministry were under strike in Belgorod, Russia. Reportedly, the buildings were attacked by drones.pic.twitter.com/rJrN4QKfg6 â€” Anton Gerashchenko (@Gerashchenko_en)May 22, 2023  The Telegram channel Baza, which has links to Russiaâ€™s security services, said there were indications of fighting in three settlements along the main road leading into Russia. The â€œOpen Belgorodâ€ Telegram channel said power and water had been cut off in several villages. The Liberty of Russia Legion said on Twitter it had â€œcompletely liberatedâ€ the border town of Kozinka. It said forward units had reached the district centre of Graivoron, further east. â€œMoving on. Russia will be free!â€ the group wrote. The Legion and the RVC completely liberated n/a Kozinka, Belgorod Oblast. Forward units have entered Graivoron. Moving on. Russia will be free! â€” "Liberty of Russia" Legion (@legion_svoboda)May 22, 2023  Early in March, the FSB reported an incursion from Ukraine into Russiaâ€™s Bryansk region. In videos circulating online at the time, armed men saying they belonged to the Russian Volunteer Corps said they had crossed the border to fight what they called â€œthe bloody Putinite and Kremlin regimeâ€. The RVC was founded last August by Denis Kapustin, a Ukraine-based Russian nationalist, and announced on May 17 that it was joining forces with the Liberty of Russia Legion, which calls itself the Freedom of Russia Legion in English. The group says it has made at least three incursions into the Bryansk region since March.

Title: Fall of Bakhmut would signal â€˜a Pyrrhic victory for Wagnerâ€™
Subtitle: We speak to a Ukrainian military expert, serviceman and analysts on what the possible capture of Bakhmut means.
Content: Kyiv, Ukraineâ€“ According to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Bakhmut resembles Hiroshima after the 1945 nuclear bombing. The ravaged southeastern city, home to about 70,000 people before the war broke out, has been reduced to ruins after a 10-month-long siege. â€œNothing alive left. All of the buildings have been ruined,â€ Zelenskyy told a meeting of the Group of Seven (G7) nations in Hiroshima on Sunday. Hours earlier, Yevgeny Prigozhin, head of the Wagner mercenary group, announced a complete takeover of Bakhmut while Kyiv said it still had toeholds on the outskirts of the mining and university city. If confirmed, Bakhmutâ€™s capture would be Russiaâ€™s first military gain since the fall ofSoledar, a much smaller town northeast of Bakhmut, in January. However, the gain is more symbolic than strategic â€“ especially given Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s hopes for a triumphant blitzkrieg in Ukraine in February 2022. Bakhmut was seized mostly by Wagnerâ€™s forces, a group that largely consists of untrained inmates recruited from Russian prisons after regular Russian servicemen proved too disorganised, disheartened and poorly trained. Wagner started human-wave assaults, called â€œmeat marchesâ€, in December. They were backed by massive, nearly round-the-clock artillery and mortar fire as well as air strikes. A top Ukrainian military expert said Wagner has been bled dry by colossal losses of manpower and equipment in their slow, street-by-street advance. â€œThis is a Pyrrhic victory for Wagner,â€ Lieutenant General Ihor Romanenko, former deputy chief of the General Staff of Ukraineâ€™s armed forces, told Al Jazeera. â€œPrigozhin understands it too,â€ he said. â€œHe just had to report a military-political result [to Putin], something apart from Soledar.â€ Prigozhin reportedly made a personal pledge to Putin to seize Bakhmut, even though the city had lost its transport and logistical importance for Ukraineâ€™s forces, which rerouted their supply lines last year. Romanenko said Kyivâ€™s troops still control the hills near Bakhmut, preventing Russiaâ€™s advance towards the heavily fortified cities and towns of Chasiv Yar, Konstantinivka, Kramatorsk and Sloviansk. United States President Joe Biden told the G7 that Russians had lost 100,000 servicemen there since the siege began in July â€“ more than Bakhmutâ€™s entire pre-war civilian population. Russia lost five servicemen to Ukraineâ€™s every one, a NATO source told CNN on Sunday. Prigozhin said his mercenaries willretreatfrom Bakhmut in days. They will hand over the city to regular Russian servicemen, he said, something that could prove problematic because they largely consist of recently mobilised men with poor training and low morale. Ukraine has never divulged its military losses, but they were so severe that the White House urged Kyiv to leave Bakhmut in February, according to leaked US documents. Some Ukrainian servicemen expressed doubts about their commanders and said they were forced to return to defending Bakhmut despite severe wounds. â€œA bomb went off just metres away from me,â€ a Ukrainian serviceman who said he arrived in Kyiv for a â€œquick patch-upâ€ and the christening of his son told Al Jazeera. â€œI see double, I had five contusions, but they want me back,â€ he said on the condition of anonymity. To his wife, his return to the front lines seems like an absolutely unnecessary sacrifice. â€œDo they have to finish him off there? Why canâ€™t they find someone younger, someone who hasnâ€™t been wounded that many times?â€ she told Al Jazeera. The takeover of Bakhmut seemed especially bitter after Ukraine started a surprising and successful counterattack there this month. But the counterattack was apparently aimed at saving the remaining Ukrainian servicemen, a military analyst said.    â€œThe goal has been achieved,â€ Nikolay Mitrokhin of Germanyâ€™s Bremen University told Al Jazeera. â€œThe [city] has been abandoned.â€ Bakhmutâ€™s fall may delay a much bigger counteroffensive in the south, especially in the Zaporizhia region, where Kyiv had been amassing forces in recent weeks, he said. The delay also has to do with the arrival of new Western weaponry, especially advanced German-made Leopard A1 tanks, he said. Ukrainian forces â€œmostly likely wonâ€™t start an offensive in the south or elsewhere until they receive and test 80 Leopard A1 tanks that were pledged to them by June 1,â€ Mitrokhin said. The delay may prove detrimental to the restoration of Ukraineâ€™s economy, which shrank by almost a third last year and has barely started recovering, observers said. Western governments and millions of refugees await the warâ€™s end to pour aid in and return home. â€œNaturally, if the [victory] date is delayed by years, there are almost no chances for development,â€ Kyiv-based analyst Aleksey Kushch told Al Jazeera. Despite what Zelenskyy said about the ruins of Bakhmut, to the Kremlin and its backers, it was not a Hiroshima. It is not even Bakhmut because they persistently use the townâ€™s Soviet-era name, Artyomovsk. The Kremlin released a statement promising state awards to â€œall those who distinguished themselvesâ€, andpro-war Russianscompeted to praise the â€œtriumphâ€. â€œArtyomovsk has been liberated. Itâ€™s a historic event,â€ a news host on Kremlin-controlled Channel One announced on Sunday. â€œThe myth that Artyomovsk is an impregnable fortress has been destroyed.â€ â€œThe takeover opens a direct and short way towardsâ€ the eastern city of Dnipro,â€ the Russia 1 channel reported. A few figures on Moscowâ€™s side who dare contradict the Kremlinâ€™s viewpoint do not consider Bakhmutâ€™s takeover as a major event. â€œThe efforts wasted on Bakhmutâ€™s takeover are incalculable,â€ Aleksandr Khodarovsky, a commander in the separatist-controlled â€œPeopleâ€™s Republic of Donetskâ€ wrote on Telegram on Sunday. â€œBakhmut is no Berlin, and its fall doesnâ€™t signify the warâ€™s end.â€ Another rebel warlord echoed Romanenkoâ€™s words about Russiaâ€™s â€œPyrrhicâ€ victory. â€œIt wasnâ€™t even approximately worth the forces and funds spent on it,â€ Igor Girkin, a former defence minister in separatist-occupied Donetsk, said in a Telegram post.

Title: Ukraine still has a foothold inside Bakhmut, says official
Subtitle: The deputy defence minister says Ukrainian troops are advancing near the city, over which Russia claimed victory.
Content: Ukrainian troops are still advancing on the flanks of Bakhmut and have a small foothold inside the eastern city, a defence official in Kyiv has said, again raising doubts on Russiaâ€™s claims. Over the weekend, the Wagner Group and Russian military chiefs announced the capture of Bakhmut after months of heavy fighting. But on Monday, Ukraineâ€™s Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar said in televised comments: â€œWe are still advancing, but the intensity is somewhat reduced. â€œIf we talk about the north, there is much less active action there. If we talk about the south, we are advancing and the defence of Bakhmut as a city has completely fulfilled its military objective.â€  On Saturday, Russia announced it had taken control of Bakhmut after a bloody 15-month battle, which, if confirmed, would be a significant success for Moscow after facing setbacks on the front lines. The fight for the city has been the longest and bloodiest of the war so far. Mercenary forces, who have spearheaded the fight, posted videos on Telegram waving Wagner and Russian flags in the destroyed city.    Russian President Vladimir Putincongratulatedhis army and Wagner on the alleged capture. To Moscow, seizing Bakhmut would be a stepping stone towards advancing deeper into the Donbas region and towards the city of Sloviansk. However, since making the announcement, officials from Russia and Ukraine have given contrasting status updates about who has won the city or whether fighting was still ongoing. On Sunday, Ukrainian General Oleksandr Syrskyi said on Telegram that Kyivâ€™s troops were continuing to advance on Russian forces in the suburbs and getting closer to a â€œtactical encirclementâ€ of the city. Maliar echoed Syrskyiâ€™s observations on Sunday, saying a â€œsemi-encirclementâ€ could allow Ukraine to â€œdestroy the enemy â€¦ the enemy has to defend himself in the part of the city he controlsâ€. At a meeting of Group of Seven (G7) countries in Japan, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Bakhmut had not fallen and likened the city to the destruction of Hiroshima. Responding to a reporterâ€™s question about the cityâ€™s status, he said: â€œBakhmut is not occupied by the Russian Federation as of today.â€ Yevgeny Prigozhin, head of the Wagner forces, responded to Zelenskyyâ€™s comments, saying: â€œThere is not a single Ukrainian soldier in the village of Bakhmut, for the reason that we have stopped taking prisoners. â€œThere are a huge number of corpses of the Ukrainian military. Bakhmut is taken completely along all its legal boundaries, to the last centimetre. [Zelenskyy] is disingenuous, or he, like our military leaders, is simply not aware of what is happening on the ground.â€ On Monday, Prigozhin said his troops would leave Bakhmut later this week after taking the city as promised and transfer control of Bakhmut to the Russian military.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 453
Subtitle: As the war enters its 453rd day, we take a look at the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation as it stands on Monday, May 22, 2023. Colonel General Oleksandr Syrsky, the commander of Ukraineâ€™s ground forces, has said Ukrainian troops were approaching a â€œtactical encirclementâ€™ of Bakhmut,â€ according to the Kyiv Independent. The commander earlier visited the front line.

Title: Russia says F-16 transfer to Ukraine would raise NATO question
Subtitle: Latest Russian warning comes after US President Joe Biden agreed to provide training to Ukrainian pilots on fighter jets.
Content: The transfer of F-16 fighter jets to Ukraine would raise the question of NATOâ€™s involvement in the conflict, Russiaâ€™s Ambassador to the United States Anatoly Antonov has said. â€œThere is no infrastructure for the operation of the F-16 in Ukraine and the needed number of pilots and maintenance personnel is not there either,â€ Antonov said in remarks published on the embassyâ€™s Telegram messaging channel on Monday. â€œWhat will happen if the American fighters take off from NATO airfields, controlled by foreign â€˜volunteersâ€™?â€ Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has for months been calling on the countryâ€™s Western allies to supply advanced fighter jets amid concerns such a move would be met with an escalation by Russian President Vladimir Putin. But amid a flurry of diplomacy by Zelenskyy ahead of the just-concludedG7 summitin Hiroshima, Japan, United Kingdom Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte announced last week they had agreed to build an â€œinternational coalitionâ€ to provide fighter jet support for Ukraine. Then on Friday, US President Joe Biden endorsed training programmes for Ukrainian pilots on F-16 fighter jets, with Zelenskyy assuring Biden that the aircraft would not be used to go into Russian territory. Over the weekend, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Grushko warned Western countries would be running â€œcolossal risksâ€ if they went ahead with the supply of the F-16s. Antonov said that any Ukrainian attack on Crimea, which Moscowinvaded and annexed in 2014, would be considered an attack on Russia. â€œIt is important that the United States be fully aware of the Russian response,â€ Antonov said. The international community does not recognise Russian sovereignty over Crimea. Air defence experts say US-built F-16 fighter jets wouldoffer Ukraine an edgeover the Russian air force, but only if combined with powerful missiles and targeting information, which the West would also have to provide and which would risk drawing Ukraineâ€™s Western allies more actively into the war.

Title: Russians celebrate reports that â€˜fortress Bakhmutâ€™ has fallen
Subtitle: Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is denying claims that the eastern city is under Russian control after months of heavy battle.
Content: On Saturday, mercenaries from the Russian private military contractor the Wagner Groupclaimed victoryin the east Ukrainian town of Bakhmut after a gruelling battle that lasted for eight months. For the most part, the pro-Moscow camp has been elated at finally dislodging the stubborn Ukrainian defenders. Although Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy hasdenied on Sunday that Bakhmut has fallen, Russian businessman andWagnerboss Yevgeny Prigozhin claimed otherwise in a voice memo to his 420,000 Telegram followers. â€œThere is not a single Ukrainian soldier in the village of Bakhmut, for the reason that we have stopped taking prisoners,â€ he declared. â€œThere are a huge number of corpses of the Ukrainian military. Bakhmut is taken completely along all its legal boundaries, to the last centimetre. Vladimir Alexandrovich [Zelenskyy] is disingenuous, or he, like our military leaders, is simply not aware of what is happening on the ground.â€ Through a statement on the Kremlinâ€™s official press service, Russiaâ€™s President VladimirPutin congratulated the Russian army and Wagnermercenary group on the capture of Artemovsk, as the city was known in Soviet times and until 2016. Footage on both Russian TV and Telegram channels showed the Russian flag waving from the rooftop of an apartment building still standing among the ruins of Bakhmut. â€œWithout exaggeration, a historical moment â€“ the Wagner fighters are hoisting the Russian flag, and the flag of their company, on the last street of Artemovsk,â€ Amir Yusupov, a correspondent embedded on the front line, reported for the state-owned Channel One. â€œThe city has been cleared â€¦Â  Many could have left at the end of their contract, but every single one stayed.â€ One masked mercenary interviewed on camera compared the experience to World War II. â€œHow could I leave the lads?â€ he asked. â€œI had to see this moment. These are probably the same emotions as our grandfathers felt in Berlin.â€    The Wagner Orchestra, a Telegram channel describing themselves as â€œfansâ€ of the mercenary outfit, published a video of bearded commander Alexander â€œRatiborâ€ Kuznetsov raising the Russian and Wagner flags over the ruined city and yelling ethnic slurs at Ukrainians, telling them to â€œgo f*** themselves!â€ Another video on the channel shows a group of Wagner fighters triumphantly firing their weapons into the air as a Wagner flag waves in the background. An article by the state-owned news agency RIA Novosti on the â€œliberation of Artemovskâ€ blames Ukrainian forces for any civilian casualties. â€œBefore the conflict began, more than seventy thousand people lived here,â€ it read. â€œMost have left the city. According to the refugees, Ukrainian soldiers deliberately fired on civilians.â€ The article assured that, despite Ukrainian propaganda, â€œfortress Bakhmutâ€ had indeed fallen, which will allow Russian forces to move on to the nearby town of Chasiv Yar. â€œThis is a victory, one of those that bring the main victory closer,â€ Andrey Medvedev, former journalist and Moscow politician, wrote on Telegram. â€œThe path we still have to go is long and difficult, and we still have a lot to go through. There will be failures and disappointments. There will be days of dark despair and unbelief. But on such days we can remember just Bakhmut â€¦ Glory to the Russian soldier!â€ Despite Moscowâ€™s claims of victory, Igor Girkin, nom de guerre Strelkov, a former Russian soldier and intelligence officer who led the original 2014-15 uprising of east Ukrainian separatists, painted a bleaker picture to his nearly 800,000 Telegram subscribers. He describes the capture of Bakhmut as not a victory in any tactical sense, but part of the Kremlinâ€™s policy of â€œfreezing the conflict through a compromise agreementâ€, and as such, only intending to wear the enemy down until Kyiv and its Western allies agree to let Russia keep Crimea and the Donbas. Strelkov is a hardline Russian nationalist who believes Moscow is not taking the conquest of Ukraine seriously enough. â€œOn the whole, the operation ended in a strategic failure of our troops,â€ wrote Strelkov. â€œThe enemy has NOT been ousted from the Donbas in all the main directions, in most directions â€“ not moved at all.â€ He added that the Russian military had exhausted weapon stockpiles, ammunition and manpower that will be â€œnecessary for further offensive operationsâ€. â€œThatâ€™s why Bakhmut was given increased attention for the last two months â€“ it was necessary to achieve at least some result â€˜for propagandaâ€™ in order to â€˜take a breathâ€™ afterwards. And so we won, sort of,â€ Strelkov said. Strelkov also warned that the resources spent on Bakhmut, an â€œunnecessaryâ€ and â€œPyrrhicâ€ victory that was â€œnot worth the effort and money spent on itâ€, will leave the Russian side vulnerable to the Ukrainian counteroffensive.

Title: Why is Bakhmut important in the Russia-Ukraine war?
Subtitle: The symbolic importance of the small city in Ukraineâ€™s east now far outweighs any strategic value for either side.
Content: Russia claims it has fully captured Bakhmut in eastern Ukraine, but Kyiv says it still controls part of the city. Bakhmut, which once had a population of about 70,000 people, has seen eight months of fierce fighting in the bloodiest battle since Russia invaded Ukraine in February 2022. Russian President Vladimir Putincongratulated his troops and the Wagner Group private armyfor â€œliberatingâ€ the city on Saturday, but Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said that although Russian troops are in Bakhmut, the city is â€œnot occupiedâ€. Colonel General Oleksandr Syrsky, commander of the Ground Forces of Ukraine, said on Sunday that Ukrainian troops are approaching the capture of the city in a tactical encirclement. Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Malyar said Ukrainian troops are advancing â€œin the suburbs on the flanksâ€ and have â€œsemi-encircled the cityâ€.  But why has Bakhmut, a previously sleepy, nondescript city nestled away in the salt-mining region of eastern Ukraine, become so significant in the Russia-Ukraine war? Here is what you need to know: In order for Russia to advance further into Ukraine and achieve Putinâ€™s aim of â€œliberating the Donbasâ€, Russia needs to capture Bakhmut. However, the huge amount of emphasis that both sides have placed on the city goes far beyond any strategic value. If either side were to completely capture Bakhmut, they would then face a series of defensive lines positioned around it. The cityâ€™s importance instead lies in the symbolic weight it has garnered over months of bitter, entrenched fighting. For Ukraine, it has become an example of dogged, determined resistance. The city has seen some of the most intense fighting since Russiaâ€™s invasion. Images of blood-soaked trench warfare are shared on the messaging app Telegram, and â€œBakhmut holds!â€ is a popular slogan on social media. Russia, on the other hand, needs a victory. After its initial advances in the first months of its full-scale invasion, a successful Ukrainian counteroffensive reclaimed swathes of territory in a series of humiliating defeats for Russian forces.    As the Russian military lost face, the Wagner Group, a mercenary outfit hardened by years of deployments in Syria and various African nations, took on the fight for Bakhmut late last year. Since then, the Russian offensive in Bakhmut has become synonymous with the group, and its abrasive chiefYevgeny Prigozhinhas called out senior Russian military leaders and publicly berated them for not providing his forces with enough ammunition. A victory for Russia in Bakhmut could also be seen a victory for Prigozhin and potentially raise his standing with the Kremlin. Speaking on Sunday at the Group of Seven (G7) summit in Hiroshima, Japan, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the city has been â€œcompletely destroyedâ€, suggesting that a potential defeat would be cast by Kyiv as a pyrrhic victory for Russia. The loss of the city could inflict a blow to morale for Ukraine after so many months of bitter fighting. It is not known exactly how many troops on both sides have died in the conflict, but Moscow and Kyiv have both claimed to have killed hundreds in a single day. It would come at a time when Ukraine is expected to launch a highly anticipated counteroffensive, which could raise concerns amongst Ukraineâ€™s allies. In March, Zelenskyy said if Bakhmut fell it could allow Russia to garner international support for a deal that might force Ukraine to make unacceptable compromises. The fall of the city could be a huge morale boost for Russia, which is in need of its first major victory in more than 10 months. Since the latter half of 2022, reports from the front lines of the war have tended to reflect Ukrainian advances in some areas and a grinding stalemate in others. Russia has launched several waves of drone and missile strikes at Ukrainian cities but claimed no significant territorial gains. Putin congratulated both the Wagner private army and regular Russian forces in a statement, indicating that the leader is eager to close what has been a grinding, resource-draining chapter in Russiaâ€™s attempts to capture the Donbas region. Strategically, a victory in Bakhmut could open up a path further west, possibly to Kramatorsk, a city with roughly 150,000 inhabitants before the war. However, Ukraine has heavily fortified the areas around the city of Bakhmut.

Title: Zelenskyy calls on G7 to ensure Russia is â€˜last aggressorâ€™
Subtitle: Ukrainian leaderâ€™s visit to Japan highlighted significant divisions preventing the formation of a united front against Russia.
Content: Hiroshima, Japan â€“Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has called on the world to prevent future wars by ensuring Russia is the â€œlast aggressorâ€, capping avisit to Japanthat secured new sanctions against Moscow and weapons for Kyiv. In a speech marking the end of a week-long diplomatic blitz spanning Europe, the Middle East and Asia, Zelenskyy said Ukraineâ€™s victory against Russia would deter future aggressors, casting his10-point peace planas the worldâ€™s â€œsalvation from warâ€. Zelenskyyâ€™s plan, first proposed in November, would restore Ukraineâ€™s borders and see the withdrawal of Russian forces from Ukrainian territory, as well as provide guarantees for nuclear, energy and food security. â€œWe will paralyse other potential aggressors,â€ Zelenskyy told a press conference on Sunday, the last day of the Group of Seven (G7) summit in Hiroshima. â€œWhen everyone who wants war sees how determined the world is when it wants peace, there will be no point to start a war.â€ Zelenskyy made his address after securing commitments from G7 countries to ramp up pressure on Russia and boost support for the defence of Ukraine. United States President Joe Biden earlier announced a$375m military aid packagethat includes more ammunition, artillery and armoured vehicles, on top of offering his support for the training of Ukrainian pilots to fly F-16 fighter jets. On Friday, the G7 leaders pledged to tighten their sanctions against Russia and continue to support Ukraine for the long term. Washington separately imposed new sanctions on 22 Russians and 104 Russian entities, while United Kingdom Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced a ban on imports of Russian diamonds, copper, aluminium, tin and nickel. The European Union is currently negotiating an 11th package of sanctions that aims to close loopholes and tackle theÂ evasion of existing measures.    In a speech against the backdrop of the Atomic Bomb Dome earlier on Sunday, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, the G7 host, cast Zelenskyyâ€™s attendance as evidence of his countryâ€™s â€œunwavering solidarityâ€ with Ukraine and condemned Moscowâ€™s invasion as striking at the â€œvery foundation of the international orderâ€. Even so, Zelenskyyâ€™s visit highlighted significant divisions preventing the formation of a united front against Russia, and the Ukrainian leader did not get everything that he wanted in Hiroshima. While the G7 remains influential, its share of the global economy has plunged from about 70 percent during the 1980s to 44 percent today â€“ meaning that choking the Russian economy increasingly requires buy-in from the wider international community. Kishida invited eight non-G7 members to the summit, including India, Indonesia, Australia and South Korea, as part of efforts to boost cooperation on global challenges, including the war in Ukraine. India, China and Turkey have ramped up imports of Russian energy since the invasion, blunting the impact of sanctions on Russiaâ€™s economy, which shrank by a less-than-expected 2.1 percent last year. While Zelenskyy met with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who pledged to do â€œwhatever we canâ€ to resolve the Ukraine crisis, there were no indications that New Delhi would impose sanctions or curtail its purchases of Russian energy. â€œNothing has changed fundamentally since the war began,â€ Alka Acharya, a professor at the Centre for East Asian Studies at Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi, told Al Jazeera. â€œIn terms of Indian interests and as he [Modi] has indicated, he would be championing the cause of the Global South at the summit. He would, in my view, stick to that brief â€“ apart from making general observations about desiring a quick end to the war.â€ Zelenskyy did not meet with Brazilian President Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva, commonly known as Lula, who last month said it was â€œno use now in saying who is rightâ€ in the conflict. The Ukrainian leader played down the lack of talks, suggesting that it was a simple matter of scheduling. â€œI think it disappointed him,â€ Zelenskyy said when asked if he was disappointed the two men did not meet, prompting laughter among the assembled media. Zelenskyy also admitted he would like to see Japan and South Korea provide weapons to Ukraine, along with all other countries capable of doing so, but acknowledged that â€œlegislative and constitutional complicationsâ€ made such moves difficult for some governments. Zelenskyy expressed confidence that his country would receive F-16 fighter jets from Western countries, although Kyiv has yet to secure commitments for the delivery of the planes. Yet even among the G7 members, gaps in the sanctions regimeÂ against Russia persist. Philipp Lausberg, a policy analyst at the European Policy Centre in Brussels, described the G7â€™s measures against Russiaâ€™s diamond trade, for example, as â€œmeagreâ€. â€œThe UK is the only country that went ahead and put in place an embargo on Russian diamonds, but all the other countries have only expressed their intent to at some point restrict the trade of Russian diamonds,â€ Lausberg told Al Jazeera. Still, Zelenskyy was defiant on Sunday evening as the curtain closed on his visit to Japan, expressing his belief that Russia â€œcannot winâ€ its war and that â€œinternational law will never again applyâ€ if Moscow is not stopped. â€œI believe war has no place in the world,â€ he said.

Title: Tens of thousands rally in Moldova for EU membership
Subtitle: Demonstrators called on political leaders to amend the constitution to specifically mention the countryâ€™s European orientation.
Content: Tens of thousands of Moldovans rallied in the capital Chisinau to support their pro-Western governmentâ€™s drive towards Europe amid what officials have said areRussian effortsto destabilise their country. More than 75,000 people participated on Sunday in the demonstration in the centre of the capital, according to initial police estimates. They waved European Union flags and chanted pro-European slogans. â€œWe came to say loudly, confidently and proudly that Moldovans are Europeans!â€ President Maia Sandu, who had called for the rally, told the crowd. She said her country wanted to join the 27-nation EU by 2030. â€œThis is the chance for our people to live in peace and prosperity,â€ she said. Moldova has been badly hit by the impact of Moscowâ€™s invasion of neighbouring Ukraine, which Chisinau has repeatedly condemned, andapplied to join the EU. Sandu has accused Russia of seeking to sabotage its European integration by fuelling anti-government protests and propaganda. Moscow denies meddling in Moldovaâ€™s affairs. â€œMoldova does not want to be blackmailed by the Kremlin,â€ Sandu said at the rally that packed a central square. Police said more than 75,000 demonstrators were present. â€œWe donâ€™t want to be on the outskirts of Europe anymore,â€ she said. On a visit to Chisinau, European Parliament President Roberta Metsola also addressed the rally, saying Europe would welcome Moldova â€œwith open arms and open heartsâ€. â€œThis is about the both of us: You will bring a piece of Moldova to Europe, and you will make Europe stronger,â€ she said. Demonstrators called on Moldovaâ€™s political leaders to amend the constitution to specifically mention the countryâ€™s European orientation. The leader of the pro-Russian opposition Shor Party, exiled businessman Ilan Shor, told his supporters at rival protests in several cities via video link that he would seek a referendum on Moldovaâ€™s foreign policy. Shor, sanctioned by the United States as an agent of Russian influence in Moldova, was handed a 15-year jail sentence in absentia last month for his role in the 2014 theft of $1bn from Moldovan banks.

Title: Russians â€˜destroyed everythingâ€™ in Bakhmut: Ukraineâ€™s Zelenskyy
Subtitle: His spokesman denied earlier reports attributed to the Ukrainian president that the besieged city was captured by the Russian forces.
Content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has said the city of Bakhmut has been â€œcompletely destroyedâ€ by Moscowâ€™s Wagner private army, backed by Russian troops, after a bloody eight-month battle. â€œThey destroyed everything,â€ Zelenskyy said on Sunday, speaking at the G7 summit in the Japanese city of Hiroshima. â€œFor today, Bakhmut is only in our hearts,â€ he said. â€œThere is nothing in this place.â€  However, his spokesman earlier on Sunday denied reports attributed to the Ukrainian president that the besieged eastern Ukrainian city was captured by the Russian forces. â€œReporterâ€™s question: Russians said they have taken Bakhmut,â€ Sergii Nykyforov wrote on Facebook. â€œPresidentâ€™s reply: I think no.â€ He added in Ukrainian: â€œIn this way, the president denied the capture of Bakhmut.â€    Russia claims to havefully captured the cityin what would mark its first major victory in more than 10 months. â€œAs a result of offensive actions of the Wagner assault units, with the support of artillery and aviation of the â€˜Southernâ€™ unit, the liberation of the city of Artemovsk was completed,â€ Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said in a statement on Sunday. In a Kremlin statement, Russian President Vladimir Putin is said to have congratulated the assault units and support servicemen of units involved in the battle for the city. Wagnerâ€™s boss Yevgeny Prigozhin had posted a video earlier on the messaging app Telegram that showed Russian fighters in front of a ruined cityscape. â€œToday on May 20, around midday, Bakhmut was taken in its entirety,â€ Prigozhin said in the video, adding that Wagner fighters would search the captured city before handing it over to the Russian army. â€œBy May 25, we will completely examine [Bakhmut], create the necessary lines of defence and hand it to the military,â€ Prigozhin said. â€œWe ourselves will go into field camps.â€ Fighting was audible in the background as he spoke.

Title: Putin congratulates Russia troops, Wagner for â€˜capturing Bakhmutâ€™
Subtitle: Russian claims of capturing Bakhmut came hours after Ukraine said the battle for the eastern city was continuing.
Content: Russia has claimed to have fully captured Ukraineâ€™s Bakhmut, with President Vladimir Putin congratulating his troops and the mercenary Wagner Group for taking the largely levelled eastern city. The Russian announcement on Saturday came hours after Kyiv said the battle was still continuing whileadmitting the situation was â€œcriticalâ€. Bakhmut, a salt-mining town that once had a population of 70,000 people, has been the scene ofthe longest and bloodiest battlein Russiaâ€™s 15-month war in Ukraine. The fall of Bakhmut, where both Russia and Ukraine are believed to have suffered huge losses, would represent Moscowâ€™s first big victory in the conflict in more than 10 months. â€œAs a result of offensive actions of the Wagner assault units, with the support of artillery and aviation of the â€˜Southernâ€™ unit, the liberation of the city of Artemovsk was completed,â€ Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said in a statement, using the Soviet-era name of Bakhmut. â€œVladimir Putin congratulated the assault units of Wagner as well as all servicemen of units of the Russian armed forces who provided them with the necessary support and flank cover, on the completion of the operation to liberateâ€ the city, the TASS state news agency quoted a Kremlin statement as saying. The Russian president said those who had distinguished themselves would be given awards, the news agency added.    Wagnerâ€™s boss Yevgeny Prigozhin earlier claimed the city had fallen to his mercenaries in a video posted on Telegram, in which fighters held Russian flags against a backdrop of ruins. â€œToday on May 20, around midday, Bakhmut was taken in its entirety,â€ Prigozhin said in the video, adding that Wagner fighters would search the captured city before handing it over to the Russian army. â€œBy May 25 we will completely examine [Bakhmut], create the necessary lines of defence and hand it to the military,â€ Prigozhin said. â€œWe ourselves will go into field camps.â€ Artillery sound could be heard in the background of Prigozhinâ€™s video. The claims came after a week in which Ukrainian forces have made their most rapid gains for six months on Bakhmutâ€™s northern and southern flanks. Kyiv had denied Prigozhinâ€™s claim earlier on Saturday but did not have an immediate response to the defence ministryâ€™s statement. â€œHeavy fighting in Bakhmut. The situation is critical,â€ deputy defence minister Hanna Maliar posted on Telegram. She said Ukrainian troops were â€œholding the defenceâ€ in the cityâ€™s â€œAirplane areaâ€. â€œAs of now, our defenders control certain industrial and infrastructure facilities in the area,â€ she said. It was not possible for Al Jazeera to verify either claim. Whether the Ukrainian forces have left Bakhmut or not, they have been slowly pulling back inside it, to clusters of buildings on the cityâ€™s western edge. Meanwhile, to the north and south, they have seized swathes of territory from Russian troops. Russia has acknowledged losing some ground around Bakhmut in the past week, while denying assertions by Prigozhin that the flanks around the city guarded by regular troops have collapsed. Kyiv says its aim in Bakhmut has been to draw Russian forces from elsewhere on the front into the city, to inflict high casualties there and weaken Moscowâ€™s defensive line elsewhere ahead of a planned major counteroffensive. Moscow has long claimed that capturing Bakhmut would be a stepping stone towards advancing deeper into the Donbas region it claims to have annexed from Ukraine. It has made it the principal target of a massive offensive that failed to capture any significant ground elsewhere. Prigozhin has acknowledged that Bakhmut has little strategic significance, despite its huge symbolic importance because of the scale of losses in Europeâ€™s bloodiest ground battle since World War II.    The battle for Bakhmut has meanwhile revealed a deepening split between Wagner, a mercenary force that has recruited thousands of convicts from Russian prisons, and the regular Russian military. For two weeks, Prigozhin has been issuing daily video and audio messages denouncing Russiaâ€™s military leadership, often in expletive-laden rants. In Saturdayâ€™s video, he said that because of the â€œwhimsâ€ of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of Staff Valery Gerasimov, â€œfive times more guys died than they should haveâ€. He thanked Putin â€œthat he gave us this chance and great honour to defend our motherlandâ€. Russiaâ€™s announcement that the city had fallen came as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was set to meet with his American counterpart, Joe Biden, in Japan during the G7 summit. Biden, who has spearheaded Western backing of Ukraine with sanctions and supplies, â€œlooks forwardâ€ to the meeting, a senior official in the United States said, adding that it is expected to take place after 2:00pm local time (0500 GMT) on Sunday. The Ukrainian president, who was flown in on a French government plane, was able to meet not just G7 leaders but those fromother key international playerssuch as unaligned powers Brazil and India. The fruits of his diplomatic efforts have already paid off, with the US announcing Friday that it would allow Kyiv to acquireF-16 fighter jets, the most sophisticated material yet supplied by the West. En route to Japan, Zelenskyy also stopped at anArab League summit in Saudi Arabia. The Vatican said on Saturday that Pope Francis had asked Cardinal Matteo Zuppi, head of the Italian bishopsâ€™ conference, to carry out a peace mission to try to help end the war.

Title: The battle for Ukraineâ€™s Bakhmut: A timeline
Subtitle: Wagner claims control of Bakhmut but Kyiv says fighting continues. Here are some key moments in the battle for the city.
Content: The battle for the city of Bakhmut in Ukraineâ€™s eastern Donbas region has become the longest and bloodiest of Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Here is a timeline of key events there: May 8, 2022 â€“Ukraine confirms its forces havewithdrawn from Popasna, a town around 24km east of Bakhmut, with a major road running between the two settlements. Russian forces can now advance towards Bakhmut and pound it with artillery. August 9, 2022 â€“British defence intelligence says the Bakhmut axis has been Russiaâ€™s most successful front during the last 30 days and troops have advanced about 10km in the region. October 8, 2022 â€“The start of the assault on Bakhmut city byWagner fighters, according to Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin. October 15, 2022 â€“Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says the situation in Bakhmut is â€œthe most difficultâ€ of all the front lines. â€œWe are holding our positions,â€ he says.    December 20, 2022 â€“Zelenskyy pays a surprise visitto the city, where he hails his â€œsuperhumanâ€troopsand urges them to fight on. January 25, 2023 â€“Ukraineâ€™s military says it has withdrawn from the town ofSoledar, north of Bakhmut. Two weeks earlier, Prigozhin posted a photo of himself along with some of his fighters in what he said was one of Soledarâ€™s salt mines. February 3, 2023 â€“Zelenskyy says Ukraine will fight â€œas long as we canâ€ for Bakhmut. â€œNobody will give away Bakhmut â€¦We consider Bakhmut our fortress,â€ he says. March 10, 2023 â€“After appearing to plan a retreat in early March, andWestern allies questioningthe strategic importance of Bakhmut, Ukraine decides to reinforce its beleaguered soliders in Bakhmut, saying that battle islocking downRussiaâ€™s best military units. March 22, 2023 â€“Zelenskyy makes a surprise visit to troops near Bakhmut to thank them for their bravery and hand out awards. April 2, 2023 â€“Prigozhin hoists a Russian flag by what he says is Bakhmutâ€™s city hall. He says taking the building means Bakhmut has been captured by Moscow â€œfrom a legal point of viewâ€. Ukraine rejects his claim, saying it is not clear where Prigozhin raised the flag.    April 11, 2023 â€“Prigozhin says Wagner controls more than 80 percent of Bakhmut. Ukraine denies this, saying it controls â€œconsiderablyâ€ more than 20 percent of the city. April 26, 2023 â€“The United Kingdomâ€™s Ministry of Defence says fighting has reached Bakhmutâ€™s western outskirts over the past week, especially around the settlement of Khromove on its northwestern edge, as Ukraine seeks to retain control of the main access road. May 1, 2023 â€“Ukraine claims to have ousted Russian forces from some positions in Bakhmut amid fierce battles. May 10, 2023 â€“Ukraineâ€™s ground forces commander says Russian units in some parts ofBakhmuthave retreated by up to two kilometres. May 19, 2023 â€“Ukraine says it hasrepelled attacks by Russian forcestrying to recapture ground around Bakhmut. Prigozhin says â€œheavy, bloody battlesâ€ are continuing and his men are close to completely capturing Bakhmut. May 20, 2023 â€“Prigozhin says Wagner forces havecompleted the capture of Bakhmut. Ukraine says the situation there is critical, with its troops still defending the southwestern part of the city.

Title: Kyiv says Bakhmut situation â€˜criticalâ€™ as Wagner claims control
Subtitle: Ukraine rejects claim, says heavy fighting continues in the city and describes the situation there as â€˜criticalâ€™.
Content: The head of the Russian private army Wagner has said his fighters have completed thecapture of Bakhmutin eastern Ukraine, but Kyiv immediately rejected the claim and said fighting was still going on. Yevgeny Prigozhin made the claim in a video on Saturday in which he appeared in combat fatigues in front of a line of fighters holding Russian flags and Wagner banners. â€œToday, at 12 noon, Bakhmut was completely taken,â€ Prigozhin said. â€œWe completely took the whole city, from house to house. â€œThe operation to capture Bakhmut â€“ the Bakhmut meat grinder â€“ lasted 224 days,â€ he said. But Ukraine said it retained some ground control in the eastern city of Bakhmut, with fighting continuing and the situation â€œcriticalâ€. â€œHeavy fighting in Bakhmut. The situation is critical,â€ Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar posted on Telegram. She said Ukrainian troops were â€œholding the defenceâ€ in the cityâ€™s â€œAirplane areaâ€. â€œAs of now, our defenders control certain industrial and infrastructure facilities in the area.â€  Ukrainian military spokesperson Serhii Cherevatyi told the Reuters news agency: â€œOur units are fighting in Bakhmut.â€ Al Jazeera was not able to verify the claims. Journalist Yulia Shapovalova, reporting from Moscow, told Al Jazeera that this isnâ€™t the first time Prigozhin has made a statement like this. â€œEarlier he repeatedly reported about the capture of Bakhmut but every time it turned out to be wrong. The Russian authorities have not commented on his statements,â€ she said. â€œEarlier the Russian defence ministry official representative said that theyâ€¦ continue operations to liberate the western part of this city. â€œA big question now â€“ whoâ€™s going to hold the city if the Ukrainian forces are not withdrawing and according to Prigozhin, the city will be handed over the Ministry of Defence?â€ Bakhmut has been the focus of the longest and bloodiest battle of Russiaâ€™s war in Ukraine, which is nearly at the end of its 15th month. The battle has flattened the salt-mining centre that once had a population of approximately 70,000 people. Distant explosions could be heard in the background as Prigozhin spoke during the video, in which he said his forces would withdraw from Bakhmut from May 25 for rest and retraining, handing over control to the regular Russian army. Prigozhin taunted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and US President Joe Biden, who weretaking part in a G7 summit in Japanon Saturday where the Ukraine war was front of mind for world leaders. Addressing Zelenskyy, Prigozhin said, â€œToday, when you see Biden, kiss him on the top of his head, say hi to him from me.â€    Al Jazeeraâ€™s Natacha Butler, reporting from Kyiv, said the timing of Prigozhinâ€™s announcement is â€œsignificantâ€ as his comments are â€œperhaps aimed to try and embarrass the Ukrainian president. â€œLetâ€™s not forget that Russia used to be part of the G7 â€“ then the G8 â€“ before it was kicked out in 2014 after illegally annexing Crimea,â€ Butler said. â€œHere, Moscow is looking at these images of Zelenskyy talking to the worldâ€™s wealthiest nations, this elite club it was once part of â€¦ but also talking over the past few days and on the sidelines of this G7, with some of Russiaâ€™s allies. â€œZelenskyy had meetings with the crown prince of Saudi Arabia, but also with Narendra Modi of India, so no doubt, all of those optics are infuriating for Moscow.â€ In his video message, Prigozhin also repeated complaints he has frequently made in the past that his forces suffered far heavier losses than necessary because of inadequate support and ammunition supplies from Russiaâ€™s regular army. Earlier this month he hadthreatened to pull his forces outafter publishing a furious tirade against Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu while standing in a field of bloodied corpses. Because of Russian bureaucracy and the â€œwhimsâ€ of Shoigu and Chief of Staff Valery Gerasimov, â€œfive times more guys died than they should haveâ€, he said in Saturdayâ€™s video. â€œOne day in history, they will pay for their actions,â€ Prigozhin said. His victory claim followed fierce fighting around the city in the past week in which Ukraine said itpushed back some Russian forces. British defence intelligence said on Saturday it was â€œhighly likelyâ€ that Russia had deployed up to several battalions to reinforce the Bakhmut sector, following Ukrainian tactical gains on the flanks of the town. It said this represented a â€œnotable commitment by the Russian commandâ€. â€œRussiaâ€™s leadership likely continue to see capturing Bakhmut as the key immediate war aim which would allow them to claim some degree of success in the conflict,â€ it said on Twitter. Prigozhin has acknowledged that Bakhmut had no strategic significance, but it took on huge symbolic importance for both sides because of the sheer intensity of the fighting and the scale of losses.

Title: Zelenskyy goes on diplomatic blitz to tighten screws on Russia
Subtitle: Ukraine leaderâ€™s visit to Hiroshima thrust the G7â€™s efforts to choke Russiaâ€™s economy to the top of a busy agenda.
Content: Hiroshima, Japan â€“Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has embarked on a flurry of diplomacywith international leaders in Japan, turning the focus of theGroup of Seven summitfirmly towards efforts to end Russiaâ€™s 15-month war in Ukraine. Zelenskyyâ€™s surprise visit to Hiroshima on Saturday evening, following earlier reports that he would only attend online, immediately thrust theG7â€˜s efforts to choke Russiaâ€™s economy to the top of a busy agenda that has touched on issues ranging from Chinaâ€™s rise to the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence. Shortly after touching down in Japan in a French aircraft, fresh on the heels of whistlestop visits to Europe andSaudi Arabia, Zelenskyy said the summit would be an opportunity for â€œenhanced cooperation for our victoryâ€. â€œPeace will become closer today,â€ he said on his official Twitter account. French President Emmanuel Macron late on Saturday hailed Zelenskyyâ€™s attendance at the summit as a potential â€œgame changerâ€. Within hours of his arrival in Hiroshima, Zelenskyy, who is seeking tougher sanctions against Russia and further aid and weapons for Ukraine, held bilateral talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, United Kingdom Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Italyâ€™s Giorgia Meloni and Macron. The Ukrainian leaderâ€™s talks with Modi held particular significance as the Indian leader is among a number of non-G7 leaders attending the summit that have been hesitant to join the pressure campaign against Moscow. Modi has not directly condemned Russiaâ€™s invasion and his country has ramped up imports of Russian oil, coal and gas since the outbreak of the war in February 2022, helping blunt the impact of sanctions on Russiaâ€™s economy, whichcontracted by a less-than-expected 2.1 percent last year. While the meeting between Zelenskyy and Modi did not seem to produce an immediate shift in New Delhiâ€™s stance, the talks appeared to be cordial and productive. Zelenskyy thanked Modi for â€œsupporting our countryâ€™s territorial integrity and sovereigntyâ€, while his Indian counterpart pledged to do â€œwhatever we canâ€ to resolve the crisis in Ukraine. Still, Zelenskyy may struggle to convince Global South leaders such as Modi and Brazilian President Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva, who has said there is now â€œno useâ€ assigning blame for the conflict, to take a more forceful stance against Moscow. â€œIndiaâ€™s stance on the war in Ukraine is backed by popular sentiment in India,â€ Archana Upadhyay, a professor at the Centre for Russian and Central Asian Studies at Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi, told Al Jazeera. â€œThe Western narratives have few takers here.â€    Upadhyay said that while bringing all stakeholders to the negotiating table should be everybodyâ€™s responsibility, it did not follow that Russia â€œhas been shunned or is likely to be shunnedâ€. â€œThe reasons for the war are much more complex than what the West is willing to acknowledge,â€ she said. Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, the host of the G7 this year, has expanded the gatheringâ€™s guest list as he seeks the support of developing and middle-power countries to tackle global challenges, including the conflict in Ukraine. Kishida has adopted by far the regionâ€™s strongest stance against Russia, casting the conflict as a violation of the international rules-based order that upholds the peace and security of all countries, including his own. The Japanese leader, who is leading Tokyo to undertake its biggest military buildup since World World II, has repeatedly linked the plight of Ukraine to the fate of Taiwan, which China claims the right to â€œreunifyâ€ with the Chinese mainland, including by force if necessary. While the G7 is still influential, its share of the global economy has declined from about 70 percent during the 1980s to 44 percent today â€“ meaning its ability to tighten the screws on Russia is limited without buy-in from the wider international community. On Sunday, the final day of the summit, Zelenskyy is scheduled to join G7 leaders and invited non-members, including India, Indonesia and Brazil, for talks on peace and global stability. Zelenskyy is also expected to hold moreÂ bilateral talks with world leaders,including US President Joe Bidenand Kishida.

Title: Russia: Giving F-16 fighter jets to Ukraine a â€˜colossal riskâ€™
Subtitle: Western countries â€˜are still adhering to the escalation scenarioâ€™ that risks widening the Ukraine war in Europe, says deputy foreign minister.
Content: Western countries will be running â€œcolossal risksâ€ if they supply Ukraine with F-16 fighter jets, a Russian official says. Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Grushko was responding to a question on Saturday about the implications of providing the jets, which Ukraine has been requesting from NATO countries, the TASS news agency reported. Ukraine has not yet won commitments to deliver the planes, but US President Joe Bidentold G7 leaders on Fridaythat Washington supports joint allied training programmes for Ukrainian pilots on F-16s, senior United States officials said. â€œWe see that Western countries are still adhering to the escalation scenario. It involves colossal risks for themselves,â€ Grushko was quoted as saying. â€œIn any case, this will be taken into account in all our plans, and we have all the necessary means to achieve the goals we have set.â€ Alexandre Vautravers, editor-in-chief of the Swiss Military Review, said despite Russiaâ€™s warning Moscow was unlikely to escalate the situation. â€œEvery time a new weapon system has been given to Ukraine, we have heard a lot of rhetoric â€“ but very little in the way of action from Russia,â€ he told Al Jazeera from Geneva.Â â€œI think the rhetoric today is not a sufficient deterrence.â€ Vautravers added Kyiv is also facing important technical issues that needed to be addressed for the F-16 fighters. â€œIt is rapidly running out of air defence missiles, and it is necessary to plug in the holes of Ukraineâ€™s air defence with these aircraft,â€ he said.  Ukraineâ€™s President VolodymyrÂ Zelenskyy has for months called for the supply of advanced fighter jets tosupport Ukraineâ€™s defences against Russiaâ€™sinvasion. But the Ukrainian leader had faced rejection until now from his Western allies who feared providing Ukraine with advanced offensive weapons could be met with an escalation by Russian President Vladimir Putin and the spread of the war in Europe. Zelenskyy on Saturday thanked British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak at the G7 summit in Japan for hissupport in forming a coalition to deliver Western fighter jets. â€œIt is necessary to improve [Ukraineâ€™s] air defence capabilities, including the training of our pilots,â€ Zelenskyy wrote on his official Telegram channel. The green light on F-16 training is the latest shift by the Biden administration as it moves to arm Ukraine with more advanced and lethal weaponry, following earlier decisions to send rocket launcher systems and Abrams tanks. The United States has insisted it is sending weapons to Ukraine to defend itself and has discouraged attacks by Ukraine into Russian territory. Bidenâ€™s decisions on when, how many, and who will provide the fourth-generation F-16 fighter jets will be made in the months ahead while pilot training is under way, he said.

Title: ICC war crimes prosecutor â€˜wantedâ€™ in Russia over Putin warrant
Subtitle: International Criminal Court member states â€˜deeply concernedâ€™ by Russian decision to put Karim Khan on a wanted list.
Content: Moscow has issued an arrest warrant for the International Criminal Court (ICC) prosecutor who in Marchprepared a warrantfor the arrest of Russiaâ€™s President Vladimir Putin on war crimes charges, Russian media reported on Friday. Karim Khan, the prosecutor at the Hague-based war crimes court, was added to the Interior Ministryâ€™s wanted list, Russiaâ€™s state-owned TASS news agency reported on Friday, citing the ministryâ€™s database. A picture of the ICC prosecutor, who is a citizen of the United Kingdom, could be seen in the Russian interior ministryâ€™s database on Friday,according to news reports. Russiaâ€™s Investigative Committee, which handles major crimes, said in March thatKhan was being probedfor the â€œcriminal prosecution of a person known to be innocentâ€ â€“ in reference to the war crime charges against Putin. The ICC prosecutor was also being investigated for allegedly preparing â€œan attack on a representative of a foreign state enjoying international protectionâ€, Russian investigators said at the time. The ICC member states on Saturday said they were â€œdeeply concernedâ€ by Russiaâ€™s decision. The Presidency of the Assembly of States Parties to the ICC, the courtâ€™s management oversight body, said in a statement it â€œregrets these acts of intimidation and unacceptable attempts to undermine the mandate of the International Criminal Court to investigate, sanction and prevent the commission of the gravest international crimes.â€ In a separate statement, the court said the measures were â€œunacceptableâ€ and that it â€œwill remain undeterred in the conduct of its lawful mandate to ensure accountability for the gravest crimes of concern to the international community as a whole.â€ The wanted notice described Khan as a man born on March 30, 1970 in Edinburgh, Scotland but did not specify his alleged offence. Russia opened the criminal probe into Khan after the ICC announced anarrest warranthad been issued for Putin over accusations he had committed war crimes by unlawfully deporting thousands of Ukrainian children to Russia.     Announcing the arrest warrants in March, the ICC said there were â€œreasonable grounds to believe that Mr Putin bears individual criminal responsibilityâ€ for the abductions of Ukrainian children, and â€œfor having committed the acts directly, jointly with others and/or through others (and) for his failure to exercise control properly over civilian and military subordinates who committed the actsâ€. The ICC was later forced to issue astatementof concern after former Russian President Dmitry Medvedevthreatened to hitthe war crimes court in The Hague with hypersonic missiles. Earlier this month, Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov called the ICC â€œa puppet in the hands of the so-called collective Westâ€, the Moscow Times reported. Russia, which is not a member of the ICC, has said the warrant is â€œvoidâ€. The international court also issued an arrest warrant against Maria Lvova-Belova, Russiaâ€™s presidential commissioner for childrenâ€™s rights. Kyiv says more than 19,000 Ukrainian children have been deported to Russia since the beginning of Moscowâ€™s full-scale invasion in February 2022, with more than 4,000 believed to be orphans. Many are allegedly placed in institutions and foster homes. Rights groups and the top US justice envoy on Saturday criticised a meeting between Virginia Gamba, the special representative of the UN secretary-general for children, and Lvova-Belova. Russiaâ€™s ombudsman for childrenâ€™s rights said on her website on Friday that she held a working meeting with the top UN official. â€œThe conversation turned out to be constructive and sincere â€“ without politics,â€ she said. â€œAfter all, we are united by a sense of personal responsibility for the life and safety of children.â€ Balkees Jarrah, associate director in the International Justice Program at Human Rights Watch, said â€œUkrainian victims deserve to see Lvova-Belova behind bars in The Hague, not meeting with high-level UN officials.â€ US Ambassador for Global Justice Beth van Schaack said on social media Friday night that such a meeting would be â€œdeeply concerning.â€

Title: Zelenskyy attendance at G7 confirmed, set to meet Japanâ€™s Kishida
Subtitle: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will hold a bilateral meeting with Japanese PM Fumio Kishida at the G7 summit in Hiroshima.
Content: Hiroshima, Japan â€“Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will hold a bilateral meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida during his attendance at theGroup of Seven summit, Japanâ€™s foreign ministry has announced. Zelenskyy will also join a meeting on peace and security with the G7 leaders and other country representatives during the summit in Hiroshima, Japanâ€™s foreign ministry said on Saturday. The Ukrainian leader is expected to arrive in Hiroshima on Saturday after wrapping up a surprise visit to an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia, where he called on Middle Eastern leaders to â€œhelp protect our people, including [the] Ukrainian Muslim communityâ€. Earlier in the week, Zelenskyy conducted a whistle-stop trip to Italy, the Vatican, Germany, France and the United Kingdom, where political leaders pledged to help restock Ukraineâ€™s depleted supplies of missiles, tanks and drones.    Oleksiy Danilov, secretary of Ukraineâ€™s National Security and Defence Council, confirmed reports on Friday that Zelenskyy would attend the G7 summit in person after early indications the Ukrainian leader would only attend the gathering online. Zelenskyyâ€™s trip to Japan will be his first visit to Asia since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Kishida, the host of the G7, has taken by far the strongest stand against Russiaâ€™s war in Ukraine among Asian leaders, imposing sanctions on hundreds of Russian entities and pledging billions of dollars in aid to Kyiv. Kishida is implementing Japanâ€™sbiggest military buildupsince World War II and has repeatedly linked Ukraineâ€™s plight to the fate of Taiwan, which China has threatened to â€œreunifyâ€ with the Chinese mainland by force if necessary. In March, Kishida visited Ukraine where Zelenskyy described the Japanese leader as a â€œpowerful defender of the international orderâ€ and â€œa longtime friend of Ukraineâ€. Nick Bisley, a professor of international relations at La Trobe University in Melbourne, told Al Jazeera that Zelenskyyâ€™s attendance would be a â€œbig boostâ€ for the summit and help to â€œmobilise a unity ticket on Russiaâ€.     In Hiroshima, Zelenskyy is expected to rally the member nations of the G7 â€“ Canada, France, Germany, Japan, the UK and the United States â€“ to ramp up pressure on Moscow to end the war and increase their support for Ukraine. Zelenskyy is also expected to hold bilateral talks with G7 leaders, including US President Joe Biden. On Friday, the G7 leaders pledged to tighten sanctions on Russia further to degrade its ability to continue its â€œillegal aggressionâ€ against Ukraine. The club of rich economies is expected to unveil a range of coordinated measures targeting the Russian economy, although there are divisions among members about how far punitive measures should go. The US and the UK on Friday announced new unilateral sanctions, including a ban by London on imports of Russian diamonds.

Title: Zelenskyy hails Bidenâ€™s decision on F-16 jet training for Ukraine
Subtitle: Training Ukrainian pilots to fly US-made F-16 fighter jets will â€˜greatly enhance our army in the skyâ€™, President Zelenskyy said.
Content: Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has welcomed United States President Joe Bidenâ€™s decision to support the training of Ukrainian pilots onUS-made F-16 fighter jets, saying it would â€œgreatly enhance our army in the skyâ€. Describing the plans to train Ukrainian pilots to fly F-16 jet fighters as a â€œhistoric decisionâ€, Zelenskyy said he would discuss the details with Biden when they meet at the G7 Summit in Japanâ€™s Hiroshima city â€“ the latest international trip by the Ukrainian leader, which was confirmed on Saturday. â€œI count on discussing the practical implementation of this decision at the #G7 summit in Hiroshima,â€Zelenskyy said in a tweet. Biden told G7 leaders on Friday that Washington supports joint allied training programmes forÂ  Ukrainian pilots on US-made F-16 fighter jets, senior US officials told the Reuters news agency. I welcome the historic decision of the United States and@POTUSto support an international fighter jet coalition. This will greatly enhance our army in the sky. I count on discussing the practical implementation of this decision at the#G7summit in Hiroshima. â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)May 19, 2023   Zelenskyy has for months called for the supply of advanced fighter jets tosupport Ukraineâ€™s defences against Russiaâ€™sinvasion. But the Ukrainian leader had faced rejection until now from his Western allies who feared providing Ukraine with advanced offensive weapons could be met with an escalation by Russian President Vladimir Putin and the spread of the war in Europe. Now, as Ukraine has improved its air defences with a host of Western-supplied anti-aircraft systems and prepares to launch a counteroffensive against Russian forces, officials believe the fighter jets could become useful in Ukraineâ€™s battle with Moscow and essential for the countryâ€™s long-term security. Poland and Slovakia have handed over 27 older MiG-29s to Ukraine. Al Jazeeraâ€™s John Psaropoulosreports that air defence experts say US-built F-16 fighter jets wouldoffer Ukraine an edgeover the Russian air force but only if combined with powerful missiles and targeting information, which the West would also have to provide.  The United Kingdomâ€™s Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said his country would work with the Netherlands, Belgium and Denmark â€œto get Ukraine the combat air capability it needsâ€. Denmark also said it would help train Ukrainians to pilot F-16s, the countryâ€™s defence minister said after Washington announced it would back such an initiative. Denmarkâ€™s acting Defence Minister Troels Lund Poulsen said his country â€œwill now be able to move forward for a collective contribution to train Ukrainian pilots to fly F-16sâ€. Denmark will make a priority of working with its allies to support the scheme, he said, hailing Bidenâ€™s decision to approve the plan. Lund Poulsen did not say if Denmark would be among those countries delivering the fighter jets to Ukraine. Denmarkâ€™s air force has some 40 F-16s, approximately 30 of which are operational. It recently began taking delivery of the more advanced F-35 fighters. Ukraine, which does not possess any Western-designed jets, says the F-16s are far more effective than the Soviet-era fighters it currently deploys.    Training on the fighters will take place in Europe and will require months to complete, US officials told the Reuters news agency. The US officials estimated the most expeditious timeframe needed for training and delivery of F-16s at approximately 18 months. Bidenâ€™s green-lighting of F-16 training is the latest shift by the US administration as it moves to arm Ukraine with more advanced and lethal weaponry, following earlier decisions to send HIMAR rocket launcher systems, Patriots air defence systems and Abrams tanks. The US has insisted it is sending weapons to Ukraine to defend itself and has discouraged attacks by Ukraine into Russian territory. The G7 leaders also used the first day of their summit on Friday to roll out a new wave of globalsanctions on Moscowas well as plans to enhance the effectiveness of existing financial penalties meant to constrain Putinâ€™s war effort. â€œOur support for Ukraine will not waver,â€ the G7 leaders said in a statement released after closed-door meetings. They promised â€œto stand together against Russiaâ€™s illegal, unjustifiable and unprovoked war of aggression against Ukraineâ€. â€œRussia started this war and can end this war,â€ they said.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 451
