Title: G7 tightens sanctions over Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine
Subtitle: On first day of G7 summit in Japan, US and partners announce new penalties aimed at punishing Russia.
Content: Leaders of the Group of Seven (G7) countries have pledged to tighten sanctions aimed at punishing Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, intensifying what is already one of the harshest sanctions efforts ever implemented. The move came on the first day of thethree-day G7 summit in Japanand marked the latest sanctions and export controls targeting Moscow, which have hit thousands of targets and imposed steep curbs on Russia over its full-scale invasion of Ukraine last year. â€œOur support for Ukraine will not waver,â€ the G7 leaders said in a statement released after closed-door meetings on Friday. They pledged â€œto stand together against Russiaâ€™s illegal, unjustifiable and unprovoked war of aggression against Ukraineâ€. â€œRussia started this war and can end this war,â€ they said. A statement issued by G7 leaders said restrictions would cover exports of industrial machinery, tools and technology useful to Russiaâ€™s war effort, while efforts would be pursued to limit Russian revenues from trade in metals and diamonds. Separately, United States Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said a raft of new US actions â€œwill further tighten the vice on [Russian President Vladimir] Putinâ€™s ability to wage his barbaric invasion and will advance our global efforts to cut off Russian attempts to evade sanctions.â€ The actions targeted Russiaâ€™s sanctions evasion, future energy revenues and military-industrial supply chains, with sanctions imposed on more than 300 targets on Friday. The Treasury said it imposed sanctions on 22 people and 104 entities with touchpoints in more than 20 countries in jurisdictions, while the Department of State targeted almost 200 people, entities, vessels and aircraft. US sanctions authorities were also expanded to more sectors of the Russian economy, including architecture, manufacturing and construction, the Treasury said, allowing any person or entity operating in those sectors to be hit with sanctions. President Joe Bidenâ€™s administration also halted the export of a wide range of consumer goods to Russia on Friday and added 71 companies to the Department of Commerceâ€™s â€œEntity Listâ€, which bars suppliers from selling them US technology without a hard-to-obtain licence. The new curbs were aimed at items that can be used to help Russiaâ€™s military, including those used in daily life like clothes dryers, snowploughs and milking machines, which the US thinks could be repurposed to support Moscowâ€™s war machine. â€œYou canâ€™t even ship contact lenses or sunglasses now,â€ said Washington lawyer Kevin Wolf, a former Commerce official, as he reviewed the new rules. Wolf said that â€œit would be simpler to describe the items that are not controlled for export to Russiaâ€.    The blacklisted companies include 69 Russian entities, one from Armenia and one from Kyrgyzstan. The targeted companies include aircraft repair and parts production plants, gunpowder, tractor and car factories, shipyards and engineering centres in Russia. The US and Europe imposed financial penalties on Russia immediately following the start of the full-scale war and have steadily ratcheted up the pressure since, targeting Russiaâ€™s President Vladimir Putin and officials close to him as well as the financial sector and oligarchs. Experts have said Washington could still impose tougher penalties. While the sanctions have clearly damaged Russiaâ€™s economy, they have not stopped Putin from pursuing a war that has killed thousands and turned cities to rubble. Biden informed G7 leaders at their summit in Japan that Washington will support a joint effort with allies to train Ukrainian pilots on F-16 fighter jets, the Associated Press news agency and CNN reported on Friday, citing sources. Ukraine is requesting the US-made jets as it seeks to press on with its biggest advance for months against invading Russian troops before a planned counteroffensive. It says the F-16s are far more effective than the Soviet-era jets it currently has. Biden told G7 leaders that decisions on when, how many and who will provide the jets, built by Lockheed Martin, will be made in the coming months while training is under way, the AP reported, citing two people familiar with the matter. The training will be conducted in Europe, the AP reported. Meanwhile, G7 leaders also called for a â€œworld without nuclear weaponsâ€, urging Russia, Iran, China and North Korea to cease nuclear escalation and embrace non-proliferation, a statement released by the US White House showed on Friday. Russiaâ€™s nuclear rhetoric and stated intent to deploy nuclear weapons in Belarus â€œare dangerous and unacceptableâ€ and Russia should return to full implementation of the New START treaty, the leaders said in the statement.

Title: Ukraineâ€™s Zelenskyy seeks Arab League support on Saudi visit
Subtitle: President Zelenskyy calls on the Arab League to help protect â€˜our peopleâ€™ and the Ukrainian Muslim community amid Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine.
Content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has attended an Arab League summit in Saudi Arabia to seek support for his country in the face of Russiaâ€™s invasion, as Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman expressed his readiness to mediate in the war between Moscow and Kyiv. Speaking at the event on Friday, Zelenskyy, in his trademark green military-inspired outfit, told the audience that he hoped â€œmost of us are here for the sake of peace and justiceâ€. â€œWe do not have missiles as our enemy has. We have less air power; we do not possess numerous killer drones that Iran supplies to Russia. We do not have that much artillery, but we do stay strong because we do have truth on our side,â€ he said. Zelenskyy then added that he wanted to leave â€œa noble call to all of you to help protect our people, including [the] Ukrainian Muslim communityâ€. Mustafa Dzhemilev, the leader of the Crimean Tatar community, a Turkic group of Sunni Muslims indigenous to the Crimean Peninsula, was also in attendance. Zelenskyy also highlighted the importance of Ukraineâ€™s economic and educational ties with the Arab world. Beginning my first-ever visit to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to enhance bilateral relations and Ukraineâ€™s ties with the Arab world. Political prisoners in Crimea and temporarily occupied territories, the return of our people, Peace Formula, energy cooperation. KSA plays aâ€¦ â€” Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)May 19, 2023  The Ukrainian president has visited a number of countries since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of the country on February 24, 2022. However, his visits have been largely confined to staunch allies, including several European Union states, the United Kingdom and the United States. He will also travel to Japan over the weekend to attend the G7 meeting. His visit to Saudi Arabia marks a clear deviation from this strategy as Ukraine looks to drum up support among countries that have resisted public condemnation of Russiaâ€™s actions. Arab states have remained largely neutral over Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine, with many maintaining close ties to Moscow. It was something that Zelenskyy appeared to briefly address when he said there were some among the audience who chose to â€œturn a blind eyeâ€ to Russiaâ€™s actions. He added that he was in Jeddah â€œso that everyone can take an honest look no matter how hard the Russians tried to influenceâ€. Saudi Arabia has maintained good relations with Russia, and the two countries have co-operated on oil production cuts through OPEC+, the Saudi-led oil producersâ€™ alliance. Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman renewed an offer to mediate between Ukraine and Russia, following a prisoner exchange deal brokered by Riyadh last year. â€œWe reaffirm the kingdomâ€™s readiness to continue mediating efforts between Russia and Ukraine, and to support all international efforts aimed at resolving the crisis politically in a way that contributes to achieving security,â€ the crown prince said in his opening speech. Zelenskyy said, â€œWe already have a positive experience with Saudi Arabia regarding the release of our people captured by Russia.â€ Saudi Arabia also pledged $400m in aid to Ukraine earlier this year and has voted in favour of United Nations resolutions calling on Russia to end its invasion and refrain from annexing Ukrainian territory. The Ukrainian president also mentioned the decision in 2021 to allow visa-free travel for nationals of several Arab nations as well as the thousands of Arab students enrolled in Ukrainian universities as examples of the close ties Ukraine has with the Arab world. As the speech reached its end, Zelenskyy highlighted several of Russiaâ€™s actions, including the occupation of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant â€œto blackmail the worldâ€ as he encouraged the leaders to consider Ukraineâ€™s10-point peace plan. In his concluding remarks, he asked the Arab League to â€œlisten to the Crimean Tatar people, listen to the Muslims of Ukraine. May the almighty protect our soldiersâ€. Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, heavily backed by Russia, and recently allowed torejoin the Arab League, is also attending the summit. Al-Assad had been shunned from the group since 2011 after abrutal crackdown on oppositionprotesters and the subsequent devastating war in Syria.

Title: Ukraineâ€™s Zelenskyy to attend G7 as leaders up pressure on Russia
Subtitle: Presence of Ukrainian president is likely to bolster G7 and NATO resolve to continue supplying weapons.
Content: Hiroshima, Japan â€“Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will attend the Group of Seven summit in Japan in person as the club of rich democracies seeks to ramp up pressure on Russia to end its war in Ukraine. Zelenskyyâ€™s attendance at the G7 leadersâ€™ summit in Hiroshima is an unexpected development after the Japanese government earlier told local media that the Ukrainian leader would only attend Sundayâ€™s talks via video link. Oleksiy Danilov, secretary of Ukraineâ€™s National Security and Defense Council, confirmed on national television on Friday that Zelenskyy would attend the summit. â€œWe were sure that our president would be where Ukraine needed him, in any part of the world, to solve the issue of stability of our country,â€ Danilov said. â€œThere will be very important matters decided there, so physical presence is a crucial thing to defend our interests.â€ Ukraineâ€™s presidential office said it had told Japanâ€™s Kyodo News a day earlier that Zelenskyyâ€™s attendance had not been ruled out, but would depend on the â€œsituation on the battlefieldâ€. Nick Bisley, a professor of international relations at La Trobe University in Melbourne, described Zelenskyyâ€™s confirmed attendance as a â€œbig boostâ€ for the summit. â€œParticularly in their efforts to mobilise a unity ticket on Russia,â€ Bisley told Al Jazeera. In Japan, G7 â€“ the United States, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, and Italy, along with the European Union â€“ are seeking to convey a united front as they weigh new punitive measures to punish Moscow over its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, which is now in its450th day. G7 leaders are expected to announce new coordinated measures targeting Russiaâ€™s economy, although there are reportedly divisions among members about how far sanctions should go. Zelenskyy has repeatedly called on the international community to increase its support for Kyiv and take stronger action to punish Moscow for its invasion of his country. Last week he made a whistle-stop tour of Berlin, Paris and London where he secured new weapons commitments. John Blaxland, a professor of international security and intelligence studies at Australian National University, said Zelenskyyâ€™s visit to Japan was reflective of his charisma and would bolster momentum to supply further arms to Ukraine. â€œZelenskyy will also be looking to meet with his South Korean and Australian counterparts â€“ to push for additional Korean military supplies and for Australia to supply more Bushmasters and Hawkei protected mobility vehicles,â€ Blaxland told Al Jazeera. â€œHe will also be eager to press for the F-16 fighter aircraft to be made available.â€ On Friday, a senior official with the administration of US President Joe Biden said Washington will roll out 300 new sanctions targeting 70 Russian entities and place more countries on a US blacklist. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak also announced that the UK will ban imports of Russian diamonds, copper, aluminium and nickel, and sanction 86 people and companies linked to Russian President Vladimir Putin. In a joint statement released on Friday evening, the G7 leaders said that additional sanctions would â€œstarve Russia of G7 technology, industrial equipment and services that support its war machineâ€ and restrict exports of goods â€œcritical to Russia on the battlefieldâ€.

Title: Bakhmut battle rages as Ukraine claims advances, Russian retreat
Subtitle: The Institute for the Study of War says Ukrainian forces have seized the â€˜tactical initiativeâ€™ and gained ground in Bakhmut counterattacks.
Content: The Ukrainian military and Russiaâ€™s mercenary Wagner forces have reported further Russian retreats around the city of Bakhmut, as Kyiv pressed on with itsbiggest advance in the city for monthsin advance of a long-awaited counteroffensive. Ukraine said it had repelled a day of Russian attacks in and around the ruined eastern city on Thursday and made gains of up to 1km (almost 3,300 feet) in some places. The head of the Wagner Group, which isspearheading the Russian attack on Bakhmut, said his forces had also advanced up to 400 metres (more than 1,300 feet) in parts of the city. â€œWeâ€™re pushing Bakhmut all the way to the end,â€ Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin said in an audio recording on his Telegram channel. Prigozhin has said Wagner fighters are on the cusp of pushing Ukrainian troops out of their last foothold in the built-up area on the cityâ€™s western outskirts. But he also accused Russiaâ€™s regular forces of abandoning ground north and south of the city, raising the risk of Russian troops inside being encircled. â€œUnfortunately, units of the Russian defence ministry have withdrawn up to 570 metres (1,880 feet) to the north of Bakhmut, exposing our flanks,â€ Prigozhin said in his latest voice message on Thursday.    â€œI am appealing to the top leadership of the Ministry of Defence â€“ publicly â€“ because my letters are not being read,â€ Prigozhin said, addressing Russian Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov. â€œPlease do not give up the flanks,â€ he said. Ukraineâ€™s Deputy Defence Minister Hanna Maliar, reporting on the advances in Bakhmut, said Ukrainian forces were meeting their â€œmilitary objectivesâ€. â€œAs of now, we control the southwestern part of Bakhmut,â€ she said.  Russia attacked Bakhmut all day on Thursday having â€œsignificantly strengthenedâ€ its forces in the city by bringing in most of its reserves, but all â€œattacks were repelledâ€, she said. The Russian defence ministry has acknowledged some withdrawals from positions near Bakhmut over the past week butdenies Prigozhinâ€™s assertions that flanks are crumbling, or that it has withheld ammunition from Wagner. Ukrainian forces have seized the â€œtactical initiative and made tactically significant gains around Bakhmut in counter-attack operationsâ€ on Thursday, the Institute for the Study of War said in its latest briefing on the conflict. â€œThe limited nature of Wagnerâ€™s offensive operations in Bakhmut compared to the localized Ukrainian counterattacks underscores the loss of Russian initiative in the area,â€ the Washington, DC-based think tank said. 3/#Prigozhinâ€™s efforts to blame the Russian military for failures around#Bakhmutare causing some ultranationalists to accuse him of using the Battle for Bakhmut to satisfy his personal ambitions.https://t.co/x4d8VUsgOm â€” ISW (@TheStudyofWar)May 19, 2023  Declaring victory in the blackened ruins of Bakhmut, described by both sides as a â€œmeat grinderâ€, would be Moscowâ€™s only prize for its huge winter offensive that failed elsewhere along the front. Kyiv says its tactic in Bakhmut is to draw Russian forces into the cityâ€™s urban warfare, so as to weaken Russiaâ€™s front-line defences elsewhere before Kyivâ€™s planned counterassault. The area around the city, once home to 70,000 people in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, has been the focus of fighting for months. Oleksander Syrskyi, commander of Ukraineâ€™s ground forces, said in social media message this week that Wagner forces had â€œclimbed into Bakhmut like rats into a mousetrapâ€. â€œThe enemy has more resources, but we are destroying his plans,â€ he said.    On Thursday night, Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelenskyy praised his troops and the countryâ€™s air defences amid days of complex missile and drone attacks on Kyiv and other cities, which have been largely repelled resulting in the downing of the incoming Russian missiles. â€œFirst of all, the defence brigades did a good job, they fulfilled the main strategic tasks, but now is not the time to give details,â€ Zelenskyy said in his nightly address. â€œSecondly, the offensive brigades are doing a good job, we are preparing,â€ he said, adding that no details could be given. â€œThirdly, on the protection of civilians, the Air Force is doing a great job â€¦ Our priorities for this week, next week, and for the near future are additional air defence systems, additional missiles, training and aircraft, and long-range weapons. And this will be fulfilled.â€ Secretary of Ukraineâ€™s National Security and Defence Council Oleksiy Danilov said Russiaâ€™s repeated missile attacks on Kyiv â€“there have been nine so far this monthâ€“ was a sign of Moscowâ€™s desperation. Kyiv remains putinâ€™s maniacal and unattainable goal. Symbolic places of Kyiv are the target of russian missile attacks. The kremlin needs those senseless and super-expensive attacks for russia on the capital to raise the degree of patriotic hysteria inside the country. In russia,â€¦ â€” Oleksiy Danilov (@OleksiyDanilov)May 18, 2023  Moscow was attacking the â€œsymbolic placesâ€ of Kyiv as it needed to â€œraise the degree of patriotic hysteriaâ€ within Russia, Danilov wrote in a tweet. In Russia a â€œprocess of despair and disappointment with the authorities is developing against the background of the unsuccessful offensive and failures at the frontâ€, he added.

Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 450
Subtitle: As the war enters its 450th day, we take a look at the main developments.
